description: The Abugbe and Agbaduma engaged in bilateral negotiations in June 2019 in response to armed clashes between the two tribes in the Local Government Area of Agatu in Benue State. This led to a peace agreement on 29 June 2019. However, fighting resumed directly after the signing of the agreement.

On 29 August 2019, the two rival communities reached a peace agreement during a peace meeting mediated by the deputy Governor of Benue State, Benson Abounou, in Makurdi. This agreement partially resolved the land dispute between the parties. The agreement built on the efforts of a peace committee that had previously been set up by the state government to discuss the chieftaincy title in Aila, ownership of the Ohebu fish pond, the agricultural land surrounding the pond, Ashukwu, and Adagole. The Abugbe community agreed to renounce its claim to ownership of the Ohebu fishpond in favor of the Aigocheigwu family in Agbaduma. In addition, it was agreed that all the people farming around the Ohebu pond should continue unhindered access until the dry season, when the committee will visit the area and solve the problems concerning the farmland.

In 2019, the Libyan National Army (LNA) attempted to maintain its hold on the Toubou-dominated town of  Murzuk. The battle between the LNA and opposition from Toubou leadership negatively impacted the relations between the Ahali and Toubou communities. In September 2019, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) flew in Mohammed Adam Lino of the Toubou group to prepare him for mediation between the two communities, butthis mediation effort never materialized. In October 2019, the Ara Pacis Initiative and the Italian government jointly mediated between the conflict parties. The series of negotations, referred to as the Murzuq Peace Dialogues, took place in Rome and led to the signing of the Agreement in Principle on 17 October 2019. This agreement outlined steps for a more coprehensive peace agreement.
A follow-up meeting took place in Ubari December 2019.

To this purpose, a follow-up commission of representatives of the conflict parties convened in Rome from 12 to 14 November 2019. The Ara Parcs Initiative mediated this meeting, which was aimed at determining how to move forward with implementation of the previous agreement.

The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: The Sudan-based Arab Mediation and Reconciliation Committee, comprised by 17 Taish, Salamate and Missiria community leaders, mediated a temporary ceasefire between the MLCJ/Kara and the FPRC/Rounga in Am-Dafock in December 2019.
Goula elders mediated between the MLCJ/Kara and the FPRC/Rounga in December 2019.
Negotiations between the Beni Amir and Nuba led to a peace agreement in El Gedaref in May 2019.

In resonse to armed clashes between the conflict partis, the Sudanese government, in the form of the Sovereignty Council of Sudan, mediated between the confict parties on 22 August 2019. These talks did not lead to an agreement.

In response to armed clashes between the Ikurav and Shitilet in the town of Katsina-Ala in Benue State in April 2019, the Benue state government imposed a 24-hour curfew on 22 April 2019 as part of peacekeeping efforts in the region. Directly after the resumption of hostilities in August 2019 in Katsina-Ala, the Benue State Police Command mediated negotiations between the communities to resolve the crisis. However, this did not result in any agreement since the two tribes could not agree on the causes of the attacks.

A land dispute between Lugunda and Waja youths in the Lamurde Local Government Area in Adamawa State in October 2018 escalted into a series or reprisal killings and armed conflict. In early November 2018, the Assessment and Reconciliation committee set up by the Governor of Adamawa mediated between the leaders of the Lugunda and Waja. Waja leader Malam Saleh and Lunguda leader John Monsirmi declared their desire to maintain peace between the two communities, though no agreement was concluded.

Fulani herders and Yandang farmers clashed violently in Taraba State in early July 2018. A peace meeting between the Fulani on the one side and the Yandang and four other ethnic groups on the other side led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in the Lau Local Government Area in Taraba State on 21 July 2018. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, the withdrawal of all militias, and the formation of a peace and reconciliation committee.

Communal clashes between the Chiebiliew Yoal and the Chiebol Nyak started in February 2018. This triggered a cycle of revenge attacks. Following an armed clash in Akobo on 6 July 2018, the governor of Bieh state, Brigadier General Simon Hoth Duol with the help of local chiefs, mediated between the conflict parties and managed to separate the two groups.

From 10 to 13 December 2018, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) convened a peace conference in the Greater Lakes, along with the Disabled Association for Rehabilitation and Development and Oxfam. The Gak and Manuer Dinka attended the conference and they reached a truce on 13 December 2018.
In July 2001, the US Agency for Internal Development (USAID) sponsored a conflict resolution workshop in which the conflict parties discussed solutions to their conflict.

However, violence between the Bassa Kwomu and Egbura Mozum clans resumed in Kogi State and in the Toto LGA of Nasawara State in 2018. In the week of 9 July 2018, Governor of Nasawara State Umaru Tanko Al-Makura met with stakeholders from the Bassa ethnic group and members of the State Security Council in Abuja to ease tensions. In his statement, Al-Makura promised to create a Bassa Chiefdom before the end of his mandate and set up peace between the two communities. No agreement was reportedly signed during this meeting.

After the two communities clashed from January to March 2019, the Nigerian arm began to disarm the conflict parties. Moreover, the governor of Nasarawa state and Major General Adeyemi Yekini convened a peace meeting at the government house in Lafia on 26 March 2019. The heads of security agencies in the state, political officials, the Chairman of the Toto local government council, and traditional rulers also took part in the meeting. The peace meeting led to the signing of an eleven-point peace agreement in which the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and for the army to disarm the groups of their illegal weapons. In addition, the tribes pledged to establish Joint Peace Reconciliation Committees.
third_party: local government; government forces; traditional leaders

description: The conflict between the Biide and Saad subclans in Somaliland is rooted within the long-standing rivalry between the Habar Jeclo and Habar Yonis. The election of Muse Bihi Abdi in November 2017 as Somaliland’s president exacerbated tensions between the two subclans: while the Habar Jeclo supported Muse Bihi Abdi, the Habar Yonis opposed Muse Bihi Abdi. A round of bilateral negotiations between the Biide and Sa’ad in Somaliland in November 2019 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. However, the agreement already broke down in December 2019.

In May 2014, the South Sudanese government and the South Sudan Democratic Movement/Army (SSDM/A) – Cobra led by David Yau Yau signed a peace agreement which stipulated the formation of the formation of a new Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA). This led to widespread grievances among the Jie. Not being a signatory to the peace agreement, the Jie residing in the Pibor area wanted a country independent of the GPAA. Responding to growing tensions, the US company AECOM organized a peace meeting in Boma involving Murle, Jie, Kachipo, and Toposa representatives. Several resolutions on peaceful relations were adopted at the meeting, but animosity between the Jie and the Murle persisted.

The animosity escalated into armed violence on 6 July 2018, when the Murle community attacked the neighboring Jieh community in the border area of Boma and Kapoeta. The Murle attack was in response to a dispute over access to land and water resources. Government officials and army generals in Juba allegedly supported the Murle in their attack on the Jie. Boma State governor David Yau Yau met with the conflict parties in conflict area on 9 July 2018.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: The Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council formed in June 2014, following Khalifa Haftar’s Operation Dignity assault on the Islamist presence in Libya. Islamist groups such as the February 17th Martyrs Brigade, the Rafallah al-Sahati Brigade, and the Ansar al-Sharia in Libya (ASL) united to combat Haftar’s Libyan National Army (LNA). The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the conflict parties on 19 November 2014, which led to the conclusion of a humanitarian ceasefire for 12 hours.
UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2016. On 10 December 2016, the LNA declared a six-hour unilateral ceasefire for citizen evacuation.
UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2017.

On 27 and 28 September 2015, a CMA delegation held meetings with President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta and the leaders of the Platform in Bamako. Following the meetings, CMA announced that it would stick to the ceasefire and order its combatants to refrain from using force against the troops of the Government forces and Platform.

Between 27 September and 14 October 2015, CMA and the Platform engaged in direct talks in Anéfis. At the end of the talks, the parties endorsed a road map – the Anefis road map – comprising a series of measures, including the cessation of hostilities, joint initiatives for intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation, the exchange of prisoners, the establishment of interim local administrations and the free movement of people and goods. During and following the Anéfis talks, CMA and the Platform mediated a series of intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation agreements in Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions, including between the Ifoghas and Imghad Tuareg communities affiliated with CMA and the Platform, respectively.

In 2019, the CMA and a faction of MSA came into conflict over control of Talataye, an area that both parties valued for its trade routes. In January 2019, the CMA represented by Salah Ag Ahmed and Alhousseiny Ag Ahmedou and the MSA represented by Mohamed Ag Kassoum engaged in bilateral negotiations, which led to the conlusion of a peace agreement on 20 January 2019. However, fighting resumed the next month.
Another round of bilateral negotiations in Tinfadimata in May 2019 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 21 May 2019.

Located in the Ituri region, a coalition of Hutu groups are collectively referred to as the Collectif des mouvements pour le changement (CMC) (English: Coalition for movements of change). The CMC’s mission statement is to bring the end of rule by Joseph Kabila and the corrupt government structures. In February 2018, the CMC clashed with Mayi-Mayi Mazembe, a widespread alliance of local self-defence forces. In July 2018, the two groups met to negotiate, but no peace accord was concluded.

The Arab Brabich and Idnan (Tuareg) coexisted in Bordj Badji Mokhtar, a town near the border of Algeria and Mali. A failed robbery attempt triggered an armed conflict between the two groups. Negotiations, mediated by representatives of government forces, led to a reconciliation agreement on 17 August 2013.
On 19 August, local authorities from Regnae arrived to mediate between the conflict parties.

On 21 August, a local peace committee with members from both tribes held a meeting with community members, as well as religious, local, and regional authorities in the town. At this meeting, the Arab Brabich and Idnan signed the Document d’initiation au dialogue pour réhabiliter le calme et cesser l’effusion du sang afin d’atteindre la reconciliation.
third_party: local peace committee; religious leaders; traditional leaders; local government
agreement_name: Document d’initiation au dialogue pour réhabiliter le calme et cesser l’effusion du sang afin d’atteindre la reconciliation

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant’Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all “politico-military groups” into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant'Egidio; UN; EU; Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touadéra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that peace agreement signed in Rome on 19 June.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant’Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 27 June 2017, the Prefect of Haute-Kotto set up a mediation committee to resolve the conflict. MINUSCA pledged to support the committee’s efforts. The UPC and the FPRC entered into negotiations mediated by Christian and Muslim religious leaders in Bria on 17 September 2017. On 21 September 2017, a team of emissaries from Bangui and Birao arrived in Bria to take over the mediation process from the religious leaders. This paved the way for negotiations in Ippy.

On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance. In addition to this local peace process aimed at ending violence between the conflict parties in the Bambari area, the conflict parties were involved in a national-level peace process in 2017.
In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement.

On 28 August 2018, Russia – which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 – and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: The conflict in between Batabwa on the one side and the Bambuti and the Batwa on the other side should be seen in the context of a broader conflict between the Bantu (including Baluba, Batabwa, and Bazela) and Pygmies (Batwa and Bambuti) in the Tanganyika province. The Batabwa attacked the Batwa and Bambuti in the Moba and Kalemie localities on 13 January 2017, resulting in at least 600 deaths. Negotiations in Miketo, facilitated by MONUSCO, led to the signing of a peace agreement on 20 January. MONUSCO agreed to support the implementation of this agreement. On 22 February 2017, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior and Security, Emmanuel Ramazani Shadary, arrived in Kalemie, the capital of Tanganyika, to discuss the recent fighting between the Pygmies and the Bantu. According to a civil society organization which attended the meeting, this meeting did not help to resolve the conflict because no representatives of the conflict parties were invited to participate in the meeting. Fighting continued.

On 24 February, following a mediation effort by the Congolese authorities, the leaders of the communities signed a Peaceful Coexistence pact in Kalemie of the Tanganyika province. The Batabwa on the one side and the Bambuti and the Batwa on the other side did not engage in any armed clashes after the signing of this pact.

The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO signed a peace agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). Following the signing of the R-ARCSS, the South Sudanese government and SPLM/A-IO representatives continued engagement to persuade the NAS to sign and implement the agreement. During a meeting in Texas on 23 September 2018, the NAS leader said his group is not committed to the ceasefire in South Sudan even if their group is a signatory to the security arrangements.
Both being pastoral groups, the Pakam Dinka and Rup Dinka clashed over cattle in December 2017. Security chiefs from both groups were brought together to discuss the violence that same month.

The Pakam Dinka and Rup Dinka attended a two-day peace conference in Greater Lakes on 26 January 2019. This effort was organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), African Mission Assistance (AMA), and Oxfam. This round of peace talks ended with a peace agreement on 28 January 2019.

Immediately after armed clashes between the Bwatiye and Fulani on 4 December 2017, vice-president Yemi Osinbajo held separate talks with both sides, trying to convince the conflict parties to stop fighting.

In mid-December 2017, the Secretary to the Government of the Federation Boss Mustapha visited the leaders of the Bwatyie and Fulani. He called uppon the communities to stop fighting, but no agreement was concluded as a result of these shuttle talks.

On 11 November 2017, under an alleged authorization of Abdoulaye Hissene, a local mediation team and a MINUSCA CLA mediated an agreement between the rival wings of the FPRC. The FPRC-AK wing subsequently returned to Bria on 27 November 2017.
A mediation team led by FPRC military leader Abdoulaye Hisseine mediated between the rival factions of the FPRC in the locality of Tissi-Fongoro in December 2018.

The MINUSCA field office in Bouar town initiated a mediation effort between 3R and anti-Balaka in December 2017. The Prefect of the Nana-Mambéré Prefecture and Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) were also involved in this mediation effort. On 15 December 2017, 3R and anti-Balaka signed the Acte d’engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mambéré et les 3R. The agreement stipulated a cessation of hostilities, non-use of arms, freedom of movement, and the establishment of information network made up of community leaders, and leaders of the two armed groups. The implementation of the agreement was relatively successful since it contributed to a decrease in violence and direct confrontation between the groups, an improvement in the free movement of people and goods and a considerable decline in livestock theft.
third_party: MINUSCA; local government; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD)
agreement_name: Acte d’engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mambéré et les 3R

description: Another local-level peace procces took place between the anti-Balaka and 3R in Koui-De gaulle between 18 and 20 October 2018. This resulted in the signing of the Déclaration de coordination des groupes armés – plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix (English: Declaration of coordination of the armed groups - Central African Rally for Peace Platform). Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.
agreement_name: Déclaration de coordination des groupes armés – plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: Negotiations between representatives of Irigwe, Hausa, and Fulani communities led to the signing of a peace agreement in Bassa in Plateau State on 8 February 2011. The president of the Bassa local council,  government representatives, soldiers from the Spiecial Task Force, and police officers acted as mediators during the peace talks.
third_party: local government; government; government forces; police

description: In response to armed clashes in 2017, soldiers from the Spiecial Task Force launched a military operation to create a safe haven in 2017 – dubbed Operation Safe Haven – and convened a series of peace meeting between leaders of the two feuding tribes. However, the violence continued.

The many meetings convened the Spiecial Task Force cumulated into to the signing of a ceasefire agreement in early August 2018. Major-General Augustine Chris Agundu, the Commander of the Operation Safe Haven, mediated between the conflict parties at these meetings.

After the alleged attack by an Irigwe man on Fulani people and their livestock in March 2019, the police summoned a peace meeting between the two communities to ensure that such an event would not occur again. However, violence resumed between the two communities in April 2019. On 21 September 2019, on the occasion of the World Peace Day, the Plateau Peace Building Agency (PPBA) facilitated a peace parley between the Irigwe and Fulani leaders in Miango district in the Local Government Area of Bassa in Plateau State. The two leaders of the conflict parties, who had not met in six years, signed a peace agreement and expressed their hope for long-lasting peace in the area. However, attacks resumed only two days later.

A series of revenge killings between the Bahararsame and Qayaad subclans took place in the Sool region during June 2016. The Somali government immediately ordered an end to the fighting. In order to reconcile the two communities, a government delegation mediated negotiations attended by 20 individuals from both sides.

On 8 March 2016, the MPC and anti-Balaka operating on Kaga Bandoro-Bangui axis signed a Protocole de non agression (English: Non-Aggression Protocol). The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities. The anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand signed a non-aggression pact in the sub-prefecture of Mbrès on 8 June 2016. The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: MINUSCA; religious leaders; local government; local peace committee

third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: After the resumption of the conflict between the Kadara and Fulani in Kajuru in Kaduna Stat in February 2019, the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN) mediated between the conflict parties in March 2019.

A Truth and Reconciliation Committee composed of Fulani and Kadara representatives was set up by the Kajuru government in March 2019. The committee was tasked to find a solution to the ongoing crisis and ensure a ceasefire. This committee was reportedly successful and fighting ended in the region in August 2019. On the weekend of 19 and 20 October 2019, the Commander of the Nigerian Naval Weapons Technology School in Kachia in Kaduna State, Commodore Tanko Yakubu Pani, mediated between leaders of the Fulani and Kadara communities. The communities, who were given two weeks to surrender their weapons or face sanctions, pledged to contribute to the return of peace in the region. No written agreement was signed on this occasion.

A dispute over ownership of a piece of farming land at the boundaries Wanhihem and Wanikade communities in the Yala Local Government Area in Cross River State escalated into armed fighting between 27 and 29 June 2017. Fighting in this short period of time resulted in around 150 deaths. Deputy Governor of Cross River State Professor Ivara Esu and Senator Ben Ayade  mediated between the members of the two communities in early July 2017. The mediators called on the Wanhihem and Wanikade communities to not return to armed conflict and to agree on clear boundaries between them. The conflict parties did not conclude a peace agreement.

Another peace meeting was held in Mfuma in the Yala Local Government Area on 15 July 2017. Wanhihem and Wanikade leaders, as well  representatives of other Ukulle people to which both communities belong, signed a communiqué at this peace meeting. This communiqué stipulates a ceasefire between the two communities, as well as calls uppon the federal government to assist them in resolving the conflict and to establish a Judicial Commission of Inquiry into the conflict and a Truth and Reconciliation Committee.

The Hamar and Kababish are two tribes that reside in Sudan’s West Kordofan State. Some Kababish have acted as pro-government militia by the Sudanese government. The Hamar and Kababish clashed over a theft of camels in Wadi Al Zeima Locality in West Kordofan, claiming more than 50 lives from both sides in early April 2017. On 6 April, the governors of North and West Kordofan declared the State of Emergency for the period of one month in order to contain the situation. Government forces subsequently managed to separate the warring tribesmen at Um Marahik. A committee was established to investigate the incident and the West Kordofan police were tasked to arrest those that engage in armed violence. On 14 April 2017, the Governor of North Kordofan, Governor Ahmed Haroun, tried to initiate peace negotiations between the leaders of the two tribes. Together with the Chief of the Kababish tribe, he traveled to the territory of the Hamar tribe near En Nahud in West Kordofan.

The Mahadi and the Rizeeigat Abbala clashed in April 2016. Following another clash in June 2016, government forces were deployed to the area to end the violence. With support from UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 22 July 2016. Yet, the Mahadi tribal leadership expressed dissatisfaction with this agreement because it did not include any provisions on compensation (diya) and that the Rizeeigat Abbala continued occupy of their land.

On 24 March 2016, Fulani herders clashed with farmers from the Koulango, Lobi, and Malinké communities in the northeast region of Bouna. This region had been experiencing a severe drought for several months before the armed clash took place. This drought forced the Fulani herders to find new swaths of land where there cattle could graze, but the Koulango, Lobi, and Malinké wanted to protect their crops and attacked the Fulani herders. A delegation led by the Minister of Justice, who originates from the region visited Bouma on 26 March 2016 to mediate between the conflict parties. This mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.
The German development agency, Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ), facilitated a community dialogue between the communities in February 2019.

The Governor of Akwa Ibom, Udom Emmanuel, subsequently met with youth and leaders of the fighting community of Oku Iboku in the Itu Local Government Area on 23 April 2017 and called for peace between the two communities.

The federal government convened a peace meeting, mediated by Director General of the National Border Commission Muhammad Ahmad, between the leaders of the conflict parties at the bridge between the Odukpani and Itu Local Government Areas on 11 July 2017. The leaders of the conflict parties expressed their commitment to peace during this peace meeting.

The Panyar Dinka and the Waat Dinka are both subgroups of the Gok Dinka, living in the Cueibet and the Rumbek North counties of Lakes state in South Sudan. Following clashes in March 2014, the acting secretary-general of South Sudan’s ruling party – the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM) - Anne Itto conducted a surprise visit to talk to local governors and mediate between representatives of the Panyar Dinka and the Waat Dinka in Rumbek.

Active fighting between the coalition of the FPRC, MPC, RPRC, and the Anti-Balaka-Mokom on the one side and the UPC on the other side had started in Bambari in November 2016, greatly decreased from April 2017 onwards. On 27 June 2017, the Prefect of Haute-Kotto set up a local mediation committee to resolve the conflict. MINUSCA pledged to support the committee’s efforts. The UPC and the FPRC entered into negotiations mediated by Christian and Muslim religious leaders in Bria on 17 September 2017. On 21 September 2017, a team of emissaries from Bangui and Birao arrived in Bria to take over the mediation process from the religious leaders. This paved the way for negotiations in Ippy.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant’Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance. In addition to this local peace process aimed at ending violence between the conflict parties in the Bambari area, the conflict parties were involved in a national-level peace process in 2017.
third_party: government; local government; community leaders; MINUSCA

description: In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement. Russia and Sudan started a national-level mediation effort in August 2018, but instead of making peace between the FPRC and the UPC this mediation effort was aimed at negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed in October 2018.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed on 24 November 2019. The document serves to remind the parties to respect the peace agreements previously signed in Zemio in October 2018.

An armed conflict between the Bakonzo and Bamba started following local elections in 2016. While several peace committees had been set up in the conflict area in 2014, these committees refrained from mediating. Instead, a peace meeting was facilitated by the Kabarole Research and Resource Centre, Peace and Justice Commission in the Catholic diocese, and the Rwenzori Forum for Peace and Justice in early April 2016.

On 14 April 2016, another round of negotiations, mediated by Ugandan government officials and religious leaders, led to the conclusion of a 4-point communique that included provisions for peace and inter-community dialogue.
In late April 2016, President Yoweri Museveni subsequently mediated another round of peace talks between the leaders of the conflict parties that led to the conclusion of an informal peace agreement.

The Toubou and Zuwaya ethnic tribes were allies during the conflict between the National Transitional Council (NTC) and Colonel Muammar al-Gadaffi in 2011. However, this alliance disintegrated quickly once the NTC took over the Libyan government. The tribes began to fight over resources. Clashes began in the new year in Kufrah. Local leaders mediated a round of negotiations between the two sides, which led to a ceasefire on 19 February 2012. This ceasefire soon broke down.  A round of mediation led by local authorities succeeded in getting the two sides to agree to a ceasefire on 7 July 2012.
The government sent an armed force to quell fighting in March and another ceasefire was brokered on 26 March 2012. However, fighting resumed days later.
The conflict parties reached a truce during a round of bilateral negotiations on 11 May 2013, but this did not prove sustainable.
Negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 26 July 2015.

UNSMIL mediated a round of peace talks in Tunis from 19 to 20 February 2018. The two conflict parties agreed to a document outlining mechanisms for reconciliation, which was signed by the conflict parties on 21 February.
On 18 July 2015, tribal leaders participated in a round of negotiations that led to a ceasefire. However, this ceasefire broke down just days later.
Another round of negotiations led to a ceasefire on 25 July 2015.
Qatar began a round of negotiations between the two tribes in Doha on 23 November 2015. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement in Doha on 25 November 2015.
Fighting took place again in January 2016, when tribal leaders met to implement the Doha agreement. Negotiations in February 2016 led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement.
The Community of Sant’Egidio mediated a humanitarian accord in Rome on 16 June 2016 between various tribes in the Fezzan region in order to provide aid.

In March 2017, 60 tribal representatives engaged in negotiations in Rome mediated by the Libyan Presidency Council, the Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti, the Ara Pacis Initiative, and the Community of Sant’Egidio. This led to the signing of the Reconciliation and Peace Agreement on 29 March 2017 and a document regarding methods for implementation on 31 March. A faction of the Toubou tribe rejected this agreement on 6 April and fighting resumed.
third_party: government; Italy; Ara Pacis Initiative; Community of Sant'Egidio

description: With the national-level peace process spearheaded by Algeria unfolding, the various armed groups participating in the peace process had clustered into two main camps by June 2014. One camp sought self-determination for northern Mali and the other camp sought to maintain Mali’s national unity. The former camp – consisting of the Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad), the Coalition du peuple pour l’Azawad (CPA) (English: Coalition for the People of Azawad), the Arab Mouvement Arabe de l’Azawad (MAA) (English: Arab Movement of Azawad) splinter faction led by Ould Sidatti, and the Coordination des Mouvements et Forces Patriotiques de Résistance (CM-FPR) (English: Coordination of Patriotic Resistance Movements and Forces) II – merged into the Coordination des Mouvements de l’Azawad (CMA) (English: Coordination of Azawad Movements) in mid-2014. The pro-unity camp was a more loosely organized coalition than the CMA and consisted of three groups – including the Arab Mouvement Arabe de l’Azawad (MAA) (English: Arab Movement of Azawad), the Coordination des Mouvements et Forces Patriotiques de Résistance (CM-FPR) (English: Coordination of Patriotic Resistance Movements and Forces), and the Groupe Autodéfense Touareg Imghad et Alliés (GATIA) (English: Imghad Tuareg Self-Defense Group and Allies) – that formed a coalition called Platform, but largely continued to operate autonomously. Trying to strengthen their positions before official negotiations started in Algiers in mid-July 2014, the two camps clashed in Tabankort and Anefis areas on 11 July 2014. After these initial clashes, fighting continued intermittently. Following a request from the Government of Mali and the armed groups for tailored training on negotiation skills and thematic areas, MINUSMA funded the organization of training sessions for CMA and Platform representatives in the margins of the national-level peace process. On 25 August 2014, CMA and Platform began negotiations in in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. These talks were mediated by Burkina Faso, whose president was the ECOWAS mediator in the Malian crisis, with support from the UN and the AU. This round of negotiations took place in between a round of negotiations between the Government of Mali and the CMA in Algiers in July 2014 and another round of negotiations in Algiers in September 2014. After four days of discussions, the talks in Ouagadougou led to the Declaration Finale on 28 August 2014. This peace agreement specifies how the parties position themselves in talks with the government of Mali, but also stipulates a ceasefire. The agreement between CMA and Platform was signed by Alghabass Ag Intalla on behalf of the CMA and Ahmed Ould Sidi Mohamed on behalf of the Platform coalition. The peace agreement consolidated two agreements concluded the day before, namely the Protocol D’Entente and the Pacte de non agresssion avec arret immediat des hositilites, both concluded on 27 August 2014.

The UN Secretary General’s Special Representative convened a meeting between the military leadership of CMA and Platform in Bamako in July 2015. Under his auspices, the parties concluded another ceasefire and promised to end all incursions into the areas under the other party’s control. The parties also agreed to initiate dialogue in Anéfis, with a view to solving the long-standing intercommunal and intra-communal tensions at the root of the conflict between them.

With the national-level peace process spearheaded by Algeria unfolding, the various armed groups participating in the peace process had clustered into two main camps by June 2014. One camp sought self-determination for northern Mali and the other camp sought to maintain Mali’s national unity. The former camp – consisting of the Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad), the Coalition du peuple pour l’Azawad (CPA) (English: Coalition for the People of Azawad), the Arab Mouvement Arabe de l’Azawad (MAA) (English: Arab Movement of Azawad) splinter faction led by Ould Sidatti, and the Coordination des Mouvements et Forces Patriotiques de Résistance (CM-FPR) (English: Coordination of Patriotic Resistance Movements and Forces) II – merged into the Coordination des Mouvements de l’Azawad (CMA) (English: Coordination of Azawad Movements) in mid-2014. The pro-unity camp was a more loosely organized coalition than the CMA and consisted of three groups – including the Arab Mouvement Arabe de l’Azawad (MAA) (English: Arab Movement of Azawad), the Coordination des Mouvements et Forces Patriotiques de Résistance (CM-FPR) (English: Coordination of Patriotic Resistance Movements and Forces), and the Groupe Autodéfense Touareg Imghad et Alliés (GATIA) (English: Imghad Tuareg Self-Defense Group and Allies) – that formed a coalition called Platform, but largely continued to operate autonomously. While GATIA fought the CMA independently, GATIA operated under the banner of Platform in the peace process. The UN Secretary General’s Special Representative convened a meeting between the military leadership of CMA and Platform in Bamako in July 2015. Under his auspices, the parties concluded another ceasefire and promised to end all incursions into the areas under the other party’s control. The parties also agreed to initiate dialogue in Anéfis, with a view to solving the long-standing intercommunal and intra-communal tensions at the root of the conflict between them.

On 27 and 28 September 2015, a CMA delegation held meetings with President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta and the leaders of the Platform in Bamako. Following the meetings, CMA announced that it would stick to the ceasefire and order its combatants to refrain from using force against the troops of the Government forces and Platform.

Between 27 September and 14 October 2015, CMA and the Platform engaged in direct talks in Anéfis. At the end of the talks, the parties endorsed a road map – the Anefis road map – comprising a series of measures, including the cessation of hostilities, joint initiatives for intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation, the exchange of prisoners, the establishment of interim local administrations and the free movement of people and goods. During and following the Anéfis talks, CMA and the Platform mediated a series of intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation agreements in Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions, including between the Ifoghas and Imghad Tuareg communities affiliated with CMA and the Platform, respectively.

In the context of the stalling implementation process following the Bamako Agreement concluded in 2015, the violence between the CMA and GATIA intensified in early 2016, with both groups competing for territorial control, particularly in the Kidal area.  On 2 February 2016, GATIA and CMA concluded an agreement, without the involvement of any third party. The agreement stipulated that both parties would jointly control the city of Kidal. However, CMA and GATIA continued to clash sporadically after the Kidal power-sharing deal was in place. On 6 June 2016, Platform publicly stated that it considered the February power-sharing agreement on Kidal to have led to an inequitable division of power in Kidal between CMA and the Platform. The CMA reacted by stating that CMA remained in charge of the management of the town.

On 14 July 2016, representatives of the CMA and GATIA held discussions in Niamey, at the invitation of the Government of the Niger, to address outstanding political and security issues between them. On 17 July 2016, an agreement was reached by the two groups on the joint management of Kidal and other measures to reduce tensions. Nevertheless, heavy fighting erupted in Kidal two days later, resulting in GATIA being pushed out of the town.

Heavy fighting continued in August 2016. Talks aimed at cessation of hostilities initiated in mid-August by the Government of Niger ended without reaching agreement and talks broke down in September 2016.
On 22 August 2017, MINUSMA mediated between the CMA and Platform, which led to the conclusion of a 15-day ceasefire in Kidal. The ceasefire was extended on 6 September 2017.

Another round of negotiations mediated by MINUSMA led to the signing of a definitive ceasefire by the conflict parties in Bamako on 21 September 2017. The ceasefire stipulated an immediate halt to hostilities, the release of prisoners, and the return of the CMA-controlled base in Takalot to Platform.

On 10 October 2017, CMA and GATIA signed yet another agreement that was mediated by MINUSMA, referred to as Anefis II. This agreement specified local security arrangements to keep peace in Kidal region.

The Kuei Dinka, Pakam Dinka and Rup Dinka all belong to the Agar sub-division of the group, but series of cattle-raids and revenge attacks in mid-March 2015 resulted in the death of 78 people. The clashes took place in the Rumbek North, East and Centre counties of Lakes state, and pitted the Kuei Dinka together with the Pakam Dinka against the Rup Dinka. In April 2015, a mediation effort was initiated by local chiefs, a county commissioner, and the governor’s peace adviser. UNMISS Civil Affairs provided logistical support by shuttling community leaders from both sides to meetings for discussing their issues. The two communities then appointed representatives who met at a roundtable organized by the NGO ACTED and UNMISS Civil Affairs to find solutions to the underlying problems of resource sharing and road access. The negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire, which was celebrated through a series of ceremonial intermarriages between the two clans.
A reconciliation committee with representatives from both communities was set up in January 2018 in response to heavy clashes in December 2017, but this mediation effort did not lead to an agreement

UNMISS and Oxfam facilitated a peace meeting in Malek County, near Rumbek, on 31 December 2018. This meeting led to conclusion of a peace agreement, which stipulated a ceasefire to end the intercommunal violence, cattle raids, and deadly revenge attacks. It was also agreed that both sides would return stolen cows and promote intercommunal interaction.

Tensions between the Luac Jang Dinka and the Thiyic Dinka increased due to the appointment of a new county commissioner in Tonj East county, Warap state. A combination of these tensions with land conflict and cattle rustling triggered armed clashes between the two groups in October 2015. In addition to deploying troops, the state governor mediated between both sides to the conflict. This reduced tensions.

At the request of district officials, the Peace Centers for Climate and Social Resilience (PCCSR) project organized various peace meetings between the Borana, Hamar, and Arbore in Marmaro between 2014 and 2017.
third_party: local government; Peace Centers for Climate and Social Resilience (PCCSR) project

description: On 22 and 24 October 2005, the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA) initiated a peace process with district officials in Arbaminch. This process focused on resolving conflicts between the Dassanech, Hamar, and Nyangatom.
The EPARDA subsequently organized a peace conferences for the groups and several peace meetings were held throughout 2006.

District and tribal officials from the Nyangatom and the Hamar held a week-long peace conference Kangaten in July 2007. The conflict parties reached an agreement to cease hostilities over grazing land and water.

The agriculturalist Masalit and the pastoralist Rizeigat Baggara clashed in 2015. The Rizeigat Baggara’s cattle grazing on Masalit farms triggered several retaliatory attacks between the two tribes. Following clashes between Rezeigat and Massalit over access to land in the Graida area on 20 and 27 November, local authorities deployed security personnel and started to mediate between the conflcit parties. This mediation effort led a peace agreement on 11 December 2015.

Tension rose again between the Masalit and Rizeigat Baggara in late 2016, with armed clashes throughout November leaving twelve Massalit and 27 Rizeigat dead in South Darfur. The paramount chief of the Rizeigat living in Ed Daein subsequently visited the conflict area in late November to defuse tensions and prevent the further mobilization of his community. Local authorities, in turn, engaged with the Masalit to defuse tensions. Yet, Masalit farmers killed two Rizeigat nomads who allegedly grazed their cattle on their farm in Dimasoya on 16 November.

The conflict parties held a reconciliation conference in Bielel on 10 December 2016, where they did not sign an agreement, but agreed that all Rizeigat herders would leave the locality until the end of the farming season in mid-January 2017.

The Fulani (commonly referred to as the Fallata in Darfur) and the Salamat Baggara are both pastoralists groups. A Salamat Baggara attack on a Fulani tribesman in Dimsu town in the Buram district of South Darfur triggered a series of revenge attacks between the two groups. Three days of fighting around Dimsu resulted in the killing of around 150 tribe members. Fighting over cattle-rustling resumed from 13 to 15 August in the Al Nadhif area in Buram and led to 83 fatalities. The conflict parties initiated negotiations in late August, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 7 September 2015.

On 3 March 2016. Sudanese government soldiers and police forcefully disarmed members of the Salamat and Fulani in Tullus and Buram localities. This led to the detaining of 84 members of both tribes. On 16 May 2016, the conflict parties held a reconciliation conference supported by UNAMID. The violations of the September 2015 peace agreement were discussed and the parties signed a new reconciliation agreement committed to disarmament and financial compensation for those killed.

However, the conflict parties clashed again on 9 October 2016. In addition to the deployment of government forces, a peace committee was established, comprising the native administrations of both communities and local authorities, which mediated between the conflict parties between October and December 2016.
third_party: traditional leaders; local government; local peace committee

description: MINUSCA helped the armed groups in Bambari reach a weapons-free-zone agreement on 8 September 2015.

On 27 January 2016, Ali Darassa from the UPC and Edouard Ngaïssona from the anti-Balaka signed a non-aggression pact, entitled the Protocole d’accord de nonagression et de bonne cohabitation (English: Memorandum of Understanding on Nonaggression and Coexistence). This agreement was aimed at preventing heavy fighting in the Bambari area, which could disrupt the parliamentary and presidential elections that were held between December 2015 and March 2016. However, the agreement specified that the ceasefire commitments could extend beyond the election period. Darassa and Ngaïssona committed to suspend violent actions, including against the population and the international forces deployed in Bambari, and to allow for the free movement of persons and goods.
agreement_name: Protocole d’accord de nonagression et de bonne cohabitation

description: Another local peace process took place in the Mbrès sub-prefecture. The MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro – with the involvement of the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities – mediated between the anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand in the Mbrès area. This led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 8 June 2016.
third_party: MINUSCA; religious leaders; local government; local peace committee

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant’Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all “politico-military groups” into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; UN; EU; Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant’Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touadéra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touadéra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant’Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017.

On 28 August 2018, Russia – which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 – and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

In addition, a local peace process took place in the Basse-Kotto prefecture. Heavy fighting had broken out between anti-Balaka and the UPC in Kongbo, Basse-Kotto prefecture in the previous year, in August 2017. In response, MINUSCA had established a temporary base in the area in August 2017. Local peace actors – including Community and religious leaders, local authorities – initiated a mediation effort between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the Basse-Kotto prefecture in July 2018. This culminated into the conclusion of a peace agreement in Mobaye on 15 October 2018. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, the free movement of the population, and a commitment to refrain from impeding the restoration of state authority.
third_party: religious leaders; community leaders; local government

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: In South Kivu, the Bafulero and Barundi reside. The Barundi have long considered themselves native to the land, while they view the Bafulero as newcomers. On 5 May 2013, fighting began when the Bafulero allegedly sought to desecrate the resting place of a Barundi leader in protest over the clan’s power in the Ruzizi Valley.  The provincial government sent officials to the region, while local clan leaders and civil society members organized sensitization meetings between the two sides.

Negotiations between the Banyamulenge and Bafuliruled to the signing of a peace agreement in Kahuna in the Bijombo groupment on 14 December 2017. The negotiations were mediated by the NGO Promotion des Personnes Marginalisees (PROPEM), representatives from the Provincial Government, and MONUSCO.

The Bishop of Uvira in South Kivu, supported by MONUSCO, organized an intercommunity dialogue between the in Uvira town on 18 and 19 September 2018. Representatives of civil society and provincial and local authorities  also attended. The dialogue session led to the conclusion of an Acte d’Engagement. A committee composed of two members of each community was set up to follow-up on the commitments, while the Bishop traveled to Kinshasa on 21 September 2018 to hand over the detailed dialogue’s report and the Actes D’Engagement to national authorities.

MONUSCO and International Alert organized a three-day intercommunity dialogue between the Banyamulenge, Babembe, Bafuliru, Banyindu, Barundi, and Pygmies in Bijombo between 25 and 28 June 2019. This led to the signing of an Act of Commitment stating necessary conditions for sustainable peace.

In March 2016, a delegation led by Congolese politician Vital Kamhere mediated between Nande and Hutu. With Kamerhe, local representatives of the communities traveled to Kinshasa to speak with the prime minister Augustin Matata Ponyo Mapon about solutions to the rising conflict. This delegation also met with the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General in the DRC to discuss how to resolve the communal conflict between the Hutu and the Nande. On 2 and 3 November 2016, MONUSCO supported awareness-raising activities on peaceful cohabitation in Buleusa to facilitate the return of internally displaced persons and peaceful cohabitation between the Hutu, Kobo and Nande communities. On 29 November 2016, MONUSCO supported the provincial assessment mission led by the Governor of North Kivu following the violent clashes in Luhanga on 27 November 2016.

MONUSCO facilitated a number of high-level visits, including by the Head of State and the Minister of the Interior with representatives of the Hutu and Nade communties in the Buleusa area in July 2016. This resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire and a reconciliation ceremony on 23 July 2016.

From 13 to 17 December 2016, MONUSCO facilitated the mediation effort of local authorities between community leaders in Luhanga, Luofu, and in the surrounding areas. The peacemaking efforts to address the conflict between the Hutu and Nande communities in 2016 also involved engagement with the respective Hutu and Nande parliamentary caucuses in Kinshasa in order to support the local reconciliation conferences in Goma, thus bringing together key state-level actors with local ones.

On 20 January 2017, a meeting between Hutu and Nande leaders, facilitated by MONUSCO, put in place a Committee on Peaceful Coexistence between the two communities. The 12-member committee, consisting of artists, church leaders and local authorities, was tasked to lead the reconciliation process.

MONUSCO supported a series of dialogues facilitated by local authorities in order to address rising intercommunal tensions between Nande and Hutu communities in the Rutshuru area between 20 and 27 March 2017.

Following several abductions of Nande by the Hutu throughout mid-July, MONUSCO supported local authorities and civil society in facilitating dialogue between Nande and Hutu leaders in July 2017. This peacemaking effort led to the conclusion of a non-aggression pact, which stipulated an end to the fighting and the return of the abductees. This subsequently led to a reduction in tensions. Only one more armed clash took place between the Nande and the Hutu from this meeting April onwards, namely in December 2017.

The Libya Dawn and the Zintan Military Council clashed in Tripoli in July 2014. The Zintan Military Council sought to eliminate Islamist influence in Libya and Libya Dawn was a coalition to counter such efforts. Following clashes at the Tripoli International Airport, a local peace council mediated a ceasefire between the conflict parties on 17 July 2014. This ceasefire did not hold. On 23 August, the Libya Dawn successfully expelled the Zintan Military Council from Tripoli. Two days later, the Libyan Dawn was absorbed into the General National Congress (GNC) as its de-facto armed forces.
On 20 February 2015, a peace meeting, mediated by religious and tribal leaders, took place in al-Asabea.
A round of bilateral negotiations was initiated following fighting in Warshafana. This led to a ceasefire agreement on 21 April 2015.
This agreement did not hold and another round of negotiations took place in early May 2015.
The two sides met again in Sabratha in late May 2015 for an unsuccessful round of peace talks.

The Zintan Military Council and Libya Dawn forces in Gharyan reached a ceasefire agreement following a round of negotiations on 9 June 2015. Similar agreements were subsequently signed by local military leaders of both sides in the cities of Zuwara, Sabratha, and Zawiya.

New negotiations between the conflict parties took place in the context of negotiations between representatives of the cities of Zintan and Kikla that began in August 2015. While the Libyan Dawn controlled Kikla, the Zintan Military Council controlled Zintan. Elders and military officials from both sides entered into negotiations.

The negotiations that had been started in August 2015 finally led to the conclusion of a peace agreement between Zintan and Kikla in January 2016. This agreement was concluded outside the ongoing UN national-level peace process.
The UN mediated a peace agreement in February 2017 between the conflict parties. This agreement did not hold. Violence continued until the end of 2017, but no clashes took place during 2018.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: In 2011, popular protests against the regime of Muammar al-Gaddafi in Libya quickly evolved into an armed uprising led by the National Transitional Council (NTC). The General National Congress (GNC) assumed power on 8 August 2012. The Libyan National Army (LNA) and Zintan Military Council (ZMC) resisted the GNC. In June 2014, the country held general elections in which a new legislative assembly was elected: the House of Representatives (HOR). However, the transfer of power never happened as the GNC contested the legitimacy of the elections and the HOR was pushed out of Tripoli by pro-GNC factions. The forces of HOR are a collection of various militias that support its claim to legitimacy, including the ZMC and LNA. The Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council was formed in June 2014 in response to Khalifa Haftar’s Operation Dignity that aimed to defeat all Islamist armed groups in Libya. The Forces of the HOR participated in the fight against the Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council. The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the conflict parties on 19 November 2014, which led to the conclusion of a humanitarian ceasefire for 12 hours.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2016. On 10 December 2016, the LNA declared a six-hour unilateral ceasefire for citizen evacuation.

side_b: Forces of the House of Representatives
description: UNSMIL supported local mediation efforts between the conflict parties in 2017.

The Awlad Suleiman and Toubou tribes both reside in Sabha, which is located in the Fezzan region. Tensions arose and spilled over into violent conflict during the regime change that came with the fall of the regime of Muammar al-Gadaffi. From 2012 onwards, the tribes fought each other over control of Sabha, which was a hub for smuggling. Negotiations between tribal leaders led to a ceasefire on 13 January 2013, but this ceasefire soon broke down. The Prime Minister subsequently visited the conflict area on 19 January to promote peace.

UNSMIL mediated a round of negotiations between the conflict parties in March 2013. This led to the signing of a peace agreement, but this agreement failed due to a lack of support from the wider Toubou community.
Libyan government officials mediated negotiations between the conflict parties between March and May 2013, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire and the release of prisoners in May 2013.

On 20 April 2013, a group of senior Libyan government officials led by Prime Minister Abdurraheem al-Keib mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of a document on reconciliation, stipulating a ceasefire between the two tribes. However, this did not quell the clashes.
Another reconciliation meeting between the two groups failed and immediately descended into violence an al-Gadaffi-era People’s Hall.

In January 2014, the conflict reignited after the killing of an officer from the Awlad Suleiman tribe that was blamed on the Toubou. Negotiations on 15 January 2014 led to a ceasefire, but this ceasefire failed to last for more than 72 hours.
Another round of negotiations led to the signing of a reconciliation agreement on 25 March 2014.
The Third Force, a Misratan Militia in Southern Libya, mediated another round of negotiations in June 2014. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 22 June 2014.
The Community of Sant’Egidio mediated a humanitarian ceasefire – the Fezzan Humanitarian Agreement – between various tribes in Rome on 16 June 2016 in order to provide aid in the Fezzan region.

A round of negotiations mediated by a team of elders and southern local leaders led to a three-day ceasefire between the conflict parties on 22 November 2016. As conflict persisted, the Community of Sant’Egidio and EU’s Directorate General for International Cooperation and Development, Human Development and Migration met with local representatives  to bring them to a negotiating table. These efforts led to a meeting for preliminary talks between the tribal leaders in Rome on 8 December 2016.

In March 2017, 60 tribal representatives engaged in negotiations in Rome mediated by the Libyan Presidency Council, the Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti, the Ara Pacis Initiative, and the Community of Sant’Egidio. This led to the signing of the Reconciliation and Peace Agreement on 29 March 2017 and a document regarding methods for implementation on 31 March. A faction of the Toubou tribe rejected this agreement on 6 April and fighting resumed.
third_party: government; Italy; Ara Pacis Innitiative; Community of Sant’Egidio

description: The two sides agreed to another ceasefire during another round of negotiations on 29 April.

Negotiations between 15 tribal and state officials from Chad, Libya and Niger in Rome on 21 May 2017 led to the signing of a security and peace framework called The Sahara Triangle: New Perspectives. Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti acted as the mediator during these negotiations.
Representatives from both tribes also attended a peace conference in Brussels in May 2017 and engaged in dialogue with the Government of National Accord (GNA).
On 6 February 2018, Alwad Suleiman and Toubou tribal leaders met for peace talks in Sabha and signed a ceasefire agreement.
The Awlad Suleiman and Toubou reached another ceasefire accord during another round of negotiations on 27 February 2018.
The Presidency Council mediated between the conflict parties in response to renewed fighting in March 2018, but this did not lead to an agreement.

On 7 April, the Supreme Council of the Tribes and Cities of Fezzan called for a ceasefire for the region. In response, the Toubou announced a unilateral ceasefire on 9 April. Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire between the conflict parties on 10 April 2018.
The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) successfully mediated a ceasefire between the Awlad Suleiman and Toubou on 9 May 2018, albeit fighting continued.
Local authorities mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties in Harajah on 13 May 2018.
Negotiations between the tribal leaders led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement on 20 May 2018.
On 5 July 2018, the Toubou tribe recommitted to its 9 April ceasefire, expressing its support for the ongoing national reconciliation process.

An armed conflict between the Bani Hilal tribe and Nubian Dabudiya family in Aswan erupted on 3 April 2014, after a woman was sexually harassed. A police enforcement brought the violence to a pause, after which police officers mediated between the conflict parties. The reconciliation meeting on 3 April 2014, mediated by the police, failed and fighting broke out again.

On 5 April 2014, Prime Minister Ibrahim Mehleb and Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim visited the conflict zone and shuttled between the conflict partries to urge them to end their fighting. This ceasefire was re-affirmed and extended for one month during another round of talks mediated by the Aswan peace committee on 9 April 2014.
On 7 April 2014, an Aswan peace committee led by Governor Mustapha Yasri and local leaders mediated a round of peace talks, which led to the conclusion of a three-day truce.
third_party: local peace committee; local government; community leaders

description: The Grand Imam of Al-Azhar Ahmed Al-Tayeb mediated a round of peace talks between the conflict parties in Aswan on 12 April 2014. His mediation team included the Minister of Religious Endowment Mokhtar Gomaa, Al-Azhar officials, religious and education leaders. As part of the peace process, the mediation team managed compensation for victims of the communal violence. The mediation effort by the Grand Imam of Al-Azhar led to the extension of the existing ceasefire for three months.

On 3 May 2014, the two tribes expressed their commitment to full reconciliation. However, fighting broke out again on 26 June 2014. On 28 June 2014, the Aswan peace committee mediated a round of peace talks that led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

Armed fighting between the supporters of the People’s Democratic Party (PDP) and the main opposition party, the All Progressives Congress (APC), erupted ahead of some local elections in 2014 and the 2015 general elections. The PDP candidate and then president, Goodluck Jonathan of the Niger Delta, was widely supported by Christians in the south, while the APC candidate, Muhammadu Buhari of Katsina State, represented the predominantly Muslim north. In June 2014, the Centre for Democracy and Development (CDD) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) organized a peace meeting in Ekiti State with several political parties, traditional and religious leaders, as well as civil society organizations and security personnel. The mediators tried to reach an agreement on guaranteeing violence free elections, but candidates of the APC, the Labour Party (LP), and the PDP refused to sign the agreement.
third_party: community leaders; UN; traditional leaders; religious leaders; government forces

description: Several peace meetings were held between the presidential candidates in 2015 in view of the upcoming presidential elections.
