Following a peace meeting on election-related violence, PDP leader President Goodluck Jonathan, APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, and nine other presidential candidates signed the Abuja agreement on 14 January 2015. This agreement committed the political parties and their supporters to peace during the presidential campaigns.

In respsonse to election-related violence in Kaduna State and Niger State, Deputy Inspector General of Police mediated talks between the leaders of several political parties in the region, including the leaders of the PDP and APC. This led to the signing of a peace agreement aimed at preventing further election-related violence on 10 February 2015.

During a peace meeting in Benue State on 4 March, 2015, PDP candidate John Ngbede and APC candidate Samuel Ortom reached an agreement to ensure violence-free elections in the region. This agreement was mediated by the Committee of Security Agencies, headed by State Police Commissioner Hycinth Dagala.

General Abdulsalami Abubakar of the National Peace Committee on the 2015 elections mediated a round of peace talks between PDP leader President Goodluck Jonathan and APC leader Muhammadu Buhari in Abuja on 26 March 2015. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement that committed the parties to holding violence-free elections. However, violence broke out between APC and PDP supporters shortly after the agreement was signed.

The Inter-Agency Consultative Committee on Electoral Security led by the State commissioner of police of Rivers State, Mr. Musa Kimo, mediated between regional leaders of the APC and PDP and their supporters at the Police Officers Mess in Port Harcourt in February 2016. The meeting was held to manage election-related violence ahead of the forthcoming national and state assembly rerun elections. The meeting did not lead to an agreement and the supporters of the APC and PDP clashed again soon after the meeting.

Uk’omu Igala, an Igala socio-cultural group, mediated between several political parties, including the PDP and APC, in Anyigba in the Local Government Area of Dekina in Kogi State on 22 January 2019. The meeting led to the conclusion of an agreement that committed the parties to holding elections without violence and to promoting peaceful cohabitation among their supporters.

A peace meeting between 28 party leaders, including the APC and the PDP, took place at the Kano State Government House on 23 January 2019. The meeting was mediated by the Kano State Peace Committee and led to the conclusion of an agreement that stressed the need for peaceful elections and the demilitarization of the supporters of political parties.

INEC, together with the Inter-Agency Consultative Committee on Election Security (ICCES), mediated a peace agreement between 30 political parties in the Gombe State on 24 January 2019. Muhammad Inuwa Yahaya and Usman Bayero Nafada signed for the APC and PDP respectively.

Political party leaders in Bayelsa State, including APC and PDP leaders, gathered for a peace meeting at the police officers’ mess in Yenagoa on 24 January 2019. This meeting was mediated by the state police command together with officials of the Inter-Party Advisory Council (IPAC). The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that committed the parties to peaceful elections.

A peace meeting mediated by the state police commissioner led to a peace agreement in Anambra State on 30 January 2019. The political leaders attending the meeting were encouraged to convey the call for peace to their supporters. Armed clases between the supporters of the APC and the PDP frequently occured in the run-up to the general elections in several states in spite of the many peace efforts. Consequnetly, several additional peace efforts were undertaken in early February 2019, just before the elections.

The presidential and National Assembly elections scheduled for February 2019 led to an upsurge in violence between APC and PDP supporters beginning in January 2019. During the month of January 2019, political representatives in several Nigerian states signed peace agreements to guarantee peaceful campaigns. These were most of the time mediated by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) together with state police officials. The purpose of these agreements was to encourage political leaders to ensure peaceful elections and to communicate to their supporters the importance of peaceful cohabitation with the supporters of rival parties during the campaign and beyond. On 9 January 2019, the political parties of Enugu, including the APC and PDP, signed an agreement at a meeting mediated by the state police command and INEC at the Senior Officers Mess in Agbani Road.

On 18 January 2019, INEC also mediated talks between leaders of the APC, PDP, and of 23 other political parties in Kwara State, which led to the signing of a peace accord guaranteeing violence-free elections. The peace meeting was held at the state headquarters of INEC at Adewole area of Ilorin in Kwara State.

On 18 January 2019, a peace meeting between parties in the region, including the PDP and APC, was held in the Taal Conference Hotel in Lafia in Nasarawa State. This meeting was mediated by the Center for Humanitarian Affairs, in collaboration with INEC, and led to the conclusion of a peace agreement guaranteeing free and fair elections without violence.

On 5 February 2019, PDP and several other party leaders of Akwa Ibom State engaged in talks mediated by INEC at Ibom hall. The meeting was aimed at concluding a peace agreement to mitigate election-related violence, but the APC did not sign the agreement.

On the same day (5 February 2019), the state police command mediated between governor Nasir el-Rufai of the APC and the PDP governorship candidate Isa Ashiru, as well as 20 other political leaders. The meeting led to the siging of a peace agreement that committed the conflict parties to violent-free elections. The meeting took place at the police officers’ mess in Kaduna and was mediated by Police Commissioner Alhaji Ahmad Abdurrahman.

The civil society organization Hope Givers Initiative and INEC mediated a peace meeting between five governorship candidates, including the APC and PDP candiates, in Umuahia in Abia State on 12 February 2019. This resulted in the signing of a peace agreement to guarantee peaceful elections.

On 13 February 2019, the two main presidential rivals, Muhammadu Buhari of the APC and Atiku Abubakar of the PDP attended a peace meeting in Abuja, together with 71 other political representatives. The National Peace Committee led by the former military ruler Abdulsalami Abubakar and the Kofi Annan Foundation mediated between the parties. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement and all signatories called uppoon their supporters to wage a peaceful campaign. However, this did not prevent clashes between APC and PDP supporters from occurring in Abuja only one day after the signing of the agreement.

After the reelection of President Buhari of the APC with 56 percent of the votes, violence resumed between the supporters of the APC and PDP in the second half of February 2019. The PDP considered the previously concluded agreements broken. Ahead of state governor elections in Kogi State in November 2019, several political parties, including the PDP and APC, reached a peace agreement that was mediated by the Search for Common Ground, the Kukah Foundation, and the National Peace Committee in Lokoja on 7 November 2019. The signing ceremony was disrupted by thugs who attacked the political candidates. Moreover, attacks resumed between supporters of the two main parties already the next day after the signing of the agreement.
third_party: Search for Common Ground; community leaders; government

description: A peace meeting mediated by police officials and INEC led to the conclusion of an agreement in Yenagoa in Bayelsa State on 7 November 2019. The agreement was signed by 42 parties in the run-up to the state governor’s elections. Senator Douye Diri signed on behalf of the PDP, while David Lyon signed on behalf of the APC.

An armed conflict between Fulani herders and Jukun farmers erupted in 2014 in Taraba State. Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

Representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes of Bali Local Government Area signed another peace agreement during a peace meeting on 29 April 2014. However, the hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014 in that area. On 30 April 2014, Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders in Wukari Local Government Area held a peace meeting in response to armed clashes in Wukari on 15 April 2014. Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement. However, the armed fighting resumed in early May 2014. In response, on 16 May 2014, the Governors of Benue State and Taraba State inaugurated a seven-man joint peace committee mandated to ensure the return of peace between the Tiv, Jukun, and Fulani living in the border communities of the two states.

In June 2016, Fulani and Jukun representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

Following clashes in May and June 2019, local state authorities mediated a peace meeting between the leaders of the Jukun and Fulani communities in Local Government Areas of Jalingo, Ardo-Kola, and Lau. The meeting took place at the secretariat of the local government of Jalingo. The meeting did not result in an agreement.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

President Muhammadu Buhari convended a meeting between the leaders of the conflict parties in Abuja on 2 September 2019. In addition to the conflict parties, Governor of Taraba State D.D. Ishaku also attended the peace meeting. The meeting focused on the conflict between the Fulani and the Jukun-Kona in the Local Government Areas of Jalingo and Ardo Kola in Taraba State. The conflict parties did not sign a peace agreement, but both sides agreed to live together peacefully.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.

While the Borana and Gabra have a long conflcit history, the Burji allied with the gabra in 2013. The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated a round of negotiations between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra on 24 March 2013.
The Kenyan government mediated an inter-tribal meeting between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra in Moyale on 28 August 2013.
Another round of peace talks between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra took place in Moyale in December 2013. Kenyan security forces mediated between the conflict parties at these peace talks.

Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta formed the Marsabit Peace Restoration Committee to reconcile the conflict parties. With support from the UN, this committee mediated between the Borana and Gabra. Francis ole Kaparo and Yusuf Haji, the former National Assembly speaker and county senator respectively, led the committee and acted as the chief mediators. This peace meeting led to the signing of the Boma Peace Agreement on 22 February 2014. However, fighting would continue.
third_party: UN; government; local government; local peace committee

description: On 23 March 2015, 35 elders from the Borana and Gabra, and the Burji, Sakuye, and Garre convened in Mandera to discuss prospects for peace. The elders agreed to implement the February 2014 treaty.

The Arab Mouvement Arabe de l’Azawad (MAA) (English: Arab Movement of Azawad) was established as a reaction to the Coordination des Mouvements de l’Azawad (CMA) (English: Coordination of Azawad Movements), originally the Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad). Burkina Faso’s president Blaise Compaoré mediated a round of negotiations between the CMA and the MAA in Ougadougou in June 2013. Yet, on 15 and 19 July 2013, clashes between MAA and CMA took place again, this time in Lerneb.

Between 6 and 11 August 2013, the Government of Mauritania mediated negotiations between CMA and MAA leaders in Nouakchott, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire and a joint statement on 9 August 2013, calling for collaboration among them to ensure the security of the northern regions.

On 3 September 2013, the MAA and CMA held their first meeting at the military level. Officers of the two groups met for bilateral negotiations on a neutral ground at Mishra, which was located in between their bases in the far north-eastern part of the country. The discussions centered on the implementation of the Nouakchott Agreement and an end to hostilities. The negotiation teams agreed to set up a permanent coordination mechanism between the heads of the Inhalil and Infara bases in order to guarantee security in the areas and avoid new clashes.

In late 2016, a peace committee made up of neighbouring tribes – the Warfalla Bani Wali, Zintan, Tarhuna, Barqah – mediated negotiations in Sabha between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhadhfa. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 25 November.

Another round of peace talks mediated by the peace committee led to the Agreement on Peaceful Coexistence Between the Tribes of Qadhadhfa and Awlad Suleiman on 4 December 2016. However, fighting would reignited in late December.
agreement_name: Agreement on Peaceful Coexistence Between the Tribes of Qadhadhfa and Awlad Suleiman

description: The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhahdfa in Malta from 24 to 26 May 2017.

On 6 November 2017, a follow-up round of dialogue for women-only, supported by UNSMIL, took place in Tripoli. Tribal representatives from the cities of Kabaw and Batin al-Jabal agreed on 26 November to establish an independent committee for an investigation of the conflict between the Awlad Suleiman and Qadhadhfa.

No negotiations or mediation took place in 2013. The Kuteb, sometimes referred to as the Kutev or Zompere, and Tiv tribes enagaged in an armed conflict over land use in the Tukum Local Government Area in Taraba State. In 2007, the two communities clashed violently following the conflict that had already erupted in July 2006 on the borders of Benue and Taraba States. The Governor of Benue State, together with his Taraba counterpart, mediated between the leaders of the two communities in August 2007. Chief Thomas Degaa, representing the Tiv of Benue State, and Bawa Buki, speaking on behalf of the Kuteb people of Taraba State, condemned the crisis and pledged to end the violence.

The conflict flared up again in May 2015, resulting in more than 70 deaths in Takum town in Taraba State. In September 2015, Reverend Risae Yakubu Shamaki, in collaboration with other churches, chaired a peace and reconciliation meeting at the Secretariat of the Reformed Church of Christ for the Nations (RCCN) in Takum. During this peace meeting, the Governor of Taraba State, Darius Ishaku, appealed to the two communities stop fighting. The conflict parties vowed to do so, though no written agreement was signed.
In June 2017, the governor of Taraba State convened a peace meeting between Tiv, Junkun, Kuteb and Miyeti Allah leaders in Jalingo in Taraba State. The meeting did not result in a peace agreement.

An armed conflict between Eggon farmers and pastoralists Fulani over land use emerged in Nasarawa State in 2013 and rights. On 2 September 2014, the Governor of Nasarawa State, Tanko Al-Makura, mediated between the leaders of the conflict parties at the state house in Lafia. The conflict parties did not sign a peace agreement. The meeting only resulted in an eleven-point communiqué guaranteeing the government’s support in resolving the crisis.

Joseph Haruna Kigbu – a member of the House of Representatives – mediated a round of negtoiations between the Fulani and Eggon representatives in Lafia on 27 and 28 December 2014, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

On 8 October 2017, the NGO Search for Common Ground mediated a peace meeting between representatives of several ethnic groups – including the Fulani, Tiv, Alago, Eggon, Mada, and Migili – in the Doma Local Government Area in Nasarawa State. The mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

The Hamar and the Ma’aliyah are both Arab tribes, but the Hamar are mainly agricultural while the Ma’aliyah are mainly pastoralists. An incident in which a Ma’aliyah tribesman wanted to let his cattle graze on the farmlands of the Hamar triggered an armed conflict between the two groups in December 2013. Fighting ended following the deployment of government forces and negotiations between tribal leaders from both tribes, with mediation by local authorities. However, tensions remained high.

Fighting resumed again in March 2014. Following another armed clash on 24 May, local leaders mediated between the conflict parties. This initially stopped the fighting, but later on the day Hamar fighters attacked and burned a Ma’aliyah village, which re-started fighting between the conflict parties.
Direct negotiations between the leaders of the Hamar and the Ma’aliyah continued throughout July and August, but without any results.
Nevertheless, on 27 September 2014, leaders of the Hamar and Ma’aliyah tribes signed a reconciliation agreement in El Fula, West Kordofan. UNAMID supported this peace meeting.

The Misseriya and the Salamat Baggara are both pastoralist, Arab groups. An incident in which a member of the Misseriya community shot a man from the Salamat Baggara group triggered an armed conflict on 3 April 2013 in which at least 456 people were killed. The Nazirs (the native leaders of the tribes) signed a ceasefire in Umm Dukhun on 11 April 2013. This ceasefire stipulated the dismantling of soldiers’ camps, the return of displaced to their villages, and the demilitarization of civilians. Local authorities mediated this ceasefire.

The conflict parties started an ajaweed reconciliation conference in early June 2013. UNAMID supported this reconciliation conference. The conference ended with the signing of a peace agreement. However, this agreement did not hold.
Another ceasefire was reached on 31 July 2013.

On 13 September 2013, leaders of the Salamat and Misseriya tribes agree to open the roads linking Um Dukhun, Bindisi, Abugaradil, Nyala, Zalingei, and Foro Baranga, as well as to encourage the displaced people to return voluntarily to their areas.

UNAMID Civil Affairs facilitated the travel of the Governor of Central Darfur and the State Security Committee, accompanied by a team of UNAMID mediators, to Um Dukhun on 17 November 2013 to mediate between the two tribes. The mediation effort succeeded confirming the conflict parties’ commitment to the peace agreement signed on 3 July 2013 and the conflict parties once more agreed on a cessation of hostilities.

On 16 June 2014, the Central Darfur governor dismissed leaders of the Salamat and Misseriya tribes from their administrative positions, claiming that they had put insufficient effort in trying to mediate between the conflict parties. Negotiations with support from UNAMID led to the signing of a ceasefire in Um in September 2014.
In Response to renewed armed clashes between the Misseriya and the Salamat Baggara in July 2016, the reconciliation committee in Lagawa unsuccessfully tried to mediate between the conflict parties.

Following heavy clashes between the Misseriya and the Salamat Baggara in May 2017, UNAMID and Sudanese authorities mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 27 May 2017. This ceasefire did not hold. Salamat tribesmen attacked the Misseriya in the Sure area on June 12, killing one Misseriya.

In Colloboration with Sudanese authorities, UNAMID mediated between the conflict parties on 6, 12 and 28 June, with the goal to make them implement the ceasefire. These meetings were not successful. On 21 August, another two clashes took place in Um Dukhun, resulting in the death of two people.

The Beni Halba Baggara and Gimir are both predominantly cattle herding, Arab communities in South Darfur. The communities clashed in 2013 in a land conflict. The Gimir accused the Beni Halba of trying to oust them from areas they had lived on for more than 300 years. In addition, representatives for the Gimir community accused the government – in particular Second Vice President- al-Haj Adam Youssef, who is from the Beni Halba – of supporting the Beni Halba. The paramilitary Central Reserve Police allegedly sided with the Beni Halba. The conflict was triggered by the South Darfur government allocating Gimr land in Katayla locality to the Beni Halba. On 16 March 2013, the leaders of the two tribes signed a ceasefire agreement at the house of the local commissioner. According to this agreement, the Gimr had to pay blood money to the Beni Halba for the four losses it suffered. The ceasefire was mediated by the governor of South Darfur Hammad Ismail Hammad and the locality’s “committee for goodwill”, with support from UNAMID. In addition to a commitment to “put an end to tribal gatherings, escalations of incidents and all forms of violence”, the conflict parties agreed to hold a reconciliation conference in April 2013. However, armed fighting continued.
third_party: local government; local peace committee; UNAMID

description: The governor of South Darfur, with support from UNAMID, therefore resumed its mediation effort in Nyala in early May 2013. This led to another ceasefire agreement on 4 May 2013. Yet, fighting continued.
third_party: local government; local peace committee; UNAMID

description: Negotiations therefore continued in Nyala in June, but these negotiations broke down in June, with the Gimir leaders stating their unwillingness to continue to participate in any reconciliation initiatives because they lacked confidence in the neutrality of State authorities to mediate the dispute.

Heavy fighting erupted again in March 2014, so UNAMID initiated a mediate effort between the conflict parties. UNAMID staff, together with a leader from the Tama tribe, mediated between Beni Halba Baggara and Gimir representatives at UNAMID’s base in Saraf Omra on 12 March 2014. This led to the conclusion of a reconciliation agreement, stipulating a ceasefire. The signing ceremony was attended by 50 members from each of the communities.

Tensions between the Misseriya and Nuer resumed again in early 2018, when Nuer again entered into the Abyei Area from Unity State, South Sudan. Between 16 and 17 February, at least 32 Misseriya were reportedly killed at Kadama to the east of the Abyei Area by Nuer from Mayom county in South Sudan. The killings were in response to cattle rustling. The United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) undertook a reconciliation effort in response to the armed clash.

A clash resulting in three Misseriya killed by the Nuer in the Marial Achak area on 11 May 2018 prompted the Abyei joint peace committee to invite representatives of the Nuer to attend one of their meetings on 17 May 2018.

side_b: Awlad Metanin clan (Misseriya), Awlad Serur clan (Misseriya)
description: The different clans of the Misseriya living in South Kordofan in Sudan have historically not engaged in large-scale conflict, but the discovery of oil in the region led to a land conflict between the Awlad Heiban clan on one side and the Awlad Serur and Awlad Metanin clans on the other side. In addition, all the clans involved in this conflict had formed part of the Popular Defence Forces (PDF) that had fought the Sudan People’s Liberation Army (SPLA), which meant all sides were heavily armed. The Awlad Heiban attacked the Awlad Serur and Awlad Metanin clans in al-Fula on 6 January 2013, resulting in around 80 battle-deaths. In response to the armed conflict a reconciliation conference between the three tribes was held. Minister of Decentralized Government Hasbu Muhammad Abd al-Rahman acted as the mediator at this conference. The conference ended with the signing of a peace agreement on 1 March 2013, the Final Communique of the Reconciliation Conference between the Misseriyya Tribes. The agreement specified the payment of blood money, as well as outlined punishments for transgressing the agreement and a mechanism for re-negotiation.
agreement_name: Final Communique of the Reconciliation Conference between the Misseriyya Tribes

description: The Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala are two Arab communities in North Darfur. The exploitation of a gold mine led to armed conflict between the two communities. The area where the gold mine is located has traditionally been under the control of the Beni Hussein community, but the Reizegat Abbala tried to take control of the land in 2013 in order to benefit from the mining revenues. The Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala clashed for the first time on 5 January 2013. Local authorities and a council of elders immediately initiated a mediation effort in response to the violence, with support from UNAMID. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 11 January 2013. However, fighting continued.

On 13 and 14 January, UNAMID transported state government officials to the towns of El Sireaf and Saraf Umra to mediate between the conflict parties. The peace talks in Saraf Umra, mediated by the Governor of Northern Darfur with support from UNAMID, led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 17 January, which stipulated an end to the fighting, the stop of mining activities in Jebel Amir until the dispute would be resolved, and the participation in another reconciliation conference.
A similar agreement was signed on the same day in Um Dukhun, between members of the Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala who had participated in the fighting when it spread to that area.

Sporadic, small-scale clashes between the militias continued, but heavy fighting broke out again on 21 February. On 1 March, representatives of the Aballa and Beni Hussein militias held a second reconciliation conference in Saraf Umra, again chaired by the Governor of Northern Darfur with support from UNAMID. That conference concluded again with a ceasefire agreement, stipulating and end to the hostilities and a withdrawal of roadblocks on the road between El Sireaf and Saraf Umra.
On 17 June 2013, the administrations of the Beni Hussein and the Abbala tribes met to discuss a possible ceasefire between the two tribes, but the meeting was unsuccessful.

Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of an agreement on 25 July 2013. This agreement not only stipulated a ceasefire, it also stipulated the free movement of people, vehicles, cattle, and goods to the market. In addition, government forces were to take control of the mining area. The agreement stipulated the creation of a compensation fund financed with gold revenues to pay blood money for each victim of the conflict. The governor of North Darfur announced on 6 August 2013 that government troops would soon be deployed to the El Sareif locality to monitor the agreement between the conflict parties.

The Civil Affairs section of UNAMID facilitated a peace conference between the Beni Hussein and Reizegat Abbala between 5 and 7 June 2014. The conference, which was attended by more than 250 representatives, was aimed at addressing outstanding issues between the two tribes and diffuse tensions in the area. A government delegation and sheikh Musa Hilal initiated the meeting. The conference ended with a renewal of the ceasefire, the establishment of committees to strengthen existing reconciliation mechanisms, and a resolution on pending issues, and agreement to re-open the roads leading to El Serief. In addition, the conference led to release of seven Beni Hussein tribesmen on 7 June, who had been abducted by members of the Rizeigat tribe on 26 May 2014.

The successor of the ex-Seleka movement, the Front patriotique pour la Renaissance de la Centrafrique (FPRC) (English: Patriotic Front for the Renaissance in the Central African Republic) was formed on 10 July 2014 in an attempt to keep the ex-Seleka fighters unified. The FPRC was initially led by Michel Djotodia, but Noureddine Adam assumed leadership later in 2014.  In June 2014, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) initiated the first peace initiative following the crisis in 2013. A discussion on possible mechanisms to resolve the armed conflict at a workshop that brought together 30 Central African participants from varying backgrounds – including representatives from government, anti-Balaka, and ex-Seleka – led to the idea of organizing a forum. Furthermore, on the sidelines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum.  However, clashes continued between the conflict parties.

Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC – as well as several other armed groups, though not the UPC led by Ali Darassa) – in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014.
Sassou Nguesso resumed another round of negotiations with the FPRC and anti-Balaka in Nairobi in December 2014. Kenya acted as the mediator at these negotiations.

Negotiations mediated by Kenya that had started in Nairobi in December 2014 continued in January 2015. This round of negotiations led to the signing of an agreement between the FPRC and the anti-Balaka on 22 January 2015. The FPRC and anti-Balaka negotiators present at this round of negotiations were referred to as the “Nairobists”, they included Micheal Djotodia, Nouredine Adam and their top commanders, as well as the Francois Bozizé and his son, Jean-Francis Bozizé, Maxime Mokom, and Joachim Kokaté.

Negotiations mediated by Kenya resumed in Nairobi in April 2015. This led to the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on Ceasefire and Cessation of Hostilities, as well as the Nairobi Engagement Declaration Adherence to the Transition Roadmap in Central African Republic on 8 April 2015. Joachim Kokate signed the agreement on behalf of the anti-Balaka and ex-president Michel Djotodia signed on behalf of the ex-Seleka. The government of Interim President Samba-Panza rejected the ceasefires concluded in January and April 2015, claiming it had not been involved in the talks mediated by the Kenyan government in Nairobi
agreement_name: Nairobi Agreement on Ceasefire and Cessation of Hostilities;  Nairobi Engagement Declaration Adherence to the Transition Roadmap in Central African Republic

description: Nevertheless, building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise was given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarrmenent, demoblizaition, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, including the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces républicaines fondamentales, Seleka rénovée, Mouvement des libérateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front démocratique pour le progrès de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unité du peuple centrafricain, Révolution et justice, and the Union des forces républicaines.
third_party: government; MINUSCA; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); EU
agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic; Republican Pact

description: Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact – or in full the Pacte républicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en République centrafricaine – which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR. In addition to the ECCAS-led mediation effort and the mediation effort as part of the Bangui Forum, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) mediated a unilateral ceasefire agreement with the FPRC in N’Djamena on 20 December 2015. Cheikh Tidiane Gadio acted as the chief mediator of the OIC. Noureddine Adam promised to refrain from seeking independence from the Central African Republic issued a unilateral ceasefire and stated that the ceasefire would make it possible to hold elections. Legislative and presidential elections were held without significant armed fighting in late 2015.
third_party: government; MINUSCA; Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); EU

description: A local peace process in Batangafo, with support from the Bossangoa field office of MINUSCA, led to the conclusion of a weapon-free zone agreement in December 2015.

In February 2016, the AU mandated Mohamed El Hacen Lebatt as its special representative. Lebatt launched what was referred to as the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation. Angola, Chad, the DRC, and ECCAS supported this AU-led mediation effort. Talks mediated by Lebatt in February 2016 did not lead to an agreement.
third_party: AU; Angola; Chad; Democratic Republic of Congo; ECCAS

description: Building on the weapon-free zone agreement that had been concluded in Batangafo in December 2015, MINUSCA mediated a non-aggression pact between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC in Batangafo on 29 March 2016.

Another local peace process took place in the Mbrès sub-prefecture. The MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro – with the involvement of the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities – mediated between the anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand in the Mbrès area. This led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 8 June 2016.
third_party: MINUSCA; religious leaders; local government; local peace committee

description: In late 2016, a country-wide peace effort took place again. Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups – including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. André de Oliveira João Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: Angola; International Conference on the Great Lakes Region

description: Local state officials in Ouham prefecture engaged in shuttle diplomacy between the anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka leaders in Kouki and Nana-Bakassa between January and June 2017. The local peace committee and the bishop of Bossangoa were also involved in this peace effort. This paved the way for a few rounds of face-to-face negotiations in June 2017, alternating between Kouki and Nana-Bakassa. MINUSCA facilitated these negotiations in June. The head of MINUSCA’s Bossangoa office and the prefect of Ouham acted as the chairs of the negotiations. The negotiations led to the signing of the Acte d’engagement de non-violence et de paix (English: Act of Commitment to Nonviolence and Peace) on 15 June 2017.
third_party: local government; local peace committee; religious leaders; MINUSCA
agreement_name: Acte d’engagement de non-violence et de paix

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant’Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all “politico-military groups” into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire. In addition, a local peace initiative took place in the Ouham prefecture in 2017.
third_party: Community of Sant’Egidio; UN; EU; Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touadéra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June 2017.

With it being clear that the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic of June 2017 did not succeed, the AU presented its roadmap for peace in Libreville on 17 July 2017. The roadmap agreement assigns the responsibility for leading peace negotiations in CAR to the AU, while pledging to take into account the achievements of previous peace initiatives including the June 2017 Sant’Egidio Agreement. The Roadmap created an African Panel of Facilitators, with panel members from the AU, ECCAS, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, Angola, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. MINUSCA was granted observer status. The African Panel of Facilitators mediated for the first time Bangui between 11 and 12 September 2017
third_party: African Panel of Facilitators; AU; ECCAS; International Conference on the Great Lakes Region; Angola; Chad; Congo; Gabon; MINUSCA

description: A local mediation effort between the FPRC and the anti-Balaka led by the prefect of Haute-Kotto, with MINUSCA support, resulted in the conclusion of the feuille de route pour la Paix à Bria (English: Roadmap for Peace in Bria) on 19 December 2017. The agreement stipulates a cessation of hostilities and a commits the parties to refrain from impeding the restoration of the state’s authority.
agreement_name: Feuille de route pour la Paix à Bria

description: Another local peace process took place in early 2018. Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Armés de Batangafo on 24 February 2018.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Armés de Batangafo

description: The conflict parties also participated in the national-level peace process in 2018. On 28 August 2018, Russia – which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 – and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August 2018. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Ngaïssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, Séléka Rénovée, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); MINUSCA; local government; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: The armed conflict between Agatu farmers and fishermen and Fulani cattle herders mostly centered on land and grazing rights at the border between the Nasarawa and Benue State. The Nasarawa state government mediated between the Fulani and Agatu representatives to find a solution to the crisis on 2 February 2013. This mediation effort did not result in an agreement.

In another mediation attempt to end the crisis, the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State convened a peace meeting between the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu at the government house in Lafia on 11 July 2013.

A second peace meeting involving the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu, mediated by the the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State, was held in Lafia in early August 2013. The conflict parties agreed on the need to investigate the crisis and work towards a cessation of hostilities, but did not conclude a peace agreement. Violence resumed soon after this round of peace talks.

Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo, mediated a round of negotiations between Tiv, Fulani, and Agatu leaders at the government house in Makurdi in Benue State on 31 March 2014. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. However, armed fighting already resumed one week later.

The Governors of Benue State and Nasarawa State, Samuel Ortom and Tanko Al-Makura respectively, mediated peace talks between Agatu and Fulani leaders at the government headquarters in Makurdi in Benue State in January 2016. The two-day peace meeting led to an agreement on grazing rights in Agatu ahead of the harvest season in February and gave the Fulani permission to let their cattle graze on Agatu land. Both sides also agreed stop fighting and forgive the other side. However, new clashes broke out between Agatu farmers and Fulani herders along the Benue River in early February 2016. In response to these clashes, Bishop Benson Abounu, on request by Benue State Governor Samuel Ortom, met with Agatu traditional leaders in Agatu in February 2016, who expressed their renewed committment to peace with the Fulani. In a separate statement, Alhaji Mohammed Useni, president of MACBAN in Nasarawa State, representing Fulani herders, encouraged his people to embrace peace.

The Idoma Initiative and the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN), representing the Agatu and Fulani communities respectively, engaged in peace talks in Abuja on 29 March 2016. The Idoma community of Agatu is a group of prominent Agatu farmers. The negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement. In addition, the Fulani herders guaranteed that they would withdraw their cattle from the Agatu area, while Agatu youths would stop patrolling along the river.

Negotiations between the Agatu people in Benue State and Fulani herders in Nasarawa State, mediated by local authorities, led to the conclusion of an agreement to ensure peaceful coexistence on 6 January 2017. The agreement stipulates that both communities have the right to access to land and ensures that the two groups do not carry arms and do not send armed groups to contested land.

The Governors of Benue State and Nasarawa State mediated a two-day peace meeing between traditional rulers of the Agatu and Fulani on 18 and 19 January 2017. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that granted the Fulani to use part of Agatu’s land for herding their cattle.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); traditional leaders; religious leaders; government forces; local government

description: Between September to November 2014, several attempts were undertaken to reconcile the Bosco and Makenga factions within the M23.

The conflict between the Agatu and Tiv tribes took the form of a single deadly clash on the border between Benue and Nasarawa States in 2013. The Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State convened a peace meeting between the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu at the government house in Lafia on 11 July 2013.

A second peace meeting involving the Tiv, Fulani, Idoma, Alago, Migli, and Agatu, mediated by the the Governors of Nasarawa State and Benue State, was held in Lafia in early August 2013. The conflict parties agreed on the need to investigate the crisis and work towards a cessation of hostilities, but did not conclude a peace agreement. Violence resumed soon after this round of peace talks.

Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo, mediated a round of negotiations between Tiv, Fulani, and Agatu leaders at the government house in Makurdi in Benue State on 31 March 2014. This led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. However, armed fighting already resumed one week later.

Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

In June 2016, Hausa and Jukun representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

Mohammed Abubakar, the Inspector General of Police, mediated between the conflict parties in a peace meeting in Kaduna State in April 2014. The meeting brought together leaders of both conflict parties, as well as representatives of the Southern Kaduna Peoples Union (SOKAPU), leaders of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria (MACBAN), the Mogbai Fulani Development Association, and the Atakar Community Development Association. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.

After clashes broke out again in 2017, the Global Peace Foundation (GPF) convened the Southern Kaduna Peace and Reconciliation Meeting for Southern Kaduna representatives on 13 July 2017 in Afachan. Leaders of several different associations such as the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) and Jama’atu Nasril Islam (JNI), as well as representatives from different chiefdoms and communities in Southern Kaduna, participated in the meeting. The Atakar and Fulani also participated. The stakeholders present at the meeting promised to embrace peace and forgive each other. No written agreement was signed, but all parties encouraged the GPF to continue its peace efforts.

The conflict between Ansar Dine and the Coordination des Mouvements de l’Azawad (CMA) (English: Coordination of Azawad Movements), originally the Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad), took place in the context of the general upheaval during the lightning offensive of the CMA and several Jihadist armed groups in northern Mali in 2012.. The CMA took up arms against the Government of Mali in January 2012 and it was initially joined by Ansar Dine. By March 2012, the two groups had seized control of most of northern Mali. Yet, the tactical alliance broke down and the two groups began to fight each other intermittently from 2 April 2012 onwards. Disagreement centered on Ansar Dine wanting to impose Islamic law throughout Mali, while the CMA wanted to create the independent secular state of Azawad solely in northern Mali. On 27 May 2012, the leaders of both sides tried to reconcile their differences through bilateral negotiations. This led to the conclusion of an agreement in late May 2012. Both groups agreed to merge and create the independent Islamic state of Azawad. CMA spokesman Moussa ag Assarid said the alliance marked a compromise. The conflict parties agreed to an Islamic state but one developed by their own imams and suited to local religious practices. However, the agreement broke down almost immediately and Ansar Dine turned again to their Islamist allies. In the summer of 2012, Ansar Dine allied with al-Qaida al-Jihad fi Bilad al-Maghrib al-Islami (AQIM) (English: al-Qaida Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb) against the CMA and captured the regional capitals of Kidal, Timbuktu, and Gao, destroying many Sufi shrines and enforcing sharia law.
On 21 December 2012, Ansar Dine and CMA agreed to a seven-point ceasefire agreement in Algiers. Representatives of Algeria and Burkina Faso mediated these negotiations in Algiers.

The Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-Kisangani-Mouvement de Libération (RCD-K-ML) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-Kisangani-Liberation Movement), the Mouvement pour la Libération du Congo (MLC) (English: Movement for the Liberation of Congo), and the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-National (RCD-N) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-National) formed an alliance in January 2001 following negotiations by Uganda. This alliance was called the Front de Libération du Congo (FLC) (English: Front for the Liberation of Congo). The FLC clashed with the Mayi Mayi militias, who were supported by the Congolese government. The Mayi Mayi consisted of many local armed group and several Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu signed an agreement with the FLC on 21 March 2001. This agreement was endorsed by the Brigade Raisonneur Lafontaine of the Mayi Mayi, while the agreement also had the buy-in of Brigade Karisimbi represented by Kambale Maghulu, Brigade Rwenzori by Kiyungu, Brigade Vurondo by Kambale Tsongo, Brigade Rwenzori/Lubwe by Lakule Vulendi, and Brigade Mabanga by Sadamu Mindul. The Ugandan army, religious leaders, traditional chiefs and civil society representatives witnessed the signing of the agreement. The agreement provided for an extension of the FLC’s area of control to cover North Kivu areas occupied by the Mayi-Mayi, where some Mayi Mayi groups had been fighting against the presence of the Ugandan army. In a letter dated on 23 March 2001 addressed to the UN Special Representative, Bemba spoke of an agreement that Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu had allied themselves to FLC and would be forming a “Division speciale Mayi-Mayi” within the military forces of FLC. The March agreement also pointed out that, since it was difficult to know who was genuinely Mayi Mayi because the militia has a loose structure, it was a collective responsibility of all signatories to help make clear who committed to the newly concluded agreement. However, the agreement did not hold. However, on 25 April 2001, FLC clashed with Mayi Mayi warriors in Butembo. In June 2001, the FLC alliance broke down.

The homelands of the Al-Zayadia and the Berti borders each other in North Darfur. Tensions over grazing lands and other conflicts were historically resolved by the elders of the two tribes and different agreements have been signed through the years. However, accusations over the death of two people in August 2012 increased tensions between the tribes. In addition, the Al-Zayadia accused the Berti of receiving weapons from the former governor of North Darfur, Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir, who is from the Berti tribe. The rising tensions eventually led to an armed clash in the Mellit area of North Darfur in which six people died. In response to this outbreak of violence, Mohamed Osman Ibrahim, the Mellit commissioner quickly ordered the police and army forces to end the fighting.  In addition, UNAMID, together with Meidob tribal leaders, conducted a mediation effort in Mellit on 21 August 2012. This led to signing of a ceasefire agreement.

Several cattle raids and a conflict over grazing areas triggered renewed conflict in the Mellit area in March 2015. This time, the Berti accused former Janjaweed leader Musa Hilal of supporting the Al-Zayadia and to instigate the armed conflict. Hilal and Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir were political rivals. The use of heavy weapons in these clashes led to the death of 127 tribe members in 2015. The Zayadia, allegedly associated with paramilitary Border Guards and Central Reserve Police troops, continuously attacked the Berti in Mellit. UNAMID support traditional authorities in their peacemaking efforts. UNAMID was involved in seven meetings in March with key stakeholders both in Northern Darfur and Khartoum as part of efforts to reach a peaceful resolution of the conflict. The conflict parties subsequently signed a ceasefire on 24 March 2015, as well as agreed on forming a commission to investigate the recent clashes.

However, fighting resumed again already the next day. UNAMID was heavily involved in peacemaking throughout July 2015, engaging with community leaders, local authorities, influential tribal figures in Khartoum, the native administrations in Khartoum, and the Darfur Regional Authority. UNAMID also supported the Sudanese government’s mediation effort, which led to the conclusion of another ceasefire agreement on 13 July 2015, but fighting continued.

The Amothnhom Dinka and Panyon Dinka are two subgroups of the Agar Dinka. The groups regularly engage low-intensity clashes over access to land for their cattle, but clashes in 2012 and 2013 had a higher intensity. Following armed clashes in a cattle camp 34 kilometers north-east of Rumbek in November 2012, the Minister of Local Government and Law Enforcement visited the area with Rumbek Central Commissioner Abraham Mayen Kuc to gather information and to mediate between the conflict parties near the cattle camp. The government of Lakes State’s also responded through deploying heavily armed police and military patrols to the area in and around the Luak-Makuer Gol cattle camp.

No longer able to control the Seleka fighters or violence in the Central African Republic in general, Michel Djotodia stepped down on 10 January 2014.  This trigged even greater reprisal killings of Muslims conducted by Christians. The French military – which had begun an intervention in in the Central African Republic in late 2013, dubbed Operation Sangaris – mediated between the Christian and Muslim communities in the PK5 and Bimbo 3 neighbourhoods in Bangui on 11 and 12 January 2014, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.

Intense communal violence between Christians and Muslims also took place in Boda, located 200 kilometer west of Bangui, after the ex-Seleka withdrew from this town when President Michel Djotodia resigned in early January 2014. Bilateral negotiations between Muslim and Chrisitian leaders in Boda led to the conclusion of an agreement to end hostilities on 16 March 2014.

The Government of the Central African Republic facilitated a peace meeting aimed at reconciliation between Muslims and Christians in the PK5 neighborhood in Bangui in early April 2014, but this did not lead to an agreement.
Another peace meeting mediated by the government, this time with support from the UN, led to the singing of an agreement in PK5 on 17 May 2014.

The government of the Central African Republic, with the support from MINUSCA and various other partners working in the realm of social cohesion and development, mediated between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 between June and September 2015. As part of these negotiations, the UN developed a plan for a labor-intensive project, refereed toi as travail à haute intensité de main d’oeuvre, in which members from both communities could participate to help reopen the cemetery. In August 2015, 200 youths, 100 from the Christian and 100 from the Muslim community, were mobilized and started working together to weed the grounds of the cemetery. Negotiations culminated into a planned signing ceremony of a non-aggression pact on 17 September 2015, but the conflict parties refused to sign last minute. Violence between the PK5 and Bimbo 3 communties resumed  and Muslims were once again prevented from accessing the cemetery.
Negotiations mediated by MINUSCA between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of the Batangafo Weapon Free Zone agreement on 12 December 2015.

On 6 January 2016, negotiations between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 in Bangui resumed. These negotiations, which were mediated by government officials with support from MINUSCA, resulted in the signing of the Pacte de non-agression et de réconciliation intercommunautaire (English: the Non-Aggression and Community Reconciliation Pact) by the two communities on 11 February 2016. Signatories included the religious leaders, women, youth, civil society representatives, the mayors of the two localities, but also representatives of the anti-Balaka forces. The pact guaranteed the Muslims free access to their burial grounds, as well as stipulated an end to the use of armed violence and igniting intercommunity tensions. In addition, the agreement stipulated that the PK5 community would not carry weapons when accompanying funeral processions, while the community of Boeing would guarantee the security of the processions.
agreement_name: Pacte de non-agression et de réconciliation intercommunautaire

description: Negotiations between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 29 March 2016. These negotiations were mediated by deputy prefect, Ngozila Deo-Bafounga, with support from MINUSCA. The agreement committed both sides to allow for the free movement of people.

The Berberati field office of MINUSCA supported community-led initiatives in Carnot to help displaced Muslims return. On 8 May 2017, MINUSCA organized a workshop to resolve disputes between Christian occupants who resided in the houses of Muslim returnees.

In June 2017, MINUSCA mediated between the internally displaced Muslim community living in Kaga Bandoro and the Christian community of Ndenga. In addition, MINUSCA involved anti-Balaka representatives in the talks. MINUSCA’s mediation effort took place in the context of a high level of tensions between the Muslims and Christian communities in this area in the wake of an ex-Seleka attack on an internally displaced people camp in Kaga Bandoro on 12 October 2016, which resulted in at least 37 deaths. The mediation effort was successful and led to the signing of a a non-agression pact on 10 June 2017: the Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de ndenga et les deplaces de ndenga vivant a kaga bandoro.
agreement_name: Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de ndenga et les deplaces de ndenga vivant a kaga bandoro

description: Intercommunity dialogue aimed at promoting social cohesion and reconciliation between Christians and Muslims took place in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture in February 2018. This peace effort was led by religious and community leaders and the deputy-mayor of Zemio, but was also supported by the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section in Obo. The peace effort led to the signing of the Pacte de non-agression et de réconciliation entre les communautés in February 2018. This agreement stipulated the non-violent resolution of disputes, freedom of movement, prohibition of carrying weapons, and a commitment to counter false rumors and misinformation. The agreement was successful in mitigating violence between the two communities in spite of clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area.
third_party: religious leaders; community leaders; local government; MINUSCA
agreement_name: Pacte de non-agression et de réconciliation entre les communautés

description: A joint mediation of Cardinal Dieudonné Nzapalainga and Imam Omar Kobine Layam, with support from MINUSCA, led to the signing of the Bangassou Peace Agreement on 9 April 2018. MINUSCA supported the mediation effort. This agreement stipulates an end to violence, the freedom of movement for humanitarians and the general population, opening of the humanitarian corridor, and dismantlement of checkpoints in Bangassou and on the axes. A local peace council subsequently worked to implement the agreement.

On 4 and 5 June 2018, Cardinal Dieudonné Nzapalainga and Imam Omar Kobine Layama facilitated another round of dialogue to discuss the implementation of the Bangassou Peace Agreement that had been concluded in April 2018.

In October 2018, the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section convened a workshop between Christian and Muslim communities in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture to follow up on the Pacte de non-agression et de réconciliation entre les communautés which had been concluded in February 2018. The agreement of February 2018 had held, but tensions between the communities were increasing again as a result of fighting between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area. The workshop convened by Civil Affairs led to the signing of another agreement on 27 October 2018. This follow-up agreement confirmed the previous agreement and explicitly stated that the communities are committed to the agreement in spite of armed clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC.

Another peace process involving Muslim and Christian communities also started in October 2018. On 18 October 2018, MINUSCA facilitated an exchange of letters between the two Mayors of Pombolo and Gambo. These letters were in response to at least five large-scale clashes between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo towns since August 2017. These letters requested the start of a reconciliation process and suggested the organization of a round table discussion. Following this initial exchange of letters between the two mayors MINUSCA helped to create a peace committee in Gambo and another one in Pombolo, each consisting of 12 members. On 6 November 2018, MINUSCA and the Prefect of Mbomou facilitated an initial peace meeting between the two mayors in Pombolo. During this meeting the mayors agreed to move forward with the Peace Process and mandated the peace committees to find a solution to the conflict.
A first meeting, mediated by diated by the sub-prefect and with support from MINUSCA, was held on 9 December 2018.

Another meeting was held on 23 December 2018. This meeting was also mediated by the sub-prefect, with support from MINUSCA. The peace committees from the two communities confirmed their commitment to a peaceful resolution of the conflict, as well as agreed on a joint plan for direct dialogue.

Peace talks between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo mediated by sub-prefect, with support from MINUSCA, continued in 2019. A peace and reconciliation agreement was signed on 20 March 2019.
On 13 June 2019, the agreement was extended to the village of Ngandou, which means the agreement covers the entire sub-prefecture.

A 10-man commission – referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission – led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate armed fighting in Jos in September 2001. This commission subsequently mediated between the Afisare, Anagura, Birom, Hausa, and Fulani at a peace conference in early September 2001. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign a peace agreement.
In an attempt to find a solution to the crisis, the state government organized another round of peace talks on 12 September 2001. However, this meeting also ended in an impasse.

The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement. Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002.
Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002.

In May 2004, Chris Alli was selected to be Interim Administrator by President Obasanjo. He organized multiple efforts to resolve the ongoing conflicts between Christians and Muslims, which included the conflict between Afisare, Anaguta, Birom and Fulani, and Hausa. During the state of emergency, Chris Alli launched a six-month Plateau Peace Program to bring lasting peace to the area. The plan included meetings between religious, ethnic and community leaders and the government. On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau – including Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba – signed a peace agreement in Jos. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

Part of Alli’s Program was also a month-long peace conference that was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was mediated by a twelve-member steering committee and brought together government officials and traditional leaders to find compromises to bring peace to Plateau State. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State (e.g., Afisare, Anaguta and Birom) were allowed to send two representatives each while “settlers” (i.e., Fulani and Hausa) were allowed only one representative each. It culminated in a report containing a number of resolutions. These included the resolution stating that “the Birom, Anaguta and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos.” However, the Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it.

European Union special envoy Bernardino Leon collaborated with the United States assistance secretary of state William Burns and defense secretary Chuck Hagel mediated during the protests. The government instituted a curfew to curb the violence in August 2013.

A year after Morsi’s election, protests against him were organized. Some of these protests turned violent as supporters and opponents of Morsi met. On 3 July 2013, Morsi was removed from office by the Egyptian military. This removal from power was condemned by the Muslim Brotherhood as a coup d’etat. The opponents and supporters of the ousted President continued to clash throughout these political changes. No direct negotiations between opponents of Morsi and Supporters of Morsi took place. Yet, the Muslim Brotherhood negotiated with the Egyptian army to reinstate Morsi in July 2013. Foreign Minister Khalid Al Attiyah from Qatar mediated between various players, including the Muslim Brotherhood and the Egyptian army in late July 2013.
Al-Azhar University mediated between the Muslim Brotherhood and the Egyptian army in early August 2013.

The UCDP does not record any conflict in 2015. The conflict parties did not clash in 2013, but armed fighting resumed again in August 2014. One year later, on 9 August 2015, the two sides attended a peace meeting in Aynabo.
Another round of negotiations was held in Addis Ababa on 1 November 2015.

As a result of the Khatumo administration becoming disillusioned with ongoing talks with the Government of Somalia about the status of the Khatumo administration, its leaders started to engage with the Republic of Somaliland again. A peace conference attended by elders from both the Khatumo administration and the Republic of Somaliland was held in Aynaba on 8 August 2016.
On 17 November 2016, representatives from both sides met in Addis Ababa. Ethiopian Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn acted as the mediator at this round of negotiations.

Another round of negotiations started in mid-December 2016, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 23 December 2016. This agreement stipulated that the contested territory would be governed under shared institutions.

On 7 February 2017, Ali Khalif Galaydh, the leader of one of the two contesting administrations in Khatumo, came to Djibouti in order to meet with Somaliland representatives to discuss solutions to the conflict between the Khatumo administration and the Republic of Somaliland.

On 17 June 2017, representatives of the Khatumo administration and Somaliland signed a five-clause agreement that stipulated, among others, devolution and a quota system for political representation. However, the traditional leadership in Khatumo vocalized opposition to this agreement
A follow-up agreement was signed in Hargeisa on 28 August 2017.

A peace conference in Ainaba between 20 and 22  October 2017 led to the signing of the Ainaba Agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also altered Somaliland’s constitution and stipulated the integration of the Khatumo administration’s army into that of Somaliland.

Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Eyie, Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e. the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.

Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Green Circuit (Maphites), Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e. the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.

Both the Eiye and the Black Axe took part in the Ikorodu peace initiative in June 2017. Both sides promised to end fighting and stop all forms of criminality. In return, the Governor of Lagos State, Akinwunmi Ambode, granted them amnesty. Abdulazeez Sholebo was there to represent the Eyie brotherhood, while Seyi Ajasa led the Black Axe group.
Negotiations between the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in 2009.

Large-scale fighting erupted again in April 2017, when tribesmen from the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara clashed over 150 stolen cows in En Nadeef area. The conflict between the two tribes escalated further in Buram locality between 8 and 10 May, resulting in more than 100 people killed or injured. Sudanese government forces separated the two tribes following these clashes. The two communities agreed a ceasefire at a peace meeting on 12 May 2017. A state-level mediation committee, as well as the Governor of South Darfur, community leaders, and UNAMID, mediated this meeting.
third_party: government; local government; community leaders; UNAMID

description: The same third parties mediated a peace agreement on 29 May 2017.
third_party: government; local government; community leaders; UNAMID

description: In addition, the leaders of both tribes engaged in negotiations, with mediation by the same third parties, on 30 October 2017. This led to the signing of a peaceful coexistence agreement.
third_party: government; local government; community leaders; UNAMID

description: The armed clashes between the Luac Jang Dinka in Warrap State and the Bul Nuer in Unity State were a consequence of conflict over cattle, as well as access to water and grazing land. The armed clashes have taken place in the context of armed fighting between the Dinka and the Nuer. In response to clashes in January 2012, the deputy governor went to the conflict area to mediate.

side_a: AQIM, Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, MUJAO
description: Armed fighting between the Mouvement pour le Tawhîd et du Jihad en Afrique de l’Ouest (MUJAO) (English: Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa) and the Coordination des Mouvements de l’Azawad (CMA) (English: Coordination of Azawad Movements), originally the Mouvement national de libération de l’Azawad (MNLA) (English: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad), started in late June 2012. While the MUJAO was the most aggressive in attacking the CMA, the MUJAO was supported by several other Jihadist groups fighting the Government of Mali, including al-Qaida al-Jihad fi Bilad al-Maghrib al-Islami (AQIM) (English: al-Qaida Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb); Jama’atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda’awati wal-Jihad, also known as Boko Haram; and the Signed-in-Blood Battalion. One major source of contention between the CMA and the Jihadist groups was the CMA’s goal of self-determination for northern Mali, while the Jihadist alliance of MUJAO, AQIM, Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, and the Signed-in-Blood Battalion wanted to take control of the whole of Mali and impose Sharia law. On 28 June 2012, Iyad Ag Ghali, the leader of Ansar Dine, reportedly arrived in Gao at the head of a convoy of more than 60 vehicles to meet with the leaders of the various rebel groups operating in Gao to put an end to tensions between the different groups.

side_a: AQIM, Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, MUJAO
description: On 30 June 2012, Iyad Ag Ghaly met with some of the CMA leadership, including Colonels Mechkenani, Ntala, and Salat, to discuss the conclusion of a ceasefire between the CMA on the one hand and MUJAO, AQIM, Signed-in-Blood Battalion, and Jama’atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda’awati wal-Jihad on the other hand. The CMA agreed in principle to a ceasefire but the Jihadist groups in the end refrained from delivering a written pledge to formally endorse a ceasefire.

side_a: AQIM, Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, MUJAO
description: Negotiations between MUJAO and CMA led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 November 2012.

Violence between the conflict parties resumed in 2017 with the Dan Nan Ambassagou armed group, belonging to the Dogon tribe, taking up arms in 2017, allegedly to defend itself against the Fulani community. The Fulani were perceived by the Dogon community as an accomplice of external, Jihadist armed groups who had also targeted the Dogon. In April 2017, the government established the Mission to Support National Reconciliation, which travelled to the Dogon areas and some areas of the Central Delta to meet with the Dogon and Fulani communities for dialogue.
