From 7 to 9 September 2017, 140 community representatives – including village chiefs and religious leaders – from Bambara, Fulani and Dogon communities from the regions of Mopti and Ségou came together in the city of Ségou in order to promote reconciliation between communities in Central Mali. This peace initiative was complemented with several peace meetings between the different tribal communities organized at lower levels in the regions.

Heavy armed fighting broke out again in January 2018. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue began a peace effort in early February 2018, involving continuous talks with the political bureau, the military staff, and the local representatives of Dan Nan Ambassagou.
The Malian Minister of National Reconciliation and Social Cohesion mediated between the leaders of the Dogon and Fulani of the Mopti region in Bamako on 16 March 2018.
On 24 March 2018, there was also a meeting between Dogon and Fulani in Koro, which was mediated by a delegation of the Ministry of National Reconciliation and Social Cohesion.
On 6 and 7 June 2018, MINUSMA provided logistical support for a mediation effort by a government delegation in Mopti. This led to a local ceasefire.

On 28 August 2018, following a mediation effort conducted by HD involving 34 Dogon and Fulani village chiefs from the Koro district  that had begun in early June 2018, the conflict parties signed an intercommunal peace agreement to end violence in the Mopti region. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, as well as stressed that all communities should have peaceful access to natural resources and calls for the use of traditional mediation mechanisms to prevent and manage disputes over land access. In order to link this agreement to the national-level peace process, HD tried to work together with the monitoring committee set up following the Bamako Agreement concluded in June 2015 – the Comité du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) – to oversee the implementation of the peace agreement concluded between the Dogon and the Fulani, as well as the Bamako Agreement. However, the Bamako Agreement was rejected by the Dan Nan Ambassagou, which claimed that it had not been involved in the process. On 16 September, the militia group would agree to a unilateral ceasefire referred to as “Commitment to a unilateral ceasefire from Youssouf TOLOBA and his armed group, Dan Nan Ambassagou” in Mopti. The Fulani cultural association Tabital Pulaaku had denounced the Bamako Agreement because its leaders wanted to see Dana Nan Amassagou’s military leader, Youssouf Toloba, tried at the International Criminal Court (ICC). The HD effort to link the peace process between the Dogon and the Fulani to the national-level peace process failed.

In July 2018, MINUSMA started a reconciliation project in three villages in the Koro district of the Mopti region. The project was aimed at preventing further conflicts between the Dogon and Fulani communities.

A peacemaking effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), mandated by the Government of Mali, led to the issuing of a unilateral ceasefire in Mopti on 2 July 2018 by a Dogon militia, called the Dan Nan Ambassagou.  As part of this unilateral ceasefire, the Dan Nan Ambassagou armed group also mandated HD to mediate the conflict between them and the Fulani community armed groups actors in the areas of Koro, Bankass, Douentza, and Bandiagara in central Mali.

On 2 October 2018, the Malian Prime Minister chaired inter-community talks between the Dan Nan Ambassagou committed and Fulani representatives. This led to the conclusion of another ceasefire. However, the Dan Nan Ambassagou leaders denounced this ceasefire in November 2018, arguing that they needed to take up arms again to protect Dogon tribe members after several were Dogon were killed by Malian armed forces.

The Ogossagou massacre of Fulani herders on 23 March 2019 sent shockwaves throughout the region and led to the resignation of the prime minister and his government. In response, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) began to mediate peace talks between the Bozo, Dafi, Dogon, Fulani and Samoko in June 2019. This led to the signing of  a peace agreement in Baye on 25 July 2019.

Local leaders and MINUSMA Civil Affairs mediated between the Fulani and Dogon in the the Bambara community in Macina, San, and Niono cerces in the Segou region and the Djenné and Tenenkou cercles in the Mopti region. This led to the signing of peace agreement on 3 August 2019.

On 16 August 2019, MINUSMA Civil Affairs supported the deputy mayor of Ouenkoro, Housseyni Sankaré, in mediating a peace agreement  between the Dafing, Fulani and Dogon communities living in his commune. The agreement aimed to ensure the free movement of people and goods by putting an end to targeted attacks and ensuring the return of lost herds to the authorities.

The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue's peace efforts from earlier in 2019 had led to the signing of another peace agreement by the Dafing, Dogon and Fulani. This agreement was signed in Ouenkoro on 16 August.

Following a visit by the Malian Prime Minister, Dr. Boubou Cissé, in early July 2019, local authorities initiated a mediation effort between Fulani and Dogon communities living in Sokoura and Tori in the Bankass cercle of the Mopti region. This mediation effort resulted in a round of peace talks in the chef-lieu of Sokoura communeon 18 September 2019. This round of negotiations was mediated by the Prefect of Bankass, with support from MINUSMA Civil Affairs. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.
MINUSMA and the Mayor of Youdiou mediated between between Dafing, Dogon, Fulani and Mossi communities  on 24 November 2019. This led to a local peace agreement.
Hamisa Zaja and Sheikh Idriss, together with other religious leaders, mediated between the Orma and Pokomo communities in July 2012. Fighting flared up again in August.
On 23 August 2012, the Orma and Pokomo convened for a round of negotations mediated by Kenyan police officers. This round of talks did not lead to a peace agreement.

After another bout of violence in September 2012, the Kenyan government sent 1,000 soldiers to stabilize the Tana River District and tried to organize another round of peace talks. However, neither community wished to participate in this mediation effort, preferring instead to engage in bilateral negotiations. In mid-September 2012, tribal elders from the Mijikenda signaled their intention to mediate between the Orma and Pokomo, but this did not lead to peace talks. On 4 October 2012, 40 elders from the Orma, Pokomo, and Wardei attended a three-day peace conference in Malindi. Several different third parties acted as mediators during the conference, including the Consortium for the Empowerment and Development of Marginalised Communities, the National Commission and Integration Commission (NCIC), National Muslim Leadership Forum, and the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya. Although no peace agreement was concluded during this round of talks, the conflict parties agreed that peace was a priority.
On 23 April 1999, the three tribes reached a peace agreement in Bukavu that outlined new access to markets and herding land.

The Forces of Agala and the Forces of Edu are two armed youth militia groups that began to clash in 2005. The conflict between the two groups started when S. K. Agala was elected youth president for the Rumuekpe Youth Council, while his predecessor Friday Edu refused to give up his position, allegedly because he would then no longer benefit from paymnets made by oil companies in the oil-rich Niger Delta region. Friday Edy said that he had an “exclusive arrangement” with Royal Dutch Shell. The faith-based NGO Hope for the Hopeless Global Initiatives mediated between the feuding youth groups and convinced them to lay down their arms and sign a peace agreement in late June 2005.

In January 2001, Governor of Bayelsa State Chief D.S.P. Alamieyeseigha and the Deputy-governor Lionel Jonathan set up the Nembe Peace and Reconciliation Committee. The committee consisted of twelve members, including representatives from the Nembe community, security agencies, the local government council, the Ijaw National Congress, and the Ijaw Youth Council. This committee aimed to promote reconciliation among the youth groups in the area and implement a new community constitution in Nembe State. Peace talks during a first meeting of the  Nembe Peace and Reconciliation Committee resulted in the lifting of the ban on the Isongo-furo people returning to Ogbolomabiri.

The committee subsequently met separately (in January 2001) with numerous local chiefs – including Chief Adukpo Egi Adukpo, Chief Egi Ikata, Chief Edmund Daukuro, Chief T.E.Beregha, Chief D.C.Ikoli Berana, Chief Lionel Jonathan Omo, and Chief N.B.P.Amange – before organizing a meeting with the two youth groups.

Direct negotiations between the conflict parties (in January 2001) resulted in a three-point agreement, stipulating among others the establishment of a joint commission and mutual respect. Finally, the two leaders delivered a speech to the Nembe people at the town hall and ensured that they were committed to reconciliation and peace.

The tribes began fighting in June 2012 after a Zintan community member was allegedly killed by a Mashashia militia. The Gontrar and Zintani tribes aligned in the conflict against the Mashashia. Underlying the triggering incident were accusations towards the Mashashai tribe of loyalty towards Colonel Muammar al-Gadaffi, who the Zintan tribe helped overthrow. In response to the fighting, the National Transitional Council (NTC) formed a committee to resolve the fighting. Progress was made towards conflict resolution on 19 June 2012 when the “Committee of Libya Wisemen” met with leaders from the Zintan and Mashashia tribes, who subsequently signed a three-day ceasefire agreement.

On 18 May 2017, the Zintan and the Mashashia participated in a peace meeting that led to the signing of a reconciliation agreement regarding skirmishes in al-‘Awiniyya, Zawiyya al-Baqul, and ‘Umur. A reconciliation council of various local tribes such as the Warfallah Tribe and al-Zuwayyah acted as the mediators during this peace meeting.

The leaders of the Greenlanders and the NDV – along with the leaders five other cult groups in Okrika, including the Bush Boys, the Niger Delta Solidarity Front, the Outlaws, the Klansmen, and the Black Axe – participated in peace talks mediated by the Kirike Bese Peace and Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide in July 2007. Clara Ngelemabiri led the mediation team. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement in Okrika aimed at restoring calm in the Niger Delta on 14 July 2007. All groups pledged to end the hostilities. The full name of this agreement is the Wakirike Peace Declaration 2007 between all the warring factions involved in Okrika crisis and mediated by the Kirikie-Be-Se Peace Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide.

In July 2016, the conflict parties, along several other cult groups, participated in negotiations mediated by the Special Adviser to the Governor on Amnesty Programme Ken Chinda, the Special Adviser on Revenue Matters Harvey Ideozu, and members of the peace security and reconciliation committee in Ahoada. This led to a peace agreement aimed at ending violence in the Ahoada East Local Government Area in Rivers State on 25 July 2016.

Tensions between the Alago and Eggon communities increased when the Alago’s traditional leaders demanded long overdue taxes in return for the use of their land by Eggon farmers to be paid. Eggon farmers saw this demand as an act of provocation. The dispute escalated in armed clashes in 2012. In June 2012, in an attempt to calm the violence, Governor Tanko Almakura mediated between the conflict parties in order to encourage them to stop the killings and resolve their differences peacefully. However, the conflict resumed in November 2012.

Negotiations involving the Eggon and Alago, but also some other tribe representatives of Nasarawa State as for example the Tiv,  led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Tudun Ababu in the Obi Local Government Area on 2 May 2014.

On 8 October 2017, the NGO Search for Common Ground mediated a peace meeting between representatives of several ethnic groups – including the Fulani, Tiv, Alago, Eggon, Mada, and Migili – in the Doma Local Government Area in Nasarawa State. The mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

side_a: Black Axe, Bush Boys, Deebam, KK, PVF
description: The Black Axe, Bush Boys, Deebam, Klansmen Konfraternity (KK), and the Niger Delta Vigilantes (NDV) fought a non-state armed conflict against he Outlaws in the Niger Delta region. The Outlaws is a cult group that broke away from the NDV after a power struggle between the NDV leader Ateke Tom and his second-in-command Soboma George in 2005. Having established the Outlaws, George was employed by the PDP to help rig the 2007 elections in Rivers State. Soboma George subequnetly emerged from the 2007 Rivers State election as the most powerful and politically connected gang leader in the state, with close ties to Governor Celestine Omehia. No longer enjoying the government benefits they were used to, Ateke’s NDV and other cult groups began to attack the Outlaws. This fighting escalated into a violent crisis in the Port Harcour area. On 12 August 2007, the federal Government sent a Joint Task Force (JTF) to resore peace in the area. This brought relative calm as feuding gangs left the city or went in hiding. The leaders of the  NDV, the Greenlanders, Bush Boys, the Niger Delta Solidarity Front, the Outlaws, the KK, and the Black Axe – subsequently participated in peace talks mediated by the Kirike Bese Peace and Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide in July 2007. Clara Ngelemabiri led the mediation team. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement in Okrika aimed at restoring calm in the Niger Delta on 14 July 2007. All groups pledged to end the hostilities. The full name of this agreement is the Wakirike Peace Declaration 2007 between all the warring factions involved in Okrika crisis and mediated by the Kirikie-Be-Se Peace Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide.
The conflict parties held a peace meeting on 15 May 2001, which led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. UN Special Representative Oluyemi Adeniji acted as a mediator during this peace meeting.

The Atuot Dinka are mainly pastoralists, while the Jur Beli are mainly agriculturalists. In 2011, the Atout Dinka community in the Lakes State clashed with the Jur Beli community in Western Equatoria in February 2011 over access to grazing land. The governor of Lakes state and West county commissioner visited the area to mediate in March 2011.

On 5 April 2011, the governors of Lakes and Western Equatoria organized a meeting in Mopourdit to discuss ways to resolve the armed conflict. However, fighting between the communities continued during this meeting.

The Gony and Thiyic section of the Agar Dinka only used to engage in low-intensity clashes in the context of cattle raiding, but armed fighting escalated in April 2011. Various local politicians allegedly instrumentalized the conflict in order to empower themselves. Traditional leaders and local governors mediated between the conflict parties in October 2011.

Many of the Misseriya living in Kordofan in Sudan travel southward to the Abyei region in the dry season in order to find water for their cattle. This often leads to tensions between the Misseriya and the pastoralist Ngok Dinka in Abyei. The Misseriya claim an historic right to migrate through areas inhabited by the Ngok Dinka, but the latter have established certain requirements for such passage, including the demand that the Misseriya relinquish their cache of weapons before entering Abyei. The Misseriya generally refuse this demand, because they want protect themselves against cattle theft. Furthermore, while the Sudanese government supports the Misseriya, the leadership of the SPLM/A and later the South Sudanese government have supported the Ngok Dinka. The UCDP records the first armed clashes between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka in 2011, but several efforts to put conflict resolution mechanisms in place have taken place before that. The Sudanese government facilitated a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka in Nyala on 13 September 1999.

The SPLM/A facilitated a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka in Malwal Agak on 12 April 2000, which led to the conclusion of an agreement that stipulates the right of carrying weapons, access to pasture, commerce, payment of tax, protection of citizens and property, and the establishment of a committee to resolve violations of the agreement peacefully.
Another meeting convened by the SPLM/A was held in Wanjok in May 2000.

A Dutch government delegation and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) organized a nine-day conference in Abu Nafisa in April 2001. This resulted in the conclusion of an agreement stipulating access to pasture, commerce, ending of rape, an end to the burning of villages by Misseriya, a committee to monitor peace, and an agreement on IDP resettlement.

A follow-up meeting was organized by the Dutch government and the UNDP, this time with the involvement of the Sudanese government, in Muglad in October 2001. This meeting led to the conclusion of the Abyei Peace Agreement, which condemned the conflict between the tribes, affirmed the co-existence of Dinka and Misseriya and the rights of each over water and pasture, supported the return and resettlement of the Dinka communities in Abyei Province. A joint committee was established to review the achievements of the peace process, and to deal with violations of the agreement.

The UNDP and the Sudanese government convened a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka, as well as the Twic Dinka, in Abyei in January 2002. This led to the signing of a peace agreement by 11 tribal leaders, who agreed to live together in peace, restore good relations that they inherited from their ancestors, cooperate in the rehabilitation and development of the region, stop hostilities, and reinstate justice.

In February 2003, the UNDP and USAID organized a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka, as well as the Twic Dinka, in Kiir River. The leaders from all sides recommitted themselves to achieve and maintain peace in Abyei.
The Dinka and Misseriya also signed a peace agreement in Aweil in 2008.

Finally, a resolution was adopted at the Bentiu Peace Conference Resolutions on 2 November 2010, referred to as the Decision and Recommendation of Peaceful Co-existence in Unity State. The resolution addresses issues between Misseriya and Dinka Ngok in Unity State, including the opening of roads, police escorts of tribes, restrictions on firearms of the cattle herder, and co-operation between tribes in regards to crime.
agreement_name: Decision and Recommendation of Peaceful Co-existence in Unity State

description: The violence between the conflict parties around this time was triggered by a referendum on whether Abyei would join the north or south and that was supposed to be held on 9 January 2011, but which was postponed due to a dispute over whether the Misseriyya – who enter Abyei for a few months each year to graze cattle – should be given the right to vote. This also gave the conflict an international dimension, as Sudan’s ruling National Congress Party (NCP) demanded the Misseriyya to be allowed to vote, while the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement which governs the south says that only the Dinka Ngok have the right to participate in the referendum. In response to the outbreak of violence, a reconciliation conference was held in Kadugli on 13 January 2011. The Deputy Governor of Southern Kordofan mediated between the leaders of the Misseriyya and Ngok Dinka, with support from the Governor’s Adviser for the Western Sector and the Deputy Governor of Abyei Administration, the State Security Committee, and the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The conflict parties signed the Kadugli Conference Agreement at the end of the conference. This agreement calls for an end to the violence, but also calls for the establishment of security and awareness along the migration paths used by Misseriya herdsmen. The agreement also stresses the importance of the payment of blood money according to local custom.

Furthermore, the Federal Minister of Interior and the Minister of Interior of the Republic of Southern Sudan discussed the armed conflict between the Misseriya and Dinka Ngok in Abyei. UNMIS was also involved in these talks. The talks ended with the signing of the Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei on 17 January 2011. This agreement stipulates the facilitation of the voluntary return of displaced people through protection by Joint Integrated Units of the north-south Sudan law enforcement and UNMIS. The agreement also stipulates the opening of corridors for cattle and includes provisions on the regulation of arms carried by Misseriya herdsmen. Heavy fighting resumed in March 2011. Haile Menkerios, the special representative for the UN secretary-general condemned the fighting, stating it was a clear violation of the letter and spirit of the peace agreement signed between the two sides in January.
agreement_name: Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei

description: A round of negotiations mediated by the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC), with support from the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA), led to the conclusion of a preliminary agreement between the Ngok Dinka and the Misseriyya on 10 August 2012: the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC) Pact on Core Principles for Peaceful Coexistence. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, as well as stressed the importance of implementing “norms and practices of tolerance” agreed upon.
agreement_name: Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC) Pact on Core Principles for Peaceful Coexistence

description: Misseriyya and Ngok Dinka representatives attended a four-day peace conference in Aweil, in Northern Bahr el Ghazal state in South Sudan, in mid-April 2015. The conference was facilitated by Concordis International and the Catholic church.

In addition, UNISFA arranged the first of a series of meetings between Misseriya and Ngok Dinka tribes in Makir and Youra villages on 15 and 16 April in an effort to restore channels of communication between the two tribes at the grass-roots level.
UNISFA facilitated joint peace committee meetings between the Ngok Dinka and Misseriya at Todach in the central sector on 21 and 28 July.

UNISFA also facilitated an intercommunity traditional leaders’ meeting at Todach on 4 August, which resulted in an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and peaceful coexistence, payment of compensation for past cases of criminality, and measures to end the insecurity surrounding the common market at Amiet by establishing a joint traditional court.

On 10 August, UNISFA facilitated a follow-up meeting of the joint peace committee at Amiet to work out the modalities, resulting in a written agreement to formally reopen the common market there on 15 August.
In late October 2016, the Ngok Dinka and the Misseriyya attended a two-day peace conference mediated by traditional leaders in Amith village in Abyei.
On 2 November 2016, a peace conference ended with no approved peace resolutions.

With intercommunal tensions running high and an armed clash  on 22 July, UNISFA convened separate meetings with Misseriya community leaders in Diffra and with Ngok Dinka community leaders in Dokura on 26 July. Through those meetings, UNISFA was able to broker an agreement between leaders from the two communities when they met in Dokura on 27 July. This agreement stipulates a cessation of hostilities and commits the parties to resolve existing problems by using traditional mechanisms.

However, on the day of this agreement, on 27 July 2017, some Ngok Dinka people stole 141 cows of the Misseriyya and killed three herders. UNISFA subsequently mediated negotiations between the Ngok Dinka and the Misseriyya representatives of the joint peace committee on 30 July, which led to an agreement that stipulated that the Ngok Dinka return the cows and paid blood money for the three casualties.

On 14 November 2017, the traditional chiefs of the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka communities met in Addis Ababa. The meeting had been called for during an Abyei Joint Oversight Committee meeting held in March 2015. UNISFA facilitated the travel of the Ngok Dinka traditional chiefs from Abyei to Juba to attend the meeting. The traditional leaders signed an agreement on the establishment of a fund to compensate victims of attacks and cattle rustling. They further underscored the need for joint access to the revenues of oil revenues from Abyei Area, in line with the Abyei Protocol to the Comprehensive Peace Agreement of 2005. The leaders also expressed their full support for maintaining the common market in Amiet.

UNISFA supported a pre-migration conference in Abyei in early March 2018. The conference was attended by more than 150 people from both the Ngok Dinka and Misseriyya communities. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement on 5 March 2018, stipulating a ceasefire and peaceful coexistence of both groups. This agreement reportedly resulted in a decrease in violence and the annual migration of the nomadic Misseriya through Abyei proceeded mostly peacefully.

Following armed clashes between Tiv and Fulani in the Gwer West Local Government Area in Benue State, special adviser to the governor Titus Madugu mediated between the representatives of the Tiv and Fulani tribes on 16 February 2011. The two groups accepted to lay down their arms and find a way out of the crisis, but did not conclude a written agreement. The Benue State Government also established a peace committee in February 2011 tasked with examining the causes of the clash between the Fulani and Tiv and outlining a way out of the crisis. On 1 July 2011, the Benue and Nasarawa State governments set up together a further peace committee that had the task to find the cause of the conflict that happened at the border between the two states and achieve peace between the two groups.

At the beginning of February 2012, following renewed fighting at the Nasarawa/Benue border, Al-Makura, the Governor of Nasarawa State, facilitated a meeting between rival groups in the area, including Fulani and Tiv, in an attempt to restore peace.

On 18 March 2012, the Madakin Lafia, under the orders of the Emir of Lafia Alhaji Mustapha Agwai I summoned the leaders of Tiv and the Fulani – Barrister Gabriel Akaaka and Senator Jibrin respectively – to a peace meeting in Lafia. This meeting resulted in the signing of a peace agreement.

On 31 March 2014, Tiv and Agatu leaders signed a peace treaty with the leadership of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association, representing Fulani herdsmen, promising to end the violence in the region. This agreement was mediated by the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo.

Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

Representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes of Bali Local Government Area signed another peace agreement during a peace meeting on 29 April 2014. However, the hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014 in that area.

On 30 April 2014, Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders in Wukari Local Government Area held a peace meeting in response to armed clashes in Wukari on 15 April 2014. Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement.

Following armed clashes between Fulani and Tiv in the Guma Local Governement Area (LGA) in Benue State, the state government represented by Mr. Stephan Ugbor mediated between the conflict parties on 30 April 2015. This meeting was aimed at finding lasting solution for peace in the region, but the meeting did not lead to a peace agreement.

In June 2015, following recurrent clashes in the Logo Local Government Area, Chief Terkura Suswam, under the auspices of the state government, mediated between Tiv and Fulani leaders, which resulted in the signing of a peace agreement. Violence nevertheless continued in the region.

The Turan community in the Kwande Local Government Area in Benue State, which was mainly composed of Tiv people, engaged in peace talks with Fulani herders in March 2016. The talks were mediated by an ex-member of House of Representatives, retired Colonel Benjamin Aboho. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement on 13 March 2016 in which both sides committed to a ceasefire and pledged to bring back peace in the area. The Tiv traditional ruler Zaki YAlu Agbo and the representative of the Fulani for the area, Yakubu Abubakar, signed the agreement. Furthermore, a 20-person committee was set up at the end of the meeting to monitor the peace process.

In June 2016, Fulani and Tiv representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

In early July 2016, Chief Terkula Suswam convened a three-week peace meeting between the Tiv and Fulani leaders of the Logo Local Government Area. The peace meeting did not lead to an agreement and armed violence resumed between the two communities in the area.

On 23 September 2017, the Nasarawa State governor Umaru Tanko Al-Makura represented by his Adviser retired Brigadier-General Muhammed Adeka mediated peace talks between Fulani and Tiv representatives in Lafia in Nasarawa State. Alhaji Haruna Usman, representing the Fulani community, and Peter Ahemba, president of the Tiv Development Association, agreed to a ceasefire on behalf of their respective communities during this peace meeting.

On 8 October 2017, the NGO Search for Common Ground mediated a peace meeting between representatives of several ethnic groups – including the Fulani, Tiv, Alago, Eggon, Mada, and Migili – in the Doma Local Government Area in Nasarawa State. The mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

On 16 January 2018, Governor of Ekiti State Ayodele Fayose summoned the Fulani and Tiv leaders to a peace meeting to avoid a spiral of reprisal killings following the murder of a Fulani herder. The Fulani and Tiv leaders agreed to a communiqué in which they called for peace between the two communities in the region.

Tiv and Fulani representatives held another peace meeting in Lafia on 25 April 2018, which led to the signing of a peace agreement between the two tribes. Nevertheless, violence resumed a few days later.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.

The conflict between the Ezilo, sometimes also referred to as Ezillo, and Ezza tribes is rooted in a long history of political control of the Ezillo region in Ebonyi State. The Ezza community came to the Ezillo region in the 1930 to support tthe Ezilo people in an armed conflict with the Egbo tribe. The Ezza people remained in the Ezzillo region ever since, sometimes leading to tension between the Ezza and the Ezilo people who wanted the Ezza community to leave the Ezillo region. Tensions escalated into armed conflict in May 2008. The Ebonyi state government mediated between the conflict parties in early May 2008.

In addition, Senator Julius Ucha mediated between the conflict parties at his home on 12 May 2008. The fourteen Ezilo and Ezza leaders who participated in this peace meeting signed a peace agreement stipulating an immediate cessation of hostilities.

Another meeting between the tribe leaders, mediated by Senator Ucha and other state officials, took place at the council headquarters on 16 May 2008. This meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. A traditional ceremony held at the local government headquarters in Ezillo in late 2008 was supposed to mark the end of the conflict. However, retaliatory attacks quickly resumed. The Governor of Ebonyi State, Martin Elechi, announced his strategy for ending the violence in the region on 2 October 2008, which, among others, entailed a plan to relocate the Ezza people to the lands of Egu Echara.

Governor Martin Elechi and the Police Commissioner Ammanual Dipo Yeni visited the conflict area in February 2010 to mediate between the conflict parties. This led to a ceasefire in late February 2010, after which the tribes began to surrender their arms to the local authorities. However, the ceasefire did not hold.

In April 2015, the Deputy Governor of Ebonyi shuttled between the conflict parties before bringing them together for peace talks. The peace meeting resulted in the issuing of a communiqué guaranteeing that neither party would re-enter the buffer zone that had been set up in between the two communities.

Following a round of negotiations mediated by Ebonyi State governor David Umahi, Ezilo and Ezza leaders signed a peace agreement at the Abakaliki Township Statium on 5 September 2016 in the presence of the minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Chief Audu Ogbeh, the Minister of health Prof. Issac Adewole, and the Deputy Governor Kelechi Igwe.

The Hausa and Sayawa communities engaged in an armed conflict over political power and land ownership in the Tafawa Belawa Local Government Area in Bauchi State. The conflict was triggered by an attempt by the Sayawa people to establish their chieftaincy in the region, which the Hausa and other communities opposed. The religious Hausa and Sayawa leaders in the region entered into peace talks, mediated by Bauchi State Governor Isa Yuguda in January 2011. These talks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

The Borana and Turkana have repeatedly clashed in the context of land disputes and cattle raids. Internal Security Permanent Secretary Francis Kimemia mediated peace talks between the Borana, Turkana, Meru, Samburu, and Somali at Harambee house on 16 and 17 November 2011. The peace talks did not end in the conclusion of a peace agreement.
A peace meeting between the Samburu, Turkana, Borana, and Turkana was held in Marsabit on 24 March 2013. The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated the peace talks.
The Borana, Meru, Samburu, and Turkana from Isiolo County attended a peace meeting in September. 2013
The Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS) mediated peace talks between the Borana, Gabra, and Turkana in December 2013.

The Convention des patriotes pour la justice et la paix (CPJP) (English: Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace) and the Seleka alliance, before December 2012 known as Union des Forces Démocratiques pour le Rassemblement (UFDR) (English: Union of Democratic Forces for Unity), clashed in the town of Bria in September 2011. The conflict parties fought each other over control over diamond mines. The Government of the CAR mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in October 2011, which led to the signing of a ceasefire on 8 October 2011. The ceasefire was signed by Zakaria Damane for the UFDR and Hissene Abdoulaye Ramadan for the UFDR. This ceasefire terminated the fighting.

In early January 2011, the death of a Malinké following an attack on a bus by armed men near the city of Duékoué led to an armed conflict between the Malinké and Guérés communities. Malinké community members suspected that the attack had been conducted by ethnic Guérés. To retaliate, young Malinkés attacked Guéré community members. Subsequent fighting between the conflict parties took place at several locations within the city of Duékoué and and led to the destruction of hundreds of homes. Although the city was under the control of security forces, they were unable to stop the ongoing violence which lasted for 5 days. Most prominent local leaders were unwilling to mediate or engage in dialogue, though some religious authorities and Parti Démocratique de la Côte d’Ivoire (PDCI) (English: Democratic Party of Côte d'Ivoire) Guéré leaders mediated between the leaders of the two communities in the Duékoué region in January 2011, but with no tangible results.
In March 2005, the International Islamic Forum and Middle East Council of Churches convened a peace conference.
A peace meeting between young men from the Coptic community and the the Muslim Brotherhood (al-Ikhwan) took place in December 2007.

Tensions between Copts and Muslims in Egypt increased in the aftermath of the fall of the regime of Hosni Mubarak during the Arab Spring. In 2011, the Home of the Egyptian Family organization was established. Aimed at promoting peaceful relations and dialogue between the religious communities, this initiative was headed by Sheikh Ahmed Al-Tayeb, the Grand Imam of Al-Azhar, with collaboration with Coptic Pope Shenouda III. The Home of the Egyptian Family monitored inter-religious violence and sent deputies to quell tensions. In March 2011, the Muslim Brotherhood called for a political dialogue with the Christian community, but this offer was rejected.

A new constitution adopted in 2014 included a provision that protects the rights of Christians to practice their faith. In March 2014, the Evangelical Presbyterian Church’s Council of Ecumenical Relations and Dialogues led an inter-faith conference in Cairo to promote peaceful dialogue on a variety of topics. Two other conferences were held that year.

From 30 September to 1 October 2016, a round of peace talks was held in Geneva between the Muslim Council of Elders and the World Council of Churches (WCC). In a communique, the two parties affirmed their commitment to pursuing a peaceful relationship.

In February 2017, a cross-country peace dialogue was organized in Cairo by Grand Iman of Al Azhar.  On 27 October 2017, the Coptic Christians and Muslims took part in a a Bedouin Peace Reconciliation meeting in Al Kashery. However, the latter threatened the former into participation.

On 26 to 30 April 2017, Grand Imam of Al Azhar organized a large International Peace Conference in Cairo. This conference was convened to promote dialogue after another bout of violence between the Christina and Muslim communities. In attendance were His Holiness Pope Francis, His All-Holiness Bartholomew I, His Holiness Pope Tawadros II, and World Council of Churches general secretary Rev. Dr. Olav Fykse Tveit.

Abdullahi Yusuf assumed the presidency of Puntland in 1998, which brought his clan, the Majerteen, to political power in a region that is heavily Darod-dominated. His term was designed to end in July 2001. However, Yusuf declared an extension of his term, which was a move denounced by Puntland’s Supreme Court judge Yussuf Hajji Nur. During a meeting in Garowe on 25 July, traditional authorities announced Yussuf Hajji Nur to be the interim leader until proper elections would be held in August 2001. Forces loyal to Abdullahi Yusuf clashed with forces loyal to Yussuf Hajji Nur on 6 August 2001. Fighting continued despite combined peace efforts by local business and clan leaders throughout August 2001.  The Supreme Court organized a conference between 26 August and 14 November to select a successor to Abdullahi Yusuf. At this conference, clan elders selected Jama Ali Jama as President of Puntland. However, Abdullahi Yusuf managed to defeat the forces of Jama Ali Jama. As such, Abdullahi Yusuf remained in power throughout his second term as president of Puntland until October 2004. He subsequently became the became President of the Transitional Federal Government (TFG).

The clashes between the Abgal and Garre subclans took place in the context of competing claims to land. From the start of the armed conflict on 1 December 2001 onwards, clan elders conducted five different mediation attempts to end the conflict.

In February 2002, the Transitional National Government (TNG) Minister of Science and Technology, Abdulkadir Mohamed, mediated between the conflict parties, trying to resolve the conflict parties’ grievances.
From 26-27 November 2008, the Kotido Peace Initiative (KOPEIN) held a peace conference that brought together representatives of the Dodoth, Matheniko, and Acholi.
In 2013, the Dodoth and Matheniko Karimojong, along with the Bokora, Jie, Pian and Pokot, signed the Nabilatuk Declaration following mediation by Ugandan government officials.

Negotiations in 2013 between the Dodoth, Matheniko Karimojong, Bokora, Jie, Pian, and Pokot led to the conclusion of the Mourititi Declaration. This agreement, among others, stipulated a set of provisions aimed at deterring cattle rustling.

Residing along the Kenya-Ethiopia border, the Degodia and the Garre pastoralist groups have often clashed over resources. The Garre and Degodia engaged in a round of negotiations in Mandera County in mid-August 2012. County commissioner Michael Tialal acted as the mediator during these negotiations. The peace effort broke down because violence re-ignited on 25 August 2012.

Local administrators mediated a round of peace talks between the Garre and Degodia in Banisa on 23 June 2013. This round of talks led to the signing of a peace agreement to stop fighting and prevent future violence.

On 4 July 2013, a three-day peace conference was held in Mandera County. This conference was mediated by leaders from North Eastern Province communities and was attended by leaders of the Garre and Degodia. Kenyan president Uhuru Kenyatta was also involved in this peace conference. Kenyatta called for illegal arms to be collected in Mandera and Wajir counties. The conflict parties signed a peace agreement at the end of the conference.

The National Cohesion and Integration Commission, together with government officials and elders, mediated a peace meeting in Elwak in early September 2013. Although the meeting was aimed at peace among all communities in Mandera County, a special emphasis was placed on promoting peace between the Degodia and Garre. The peace meeting did not result in the conclusion of an agreement.

Armed fighting between the Degodia and Garre escalated in Mandera and Wajir counties in May 2014. In response, Kenyan President Kenyatta convened a peace meeting between the groups in Nairobi on 25 June 2014. However, no official agreement concluded during this peace meeting and conflict continued into August 2014.

On 12 and 13 October 2014, a women’s peace talk was initiated by Hodhan Ibrahim, the Mandera Governor’s wife. Bringing together women from Mandera in various positions, the meeting sought solutions to the conflict. The peace talk ended with the establishment of a 5-member peace committee made up of both Garre and Degodia members.

On 16 and 17 February 2016, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) facilitated the Mandera Peace Mediation Initiatives. This effort took place in Nairobi with local authorities and community representatives from Mandera and Wajir Counties in attendance. The Degodia and Garre agreed to a ceasefire, as well as committed to the Mandera Peacebuilding Programme that was designed to facilitate peace within the district, with special attention to the conflicts between the Degodia and Garre.

In May 2019, the Degodia and Garre participated in peace talks mediated by local and national government officials. Ali Roba, the Governor of Mandera County in Kenya, acted as the chief mediator. Although no official peace agreement came from the effort, tensions were eased.

The term Dioula refers to various ethnicities and nationalities residing in, or originating from, the northern parts of the Ivory Coast, though the term does not include people originating from Burkina Faso. The Guéré ethnic group is part of the larger Kru tribe, located mainly in the south-western parts of Ivory Coast and in Liberia. The conflict between the Dioula and the Guéré communities was triggered by shots being fired by unknown gunmen at several Dioula attending a mosque in the city of Duékoué. Dioula shop owners and truck drivers went on a strike, but members of the Guéré community refused to go on strike. This triggered violence between the two communities. President Gbago allegedly inflamed the ethnic tension, by emphasizing Ivorianness, a concept that isolates “foreign” groups such as the Dioula from “true” residents such as the Guéré.  The UN Secretary-General urged the Ivorian authorities to conduct a full inquiry into the incident in order to ensure that the perpetrators of the attack would be quickly brought to justice, but no mediation or negotiations took place. UNOCI facilitated a meeting between the conflict parties, with involvement from local leaders, to find a solution to the conflict at the mission’s headquarters on 2 May 2005. This calmed down the situation.
In late May and early June, local leaders met with Dioula and Guéré representatives to continue to try resolve the conflict.

A Burkinabe is a person who originates from Burkina Faso. However, the word is often used in the Ivory Coast when referring to a member of the Mossi ethnic group. The Guéré are part of the larger Kru tribe, located mainly in the south-western parts of Ivory Coast and in Liberia. The two communities clashed for the first time in May 2001, but it was not until February 2005 that a peacemaking effort was conducted for the first time, when the United Nations Operation in Côte d’Ivoire (UNOCI) organized reconciliation meetings between the two groups. The French operation Licorne collaborated with UNOCI to establish security for a peace process. This effort failed to resolve the conflict.
On 20 March 2008, local authorities from Turkana North District and Dassantech Woreda facilitated a peace conference for the Gabra and Dassantech. No peace agreement was concluded .

In August 2009, the Dassantech, Gabra, and Hamer organized a peace meeting in Buluk without the involvement of a mediator. This led to an agreement for peaceful coexistence, though this agreement already broke down on 23 August 2009 with another flare-up of violence.

Armed fighting between the Birom and Fulani mainly took place in the vicinity of Jos. The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.

Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002. Furthermore, in 2002, the Nigerian government created a body to investigate the causes of the conflict, the Justice Opene Commission led by Justice C. Okpene.

In May 2004, Chris Alli was selected to be Interim Administrator by President Obasanjo. He organized multiple efforts to resolve the ongoing conflicts between Christians and Muslims, which included the conflict between Afisare, Anaguta, Birom and Fulani, and Hausa. During the state of emergency, Chris Alli launched a six-month Plateau Peace Program to bring lasting peace to the area. The plan included meetings between religious, ethnic and community leaders and the government. On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau – including Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba – signed a peace agreement and issued a 13-point communiqué. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

Part of Alli’s Program was also a month-long peace conference that was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was mediated by a twelve-member steering committee and brought together government officials and traditional leaders to find compromises to bring peace to Plateau State. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State (e.g., Afisare, Anaguta and Birom) were allowed to send two representatives each while “settlers” (i.e., Fulani and Hausa) were allowed only one representative each. It culminated in a report containing a number of resolutions. These included the resolution stating that “the Birom, Anaguta and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos.” However, the Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it.

On 6 April 2010, Birom and Fulani leaders met at Birom chief Jacob Buba Gyang’s palace in Jos for peace talks. The two sides were persuaded to meet through the efforts of Aliyu Gusau, the National Security advisor, who also attended the meeting with fellow security representatives.

On 23 June 2010, the Local Government Council brought together Birom and Fulani leaders for a peace meeting. This led to the signing of a peace agreement guaranteeing that both tribes forgive each other and take the path of peace. The Fulani group was represented by Alhaji Hashim Giroma, president of the Miyetti Allah Livestock Breeders Association and the secretary, Alhaji Yusuf Aliyu, while Da Gyang Mali, the chief of Gyel district, and his counterpart from Du district, Sir Augustine Pwakim, represented the Birom community.
On 26 April 2012, the Plateau Commissioner of Police Emmanuel Ayeni meditated peace talks between the conflict parties.

The Elizabeth Pam Foundation, the former chairman of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC), Nuhu Ribadu, and the Governor of Plateau State, Jonah Jang, mediated a meeting between Fulani and Birom representatives on 29 May 2012. At this occasion, the leaders of the two tribes pledged to live in peace.

Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan mediated peace talks between Birom on the one hand and Hausa and Fulani leaders on the other hand. He shuttled between the conflict parties, meeting with the Birom on 6 August and the Hausa and Fulani from the 8 to 9 August 2012 at the State house in Abuja. The Birom leaders were led by the former Comptroller General of Nigeria’s Customs Service, Jacob Buba Gyang, who is the Gbong Gwom in Jos. The Hausa-Fulani representative who met with the President was Alhaji Ibrahim Dasuki Nakande, who was the former minister of state for information and communications. This mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.
Plateau State Police Commissioner Emmanuel Diipo Ayeni mediated peace talks between Fulani and Birom on 6 September 2012. No written agreement was signed.

On 24 September 2012, the Plateau State government and the Special Task Force (STF) mediated a peace conference between the Birom and Fulani at the conference hall of Gwol Motel in Barkin Ladi. Other communities – including the Barkin Ladi, Bogoro, Mangu, Kanke, Pankshin, Riyom, and Tafawa Balewa also participated in this peace conference. The conference was mediated by Governor Jonah Jang. The conference led to the conclusion of a peace agreement to end cattle rustling.
Bilateral negotiations between Birom and Fulani leaders led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Jos on 5 May 2013.

The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) seized the momentum and began to facilitate an Inter-Communal Dialogue process in Jos from 6 tot 10 May 2013, bringing together representatives of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Hausa, and Fulani tribes.

After meeting separately with HD, each community drafted a road map for peace and established a steering community to represent its tribe at the Inter-Communal Dialogue meetings. The representatives (Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Hausa, and Fulani) signed a peace plan in Jos on 10 July 2013.

On 19 August 2013, the five communities (Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Hausa and Fulani) as well as state representatives met again under the auspices of HD Centre at the Crest Hotel in Jos. The negotiations did not lead to an agreement.

Following peace talks between the different communities of Jos, mediated by HD, representatives of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, Yoruba, and women’s communities signed the Joint Declaration of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation in Jos on 11 December 2014. This peace agreement guaranteed peace between the signatory communities and presented recommendations on how to achieve and maintain peace.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: In February 2015, Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South South, and Yoruba representatives attended peace talks mediated by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), local government authorities, and government forces. The talks led to the conclusion of an agreement on violence-free elections. The talks took place within the framework of the HD Jos Dialogue Forum.
Plateau State Governor Simon Lalong organized a separate peace meeting in which he mediated between the Fulani and Birom leaders on 13 June 2015.

HD mediated another round of talks between representatives of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 13 July 2015. The talks led to a declaration of commitment to achieve peace.

Plateau State Governor Simon Lalong mediated another round of talks between the Fulani and Birom on 29 July 2015, which led to the establishment of a 14-person committee composed of seven people from each tribe. This did not, however, prevent the violence that took place a week after this meeting.
Fulani and Birom youths and leaders in the Riyom Local Government Area in Plateau State participated in a peace meeting on 17 October 2015.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) brought together several Plateau community leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities.
After an upsurge in violence in early July 2018, President Buhari and vice President Osinbajo met with Birom and Fulani leaders in Jos. Both side appealed for peace.
However, clashes continued, and another peace meeting between Fulani and Birom was held in the area of Riyom on 19 September 2018.

On 27 April 2019, representatives of the Birom and Fulani of Jol and Mahanga from the Local Government Area of Riyom in Plateau State engaged in negotiations mediated by the Search for Common Ground. The conflict parties committed themselves to a ceasefire in a communique.
Operation Safe Haven (OPSH), a multi-security task force set up to maintain peace in Plateau State, mediated between the conflict parties during a peace meeting in June 2019.

The commander of OPSH in Plateau State visited the Birom and Fulani communities in July 2019 to discuss further ways to enhance peace. Representatives on both sides expressed their commitment to peaceful coexistence, but no written agreement was signed.

The Boje and Nsadop communities are from neighbouring villages in the Boki Local Government Area in Cross River State. The communities clashed in October 2010 following a land dispute. Governor Liyel Imoke mediated between Boje and Nsadop leaders in a round of peace talks in the Governor’s office in Calabar on 26 October 2010. This mediation effort did not lead to the concusion of a peace agreement.

The Justice, Development and Peace Commission of the Catholic Archdiocese of Ibadan (JDPC) mediated peace talks between representatives of the two communities at the Catholic Church in the Diocese of Ogoja in early November 2014. This did not lead to a peace agreement.

The Gok and Rek clans of the Dinka used to only engage in low-intensity clashes as a result of cattle raiding, but armed fighting between the groups escalated in February 2010 in the area around Bahr Gel village. On 22 February 2010, state authorities visited the conflict areas to mediate between the conflict parties.

side_a: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: The Suleiman and Quebeys subclans cohabitate the Muduug region in Somalia. A dispute between the subclans over access to water turned violent in February 2010. On 5 March 2010, several clan leaders mediated between the conflict parties.

The Karimojong, Pokot and Turkana engaged in a peace meeting in Lokichar from 3 to 6 March 2001. This meeting resulted in the communities agreeing to establish a shared radio system to avoid future fighting, as well as an agreement to share local resources.

The traditional leaders of the Pokot, Karamoja, Sabiny, and Turkana attended a one-week peace conference mediated by the Centre for Conflict Resolution and World Vision in Mbale from 20 to 27 July 2001.
Women from both communities engaged in a peace meeting to promote peaceful relations on 30 July 2001.

In September 2010, the Samburu and Somali communities participated in locally-organized peace caravans, along with tribal delegates from the Borana, Gabra, Meru, Pokot, Rendile, and Turkana. Reconciliation talks as part of these caravans did not lead to an agreement.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa, where they renewed the Modogashe Declaration.

Internal Security Permanent Secretary Francis Kimemia mediated peace talks between the Borana, Turkana, Meru, Samburu, and Somali at Harambee house on 16 and 17 November 2011. The peace talks did not end in the conclusion of a peace agreement.

Following an armed clash in Isiolo that killed 10 tribesmen, tribal elders from the Samburu, Somali, Boran, Meru, and Turkana engaged in peace talks in late March 2017. These talks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.
In July 2011, a round of negotiations between district officials from the Dassanech and the Nyangatom, aimed at the return of stolen cattle, took place.

A round of peace talks was held between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. Government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya acted as mediators during the talks. The conflict parties reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talks.
In 2017, multiple women’s dialogue sessions took place. Women from both tribes attended the Women Intra-healing Dialogue in Omorate from 1 to 2 March 2017.
Women from both tribes also attended the Women-Led Intra-Community Healing Dialogue in Kangaten from 3 to 4 March 2017.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter’s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)’s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017.  The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.
On 12 June 2017, the Joint Women Forum was held in Lowaregnak, Turkana County. This initiative was facilitated by PDC and SAPCONE.

A Chief’s Led Inter-Community Dialogue took place in Omorate on 12 June 2017. During this dialogue, attendees discussed past peace efforts, including the Arba Minch Resolution from 2016. The session’s main conclusion was that relations between the Dassanech, Turkana, and Nyangatom had to be further improved and that to this purpose further peace initiatives would take place in the second half of the year.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 30 August 2017, the Joint Cross-Border Lower Level Government Official’s Meeting was held at Turmi, Ethiopia in order to prioritize mitigating the conflict between the Nyangatom, the Turkana, and the Dassanech.  On 24 and 25 September 2017, the Joint Cross-border Chiefs’ Led Inter-Community Dialogue was held in Omorate, Ethiopia. The peace meeting was facilitated by PCD and SAPCONE. A total of 26 participants attended the peace meeting, including Ethiopian delegates, representatives of local governments in both countries, as well as the Dassanech, Nyangatom and Turkana representatives. During this meeting, participants agreed to conflict resolution mechanisms.
third_party: local NGO; local government; government; Kenya

description: When the Mursi joined the Ari in Mago Valley in the 1970s, the communities shared a tranquil relationship. However, a Mursi was killed in the vicinity of an Ari village in May 1991, which triggered retaliatory attacks were carried out by the Mursi on Ari settlements nearby.  Negotiations between the Ari and Mursi mediated by the Ethiopian government led to the conclusion of an agreement. The agreement stipulated that compensation had to be paid by the Mursi and stolen property had to be compensated or returned.

On 29 August 2006, 50 participants (religious, political as well as Pokot, Samburu and Turkana) convened for an ecumenical prayer meeting. The meeting was held in Samburu District and proved to be productive for peace talks. At the end, the attendees reached an 8-point peace plan that included provisions for future talks.

Several peace meetings between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya, and Luo elders took place in Kaptembwo in August 2008. The UN Development Programme supported the meetings and 52 conflict resolution experts were also involved.

George Saitoti mediated a peace meeting between different Members of Parliament from the Marakwet, Samburu, and Turkana in Maralal in February 2010. After the meeting, more than 2000 police officers were deployed to collect illegal arms from warriors as proof of a commitment to peace.

Several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

Internal Security Permanent Secretary Francis Kimemia mediated peace talks between the Borana, Turkana, Meru, Samburu, and Somali at Harambee house on 16 and 17 November 2011. The peace talks did not end in the conclusion of a peace agreement.
A peace meeting between the Samburu, Turkana, Borana, and Turkana was held in Marsabit on 24 March 2013. The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated the peace talks.

On 6 June 2015, fighters from the Turkana and the Samburu engaged in a gun battle in Attan in Isiolo County, which lasted for six hours despite intervention by police. To curb the violence, the government launched a disarmament campaign in cooperation with county leaders. From 19 to 21 June 2015, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) mediated peace talks between the Samburu and Turkana in Nanyuki at the Sportsman's Arms Hotel. The lead mediator of these peace talks was Francis Ole Kapar from the NCIC. The talks led to the signing of the Sportsman’s Arms Ceasefire and Peace Agreement on 21 June 2015 in Nanyuki.
agreement_name: Sportsman's Arms Ceasefire and Peace Agreement

description: The Borana, Meru, Samburu, and Turkana from Isiolo County engaged in peace talks between 30 September and late October 2015.
The groups clashed once again in September 2015. In response, local authorities mediated between elders from the Samburu and Turkana. Yet, armed fighting continued.

The NCIC, together with Northern Rangeland Trust (NRT) and Finn Church Aid, mediated a two-day peace forum with government and community leaders at Lewa Downs in November 2015. This mediation effort led to the conclusion of the Lewa Down Peace Agreement. Both the Samburu and the Turkana signed the agreement.
third_party: government; local NGO; Finn Church Aid

description: During another round of negotiations in Loruko in December 2015, the Samburu and Turkana signed the Morans Peace Accord.
During 2015, Bishop Cornelius Korir convened government officials and leaders from the Turkana, West-Pokot, Samburu, and Baringo counties at multiple peace caravans.

In November 2019, a 5-day peace caravan consisting of religious and traditional leaders, as well as local authorities, visited locations of violence between the Samburu and Turkana to promote reconciliation between the two groups.
third_party: religious leaders; traditional leaders; local government

description: The Pokot and Samburu frequently clash in the context of land disputes and cattle raids. The Pokot and Samburu engaged in peace talks at Lake Naivasha Tourist Resort in October 2006, which resulted in the conclusion of a 26-point peace agreement. Dekha Ibrahim Abdi and Francis Mutuku Nguli, who were both mandated by the Kenyan government, acted as the mediators at these talks.
Dekha Ibrahim Abdi and Francis Mutuku Nguli mediated between the conflict parties in 2007 in order to ensure the implemtnation of the peace agreement concluded in October 2006.
Peace talks between the Pokot, Samburu, and Turkana took place in the North Rift Valley in August 2008.

Several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa, where they renewed the Modogashe Declaration.
Another round of peace talks was held at the boundary of Laikipia and Samburu counties on 6 July 2011.
Bishop Cornelius Korir convened government officials, as well as leaders from Turkana, West-Pokot, Samburu, and Baringo counties at multiple peace caravans during 2015.

In July 2005, the Turbi massacre took place and led to bloody fighting between the Borana and the Gabra in Moyale Sub-County. In response, the Arid Lands Resources Management Project in Moyale, ActionAid, Codep, and Oxfam collaborated in an effort to reconcile the communities. A first round of peace talks mediated by these third parties took place in Yabello in Ethiopia in December 2005.
third_party: World Bank; Action Aid; Codep; Oxfam

description: A second round of peace talks facilitated by the Arid Lands Resources Management Project in Moyale, ActionAid, Codep, and Oxfam took place in Moyale in Kenya from 15 to 18 January 2006. Around 150 leaders from the Borana, Gabra, and Rendille clans in the Marsabit and Moyale Districts attended the talks. A final round of peace talks aimed at signing a peace agreement was scheduled to be held in April 2006. This round of peace talks would be witnessed by Kenyan and Ethiopian members of parliament. However, the peace talks were cancelled because the plane carrying the members of parliament crashed.
third_party: World Bank; Action Aid; Codep; Oxfam

description: A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.
In February 2007, the Borana and Gabra engaged in bilateral peace talks.
On 4 December 2008, the groups clashed once again. The violence took one life and led to hundreds of cattle being stolen. In response, a cross-border dialogue was led by Ethiopian local authorities.

USAID mediated between community members of the Borana, Gari, Guji and Gabra people, residing in the bordering areas of Somali and Oromia regional states, in the context of the Negelle Peace Process that started in February 2009.

On 19 July 2009, leaders from the Borana and the Gabra convened in Maikona for a peace meeting. At this meeting, the two groups signed Maikona Declaration. The Kenya National Steering Committee (NSC) supported this peace effort.
Top clan leaders, regional government officials, and a peace committee signed a peace agreement in Yabello in December 2009.

A round of peace talks between tribal leaders from Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi took place in Almond Resort in Garissa on 7 and 8 April 2011. The conflict parties expressed their renewed commitment to the Modogashe Declaration during these talks. Provincial commissioners acted as mediators.
In June 2011, the leaders of the conflict parties ratified the Negelle Peace Accords.

The Borana resumed armed fighting with the Gabra and Garre alliance on 15 November 2011. The district government deployed security forces to the conflict area. The district government mediated peace talks between the three tribes in Moyale on 28 and 29 November 2011.
The conflict parties engaged in peace in Moyale on 4 January 2012. This round of talks did not lead to a peace agreement and instead ended in violence.
The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated a round of negotiations between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra on 24 March 2013.
The Kenyan government mediated an inter-tribal meeting between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra in Moyale on 28 August 2013.
Another round of peace talks between the Borana, Burji, and Gabra took place in Moyale in December 2013. Kenyan security forces mediated between the conflict parties at these peace talks.

Representatives of the Borana and Gabra engaged in peace talks at Koket-Borana Hotel in Moyale in Ethiopia in August 2017. The Inter African Group (AIG), Strategies for Northern Development (SND), and USAID mediated these talks. The negotiations focused on implementing the 2009 Dukana-Dillo-Maikona Declaration. On 30 August 2017, the Borana and Gabra agreed to implement the Dukana-Dillo-Maikona Declaration.
third_party: Inter African Group; Strategies for Northern Development; USAID

description: A round of peace talks between the Borana and Gabra, mediated by local politicians, tookplace on 8 September 2018.
Another round of peace talk was held in Nairobi on 18 October. This round of talks was mediated by the Marsabit Interfaith Council and led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

Leaders from the Borana and Gabra tribes took part in a peace conference in Eldoret on 15 July 2019. The peace talks were mediated by local authorities from Marsabit. The peace conference led to the signing of a peace agreement.

Residing in both Somalia and Ethiopia, the Geri and Makahin have clashed over scarce resources and land. Heavy fighting took place between the Geri and Makahin in June 2001. The conflict parties engaged in bilateral negotiations in June 2001 that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

After the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-Kisangani-Mouvement de Libération (RCD-K-ML) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-Kisangani-Liberation Movement) split away, the Nyamwisi faction sided with the Lendu in the Ituri conflict. Mbusa Nyamwisi appointed Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo governor and chief of staff in Ituri in early 2002. Although Lonpondo was a from the Nande ethnic group, many Hema perceived him, as biased against them as he had almost exclusively members of the Lendu ethnic group working in his administration. This further exacerbated local tensions. Around the same time, the RCD-K-ML’s minister of defense, Thomas Lubanga, proposed a plan to restructure the army, but both Molondo and Nyamwisi rejected this plan. Lubanga subsequently announced in April 2002 that he was no longer with RCD-K-ML, but with UPC (he was allegedly supported in that move by Uganda). As a consequence, Molondo sent RCD-K-ML troops to attack the residence of Lubanga. The Ugandan government sent troops to calm the situation and evacuated UPC fighters to the airport. Uganda also tried to mediate, inviting the UPC to Kampala and offer them to put them in touch with RCD-K-ML leader Mbusa Nyamwisi. The Ugandans subsequently brought the UPC delegation to Kasese in early August 2008 to negotiate with a RCD-K-ML delegation, though Nyamwisi was not present at these negotiations. The talks end without resolution. When arriving for supposedly another round of negotiations in Uganda mediated by Museveni, the UPC delegation was deported to a prison in Kinshasa. Yet, on 22 August 2002, the UPC – now led by General Floribert Kisembo (who would later lead the Parti pour l’unité et la sauvegarde de l’intégrité du Congo (PUSIC) (English: Party for Unity and Safeguarding of the Integrity of Congo) together with Yves Khawa Panga Mandro) – took control over Bunia from RCD-K-ML, chasing  Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo and his forces to Beni. The UPC subsequently formed a government in Bunia and temporarily managed to rule over most of Ituri.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar Es Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).

President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi’s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking. In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started.

The Front des Nationalistes et Intégrationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front) was formed in late 2002, with support from the RCD-ML under Mbusa Nyamwisi and the Government of the DRC. One faction was led by Floribert Njabu at the northern border of Djugu, while another faction was led my Mathieu Ngudjolo located east of Bunia. The armed conflict between  the FNI and the Forces de Résistance Patriotique d’Ituri (FRPI) (English: Patriotic Force of Resistance in Ituri) on the one side and the Union des Patriotes Congolais (UPC) (English: Union of Congolese Patriotes) on the other is an extension of the conflict between the Hema and Lendu, since the UPC is predominantly made up of Hema fighters, while the FNI consists mainly out of Lendu fighters and the FRPI consists mainly of Ngiti fighters, which is a sub-group of the Lendu. The immediate trigger of the conflict was the withdrawal of the Ugandan forces from Ituri as a result of international pressure. Anticipating this withdrawal, the UPC attacked a Ugandan military base in N’Délé on 6 March 2003. Uganda, in turn, attacked the UPC in Bunia in close cooperation with the FNI and the FRPI. This offensive was aimed at putting the FNI and the FRPI in control of Bunia before Uganda’s withdrawal. The coalition of FNI and FRPI came into Bunia from the North, while the Ugandan army came in from the South. The UPC resistance quickly collapsed and the UPC fighters left the city in March 2003. Yet, by May 2003, they had reconquered positions from FNI. In March 2003, the UN Special Representative Namanga Ngongi, with help from Petronille Waweka of the Alur tribe, negotiated a ceasefire in Ituri. On 18 March 2003, Ngongi finally succeeded in creating a ceasefire signed by several militias in Ituri at a round of negotiations in Bunia: the Ituri Cessation of Hostilities Agreement. However, while the UPC participated in the negotiations, it refused to sign the ceasefire.

On 17 May 2003, the Government of Tanzania and MONUC facilitated a round of negotiations between the Government of the DRC and leaders of the main Iturian militias. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Dar Es Salaam Agreement, which stipulated a ceasefire and the rights of the militias to be eligible for either integration into national army or civilian reinsertion.

In response to the fighting in Ituri, the UN Security Council authorized, on 30 May 2003, the deployment of an interim multinational emergency force to be deployed in Bunia. The EU subsequently deployed troops in Bunia on 12 June as part of Operation Artemis. The force was successful in stabilizing the situation in Bunia and enforcing the UN presence in the DRC. On 1 September 2003, responsibility for the security of the region was handed over to the MONUC mission. Together with UN officials, Operation Artemis mediated between the UPC on the one side and the FNI and the FRPI on the other side in July 2003. The conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and to divide the zones of control.
