While the northern neighborhoods of Bunia were agreed to be controlled by the UPC, the southern neighborhoods were agreed to be controlled by the FNI and the FRPI. Operation Artemis controlled the center.

On 1 August 2003, three Ministers of the new transitional government, set up in April and May 2003 and coming into being on 18 July 2003, visited Bunia to support the Ituri Interim Administration. With the exception of UPC, the armed groups expressed their willingness to be incorporated into the new armed forces. The new government mediated a round of negotiations between the Ituri militias in Kinshasa on 22 August 2003, which led to a memorandum of understanding in which the militias agree to work with the government to restore state authority across the region.

Following negotiations on 16 September 2003, an agreement to make Bunia a weapons free zone was reached between the conflict parties. MONUC, the Ituri Interim Administration, and the Comite de concentration des groupes armés supported this process.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar Es Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).

President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi’s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking. In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started.

The Front des Nationalistes et Intégrationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front) was formed at the end of 2002, with support from the RCD-ML under Mbusa Nyamwisi and the Government of the DRC. One faction was led by Floribert Njabu at the northern border of Djugu, while another faction was led my Mathieu Ngudjolo located east of Bunia. The Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC) was founded by former UPC defense minister Chief Yves Khawa Panga Mandro. The FNI and PUSIC  first clashed in March 2003, when the FNI attacked Mandro, a village in Ituri. In May 2003, the FNI attacked Tchomia village. The FNI managed to take control of both villages in relatively little time during both offensives. A coalition between FNI, PUSIC, FRPI, and FAPC attacked UPC in Bunia in March 2003 and chased them out of the city. This momentary cooperation opened a window for negotiations. Indeed, in March 2003, the UN Special Representative Namanga Ngongi, with help from Pétronile Vaweka of the Alur tribe, negotiated a ceasefire in Ituri. On 18 March 2003, Ngongi finally succeeded in creating a ceasefire signed by several militias in Ituri at a round of negotiations in Bunia: the Ituri Cessation of Hostilities Agreement, which led to the opening of the Ituri Pacification Commission. Both the FNI and the PUSIC were signatories to this ceasefire.

After fighting took place between various militias in Bunia in May, the Government of Tanzania and MONUC facilitated a round of negotiations between the Government of the DRC and leaders of the main Iturian militias, including FNI and PUSIC. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the Dar Es Salaam Agreement on 15 May, which stipulated a ceasefire and the rights of the militias to be eligible for either integration into national army or civilian reinsertion.

On 1 August 2003, three Ministers of the new transitional government, set up in April and May 2003 and coming into being on 18 July 2003, visited Bunia to support the Ituri Interim Administration. With the exception of UPC, the armed groups expressed their willingness to be incorporated into the new armed forces. The new government mediated a round of negotiations between the Ituri militias in Kinshasa on 22 August 2003, which led to a memorandum of understanding in which the militias agree to work with the government to restore state authority across the region.

On 16 September 2003, an agreement to make Bunia a weapons free zone was reached between the conflict parties. The Ituri Interim Administration and the Comite de concentration des groupes armes supported this process.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar Es Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K). In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started.

President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi’s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking.

In February 2003, the first cross-border peace talk between the Dodoth and Turkana took place. This peace effort was organized by the Lotus Kenya Action for Development Organization (LOKADO) and Kotido Peace Initiative (KOPEIN).
In July 2006, the Dodoth and Turkana signed the Nawountos Peace Agreement. This was mediated by KOPEIN.

In June 2008, East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Christi (IPC), Intervida World Alliance, and Wilde Ganzen organized a four-day peace conference in Kapoeta (Southern Sudan). Mediated by Seeds of Peace in Africa (SOPA), multiple communal youths attended (including: the Acholi, Buya, Dodoth, Dongiro (Ethiopia), Jie, Kachipo, Lokir (Sudan), Lotuko, Matheniko (Uganda), Murile, Theuso, Toposa, and Turkana (Kenya). Although no formal agreement was reached, the participants did agree to establish independent peace committees and promote coexistence via cross-community activities. DADO-Kaabong (Uganda), Lotus Kenya Action for Development Organization (LOKADO), Kotido Peace Initiative (KOPEIN), Kuron Peace Village, and Catholic Diocese of Torit were among those organizations that would implement these changes. As part of this International Cross border Peace Conference, peace talks between the Dodoth, Turkana and Jie were organized.
third_party: East African Safari Air Express; IKV Pax Christi (IPC); Intervida World Alliance; Wilde Ganzen; Seeds of Peace Africa

description: In 2009, SOPA and IPC aided a peace meeting between Dodoth and Turkana women in Kaabong. This was mainly organized by the Dodoth Agropastoralist Development Organisation (DADO) and Lotus Kenya Action for Development Organization (LOKADO).
third_party: Seeds of Peace Africa; IKV Pax Christi; local NGO

description: On 21 October 2011, the Karimojong, Turkana and Dodoth convened along with government delegates for a cross-border meeting in West Turkana. Although the idea came from members of the Karimojong and Turkana Mercy Corps Uganda planned it. No peace agreement was produced from the effort.

The conflict between the supporters of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) and of the United Nigeria People’s Party (UNPP) emerged in in Bassambari town in Baylesa State in the run up to the elections in April 2003. Fighting in early April 2003 resulted in some PDP members fleeing their community. Local community leaders met about a week before the elections and set up an eight-man committee of the main political parties to resolve the crisis. The committee met on 8 April and agreed that the PDP members would be allowed to return peacefully. Representatives of all parties, including UNPP candidate George Fente and local PDP leaders, signed the pledge. However, fighting resumed on 10 and 11 April 2003.

The National Tranquility Movement convened an Islamic-Christian dialogue forum in Kaduna on 13 January 1996. Religious leaders and state representatives met to promote lasting religious tolerance. No resolution was adopted at this meeting, but the participants stressed the need to create a federal ministry for religious affairs and, in general, to involve the state more closely in the conflict.

Community and religious leaders of the two major Nigerian religions met with state officials in the beginning of September 2001 in Jos to discuss peace paths. No written agreement resulted from the meeting and the discussion ended in a stalemate.

In addition, on 16 September 2001, President Obasanjo, reacting to the violence in Jos, met political, religious and community representatives at the government building of Plateau State and encouraged them to follow peace.

El Haji Ahmed Makarfi, the Executive Governor of Kaduna State, attempted to foster dialogue between the two groups by, “recognizing the ‘customary’ laws of each one of these groups and empowering the new chieftaincies to organize their own ‘customary’ judicial systems in addition to the Islamic shari’a and state magistrate court systems.”

Directly following the crisis, NGOs also played an important role. The CAN brought the two communities together for peace talks held in the TEKAN conference hall in Jos. However, the organization was not perceived as neutral and only a few Muslims took part in the discussion.
In addition, the Christian Foundation for Peace and Equity held peace talks and workshops on non-violence with Muslim and Christian leaders.

The Interfaith Mediation Centre (IMC), the Nigerian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs (NSCIA) and Jama’atu Nasril Islam (JNI), the umbrella organization for Muslims, contributed to the mediation of various local conflicts between Muslim and Christians. On 22 August 2002, the NSCIA helped broker the Kaduna Peace declaration, which was signed by 22 representatives, 11 from the Muslim and 11 from the Christian communities. The government also acted as facilitator at this peace meeting. However, clashes resumed already three months later. The religious organizations continued to mediate and broker dialogue between the conflict parties throughout 2002.

In March 2003, the Muslim-Christian Dialogue Forum and the US Institute of Peace organized a five-day dialogue workshop in Kaduna in attempt to further help Christian and Muslim communities to address their disputes. This event concluded with a 17-point consensual declaration including, among others, the guarantee that the two warring parties will endeavor to cooperate and engage in dialogue in order to ease tensions.
third_party: community leaders; US Institute of Peace (USIP)

description: Following the burning of many churches in northern Nigeria, leaders of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), which had been pursuing peace talks with Jamatu’ul Nasir Islam (JNI) in Kaduna since 2000, announced on 1 April 2004 their withdrawal from these peace talks. The Bachama Leaders of Thought, representing Bachama people, had engaged in dialogue with conflict parties in the most recent clashes and their delegates held peace talks with the fighters to convince them to stop during the week of 7 April 2004. The Bachama leaders of thought had already conducted peace discussions between the belligerent parties during previous episodes of armed fighting.

On 17 May 2004, Christian and Muslim leaders in the conflict promised to lay down their arms and published a nine-point communiqué at the Catholic Archbishop’s Conference Hall in Jos. No mediator was involved in the negotiations leading up to this agreement.

After hostilities resumed in Plateau State between Muslims and Christians, Administrator Chris Alli launched a six-month Plateau Peace Program to bring lasting peace to the area. The plan included meetings between religious, ethnic and community leaders and the government. As part of this peace process, on 2 July 2004, members of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) and Jama’atu Nasril Islam signed a peace agreement and submitted it to the government. In that declaration, they pledged to respect and encourage the peace process.

Following violence in the Shendam region, a mediation effort by the Interfaith Mediation Centre led to the signing of the “Yelwa-Shendam Peace Affirmation” in Yelwa-Shendam, Plateau State on 19 February 2005. This agreement brought together Muslim and Christian representatives of various ethnic nationalities in Shendam local government area to ensure deeper cooperation and greater respect for each other.

Vice President Atiku Abubakar facilitated a peace meeting between Muslim and Christian religious leaders of the Southern Kaduna Inter-religious Group in the State House in early December 2006. He encouraged them to forge peaceful coexistence between the two religious groups. No agreement was signed.

The Nigeria Inter-religious Council (NIREC) – composed of 25 Christians and 25 Muslim leaders – met on 18 October 2007 in Abuja at the Transcorp Hilton Hotel to discuss ways of reaching peace in the region. No agreement was concluded between the conflict parties at this meeting.
NIREC held another meeting in Maiduguri, Borno State capital, between 4 and 7 May 2008.

On 1 February 2010, the Special Assistant to the Governor on Religious matters, Rev. Godspower Agbuduta, the Special Assistant to the Governor on Special Duties, Alhaji Awuli Tukur, and several Muslim and Christian representatives of the Delta State took part in a meeting organized by Arewa Forum and the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN). They appealed for greater cooperation between communities. No agreement was signed.
third_party: local government; community leaders; religious leaders

description: The Lagos State government held a consultative Forum on 11 March 2010 with various religious and community leaders in response to the Jos crisis. The state Governor, Mr. Babatunde Fashola (SAN), encouraged all participants to promote peace in their communities. His Eminence Dr. Sunday Ola Makinde, Prelate of the Methodist Church Nigeria, reminded politicians to not use religion for their future campaigns.

On 23 June 2010, NIREC met in Adamawa State to prepare for the 2011 elections and prevent possible violence. The event took place in response to the various crises in the North. They called on the state government to engage in peace initiatives as a model for the country.

On 17 July 2010, the NIREC met again, this time with other religious leaders and traditional rulers in Taraba State. They enagaged in discussion on how to end religious clashes in the country, especially in the North.
On the same day (17 July 2010), NIREC executives, accompanied by the Governor, also visited the secretariat of the Muslim Council and the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN).

Plateau Police Commissioner Ikechukwu Aduba separately visited the headquarters of Jamatul Nasril Islam, and the Christian Association of Nigeria in Jos on 25 August 2010. He stressed the secular nature of the Nigerian State and urged them to promote peace.

Among the numerous non-governmental organizations involved in inter-religious dialogue between the two communities, the Programme for Christian–Muslim Relations in Africa (PROMCURA) facilitated a Christian-Muslim Dialogue Conference at Jacaranda Retreat and Conference Centre in Kaduna from 6 to 9 October 2010. At the end of the conference, Christian and Muslim leaders from Bauchi, Plateau, Kano, Kogi and Kaduna assured in the Kaduna communiqué that they would take proactive measures to encourage reconciliation and work with multiple stakeholders to achieve peace between the two religious groups.

In January 2011, in response to the crisis between Christians and Muslims in Tafawa Belawa area of Bauchi State, the religious stakeholders of the state reached a peace agreement. Bauchi governor Isa Yuguda convened and mediated the meeting.

The presidential elections of 16 April 2011, in which Jonathan Goodluck, a Christian, was elected, led to new waves of violence between Christians and Muslims. The attacks in the northern states claimed more than 800 lives in total in both communities. Multiple bomb attacks on churches – claimed by Boko Haram – ravaged Jos, Madalla and the town of Gadaka in the northern state Yobe on Christmas Day in 2011. Following the attacks, leaders of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) and Jama’atu Nasiru Islam (JNI) met on 27 December 2011 and reached a peace agreement at the central mosque in Jos. The agreement confirms the need for peaceful coexistence between the two communities.

Muslim and Christian citizens of Kano State, represented by Bashir Ishaq Bashir and the chairman of the Kano branch of the Christian Association of Nigeria, Bishop Ransom Bello, signed the Kano Covenant on 15 January 2012. This peace agreement emphasized the need for cohabitation of Christians and Muslims in the state of Kano, as well as ensured that Christians should be free to practice their religion.

As step toward dialogue between both communities, Christian and Muslim Youths led by Dr. Sulieman Shuiabu and Mr. Digi Haruna held a meeting at the national headquarters of the Jama’atu Nasril Islam (JNI) on 27 March 2012. They appealed to their Muslims counterpart to end recurring violence in the north. This meeting did not lead to any official agreement, but rather aimed to open the dialogue between both communities.

The members of the Katsina State chapter of Jama’atu Nasril Islam (JNI) and the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) met in Katsina on 14 May 2012. The meeting concluded with an appeal to all imams and clerics to encourage peace in the country. In addition, a 14-person committee was established, comprising seven Muslims and seven Christians, who would then meet regularly to promote understanding of peace between the two religions.

Pastors of the Peace, Revival and Reconciliation Foundation of Nigeria visited Muslims at the Friday Mosque in Sabon Tasha on 20 May 2013. The meeting was aimed at adressing tensions in the Kaduna South region, which is predominantly populated by Christians. The Christians representatives promised to let the Muslims continue their business and practice their faith undisturbed. Members of both religions were invited to respect each other and live in peace. Pastor Yohanna Buru, coordinator of the foundation, made sure to write a letter to government officials and youth organizations to promote this approach. Muslim leaders encouraged this initiative and assured their support.

A national summit on interfaith dialogue and the quest of national security in Nigeria organized by the Interfaith Activity and Partnership for Peace (IFAPP) was held at the Abuja International Conference Centre on 5 November 2013. The meeting ended with the publication of a communiqué jointly signed by Mallam Shehu Lemu of the Islamic Education Trust, and Rev. George Ehusani of the Lux Terra Leadership Foundation. Both regretted the continuing tensions between Christians and Muslims and encouraged interfaith dialogue. Religious leaders representing NIREC and CAN, representatives of civil society organizations, and youth and women leaders participated in the event. In addition, many state representatives were also present, including President Jonathan Goodluck, Vice President, President of the Senate, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and state governors.
third_party: local NGO; President; government; local government

description: In the aftermath of reported attacks by Fulani Herdsmen in Benue State, Christian and Muslim leaders signed a peace accord on 23 March 2014 promising to work together on reconcilaition, protect each other, and stop any attack on one another. Archbishop Yimam Orkwar, President of the CAN, and Evangelist Gift Elanu, of the Benue State Christian Association of Nigeria and Secretary of the CAN, signed the treaty on behalf of the Christians, while Alhaji Garba Baba and Mustapha Garba, respectively President and Secretary of the Jama’Atu Nasir Islam (JNI), signed in the name of the Muslims. No mediator was involved in the peace effort.

Bishop Mathew Hassan, of the Kukah Centre in Abuja, brought together Muslim and Christian leaders for a dialogue early in April 2014 to facilitate peace between both religious groups and restore confidence.

The Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace Center (DREP) in Jos gathered eight religious leaders (e.g. from CAN and JNI organizations) and six community leaders from the Hausa, Afisare, Berom, Igbo, Anaguta and Yoruba communities on 19 June 2014 to work towards peaceful coexistence between Christian and Muslim communities. No agreement resulted from the meeting, but the meeting paved the way for further dialogue between the different groups.

Another peace meeting, organized in anticipation of the upcoming elections, at the Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace (DREP) Centre in Jos, led to the signing of an accord on 14 January 2015. The agreement committed religious leaders, community leaders, political parties, and local authorites to peaceful conduct during the election period.

As violence continued, Muslim and Christian leaders signed another peace agreement aimed at violence-free elections. State stakeholders representing both religions signed this agreement at a forum organized by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) in Gombe on 5 February 2015.

During the last weekend of July 2016, a delegation from the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) in the 19 northern states and the FCT visited the national JNI headquarters in Kaduna. Both organizations guaranteed that they would promote peace within the state. The organizations did not sign an agreement during this meeting.

After clashes broke out again in 2017, the Global Peace Foundation (GPF) convened the Southern Kaduna Peace and Reconciliation Meeting for Southern Kaduna representatives on 13 July 2017 in Afachan. Leaders of several different associations such as the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) and Jama’atu Nasril Islam (JNI), as well as representatives from different chiefdoms and communities in Southern Kaduna, participated in the meeting. The stakeholders present at the meeting promised to embrace peace and forgive each other. No written agreement was signed, but all parties encouraged the GPF to continue its peace efforts.

On 19 March 2018, in response to the South Kaduna crisis, a series of peace meetings were held in Kafanchan, Kaduna State. The founder of the Plateau State-based NGO “Citizens Monitoring Group”, the former Regional Secretary, International Fellowship of Evangelical Students, Rev. Gideon Para-Mallam, and Chief Imam of Kafanchan Alhaji Mami Massim organized those meetings. There is no publicly available information that indicates the signing of an agreement.
third_party: local NGO; community leaders; religious leaders

description: On 19 July 2018, the NGO Global Peace Foundation Nigeria (GPFN) also convened a meeting in South Kaduna State, bringing together stakeholders from the Christian Association of Nigeria, Jama’atul Nasril Islam, Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association, Southern Kaduna People’s Union, and the Southern Kaduna Muslim Ummah Development Association. They reviewed past conflicts in order to find long-term solutions but the meeting did not lead to the signing of a peace agreement.

Religious and community leaders met at the Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace (DREP) Centre in Jos on 26 July 2018 in response to the crisis situation in parts of Plateau State. The meeting concluded with a 13-point resolution condemning the recent killings and encouraging the center to convene another meeting to take peace-oriented decisions.

On 18 September 2018, Muslim and Christian leaders – including the Sultan of Sokoto, Sa’ad Abubakar, and the President of the Christian Association of Nigeria, Rev. Samson Ayokunle – signed an agreement in Abuja to ensure peacekeeping before and beyond the February 2019 elections. Representatives of the United Nations and the United States also attended this meeting organized by Nigerian Interfaith Action Association.

Long-standing racial tensions between Senegalese immigrants and Arab Mauritanian culminated in a violent confrontation over a land dispute in Mauritania in April 1989. A delegation of the Arab Maghreb Union went to Nouakchott to mediate in April 1989.
The Malian Foreign Minister mediated between the conflict parties on behalf of the Organization for African Unity (OAU) in Dakar and Nouakchott in April 1989.
France also mediated between the conflict parties in April 1989.

Senegalese and Mauritanian delegates engaged in peace talks mediated in Bamako in May 1989. The mediation team at this round of talks consisted of members of the OAU, Mali, France, Tunisia, and Zaire arrived in Mali in order to assist the OAU’s mediation efforts.
third_party: OAU; Mali; France; Tunisia; DR Congo (Zaire)

description: On 25 May 1989, the French Foreign Minister mediated a round of peace talks between the conflict parties.
On 28 and 29 May 1989, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat mediated between the leaders of Mauritania and Senegal to resolve the conflict.
Representatives of Mauritania and Senegal engaged in another round of peace talks mediated by the OAU in Bamako on 3 June 1989.

Another round of negotiations mediated by the OAU was held in Bamako wi on 27 June 1989. Both sides accused the other of stalling the peace process and tensions only increased following the failed mediation efforts.

On 21 August 1989, the two countries closed their borders and ended diplomatic relations. However, the OAU continued to press forward with mediation efforts, albeit this time in the form of a mediation team consisting of mediators of six OAU member states led by the new OAU chairman Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. This OAU mediation team shuttled between representatives of the conflict parties in Senegal and Mauritania in September 1989.
In November 1989, the OAU’s secretary general Salim Ahmed Salim met with representatives of the conflict parties to revitalize the mediation process.
The OAU mediation team mediated a round of peace talks in Cairo in February 1990.
The conflict parties attended a peace meeting, mediated by President Dawda Jawara of the Gambia and General Lansana Conte of Guinea, in Nouakchott on 19 March 1990.

In April 2002, the rival candidates attended peace talks in Dakar mediated by President of Senegal Abdulaye Wade. Representing the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), which became the African Union (AU) later that year, Wade led a mediation team of five presidents, including Blaise Compaoré of Burkina Faso, Denis Sassou-Nguesso of Congo, Omar Bongo of Gabon, and Tandja Mamadou of Nigeria. The conflict parties agreed to respect a recount of votes by the High Constitutional Court. Later in April 2002, the High Constitutional Court declared Ravalomanana the true winner and new president of the country. Wade attempted to bring the parties back for peace talks on two occasions in May, but both attempts failed. In June 2002, Ratsiraka left Madagascar to find safe haven in France.
On 9 June 2002, at the second peace meeting in Dakar, the Wade proposed a power-sharing deal, but both Ratsiraka and Ravalomanana rejected this deal.
A third and final round of negotiations mediated by President of Senegal Abdulaye Wade took place on 1 July. The meeting resulted in Ravalomanana obtaining full control of Madagasacar.

Following the presidential elections of Madagascar in 2001, both incumbent President Didier Ratsiraka and Marc Ravalomanana, the mayor of the Ravalomanana, announced that they had won the elections. Tensions increased between their supporters and armed conflict broke out. The government rejected all offers of international mediation. Regional authorities and religious leaders mediated between the two sides in early 2002.

The supporters of Alassane Ouattara are mainly members of the northern Muslim communities, whereas the supporters of Laurent Gbagbo are mainly members of the southern Christian communities. In October 2000, Presidential elections were held in the Ivory Coast. Prior to these elections, a new constitution had been approved through a constitutional referendum. The new constitution stipulated that both parents of a presidential candidate had to be born within the country. As a result, the Supreme Court disqualified around 70 percent of the presidential candidates. Alassane Ouattara, representing the Rassemblement des Républicains de Côte d’Ivoire (RDR), was one of the disqualified presidential candidates. What is more, when early election results suggested that the presidency would be won by opposition leader Laurent Gbagbo and his political party the Front Populaire Ivoirien (FPI), President Robert Gueï tried to clench to power by dissolving the Electoral Commission and proclaiming himself the new president. Laurent Gbagbo subsequently called upon his supporters to protests Gueï’s attempt to clench to power. After severe clashes between protesters and Security Forces, Gueï was forced to leave the country and Laurent Gbagbo assumed the role of president. In the immediate aftermath, the RDR organized demonstrations and demanded new elections in which Alassane Ouattara could also participate. Laurent Gbagbo refused new elections. This led to clashes between the supporters of the two political rivals in the streets of Abidjan. In response to the clashes in Abidjan, a mediation committee comprised of government representatives, RDR officials, and members of the security forces was formed in late October in order to ease tensions ahead of the parliamentary elections which were scheduled to take place on 10 December 2000. French and American diplomats worked behind the scene to help the mediation committee broker a deal. By 9 December 2000, a day before the parliamentary elections, the mediation committee finally came to an agreement. This agreement entailed that the government led by Gbagbo would postpone the parliamentary elections by a week to allow the RDR to appeal the earlier Supreme Court ruling to exclude Alassane Ouattara from running. In return, the RDR agreed to postpone their planned boycott of the elections and call off all street protests. However, instead of announcing the agreement on national television as agreed, Interior Minister Emile Boga Doudou rejected the plan at the last minute and publicly declared that elections would go ahead as scheduled.

The Jie and Matheniko Karimojong attended a peace meeting mediated by Ugandan army forces at the office of the Kotido Resident Commissioner on 10 July 2006. The talks focused on concluding a cessation of hostilities and the disarmament campaign of the government forces in the area. The peace meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. The army later accused the two groups of not adhering to the accord.
Peace talks between the Jie, Matheniko Karimojong, and Bokora led to the conclusion of a ceasefire in July 2006, but this ceasefire already broke down in August 2006.

The Kotido Peace Initiative (KOPEIN) and the Karamoja Agro-Pastoral Development Program (KADP) facilitated peace talks between the Bokora, Matheniko, and Jie at Kalosarich in Kotido district in November 2009.

The armed conflict between the predominately Muslim Hausa and the predominantly Christian Atyap, also known as Kataf, in 1992 started as a dispute over farmland. The violence began in the town of Zango-Kataf and quickly spread to the central city of Kaduna State. It was limited to two episodes of violence, with the first starting on 6 February 1992 and the second episode starting on 18 May 1992. Both episodes only lasted a few days. Following the outbreak of violence in February 1992, Isa Kaita, a former Muslim federal minister, and the Archbishop of Kaduna, Peter Jatau, organized meetings to help the conflict parties resolve their conflict.

In an effort to ensure durable peace between the two ethnic groups, the Kaduna State Government facilitated a peace meeting between them. This meeting resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement on 14 November 1994. As part of this agreement, both ethnic groups proposed seven names for the creation of a fourteen-member reconciliation committee. This committee was inaugurated on 15 December 1994 in Igabi House Lodge, Kawo, Kaduna State.

On 11 August 1995, the military governor of Kaduna State, Colonel Ja’afaru Isa, convened a meeting with interest groups, opinion leaders, traditional chiefs, religious leaders, politicians and non-governmental organizations. The meeting resulted in the signing of an agreement addressing the armed conflict of 1992. The agreement stated that the Katafs would return to the Hausa the land they had confiscated, while the Hausa committed to support the candidature of the Kataf people for an autonomous chiefdom.
third_party: local government; community leaders; traditional leaders; religious leaders; local NGO

description: In 2004, the Nigerian government set up multiple peace committees to resolve the Atyap and Hausa conflict. One of the committees was led by the Emir of Zaria, Alhaji Shehu Idris. Former military governor of Kaduna State Ja’afaru Isa served as mediator during one of the outbreaks of violence, managing to mediate a ceasefire.

Atyap and Hausa representatives were part of a peace effort in March 2016, which brought communities together from five Local Government Areas (LGAs) in South Kaduna, namely Sanga, Kachia, Kaura, Zangon Kataf and Jema’a. The peace meeting led to the signing of the Kafachan Peace Declaration on 23 March 2016. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) facilitated this peace effort. The declaration calls for lasting peace in South Kaduna State and was signed by a wide range of actors, including representatives of development and cultural associations, traditional councils, elders, youth, women, and religious leaders.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: The label Arab tribe is a broad definition capturing a wide variety of tribes and ethnicities residing in Mali and other northern African countries. The people that fall under the category of the Arab tribe are mostly nomadic herdsmen and traders. The Kounta is a Berber-Arab ethnic group that inhabits northern Mali. The Kounta claims to be descendants of Arab traders, and have been present in northern Mali and Mauritania since the eleventh century. In July 1999, Arab and Kounta fighters clashed in the Gao region. The conflict was triggered by local elections that took place in June 1999 in which both sides sought to gain power. The Malian government dispatched mediators that shuttled between the conflict parties in July 1999. By the end of July 1999, the government of Mali and several local leaders mediated between the conflict parties. This led to a peace agreement specified several disarmament and compensation measures that the two leaders on the Arab side, Ould Mataly and Collonel Ould Meydou, had to fulfil, as well called for a conference to further identify the underlying causes for armed clashes in the region. Colonel Meydou had to return to his barracks with the national Malian army. Meydou also had to return one pick up truck to the Tarkint gendarme base, two trucks to security forces in Gao, and repay stolen government funds worth of $33,000. Mataly was required to return 4 barrels of diesel fuel, one radio, one hunting rifle, 500 sheep, 70 camels, 111 cartons of Marlboro cigarettes, and a Toyota pick-up.

In spite of the conclusion of the peace agreement, clashes between Arab and Kounta resumed in August 1999. In response, the Minister of Interior visited the region in August in order to mediate between the conflict parties and restore order.  This effort failed, as clashes over territory division and control between the groups broke out again in October 1999. Yet, no more fighting took place after October and Colonel Ould Meydou returned to his barracks with the national Malian army.
However, tensions remained. Malian President Amadou Toumani Toure personally mediated between the conflict parties in 2003 to try to prevent a relapse to armed conflict.

Armed conflict between Fulani herders and Tarok farmers in Plateau State mainly revolved around land, as Fulani let their cattle graze on Tarok farmland. Armed clashes erupted in Wase and Shendam districts of southeastern Plateau State February 2004. In May 2004, Chris Alli was selected as an Interim Administrator by President Obasanjo and tasked with leading peace efforts in Plateau State. Alli subsequently organized multiple efforts to resolve ongoing conflicts between Christians and Muslims, which included the conflict between Fulani and Tarok. During the state of emergency, Chris Alli launched a six-month Plateau Peace Program to bring lasting peace to the area. The plan included meetings between religious, ethnic and community leaders and the government. Several communities in the Wase Local Government Area, including Fulani and Tarok, took part in a peace meeting in the conference room of Rayfield Government House in Jos on 24 June 2004. The participants concluded the conference with issueing a communiqué that was signed by the communities at the end of the peace meeting.
The Wase local government mediated between the conflict parties in January 2013. While no agreement was concluded, both sides pledged to stop the violence and live together peacefully.

In June 2016, Fulani and Tarok representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

The commissioner of Terekeka county, Juma Ali Malou, mediated between the conflict parties at a peace conference on 21 and 22 January 2008. The representatives from Bor and Mudari communities mainly discussed issues related to peaceful coexistence and sharing of grazing land. The conference did not end with a written agreement, but the parties agreed to form a committee to resolve conflict issues.

Heavy clashes took place between the Bor Dinka and Mundari in early May 2017. UNDP and UNMISS subsequently facilitated a peace conference between the conflict parties in Juba on 21 and 22 May. The peace conference was witnessed by the security advisor to the President, and the Governors of Jubek, Terekeka and Jonglei in Juba. The delegations from the Dinka Bor and Mundari communities issued a joint communiqué in which they agreed to a cessation of hostilities, and empower the Commissioners of the border Counties of Gemeiza, Bor South and Mangalla to restrain the youth and mitigate the threats to security in their areas.

However, in May 2009, fighting in the Jebel Lado area resulted in at least 40 fatalities. On 11 May 2009, Mundari and Bari representatives met for peace talks mediated by the Peace Commission Chairman Louis Lobong. The United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS) Civil Affairs section accompanied the County Commissioner to meet representatives of the conflict parties to prepare for a peace conference. The conference was postponed several times when the Bari refused to participate in the conference unless their raided cows were returned to them first. Neverthless, pressure from paramount chiefs from all the six counties in the state persuaded Bari leaders to attend a peace meeting. Tensions were high and the first round of meetings were not a success, but subsequent meetings on neutral ground at UNMIS proved to be successful and led to an agreement.

The Bari is an agriculturalists ethnic group that live in the far south in southern Sudan, close to the border of Uganda. The Mundari are a pastoralist ethnic group border the Bari to the north. Relations between the two communities have historically been peaceful because the groups do not share the same land. However, the Mundari moved a large number of cattle into the Bari area as a result of the intensification of conflict in the Equatoria province in the 1980s and 1990s. Several violent clashes subsequently took place due to Mundari’s cattle destroying Bari crops. Relations improved again following mediation efforts between leaders of the two communities conducted by several NGOs, including Oxfam Novib.
On 2 August 2002, the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) facilitated a peace meeting between the Dinka, Nuer, and Shiluk from the Upper Nile in Abwong.

Tensions between the groups increased following the conclusion of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) in 2005. Both groups claimed that Malakal, the capital of the Upper Nile province, belongs to them. Fighting in Malakal town in January 2009 resulted in at least 70 deaths. The SPLM/A deployed soldiers in the region to contain the fighting. In response to this outbreak of violence, a reconciliation committee of community leaders, headed by the governor of Upper Nile, Galwak Deng, was formed to help restore peace between the Ngok Dinka and the Shiluk in January 2009. The conflict parties clashed again in September and November 2009. The Shilluk were allegedly supported by the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-Democratic Change (SPLM/A-DC) led by Lam Akol.

While they had once formed an alliance, Hizbul Islam and Al-Shabaab clashed on 1 October 2009 in Kismayo. Earlier in the year, in May 2009, the two armed groups had conducted a joint attack on the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) in Mogadishu. However, tensions over which group controlled the port city of Kismayo lodged a wedge between the groups and eventually led to an armed conflict. On 6 October 2009, already five days after the fighting had started, Sheikh Hassan Dahir Aweys of Hizbul Islam tried to negotiate a ceasefire between his group and Al-Shabaab. On 8 October, the two sides agreed to cease their hostilities, with both sides committing to solve future disputes through the Islamic courts.

With tensions still brewing in November 2009, the group’s leaders engaged in a round of secret negotiations between late November and late December 2009. During these negotiations, Al-Shabaab demanded the resignation of Hizbul Islam chairman Sheikh Hassan Aweys. This demand was rejected by Hizbul Islam. The Hizbul Islam delegation, in turn, demanded a power-sharing deal and joint control over Kismayo. This demand was rejected by Al-Shabaab. The negotiations broke down on 28 December.

The conflict parties resumed negotiations in July 2010, with the aim to form a united front against the TFG.  This round of negotiations led to a temporary ceasefire that quickly broken down on 19 July 2010.
Another round of negotiations in August 2010 broke down because of continued disagreement on power-sharing.
On 16 December 2010, Hizbul Islam negotiated its surrender with Al-Shabaab. Hizbul Islam was subsequently disbanded and its fighters were integrated into Al-Shabaab.

In 2007, Andry Rajoelina was elected mayor of Antananarivo. In the subsequent two years, he became an increasingly vocal critic of President Marc Ravalomanana. In January 2009, after Rajoelina called for Ravalomanana to step down, supporters of Andry Rajoelina and Marc Ravalomanana clashed. Opponents of Ravalomanana included the Corps d’Armée des Personnels et des Services Administratif (CAPSAT). The African Union (AU), Southern African Development Community (SADC), United Nations (UN), and Council for Christian Churches collaborated to try and resolve the conflict. On 21 February 2009, these third parties mediated peace talks between Rajoelina and Ravalomanana, but this did not lead to a peace agreement. Instead, Rajoelina announced that he would boycott further talks unless Ravolamanana gave up the presidency. The UN tasked the Council for Christian Churches of Madagascar with organizing a peace conference. However, Rajoelina promised to boycott the initial meeting scheduled for 12 March and the conference itself was ultimately postponed. The fighting between the supporters of Rajoelina and Ravalomanana culminated into Rajoelina supporters removing Ravalomanana from office in 17 March 2009. As a result of this unconstitutional change in power, Madagascar was suspended from the AU.

On 3 April 2009, Rajoelina and Ravalomanana attended a round of negotiations mediated by the UN and the AU. This meeting led to an agreement on a timeline for elections, with a constitutional referendum planned for September 2009 and parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for March and October 2010 respectively.

Another round of negotiations mediated by the UN and the AU was held in Addis Ababa in late April 2009. On 30 April 2009, the AU, Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA), European Union (EU), the Organisation internationale de la Francophonie (OIF), SADC, and the UN created the International Contact Group on Madagascar (ICG-M) in an attempt to promote a resolution to crisis.
On 23 May 2009, the UN mediated another round of peace talks. The conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation council and transitional government during this round of negotiations.
In June 2009, the AU, OIF, SADC, and UN put together a mediation team led by President of Mozambique Joaquim Chissano. A round of negotiations mediated by this mediation team ended on 3 July 2009.
third_party: UN; AU; SADC; Organisation internationale de la Francophonie

description: Rajoelina and Ravalomana, along with former Presidents of Madagascar Didier Ratsiraka and Albert Zafy, met for a first round of negotiations mediated by SADC in Maputo from 5 to 10 August 2009. This led to the signing of the Accord No. 1 de Maputo sur l’Annulation des Charges Relatives aux Evènements de 2002 à Madagascar on 9 August 2009. This power-sharing agreement established the interim Government of National Unity that would lead the country for 15 months until elections. The agreement also included a provision stipulating amnesty for Ravalomana. The agreement did not last because Rajoelina stacked his administration with his own party members, excluding the other actors.
agreement_name: Accord No. 1 de Maputo sur l’Annulation des Charges Relatives aux Evènements de 2002 à Madagascar

description: On 4 September 2009, Rajoelina, Ravalomanana, Ratsiraka, and Zafy participated in a peace meeting in Antananarivo.
The second round of peace talks mediated by Chissano took place in Maputo in October 2009.
third_party: UN; AU; SADC; Organisation internationale de la Francophonie

description: From 2 to 5 November 2009, Rajoelina, Ravalomanana, Ratsiraka, and Zafy convened for another round of negotiations mediated by Chissano. This round of talks was in Addis Ababa and led to the conclusion of a peace agreement called the Addis Ababa Additional Act on 6 November 2009.This agreement provided for Rajoelina to remain as temporary president alongside two co-presidents. However, Rajoelina ultimately reneged on the agreement by attempting to stall elections.
third_party: UN; AU; SADC; Organisation internationale de la Francophonie

description: In late April 2010, Rajoelina and Ravalomana took part in a round of negotiations mediated by SADC in Pretoria. South African President Jacob Zuma acted as the chief mediator. These talks did not lead to a peace agreement.That year, the International Contact Group was terminated. Further violating the Addis Ababa Act, Rajoelina hosted a referendum to make himself eligible for the presidency.

In March 2011, a mediation effort by SADC produced the SADC Roadmap. On 17 September 2011, ten of the eleven main Malagasy political groups signed the SADC Roadmap. This roadmap outlined a power-sharing structure. In November and December 2011, appointments to the legislative body and presidential cabinet proceeded under the auspices of the Roadmap.

SADC mediated negotiations between Rajoelina and Ravalomana in the Seychelles in July and August 2012. The two men agreed to a deal that Rajoelina would not run for upcoming elections, but Rajoelina ultimately reneged on this agreement.

A local NGO called Forum, the Local Council responsible for the entire district (LC5), and the Resident District Commissioners (RDC) organized a series of peace conference in late 2000, including a conference in Moroto between 18 and 20 November 2000. The Matheniko Karimojong and Pokot were among the groups that participated in this peace conference.
A traditional peace meeting between the Matheniko Karimojong and the Pokot in Moroto in early 2001 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.
A peace meeting between the Matheniko Karimojong and Pokot, mediated by a traditional Pokot leader, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in November 2005.

The Karimojong and Pokot attended a peace conference in Moroto between 11 and 16 November 1996. Other warring pastoralist groups, including the Kenyan Sabiny and Turkana, also attended this conference. Local government representatives of Kenya and Uganda acted as mediators during this conference.

In 1997, elders from the Karimojong, Pokot, Sabiny, and Turkana collaborated to form the Pokot-Karamojong-Turkana-Sabiny (POKATUSA), a peace organization aimed at bringing an end to the conflicts in Karamoja. POKATUSA collaborated with World Vision and received funding from the United Kingdom. POKATUSA held several peace meetings in 1997.

On 17 November 1998, the Karimojong, Pokot, and Turkana engaged in a round of negotiations at the Namirimbe Guest House in Kampala. Francis Ewaton, a member of parliament for South Turkana, acted as the chief mediator. Kenyan and Ugandan government officials were also attending the conference. The peace conference ended with all sides agreeing to counter the sale of illegal arms.

The Karimojong, Pokot, and Turkana held a peace meeting in Lokichar from 3 to 6 March 2001. This meeting resulted in the communities agreeing to establish a shared radio system to avoid future fighting, as well as an agreement to share local resources.

Another peace meeting was planned to take place in early November 2001, but this meeting was cancelled when the Pokot conducted a cattle raid. In mid-November 2001, the Pokot attended a peace meeting organized by Uganda's Karamojong community in Moroto.

In July 2002, the representatives from POKATUSA organized a peace meeting in order to find a solution for cattle raids and to stop the violence at the shared border between Uganda and Kenya. Those meetings were attended by Kenyan central government officials as well as regional government representatives, who mediated between the different communities.

A round of negotiations, mediated by the Rift Valley Province Provincial Commissioner (PC), was held near Chesegon in September 2002. This round of negotiations ended with one participant being killed.
In 2003, the POKATUSA organized peace meeting between the Pokot, Karimajong, Turkana, and Sabiny tribes. However, this peace effort was interrupted by a Pokot attack, which resulted in 27 casualties.

In November 2005, the Tegla Loroupe Foundation organized a peace forum for representatives of the Pokot, Turkana, and Karamonjong at Mtelo Hall in West Pokot District. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement stipulating an end to cattle rustling on 28 November 2005.

On 11 September 2010, the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong met at a cross-border peace meeting in Moroto. The peace committee members from the Amudat, Nakapiripirit, Moroto, and Kaabong districts, participated in this peace meeting.

The Kween Women in Peace Initiative (Kwipi) facilitated a week of peace talks between the Karimojong, Matheniko, the Pokot, and Sabiny in Suam in the Bukwo District from 20 to 27 May 2011. The peace talks were mediated by Action Aid Uganda. The peace talks did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement, but the tribes recognized the need to end cattle rustling.

On 22 January 2012, a cross-border peace meeting was organized by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) in Moroto with the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong. The Karimojong youth requested the Kenyan government to disarm the Turkana and Pokot. The peace meeting did not lead to the conclusion of a peace agreement.
On 9 August 2002, the Iteso and Karimojong attended a multi-district peace meeting between representatives of the Katakwi, Moroto, and Nakapiripirit.

Around 19 members of parliament from Iteso and Karimojong convened at a peace conference in Entebbe on 11 November 2002. This peace conference received funding from the German government and was mediated by the Centre for Conflict Resolution (CECORE).
On 30 November 2002, Germany’s Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) collaborated with CECORE to host a three-day peace meeting involving the Iteso and Karimojong in Mbale.

The conflict parties engaged in a peace conference mediated by DANIDA, the Karamoja Agro-pastoral Development Program (KADP), and Uganda Human Rights Commission in Moroto from 1 to 2 July 2004.   The Iteso and Karimojong conducted a traditional reconciliation ceremony in late 2004.
The two communities also engaged in a peace meeting in the Katakwi district in July 2004.
In late July 2004, another round of peace talks was held in Magoro, which ended with both the Karimijong and Iteso requesting government support in establishing mobile courts.

The Dodoth and Toposa frequently clash in the context of cattle raids in the Karamoja region in Uganda. The Turkana, Dodoth, Jie and Matheniko engaged in peace talks in Kalapata Dodoth county in the Kotido District on 2 September 2000. Kenyan government officials acted as mediators during the talks. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.. This agreement formalized a truce and specified grazing rights.

Oxfam and the Ugandan government mediated peace talks between the Dodoth and Turkana in Kotidobe in early 2003. The talks focused on security issues, but also focused on building a shared road that could promote peaceful relations between the conflict groups. This road would be completed in July 2005.
Negotiations mediated by USAID, KOPEIN, and Riam Riam led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 21 July 2005.
In December 2005,  the USAID-led initiative mediated discussions between the Dodoth and Turkana. This led to the conclusion of a comprehensive Provisional Peace Agreement.
The Dodoth and Turkana met for another round of talks in Kamion in February 2006. The KOPEIN, Lotus Kenya Action for Development (LOKADO), and Pax Christi facilitated these peace talks.
third_party: local NGO; Lotus Kenya Action for Development (LOKADO); Pax Christi

description: KOPEIN mediated a round of peace talks between the conflict parties in July 2006, which led to the signing of the Nawuountos Peace Agreement on 26 July 2006.

The Jie, Dodoth, Turkana, Toposa, and Didinga engaged in peace talks in Kapoeta on 13 May 2008. These talks were facilitated by Riam Riam Turkana and the Karamoja Agro-pastoral Development Program (KADP).

Between 5 and 9 June 2008, East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Christi, Intervida World Alliance, and Wilde Ganzen organized a four-day peace conference in Kapoeta in southern Sudan. This conference was mediated by Seeds of Peace in Africa (SOPA). The Acholi, Buya, Dodoth, Dongiro (Ethiopia), Jie, Kachipo, Lokir (Sudan), Lotuko, Matheniko (Uganda), Murile, Theuso, Toposa, and Turkana (Kenya) attended the conference. Although no formal agreement was reached, the participants agreed to establish independent peace committees and promote coexistence via cross-community activities.
third_party: East African Safari Air Express; IKV Pax Christi; Intervida World Alliance; Wilde Ganzen

description: Local government authorities mediated a peace meeting between the Karimojong, Turkana, and Dodoth in West Turkana in 2009.
SOPA and IKV Pax Christi facilitated a peace meeting between Dodoth and Turkana women in Kaabong in 2009.
third_party: Seeds of Peace Africa; IKV Pax Christi

description: In April 2001, the Dodoth and Jie, along other comunal groups, attended a round of peace talks in Karamoja to end ongoing armed violence. The leaders of the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire at these peace talks.

The Pokot-Karamojong-Turkana-Sabiny (POKATUSA), a peace organization that had been set up in 1997, mediated peace talks between the Jie and Dodoth in December 2001. World Vision and the Catholic Diocese World were also involved as mediators during these talks. The peace talks led to a truce between the Jie and Dodoth.
World Vision and local government officials mediated between the Dodoth and Jie at the headquarters of Jie county in Karamoja on 28 October 2003.
The Dodoth and Jie reached a peace agreement during a round of negotiations in late 2006.

The Jie, Dodoth, Turkana, Toposa, and Didinga engaged in peace talks in Kapoeta on 13 May 2008. These talks were facilitated by Riam Riam Turkana and the Karamoja Agro-pastoral Development Program (KADP).

Between 5 and 9 June 2008, East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Christi, Intervida World Alliance, and Wilde Ganzen organized a four-day peace conference in Kapoeta in southern Sudan. This conference was mediated by Seeds of Peace in Africa (SOPA). The Acholi, Buya, Dodoth, Dongiro (Ethiopia), Jie, Kachipo, Lokir (Sudan), Lotuko, Matheniko (Uganda), Murile, Theuso, Toposa, and Turkana (Kenya) attended the conference. Although no formal agreement was reached, the participants agreed to establish independent peace committees and promote coexistence via cross-community activities.
third_party: East African Safari Air Express; IKV Pax Christi; Intervida World Alliance; Wilde Ganzen

description: Leaders of the Dodoth and Jie met for peace talk in Kacheri on 21 June 2008.
On 9 August, the two sides met for another round of peace talks in Rengen.
On 15 November 2008, the Dodoth and Jie attended a peace meeting mediated by local peace committees in Loyoro.

Members of the Dodoth and Jie communities convened for peace talks led by the Dodoth Agro-Pastoral Development Organisation and the Kotido Peace Initiative on 25 July 2009. This meeting concluded with the communities agreeing to corral their cattle together at night. Furthermore, further negotiations were planned to establish a joint security commission.
On 12 June 2010, local groups in the Kaabong district convened for a peace meeting aimed at discussing disarmament. The Dodoth and Jie participated in this meeting.

The Karamoja Peace and Development Agency, Karamoja Peace Initiative, the Dodoth Agro-Pastoral Development Organization, Mercy Corps-Uganda, and CARITAS mediated peace talks between the Dodoth and the Jie in 2011, which led to the conclusion of the Moruitit Resolution.
The Ugandan government, KOPEIN, and the Karimojong Action Research Team mediated peace talks between the Dodoth and Jie on 9 August 2013. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.
The Dodoth, Jie, and Matheniko engaged in peace talks in July 2014 that led to the conclusion of the Moruitit Agreement. This agreement, among others, outlines the punishments for cattle raiding.

On 21 September 1998, the Bokora Karimojong and Matheniko Karimojong met for negotiations in Moroto and concluded a peace agreement that requested a government intervention for disarmament. However, the truce was already broken on 28 September 2000.

A local NGO called Forum, the Local Council responsible for the entire district (LC5), and the Resident District Commissioners (RDC) organized a series of peace conference in late 2000, including a conference  in Moroto between 18 and 20 November 2000. The Matheniko and Bokora were among the groups that participated in this peace conference.
In April 2001, elders from the Bokora Karimojong and Matheniko Karimojong participated in another peace meeting that aimed to bring an end to fighting in the Karamoja region.
On 21 September 2008, the Bokora and Matheniko met in Moroto district to attend a peace meeting organized by the Karamoja Agro-Pastoral Development Program (KADP).

A dispute between two peanut farmers escalated into armed conflict between the Moba and Chakosi in 1991. On 1 November 1991, in an effort to resolve the conflict between the Moba and Tschosski, the Interior Minister of Togo, Alphonse Masseme, traveled to the conflict region to mediate between the conflict parties.

Riek Machar proposed a different candidate than Paulino Matip for the gubernatorial elections in Unity State in December 1997. Since Matip’s forces were in control of most the oil-rich territory in Unity state, he saw losing political power in Unity as a significant threat to his business interests. This triggered Paulino Matip to try and remove Riek Machar from power and assume the leadership of the South Sudan Defense Force (SSDF). Since this attempt was unsuccessful, Matip decided to create the South Sudan Unity Movement/Army (SSUM/A) and continue to fight the SSDF. The Sudanese government supported Matip and his SSUM/A fighters, allowing the SSUM/A to advance deep into Western upper Nile to clear the area for oil exploration. Sudanese vice-president Ali Osmn Taha and the governor of Unity State Taban Deng Gai mediated between the conflict parties. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 2 September 1998. While the mediators announced that all differences between Machar and Matip had been resolved, fighting continued. The SSUM/A gained the upper hand on the battlefield. This led to a sidelining of Machar within the SSDF. Machar and forces loyal to him were excluded from the SSDF, after which Paulino Matip was taken back in as the Commander in Chief of the SSDF.

In August 1991, a faction within the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army (SPLM/A) led by Riek Machar and Lam Akol tried to overthrow the SPLM/A leader John Garang. The coup was unsuccessful, so Machar and Akol formed the SPLM/A-Nasir, named after the town where they set up their headquarters. The SPLM/A-Nasir fighters were soon joined by the government-backed Anyanya II, which consisted of a group of Bul Nuer from Western Upper Nile led by led by Paulino Matip and a group of Lou Nuer led by Yohannes Yoal. From this point onwards, the SPLM/A-Nasir received extensive support from the Sudanese government. While the SPLM/A leadership mobilized the titweng or gatweng (cattle guards) of the Dinka, the SSDF mobilized the militia known as the decbor or White Army. This greatly intensified the ethnic divisions in the conflict. On 14 September 1991, a civil society group, referring to themselves as the People of Peace group invited the rival factions of the SPLM/A to negotiations aimed at reconciliation between them. Both sides agreed to travel to Nairobi for negotiations.

The delegations arrived in Nairobi on 30 September 1991. The Principal Secretary of the Kenyan Ministry of Foreign Affairs subsequently started to shuttle between the two sides between 30 September and 3 October 1991. The SPLM/A-Nasir delegation led by Lam Akol demanded the release of all political prisoners, but John Garang refused this demand. The mediation effort broke down, when John Garang left Nairobi on 3 October.

On 8 October 1991, the People for Peace group shuttled once more between the SPLM/A-Nasir delegation and the SPLM/A delegation that had remained in Nairobi when Garang had left. The SPLM/A delegation indicated that it was willing to enter negotiations, but only without any preconditions. The full SPLM/A delegation arived on 29 October, ready to negotiate with the Nasir faction. The two sides shared their position papers with the mediators on 2 November, but it was not until 22 November that negotiations started. These negotiations were mediated by the Church Group, which consisted of three bishops from Sudan and four members of the Nairobi Peace Group. The conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire at negotiations in Nairobi on 26 November 1991. The Nairobi talks dragged on without making any progress on how to resolve the conflicts. The talks were eventually adjourned on 16 December 1991 because the Christmas season approached.
third_party: Kenya; religious leaders;  local peace committee

description: From early 1992 up until April 1992, various rounds of inter-SPLM/A talks in Nairobi were facilitated by Nairobi Peace Group and the Church Group. However, when it became clear that the two factions would not reconcile, Nigerian President Babangida decided to revive the plans for the Abuja peace talks, inviting both factions of the SPLM/A to attend.

When the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-William Nyuon faction (SPLM/A-WN) joined the SPLM/A-Nasir in mid-1993, the name of the SPLM/A-Nasir changed into SPLM/A-united. On 27 May 1993, the SPLM/A and the SPLM/A-united held negotiations in Nairobi. Donald Petterson, the US ambassador to Sudan, mediated the negotiations. The conflict parties agreed on a ceasefire and a demilitarized safe haven where the thousands of starving southerners could receive food aid.

In another attempt to reconcile the southern rebel movement, the former President Jimmy Carter mediated between the SPLM/A and the SPLM/A-united in Washington in October 1993. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 22 October 1993.
Another round of negotiations between the conflict parties was held in Nairobi in early January 1994. This round of negotiations resulted in the renewal of the ceasefire concluded in October 1993.

No negotiations or mediation took place in 1995. On 10 February 1995, Riek Machar announced that in pursuit of reconciliation with the SPLM/A, the SPLM/A-united issued a unilateral ceasefire. Machar further stated that a National Reconciliation and Peace Committee set up in 1994 would continue to work towards concluding a non-aggression pact between the SPLM/A and the SPLM/A-united.

In February-March 1999, a large number of Dinka and Nuer clans agreed to a ceasefire at the Wunlit Reconciliation Conference. This somewhat reduced tensions between the Dinka dominated SPLM/A and the Nuer dominated SSDF. Crucially, the Sudanese government terminated its support to the SSDF in late 1999. In addition, many political leaders among the SSDF became increasingly frustrated with the lack of implementation of the Khartoum agreement between the Sudanese government and the SSDF which had been concluded in 1997. These changing circumstances explain why some leaders of the SSDF and the SPLM/A in the Upper Nile decided to build on the peace conference in Wunlit and initiate a peace meeting between the SSDF, the SPLM/A, and Simon Gatwec’s militia in Akobo on 18 August 1999. This meeting led to the signing of a ceasefire between the conflict parties.

It was, however, not until 2006 that true reconciliation between the SPLM/A and SSDF only take place. Following the death of SPLM/A leader John Garang in a helicopter crash in July 2005, Salva Kiir assumed the leadership of the SPLM/A. Kiir subsequently initiated negotiations with SSDF leader Paulino Matip. This led to the Juba Declaration on Unity and Integration on 8 January 2006. The Declaration laid the basis for unifying rival military forces in South Sudan. The declaration set up a High Political Committee tasked with overseeing the overall implementation of the unity agreement, as well as a Military Technical Committee tasked with the integration of SSDF into the SPLA and its command structures and all its component units including the Joint Integration Units.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration on Unity and Integration

description: Low-intensity conflict between the Beni Halba Baggara and the Salamat Baggara on the one side and the Fur on the other side started in 1987, but heavy armed clashes started in March 1988. Fighting resulted in around 2000 battle-deaths in Darfur in 1989. Fighting was particularly intense in the Jebel Mara area. Tigani Sese, the Governor of Darfur, initiated a peace process in February 1989. He set up a committee composed of 26 members drawn from the ranks of tribal leaders, high ranking civil servants, and army officers. Abdel Raham Baher El Din, the Sultan of Massalit, led this committee. Each side of the conflict had the right to veto any of these members. Between February and May, the members of the mediation team traveled throughout Darfur to try to disengage the conflict parties and prepare for a peace conference in El Fasher in May 1989. In early May, the leaders on both sides agreed on a ceasefire and to attend a peace conference on 15 May 1989.
third_party: local government; local peace committee; government forces; traditional leaders

description: However, this peace conference had to be postponed because the ceasefire broke down on 13 May and fighting continued until 17 May 1989. When the peace conference finally started on 29 May 1989, the prospects for peace seemed bleak, but the military coup on 30 June 1989 had a positive impact on the negotiations. The conflict parties signed the Fur-Arab Reconciliation Agreement on 8 July 1989. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire and the termination of tribal militias, as well as specified the amount of blood money that each side had to pay. The agreement also committed the government to open routs of migration for nomads according standing agreements and maintain a presence to safeguard the rights of both pastoralists and nomads.
third_party: local government; local peace committee; government forces; traditional leaders

description: The Sudanese government facilitated a peace meeting in Zalingei in 1990 to confirm the conflict parties’ commitment.
A peace meeting was held between the Ben Halba and the Fur in Kas in 1991.

The Rizegat Abbala and Zaghawa have a history of armed clashes over water resources and grazing rights, tough these violent disputes are often solved through traditional reconciliation. Armed conflict between the two tribes escalated in 1996. The immediate trigger for this escalation was the division of the El Da’ein locality into new constituencies. Zaghawa leaders subsequently won several key positions in local elections. Angry mobs of Rizegats did not accept these results, burning the ballot boxes in Asalaya town. In addition, the Rizeigat attacked several Zaghawa villages. Some of these attacks took the form of cattle raids, but at least three villages were burnt down completely. Around 15,000 people were displaced in total. Representatives of the Zaghawa and Reizegat signed a ceasefire agreement in October 1996. The governor of South Darfur state, Abdelhalim al-Mutaafi, acted as a mediator during the meeting that led to this ceasefire. The agreement stipulated an end to the fighting, but also called for reconciliation conference to address the conflict issues.

However, fighting continued after this ceasefire. Government officials managed to initiate a mediation effort in March 1997, bringing the conflict parties to a reconciliation conference in El Da’ein between 26 and 31 March 1997, aimed at “the practical coexistence between Rizeigat, Zaghawa and other communities in the area.” At this conference, a council of elders from various communities in Darfur and Kordofan, police officers, magistrates and representatives of the Attorney-General acted as the mediators. A member of the National Islamic Front (NIF) was appointed as the chairman of this council. The members of the council subsequently investigated claims of deaths, injuries, and damage reported by the conflict parties. Based on this investigation they determined the blood money and other forms of compensation members of the conflict parties should pay. The conflict parties accepted this judgment, resulting in the signing of a negotiated settlement at the end of the conference. While fighting by and large stopped, tensions remained because Sudanese government paid half of the blood money the Rizeigat had to pay. This was widely seen by the Zaghawa as a confirmation that the government was not neutral.

President of Chad, Idriss Déby Itno, acted as the chief mediator at tribal mediation forum in Um Jaras from 26 to 29 March 2014. The forum was attended by tribal leaders from Darfur, including the Zaghawa, Rizeigat, Massalit, Ma’alia, Salamat and Ta’isha tribes. Sudanese Vice-President Hassabo Mohamed Abdul Rahman acted as the Joint Chief Mediator. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir joined the forum on 29 March 2014. The forum ended with the participants’ announcement of their full support for peace and peaceful coexistence in Darfur.
Negotiations supported by UNAMID led to a ceasefire between the conflict parties in late December 2016.

The Masalit and the Rizeigat Abbala started to clash as a result of an aggressive assertion of land claims by the Reizegat. The Sudanese government mostly endorsed these land claims. In 1995, the Sudanese government set up a new system of native administration in Darfur. The Masalit’s homeland, which was previously governed by the Masalit Sultan, was divided into thirteen emirates, of which five were assigned to Arab groups such as the Reizegat Abbala and eight to the Masalit. The new Arab emirs subsequently began to evict Masalit from their new emirates. This triggered armed conflict between the two groups, mainly in the area around Geneina town in Western Darfur. Already prior to the outbreak of intense armed conflict, the Sudanese government organized a peace meeting between the conflict parties in 1996. A high-level security delegation traveled to Geneina in March 1998 in an attempt to resolve the conflict. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir decleared a state of emergency in Darfur in December 1998 in response to the many tribal conflicts over scarce grazing land and water. One of the measures taken was to temporarily removed the pro-Masalit state governor from power.

In mid-February 1999, the Khartoum government sent the minister of Federal Relations, Ahmed Ibrahim al-Tahir, and Lieutenant-General Mohamed Ahmed al-Dabi, to the region to mediate and resolve the conflict.

On 26 May 1999, government officials mediated a meeting between the Masalit and the Rizeigat. The meeting focused on financial compensation for the families of the around 300 people killed in early 1999.
The conflict parties concluded a peace accord in early June 1999, following a government sponsored reconciliation meeting. This mediation effort ended the fighting between the two tribes.

President of Chad, Idriss Déby Itno, acted as the chief mediator at tribal mediation forum in Um Jaras from 26 to 29 March 2014. The forum was attended by tribal leaders from Darfur, including the Zaghawa, Rizeigat, Massalit, Ma’alia, Salamat and Ta’isha tribes. Sudanese Vice-President Hassabo Mohamed Abdul Rahman acted as the Joint Chief Mediator. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir joined the forum on 29 March. The forum ended with the participants’ announcement of their full support for peace and peaceful coexistence in Darfur.

Riek Machar, one of the leaders of SPLM/A-United and from a lineage of Nuer spiritual leaders, tried to initiate a peace process between the conflict parties in March 1994. This led to a peace conference between the Lou Nuer and the Jikany Nuer, which was facilitated by the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) in Akabo, along the Ethiopian border, in September 1994. By the time this conference was held, around 1,300 people had been killed, 75,000 heads of cattle had been stolen, and the conflict had spread to Ethiopia. The peace conference in Akabo led to the signing of a peace agreement on 15 September 1994. The Jikany-Lou Peace Agreement committed the conflict parties to maintain peace and security in their respective areas of Jikany and Lou, as well as stipulated the sharing of the use of water, grazing lands, and fishing grounds. In addition to the five hundred delegates that attended the conference, around 9,000 people had travel by foot to Liech State to learn about the agreement.

The NSCC facilitated another peace meeting between the Jikany Nuer and Lou Nuer in Gunyang in July 2001. This led to an agreement on cessation of hostilities and the freedom of movement of Jikany and Lou across each other’s territories.

The Kenyan NGO the Africa Center for Human Advocacy (ACHA) organized a peace meeting betwen the Jikany Nuer and the Lou Nuer in Riang between 1 and 5 March 2004, which led to the signing of a peace agreement.

Some Jinkany Nuer and the Lou Nuer leaders engaged in unofficial peace talks on the sidelines of the UN OCHA-PCI Regional Pastoralist Gathering attended by 300 African pastoralists in Yabello, southern Ethiopia, in July 2006.

When it became clear that an official peace meeting was possible, a meeting was organized in Addis Abba on 20 July 2006. Ethiopian and Sudanese government officials, as well as OCHA staff members, acted as mediators during the talks. The chief of both tribes declared an end to the armed conflict between the Jinkany Nuer and the Lou Nuer at the end of the peace meeting.

Tensions between the Jinkany and the Lou significantly increased in early 2009, especially in Wanding payam. The tensions could be traced back to the operational zones used by the SPLM/A did not match with Sudan’s administrative zones. After a series of negotiations and a joint visit to Wanding by local commissioners from both states, it was decided that the payam’s administration was handed over to Upper Nile state on 9 January 2009. The SPLM/A subsequently forced some Lou to return to Akobo, but many of the settlers remained and land disputes thus continued. Heavy clashes took place between the two tribes in May 2009. The SPLM/A deployed more troops in the Upper Nile, Central Equatoria, and Jonglei in response to the armed fighting. In addition, a reconciliation meeting was held in Unity State in May 2009. UNMISS supported this peace meeting, which was aimed at reaching agreement on grievances linked to compensation, grazing routes, and abductions. The idea was that this peace meeting would lead to an all Jonglei State peace conference in late 2009.

A nine-day peace conference aimed at Dinka-Nuer reconciliation, attended by Eight Dinka and Nuer chiefs from border areas on the east and west banks of the Nile, was held in Lokichokio, Kenya, in June 1998. This conference ended on 10 June 1998 with the signing of the Nuer-Dinka Loki Accord. This peace agreement stipulated an end to hostilities, abductions, cattle raiding, and burning of homesteads.
