The agreement also stipulated free movement between Nuer and Dinka areas, as well as committed the Nuer and Dinka leaders to “pursue all possible means towards a just and lasting peace in the land of Nuer and Dinka.”

The Loki Accord paved the way for the Wunlit Conference in 1999. However, just prior to the Wunlit conference, another smaller conference was held. In January 1999, the Sudanese NGO SUPRAID organized a meeting in Twic Country of Nuer and Dinka leaders in this area. The leader of SUPRIAD, Acuil Malith Banggol, initated the peace meeting through contacting the Paulino Matip, Riek Machar, the local SPLM/A leadership, and several spiritual leaders of the Dinka and Nuer. The conference led to an agreement that committed the Nuer and Dinka in Twic County to end violence and share grazing and fishing grounds.
third_party: local NGO; religious leaders; armed group

description: The New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) mediated peace talks between Dinka and Nuer chiefs in at the Wunlit Reconciliation Conference between 27 February and 8 March 1999. Some 360 delegates were invited from six counties either side of the Nuer-Dinka border of Bahr el Ghazal and Western Upper Nile. The peace conference  led to the signing of an agreement referred to as the Wunlit Dinka Nuer Covenant and Resolutions. This agreement includes provisions on issues related to abductees and displaced people, as well as outlines a mechanism for preventing conflict between Dinka Nuer in grazing lands. The Wunlit Dinka-Nuer Covenant was signed by more than 300 Dinka and Nuer chiefs, community and church leaders, women and youth. Bradbury et al. observe that the “local impact of Wunlit on the West Bank was immediate. Inter-group violence between those who participated in Wunlit ceased. […] Abducted women, children and cattle were returned to their families or bride price was negotiated to legitimize unions between abductors and abductees.”
agreement_name: Wunlit Dinka Nuer Covenant and Resolutions

description: Several other peace meetings organized by the NSCC were held following the Wunlit Reconciliation Conference. In June 1999, the NSCC facilitated another peace meeting between the Nuer and the Dinka, this time also involving the Murle, in Lokichoki. The conflict parties adopted a resolution that committed them to achieve peace in their communities.

The NSCC, this time together with the SPLM/A, organized another peace meeting between the Dinka and the Nuer in Yirol between 25 and 30 September 1999. The meeting was attended by twenty-three representatives from the eleven counties and provinces along the border areas of Bahr el Ghazal and Western Upper Nile regions. The purpose of the meeting was to follow up on the Wunlit Conference. Telar Deng, the Peace Council Chairman, acted as the mediator. The conference ended with the signing of the Dinka Nuer West Bank Peace Council Communication on 30 September 1999, which outlines how specific items from the Wunlit Reconciliation Conference are implemented, such as issues related to missing people, abductees, and cattle rustling.
agreement_name: Dinka Nuer West Bank Peace Council Communication

description: The NSCC continued to facilitate peace meetings building on the Wunlit Reconciliation Conference in 2000. Dinka and Nuer leaders met at a meeting organized by the NSCC in Ganyliel on 5 April.
Another meeting was held in Wunlit on 7 April, which led to the reaffirmation of the Wunlit Covenant.

Representatives of the Anyuak, Dinka, Jie, Kachipo, Murle and Nuer organized the East Bank People-to-People Peace and Reconciliation Conference in Liliir in Bor County in May 2000. This meeting was the first multi-ethnic meeting to take place on the East Bank.  SPLM/A leader John Garang supported the peace conference because it could potentially lead to a return of Dinka to Bor, but Nuer leader Riek Machar objected to the choice of Liliir as the site of the peace conference. Due to bad weather and Riek Machar’s opposition to the conference, only half of the 200 anticipated delegates participated. The participants that did attend signed the Liliir Covenant on 15 May 2000. This peace agreement calls for an end to all hostilities, an amnesty, return of abductees, freedom of movement, and the return of displaced people. However, some contentious issues relating to borders and resources remained unaddressed.

The NSCC organized another peace meeting between the Dinka and the Nuer in Wulu in November 2000. At the end of this conference, the Nuer and Dinka leaders concluded that the agreements reached at Wunlit, Waat and Liliir “had brought a new hope to the people and that the peace process was becoming a collective, southern-wide expression for unity and peace.” The participants confirmed their commitment to these agreements.

The West Bank Peace Council organized a peace meeting between Dinka and Nuer leaders on 5 April 2001. The goal of the meeting was to defuse tensions between the Dinka and Nuer, which materialized as a result SPLM/A military support provided to Bul Nuer Commander Peter Gatdet, formerly Paulino Matip’s Deputy, against the pro-government militia led by Nuer Commander, Peter Paar. In early 2001, the SPLM/A provided logistical support facilitating an attack by Gatdet on Paar’s forces in Nyal. This SPLM/A support was viewed by many Nuer as a Dinka attack on Nuer territory. The West Bank Peace Council mediated between the Dinka and Nuer leaders, but failed to involve the SPLM/A in the talks.

US church organizations brought a group of Dinka and Nuer leaders to Washington DC for a peace meeting on 12 and 13 January 2002. The meeting ended with a confirmation of a commitment to the outcomes of the Wunlit, Waat and Liliir peace conferences, as well as a call for southern unity.
On 2 August 2002, the NSCC facilitated a peace meeting between the Dinka, Nuer, and Shiluk from the Upper Nile in Abwong.

In 2003, the NSCC facilitated a peace meeting between the Dinka and the Nuer from the Upper Nile in Renk county. This led to a resolution that stipulated a ceasefire and called upon the leaders to provide better social services.
The regional Government of Southern Sudan mediated between Dinka and Nuer leaders at a peace meeting in Poktap in December 2005.

A peace meeting between the Dinka and the Nuer led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 15 May 2009. The agreement stipulated comprehensive disarmament, return of looted cattle to rightful owners, consultative sharing of resources, stationing of law enforcement units at strategic locations between the tribes, peaceful resolutions of tribal conflicts, and a cessation of prevailing hostilities. This ceasefire was concluded in the context of a Dinka / Nuer peace and reconciliation conference convened by the Jonglei State government in Bor town. UNMIS supported this conference.
Nevertheless, tensions somewhat abated when the Paar-Gatdet hostilities ended through direct negotiations between the military commanders themselves in mid-2011.

Nuer and Dinka representatives attended a two day peace conference in Unity State capital Bentiu on 11 and 12 September 2012. County commissioners and chiefs from Unity State attended the meeting, which focused on preventing cattle raiding in Unity State. The meeting ended with a vow to work towards establishing better relations between the different communities in Unity State. The conference was funded by USAID.

A peace conference, mediated by traditional leaders and government officials, was held in Duk Padiet area of Jonglei state on 13 and 16 November 2017. The conference was supported by Catholic Relief Service (CRS). The Dinka and Nuer representatives agreed to share water and grazing points peacefully by forming community police units and report to relevant authorities.
third_party: traditional leaders; local government; Catholic Relief Service (CRS)

description: The national NGO Assistance Mission for Africa, with support from the Dutch NGO PAX, facilitated a peace conference between the Dinka of the Yirol and Amongpiny areas and the Nuer of the Payinjiar area between 14 and 18 May 2018. This conference was the product of a peace effort that had been initated as early as 2015, when the Amongpiny commissioner, a government official, approached the Panyijar commissioner, a SPLA-IO official, to initiate a chiefs-to-chiefs peace process aimed at reconciliation between the Dinka in Amongpiny and the Nuer in Panyijar. The peace conference in May 2018 was attended by a total of 40 participants, largely comprised of community and border chiefs, women leaders and youth leaders. The conference resulted in the signing of 14 resolutions, which stipulated, among others, the freedom of movement for civilians and a commitment not to raid each other.

UNMISS supported a Wau, Tonj and Gogrial tri-state peace conference aimed at ending violence between Dinka and Lou Nuer communities in the Kuajena area. The conference resulted in the conclusion of a number of resolutions, including an immediate cessation of hostilities.

Following clashes early in November, the Awlad Zeid and the Zaghawa held a peace conference in El Geneina on 17 November 2016. The governor of West Darfur acted as the mediator at this conference.The negotiations led to an agreement. It was agreed that the implementation of the reconciliation agreement would be guaranteed jointly by authorities of West Darfur and the Wadi. The agreement also specified the compensation for the dead and for the stolen items must be paid.

The Awlad Omran and the Awlad al-Zuid sub-groups of the Misseriya tribe clashed in July 1993. The conflict was the result of a man seeking to marry a women from the other clan, but he was rejected. The fighting resulted in more than 100 deaths. A peace conference, which was also attended by local authorities, was held in August 1993.

Following the discovery of oil in their respective areas, the Awlad Omran and the Awlad al-Zuid clashed again in 2014 in the context of a land conflict. Local leaders organized a reconciliation conference between the Awlad Omran and the Awlad al-Zuid clans in En Nahud on 20 November 2014, but did not lead an agreement.
The leaders of the Awlad Omran and the Awlad al-Zuid signed a reconciliation accord in Ed Daein on 15 February 2016.

Lagunya and Webta are competing taxi companies in Cape Town that began to clash in 1991. Lagunya had held a monopoly on the market, but Webta became a strong competitor with financial support from white businessmen. Talks between the Lagunya and Webta led to the signing of the Ten Point Plan in March 1991. This agreement accounted for the distribution of routes and permits among other issues. Moreover, the agreement created the Taxi Crisis Co-ordinating Committee (TCCC), which was initiated by on 1 April 1991. However, in early April, Webta withdrew from the agreement and fighting resumed.
Another round of negotiations was initiated in late April in response to the renewed fighting, but these talks broke down on 2 June 1991.
Another round of negotiations between Lagunya and Webta in July 1991 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.
A round of negotiations on 27 August 1991 failed.
On 10 October, the Webta-Lagunya Peace Committee was established and a peace meeting was held on 13 October 1991.

The two taxi companies conducted another round of negotiations on 31 January 1992. Lagunya and Webta merged into the Cape Organization for a Democratic Taxi Association (Codeta)  on 8 March 1992. This ended the conflict.
NUM and Uwusa clashed at a gold mine in Johannesburg in March 1995. On 8 March 1995, the South African Police Service (SAPS) mediated peace talks between NUM and Uwusa.

NUM and Uwusa clashed at the Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd’s Leeudoorn mine in Johannesburg on 16 August 1996. A round of negotiations took place in late August 1996. Both conflict parties and the mine company participated in these talks. In response to the violence, President Nelson Mandela initiated a judicial commission of inquiry on 12 September 1996.

As the conflict continued from into 1998, Nbikande called for peace talks, but ANC leaders refused. In July 1998, in response to violence between the two sides, the South Africa National Defence Force company was deployed. On 15 July 1998, ANC and UDM leaders met for peace talks mediated by the provincial safety and security portfolio committee in Richmond. Members of the army, the KwaZulu Natal Minister of Safety and Security, the provincial commissioner, and the mayor of Richmond also acted as mediators. The round of negotiations broke down without any agreement.
Two murders triggered armed fighting between the Mangweni and Mgodini clans in Loskop in October 1993. In response, security forces intervened and local leaders mediated between the conflict parties.

The United Democratic Front (UDF) and Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) shared the same goal of ending Apartheid in South Africa. However, the UDF and IFP disagreed on a range of issues, including on the use of violence and cooperation with the African National Congress (ANC). The UDF frequently aligned with the ANC. In addition, control over land divided the groups. In March 1989, a local peace committee was established in Ntuzuma with members of the UDF, IFP and the Coalition of South African Trade Unions (COSATU). The UDF, IFP, and COSATU engaged in peace talks between July and October 1989, but this peace effort failed.
The ANC and IFP engaged in a round of bilateral negotiations in Durban on 29 January 1991, which led to the conclusion of a joint declaration.
Another round of peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 18 February 1991.

In April 1991, the prospect for reconciliation between the ANC and IFP turned bleak again when the ANC alleged that the South African government led by President F. W. de Kerk assisted the IFP. In late June 1991, the ANC, IFP, and the South African government attended a peace meeting to discuss ending armed clashes.

On 14 September 1991, the National Peace Convention was held. The ANC, the IFP, and the South African government were among the 27 groups that signed the National Peace Accord following the National Peace Convention. This agreement, among others, stipulated to end violence through the establishment of local peace committees (LPCs). The Wilgespruit Fellowship Centre’s Negotiation and Community Conflict Program tried to initiate a peace process in early 1991. The Wilgespruit Fellowship invited the IFP and ANC to a joint-research workshop in March 1991, but only the IFP showed up to the workshop. Representative of both the IFP and the ANC showed up to other rounds of workshops organized throughout the rest of the year. This paved the way for direct negotiations between the IFP and the ANC in 1993.
The ANC and IFP convened for a round of peace talks in Natal on 15 January 1993. However, fighting between the ANC and IFP continued the following week.

Desmond Tutu convinced the conflict parties to engage in bilateral peace talks in Johannesburg starting on 23 June 1993. This meeting was the first time the party leaders, Nelson Mandela of the ANC and Chief Mangosuthu Buthelez of the IFP, met in two years. The conflict parties agreed to implement joint peace measures during this round of peace talks. This round of peace talks was suspended on 6 July.
Another round of peace talks started in Johannesburg on 14 July 1993.
The ANC and the IFP agreed to a ceasefire on 22 July 1993. However, this ceasefire broke down the next week.
On 7 August 1993, the youth organizations for the ANC and IFP met for a peace meeting in Natal, which led to the declaration of a cessation of hostilities. However, fighting continued.

The next round of negotiations took place on 25 May 1995 in Cape Town. Both parties indicated a willingness to take part in a second round aimed at discussing issues related to political powers in the provinces.

Peace talks between the ANC and IFP were organized by a committee from the local government of the KwaZulu-Natal province in late January 1996. Nelson Mandela attempted initiate peace talks on 15 March, but he was unsuccessful.
Another round of negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in May 1996.
Peace talks beteween ANC and IFP representatives in KwaZulu-Natal province led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on local issues in this province in June 1996.

In July 1996, the ANC and IFP, along with other political groups such as the Democratic Party (DP) and Minority Front, engaged in negotiations on political power sharing in Durban in the KwaZulu-Natal province. These negotiations were held in Johannesburg and led to the conclusion of a power-sharing agreement for the Durban Metropolitan Council on 10 July 1996.

The ANC and IFP conducted negotiations at a peace summit on 13 June 1997. On 8 August 1997, the IFP indicated it withdrew from the peace process because of concerns about the Truth and Reconciliation Commission exhibiting a bias towards IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi.
The IFP joined the ANC for another round of talks on 17 August 1997.
A round of peace talks between the ANC and IFP resulted in a peace agreement in April 1999.
On 11 May, ten delegates from each side attended another round of peace talks in Pietermaritzburg. However, sporadic clashes continued.
The ANC and IFP engaged in peace talks with ten members from each side in Ulundi in June 2000. Dumisani Makhaye of the ANC chaired the peace talks.

The Cape Organization for a Democratic Taxi Association (Codeta) was the product of the merger between former competing companies of Lagunya and Webta. Many of the former Webta members felt dissatisfied with their treatment within Codeta and established the Cape Amalgamated Taxi Association (CATA). An election meeting in Khayelitsha in October 1994, esclated into violence between the CATA and Codeta. A peace meeting mediated by the Provincial transport minister Leonard Ramatlakane ended with the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 October 1994.
Another round of negotiations on 31 October led to the conclusion of another ceasefire. Yet, another armed clash took place soon following this meeting.
On 1 November 1994, negotiations led to another ceasefire.
During a round of negotiations on 18 November 1994, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and to re-open taxi routes.
Negotiations led to a formal peace agreement on 22 November 1994. This agreement included a provision that the two would merge into one association.
CATA and Codeta began to clash again in 1996. Western Cape police commissioner Leon Wessel and local government officials mediated peace talks between the conflict parties on 16 September 1996.

Another flare-up of violence occurred between CATA and Codeta in September 2000. The conflict parties subsequently engaged in negotiations that led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 19 September. This agreement reasserted the original taxi route plan.

The African National Congress (ANC) and the Azanian People’s Organisation (AZAPO) had notably different ideas about ending Apartheid. The ANC advocated for a non-racial constitution, while the AZAPO advocated for black self-reliance in order to fight apartheid. Fighting between the supporters of the ANC and AZAPO started in March 1990 in the Bekkersdal township. AZAPO declared a unilateral ceasefire on 28 May 1990. Archbishop Desmond Tutu facilitated a peace summit for the black political groups of South Africa in Cape Town on 29 November 1990. The ANC and AZAPO engaged in peace talks at this peace summit.

The ANC, AZAPO and the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC) attended the Patriotic Front conference on 20 and 21 October 1991. However, the AZAPO left the conference after their request for the exclusion of some South African government officials attending the conference was rejected.

The African National Congresses (ANC) ended up splitting into two groups – the ANC - ‘Greens’ and ANC - ‘Reds’ – due to a dispute over resources in Bhambayi. Aroud 2,000 people from the two factions engaged in peace talks in Amaoti in January 1993. This meeting ended with the factions’ leaders agreeing to stop their fighting.

USC/SNA leader Mohammed Farah Aideed died on 1 August 1996 following an armed clash between the USC/SNA and another armed group, the the United Somali Congress/Somali National Alliance – Osman Atto (USC/SNA-OA). After the death of Aideed, the USC-PM, together with the USC/SNA-OA, declared a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire would last until officially called off by Atto on 16 September, claiming his group was attacked by the USC/SNA.

When USC/SNA’s leader Mohammed Farah Aideed died on 1 August 1996, Atto called for a ceasefire the next day and joined the Somali president Ali Mahdi Muhammad in asking for USC/SNA not to proceed with a successor to Aideed. This request was rejected, and Hussein Aideed replaced his father. The Secretary General of League of Arab States tried to initiate a peace process aimed at national reconciliation in mid-August 1996. In early September 1996, the two rebel leaders and President of Somalia were invited to meet with the President of Yemen. Atto and the Somali President met at this meeting mediated by the President of Yemen and agreed to commit to peace, but Aideed declined to participate in this meeting. The first meeting between Atto and Aideed took place at a meeting mediated by Kenyan President Moi in Nairobi from 9 to 16 October 1996. The President of Somalia also participated in this meeting. On 15 October, the conflict parties signed a nine-point agreement, which included a ceasefire that would take effect on 17 October as further negotiations were ongoing. Violence continued in spite of the conclusion of this ceasefire. Personal tensions between Atto and Aideed also persisted, with the latter blaming the former for his father’s death.

Ethiopia convened a large national conference in Sodere between November 1996 to January 1997, but these talks were boycotted by Hussein Aideed. From Aideed’s perspective, the aim of the Sodere talks was to forge a coalition of like-minded factions against his self-proclaimed Salballar ‘broad-based’ government, of which he became leader after the death of his father on 1 August 1996. The participants of the Sodere conference instead created what they called the National Salvation Council (NSC). The Government of Yemen mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties in Sana’a in May 1997.
Between 4 and 16 May, Atto and Aideed discussed the implementation of the October agreement.

Egypt mediated between the conflict parties at a conference in Cairo in November 1997. Egypt tried to create a national government through reaching an agreement between Hussein Aideed’s Salballar government and the NSC that emerged from Sodere conference, but this mediation effort failed because of disagreements within the NSC.

Following mediation by Libya and Ethiopia in early 1998, Hussein Aideed, Osman Atto, and President Ali Mahdi agreed to establish the Benadir Administration in Mogadishu. It was decided that each of these three men would take turns leading this administration, but this initiative ultimately failed due to disagreements about reopening the capital’s seaport and main airport.

The Somali Salvation Democratic Front (SSDF) was a coalition of the Somali Democratic Action Front (SODAF), the Somali Salvation Front (SOSAF), and other smaller groups. In January 1993, the SDDF clashed with the United Somali Congress/Somali National Alliance (USC/SNA) that was comprised mainly of the Hawiye clan. Prior to these clashes, Mohamed Sahnoun had been appointed as the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General in March 1992. Sahoun was mandated to work out a “plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.” By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi would act as the chief mediator of this conference that was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC/SNA leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SSDF and the USC/SNA attended these negotiations.  In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created.
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: A donor conference organized by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement. The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. The parties agreed to set up a Transitional National Council (TNC) for a period of two years, after which a political system was to emerge based on democratic governance, rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. The TNC would have legislative functions during the transition period and it would further establish an independent judiciary. It would be composed of representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as the political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Moreover, Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils would be established.
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: Negotiations solely involving the SSDF and the USC/SNA, mediated by the UN, led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 16 April. In addition, the SSDF and the USC/SNA were involved in local peacemaking efforts without the presence of a third party.

The Conciliation and Peace Conference of the Regions of Bari Nugal and Mudug, SNA, SNDU, SSDF led to the signing of the Mudug Peace Agreement in Galkayo on 6 June 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, the disengagement of forces, and the creation of a military committee to oversee the demobilization of militias in the Mudug area. The agreement also calls for return of property and compensation. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohammed Farah Aideed’s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October 1993, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.

A third UN-sponsored conference in Addis Ababa was held in November-December 1993. Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating, “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.”
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: As a product of the Somalia National Reconciliation Conference (SNRC) led by Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), the USC/SNA and the RRA signed the Eldoret Agreement in December 2002.

From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SSDF and the USC/SNA attended these negotiations. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created.
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: A donor conference organized by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement. The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. The parties agreed to set up a Transitional National Council (TNC) for a period of two years, after which a political system was to emerge based on democratic governance, rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. The TNC would have legislative functions during the transition period and it would further establish an independent judiciary. It would be composed of representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as the political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Moreover, Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils would be established.
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: UNOSOM Zone Director Mark Walsh, together with local clan elders, mediated exploratory talks between the SPM and SPM/SNA in mid-April 1993 in Kismayo. These talks broke down as a result of a SPM/SNA attack on 6 May 1993 in the same area. SPM/SNA leader Omar Jess wanted to take back control over Kismayo, which the SPM forces led by Morgan had taken control over on 22 February 1993. The attack on Kismayo was countered by a UNOSOM intervention of a Belgian contingent that took up positions between the two rebel sides.

Mohammed Farah Aideed, leader of the USC/SSA, initiated a round of peace negotiations between the SPM and the SPM/SNA in Mogadishu in mid-May 1993. The negotiations were mediated by elders from Galkayo, who were supported from Aideed. The UNOSOM leadership was uneasy about Aideed’s initiative, concerned that he was prepared to bargain over Kismayo in return for a settlement in Galkaiyo.  As a result, UNOSOM asserted itself as a co-mediator of the negotiations and brought 40 delegates from Kismayo to Mogadishu to participate in the negotiations.

On 30 May 1993, another round of negotiations between the SPM and the SPM/SNA began in Mogadishu. General Mohamed Abshir, the leader of the  Somali Salvation Democratic Front (SSDF) leader, acted as the mediator at this second round of negotiations in Mogadishu, with support from UNOSOM. The negotiations led to a preliminary ceasefire 30 May led to the conclusion of the Declaration of Peace and Reconciliation on 3 June 1993. This agreement stipulated the complete cessation of hostilities in the Lower Juba Region, the reunification of the population of Jubaland in seven days, the reopening of the Juba region, the establishment of a working committee on the peace process, and the creation of an interim standing committee of elders to judicially resolve differences arising among parties in the region.

On 23 June, 152 representatives and 50 observers concluded a preliminary ceasefire and then began negotiations via four committees at Kismayo airport. The four committees focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire and disarmament, reopening of roads, the reunification of the people and communities, and the return of property. UNOSOM helped to facilitate these negotiations. These negotiations ended on 6 August with the signing of the Jubbaland Peace Agreement. This agreement stipulates a ceasefire, as well as stipulates the reactivation of trade, restoration of essential services, reestablishment of police and the judiciary, and deployment of UNOSOM forces in each of the 14 districts mentioned in the agreement.

A third general UN-sponsored conference in Addis Ababa was held in November-December 1993, involving all the major armed groups in Somalia. Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating, “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.”
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: Peace efforts to end fighting between the SPM and the SPM/SNA, facilitated by UNOSOM, in Kismayo took place in March 1994, resulting in the conclusion of a ceasefire on 27 March 1994. The conflict parties also agreed to organize a peace conference on 8 April 1994, but this conference was postponed to May.

The conference, referred to as the Lower Juba Reconciliation Conference, was held in Kismayo between 24 May and 19 June 1994, with support from UNOSOM. It resulted in the signing of a nine-point agreement, including a ceasefire to take effect in the region on 24 June 1994.

On 19 June 1994, General Mohamed Said Hersi “Morgan” representing the SPM and Osman Atto representing the SNA alliance signed a statement pledging the support of the SPM and the SPM/SNA for implementation of the Agreement.
Following heavy clashes in Garbaharrey in 1999, the conflict was inactive in 2000. On 4 June 2001, the two sides signed a peace agreement following negotiations mediated by Kenya and Ethiopia.

From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN – in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US – convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SSDF and the USC/SNA attended these negotiations.  In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, “The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.” On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created.

The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.

Yet, the talks did not produce any tangible results. Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi, who mediated the talks, left the conference stating, “It appears you Somalis are not willing to reconcile. Goodbye.”
third_party: UNOSOM; Ethiopia; OAU; Arab League; OIC; US

description: No armed clashes have taken place between the SNF and the USC/SNA from 1994 onwards. However, both parties participated in negotiations in 2002. A national reconciliation program in Eldoret on 27 October 2002 led to the signing of the Eldoret Declaration. The SNF and USC/SNA signed this declaration along with twenty other groups.

The Somali National Movement (SNM) is heavily tied to the creation of Somaliland, a self-declared independent state, but internationally considered an autonomous region in the north of Somalia. Soon following the declaration of Somaliland’s independence, the Issaq clan (of which SNM was largely comprised) experienced turmoil between its Habar Yunis and Habar Jaalo subclans. This cleavage was further incensed by opposition to the presidency of Ahmed Ali ‘Tuur’ (a member of the Habar Yunis subclan), which exacerbated Habar Jaalo fears that the government favored the Habar Yunis. The SNM – calan cas (“red flag”) was composed of the socialist-leaning members of SNM from opposing subclans such as the Habar Jaalo. The first effort to pacify the conflict in the Republic of Somaliland took place at a peace conference in Sheekh on 23 October 1992. Women and guurti had initiated this conference, with the latter serving as mediators. The conference resulted in an agreement on clan representation, increased government control over particular assets. On 25 November 1992, 150 elders and 30 militia leaders arrived in Sheekh to declare their commitment to peace in Somaliland.

Peace efforts continued in 1993. The Grand Conference of National Reconciliation Borama between January and April 1993 was the second attempt to resolve the conflict. This conference was attended by 2,000 people with ex-Barre regime members joining. With 150 voting representatives for each participating clan, the conference used the guurti structure. Sheekh Ibrahim, Sheekh Yusuf Sheekh Madar, and eight elders acted as the mediators at the conference, while 17 women from local organizations acted as observers. On 25 April 1993, the representatives signed the Peace Charter and a National Charter for Somaliland, stipulating the peaceful transfer of power from the SNM interim government to a Beelbased (community) system; election of a civilian President, Maxamed Xaaji Ibraahin Cigaal and a Vice President, Cabdiraxmaan Aw Cali Faarax; the adoption of a National Charter serving as a working Constitution for Somaliland for the period of 1993-1995; the adoption of a Peace Charter for the clans of Somaliland which laid down the provisions for peace agreements to be mediated by the Council of Elders (Guurti) and set out methods and procedures for conflict resolution, demilitarization, and disarmament.
agreement_name: Peace Charter; National Charter for Somaliland

description: The Galje’el and Xawaadle clans both controlled parts of Belet Weyn. When resources from aid agencies arrived in the city, the two sides clashed in August 2000, both sides wanting profit from the influx of aid as much as possible. In August 2000, local elders mediated between the Xawaadle and Galje’el, but these talks did not lead to an agreement. Another round of peace talks between the clans was held in Jowhar on 6 September 2000. Leaders of clans from the Shabeellaha Hoose Region mediated these talks. On 10 September 2000, elders from both sides met for a peace meeting in the village Qurac Ceel Been. This conference lasted ten days and culminated in the two sides signing a peace agreement on 20 September. This comprehensive peace agreement included a clear separation of clan land, security of shared public routes, return of property, and a commitment to the death penalty for murderers.
On 8 November 2000, the two conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire in Jowhar.

In mid-April 1994, the conflict between the Habar Gadir and Xawaalde was mediated by the United Nations Operation in Somalia (UNOSOM). This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that would take effect on 22 April 1994.
In April 1996, the clan leaders of the Habar Gidir and Xawaadle met in Beled Weyn and concluded an agreement to resolve the conflict between the Habar Gidir and Xawaadle.

The Barre and Jiddo have a history of cattle raids against the other. Tensions exacerbated as a result of increased land scarcity from the late 1990s onwards. Following an outbreak of clashes in May 2000, the conflict parties engaged in peace talk mediated by elders and the Islamic Courts Union (ICU) in Qorylie, but this did not produce a peace agreement.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the ICU on 25 June 2000 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire, but this ceasefire broke down the next day.

In yet another mediation effort by the ICU on 29 June 2000, the two clans signed a peace agreement in Afgoi. The agreement stipulated that a monitoring committee with aid from an Italian NGO Coordinamento delle Organizzazioni per il Servizio (COSV) would oversee the implementation of the agreement. However, the agreement had already fallen appart by 5 July 2000. This committee was set up on 13 July 2000. ICU fighters subsequently intervened in the conflict to impose the ceasefire.

The Republic of Somaliland declared its independence in May 1991. Three years later, forces of the self-declared state clashed with the Forces of Abdurahman Ahmed Ali ‘Tuur’. As the former president of the Republic of Somaliland, ‘Tuur’ was concerned that the administration’s activities worked against his own Garhajis clan, as well that the agenda for the future of Somaliland would shift towards becoming part of Somalia again rather than wholly independent.  The Garhajis’ elders and Somaliland’s parliament engaged in peace talks during the summer of 1995.

This paved the way for the start of a peace conference in Hargeisa in October 1996. This conference was mediated by the Peace Committee for Somaliland, which was a unified collection of Somaliland expatriates representing a broad constituency of clans and civil society. The peace conference in Hargeisa would last until February 1997. Locally executed, the conference agreed to a cessation of violence, as well as to Somalialand’s second interim constitution, broadening the political system from a clan based electoral representation to a multi-party democracy. Following these peace conferences, Somaliland has largely been conflict-free.

Hussein Ali Ahmed was the governor of Mogadishu when his forces clashed with the United Somali Congress/Somali Salvation Alliance (USC/SSA). The two sides clashed in March 1999 after USC/SSA leader Muse Sudi Yalahow attempted to tax local tradesmen in a Karan market. Negotiations mediated by Abgal elders took place between March and August 1999, but these negotiations ended without an agreement.

The Eli-Omar and Abdalle-Aroneh subclans reside in central Somalia. Following a failed peace conference in Mogadishu in January 1999 to resolve some longstanding conflicts over land, the Eli-Omar took up arms against the Abdalle-Aroneh in late January 1999. Negotiations at a bilateral peace meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 1 February 1999. This peace meeting involved 10 delegates from each side. Beyond ending violence, the agreement stressed the importance of future dispute settlement via peaceful means, an exchange of prisoners, and ensuring free access to roads.

side_a: Ayr subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: The Transitional National Government (TNG) in Mogadishu faced many opposition groups, among them one led by Hussein Mohamed Aideed and Osman Ali Atto. Mirroring this rivalry, the Ayr clan aligned with the TNG as the Sa’ad sympathized with the opposing faction led by Aideed and Otto. In mid-July 2001, the Ayr and the Sa’ad clashed, allegedly over alleged stolen food. A mediation effort by neutral clan leaders, Ugas Abdi Dahir and Abdi Mohamud Kheyrreh, led to a fragile peace without the signing of a formal document on 17 July 2001.

side_a: Ayr subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Peace talks at Hotel Shafi in South Mogadishu led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 19 July 2001, as well as a formal promise to collaborate over the use of the strategic junction of KM-7, which links the capital to the southern regions of Somalia. In practice, this meant that Ayr businessmen traveling through the zone would not be harmed. This peace agreement contributed to a reduction of violence in Mogadishu.

The escalation of the conflict between the Abdulleh–Galmaha and Kabaloh subclans in May 2001 was triggered by a dispute over territory. The leaders of the subclans had turned to traditional conflict resolution of this dispute, but neither side would compromise. With armed conflict ongoing, negotiations mediated by elders from the Abgal clan took place by July 2001. These negotiations failed to bring the conflict to an end.
In spite of an absence of large-scale fighting between 2002 and 2004, the Runnirgod peace meeting attended by both conflict parties led to a peace agreement.

The Abdalleh-Agon-Yar and Eli-Agon-Yar clashes as a result over a conflict over an irrigation canal that would be produced by a German NGO. In late January 2000, traditional representatives from both sides started to engage in negotiations mediated by Imam Mahmud Imam Umar. These negotiations would take place until 27 February but did not lead to a resolution of the conflict.

side_a: Abdalle subclan of Habar Awal clan (Isaaq)
side_b: Aidagalla subclan of Habar Garhadjis clan (Isaaq)
description: On 15 July, the Abdalle and Aidagalla attended a peace conference in Qoton. However, fighting continued.

side_a: Abdalle subclan of Habar Awal clan (Isaaq)
side_b: Aidagalla subclan of Habar Garhadjis clan (Isaaq)
description: In October 1996, a broader peace conference took place in Hargeisa, aimed at bringing peace to Somaliland. This conference was mediated by the Peace Committee for Somaliland, which was a unified collection of Somaliland expatriates representing a broad constituency of clans and civil society. Both Aidagalla and Abdalle representatives attended the conference. This conference lasted until February 1997, bringing this fight to an end. The conference extended the Somaliland administration’s tenure for a further four years, as well as ratified a transitionary constitution and notably increased non-Issaq representation. The conference resulted in peace in Somaliland.

side_a: Abdalle subclan of Habar Awal clan (Isaaq)
side_b: Aidagalla subclan of Habar Garhadjis clan (Isaaq)
description: The rivalry between the Aidagalla and Abdalle clans in the Republic of Somaliland was part of a rivalry between two key political figures, Abdurahaman Ahmed Ali ‘Tuur’ and Mohamed Haji Ibrahim Egal. A peace meeting was held in the spring 1996 when the rivalry between the two figureheads intensified.

The conflict between the Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri conflict, also known as the “Warri crisis” is part of a conflict between settlers and indigenous people. The three groups claim to be the original inhabitants of Warri and are vying for its control. The clashes between the three groups started during a demonstration about the location change of a local government area. While the Ijaw and Urhobo were on one side, the Itsekiri were on the other. At the end of May and June 1999, as Nigeria transitioned from a military to a civilian government, violence erupted again in Warri. As during previous episode of armed fighting, the government quickly sent soldiers to restore order. The governor of Delta State, James Ibori, announced a new curfew on 7 June 1999. Newly elected President Olusegun Obasanjo met leaders of Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Uroboh communities on 9 June 1999 in Abuja to show its commitment to peace in the Warri Delta region and encourage the stakeholders to respect each other and find a peaceful solution to the crisis.

On the same day (9 June 1999), Chief James Onanefe Ibori, Governor of Delta State, held a peace meeting with leaders of the Urhobo, Ijaw, and Itsekiri communities in Warri to prepare the visit of President Obasanjo to Warri.
President Obasanjo then visited Warri on 11 June 1999, held a peace meeting with the leaders and representatives of the conflict parties.

Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo representatives met for two days of negotiations in Asaba on 16 and 17 June 1999. The negotiations were mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State. With no progress made, another round of negotiations was scheduled for the next week later.

The negotiations mediated by Governor James Ibori one week later, in Asaba on 24 June 1999, were successful and led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws, and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos.

Following negotiations, the Ijaw and Itsekiri signed a peace agreement on 1 February 2000. The Delta State Government mediated this round of negotiations. On 17 March, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko leaders visited President Obasanjo in Abuja to announce the return of peace to Warri.
On 24 March 2003, James Ibori held an emergency meeting with the leaders of the Ijaws, the Urhobo, and the Itsekiri in Warri. No agreement was signed on this occasion.

The Governor of Delta State eventually agreed to renegotiate the electoral boundaries during peace talks in Warri in the end of March 2003. These peace talks between the Ijaw and Itsekiri leaders and the Delta State government led to the signing of a ceasefire between the two communities on 26 March 2003.
Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 March 2003 between the Ijaw youth (FNDIC) and the Itsekiri in the presence of state officials.

On 7 April 2003, Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri, and Ijaw leaders in Abuja along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peace solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the warring tribes reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, the former Minister of defense. This committee was tasked with investigating the Warri Crisis and propose ways to solve it. The report of this committee has not been made public.
On 15 May 2003, the national leader of Nigeria’s Ijaw ethnic communities reported that the youth of the Ijaw militia agreed to a ceasefire.
On 20 July 2003, the Delta State Governor announced that leaders of the two tribes declared a ceasefire in Warri.

Concerned about a possible offensive by the Ijaw and Itsekiri youths, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone 5, Mr. Gazali Lawal, and the Delta State Police Commissioner, Mr. Jonathan Akaya, held peace meetings with the leaders of the two communities in the Police Zone Command Office in Warri on the night of 9 to 10 August 2003. The meeting culminated in a communiqué signed by Mr. Justice Rewane for the Itsekiri, Chief Bare Etobor and Chief Tunde Smooth for the Ijaws, and by Akaya on behalf of the police. He urged the warring youth to support the government’s peace efforts. However, armed violence still erupted in spite of this effort and Nigerian authorities imposed a curfew on the town of Warri on 15 August 2003. Nigerian troops were deployed in Warri after some 100 people were killed between 15 and 20 August. In addition, the federal government deployed a joint security force in Delta State: “Operation Restore Hope”, which would be maintained in the following years.

On 20 August 2003, the leaders of the two ethnic groups met in Warri and signed a ceasefire mediated by Delta State governor, James Ibori. Chief Edwin Clark, the Ijaw leader, and Bob Mene-Afejeiku, the leader of the Itsekiri, announced, in separate interviews on 27 August 2003, that they agreed with Obasanjo’s proposal to end the crisis in Warri. This proposal involves separating political issues from criminal acts in order to facilitate the resolution of the conflict.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly in Asaba and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups – the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo – to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri referred to the plan of as “illegal” and “unconstitutional” and expressed their dissatisfaction with it.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri’s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori’s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

Governor James Ibori called a security meeting on 10 November 2003 in Warri to prevent a resurgence of figting in Warri. State officials as well as representatives of the Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri tribes took part in the discussion.

In late November 2003, President Obasanjo set up a new committee to resolve the Warri crisis, headed by Delta State governor James Ibori. The latter mediated several rounds of negotiations with Itsekiri, Urhobo, and Ijaw leaders.

A 28-member peace committee, consisting of 14 Itsekiri and 14 Ijaws, met on 18 February 2004 in Warri. James Ibori and the Commissioner for Special Missions, Inter-Ethnic Relations, and Conflict Resolution, Ovuozourie Macaulay, acted as the mediators. The peace committee meeting led to approval of a six-point agreement aimed at peaceful coexistence between the rival groups. Among the main points are the establishment of a joint peace vanguard composed of members of both groups and an agreement that would allow people displaced by the conflict to return to their homes of origin without fear of attack.

On 1 June 2004, leaders of ethnic Ijaw and Itsekiri youth activist groups signed a ceasefire through the platform of the Warri Ijaw/Itsekiri Grassroots Peace Front (WIIGPF) moderated by Pastor Power Ziakede Aginighan.

Three weeks after the ceasefire concluded by the militias and after more than six months of peace negotiations, the Ijaw and the Istekiri leaders signed a peace agreement on 23 June 2004 at the senior officers mess, NNS Delta Navy base, in Warri. Delta State Commissioner for Inter-Ethnic Relation and Conflict Resolution, Comrade Ovuzuorie Macauley was chief mediator of the negotiations.

The ceasefires concluded in June 2004 led to a fragile peace. However, tensions in the Delta North remained. Between 18 and 19 June 2005, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo traditional rulers launched a traditional leaders’ forum in Ozoro. This forum was initially headed by Ijaw retired Brigadier General Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide and had the goal to minimize the tensions between the ethnic groups. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities.

The conflict between the Aguleri and Umuleri is an intra-ethnic conflict since the two tribes belong to the Igbo ethnic group and to the Eri clan. The conflict erupted over the issue of control over land in Anambra. Following an outbreak of armed violence in early September 1995, colonel Mike Attah, the military governor of Anambra State,  mediated between the two communities at the Nkisi Palace Hotel in Onitscha. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

After the 1999 violence, the government of Anambra created a commission of inquiry led by Justice Emmanuel Araka. Participating members were drawn from each of the three feuding communities of Aguleri, Umuleri, and Umuoba Anam. Obaneze Ndi Igbo, an Igbo organization, set up the first civil society initiative to resolve the Aguleri-Umuleri conflict. A first meeting was held in April 1999 to find solutions to the running conflict. The meeting resulted in a communiqué calling for an immediate end to the violence and increased government action. The Ohanaeze initiative resulted in a temporary cessation of fighting for about two weeks. However, resumed soon after the conclusion of the ceasefire.

Directly after its election in May 1999, President Olusegun Obasanjo visited the communities and invited their leaders to Abuja, where another ceasefire agreement was reached and a peace committee set up to discuss the issue and pronounce a permanent peace.
Aguleri and Umuleri communities adopted a 6-point plan for peace in late June 1999.

On 14 July 1999, the Aguleri and Umuleri attended a peace meeting. The Anambra state governor Chinwoke Mbadinuju, who mediated between the parties, gave the groups one week to commit to a ceasefire agreement. The conflict parties did, however, not commit to a ceasefire.

Aguleri and Umuleri participated to a traditional oath-taking ceremony on 25 January 2000, which was facilitated by Igwe N. N. Kelly, leader of Anambra East council. This event, known as the “Declaration no more war” included peace talks that led to an agreement. This agreement committed the conflict parties to the mutual recognition of the communities and their borders and aims to guarantee peace.
On 6 April 2000, the two tribes reiterated their oath, this time in presence of members of the Omuaba Anam community as well.

In July 2005, Igwe Christopher Idigo, the leader of the Aguleri, informed Senator Joy Emodi that the Aguleri and Umuleri had begun peace meetings to resolve their border disputes. However, no agreement resulted from those meetings.

The Aguleri/Umuleri peace committee that had been set up in 2004 conducted a round of negotiations that led to the conclusion of an agreement in 2006. Chief Pius Okonkwo, the General President of the Union of Umuleri Cities mediated the agreement.
Mediation attempts by Taraba and Adamawa authorities were carried out during December 1991, but this did not ease the tensions.

The conflict intensified in early 1992. The Nigerian government convened peace meetings between the Jukun and Tiv on two separate occasions during February 1992. On 13 February, the leaders of the conflict parties – H.R.H. Dr. Shekarau Angyu Masa-Ili and H.R.H. Ochivirigh Alfred Akawa Torkula Tor Tiv for the Jukun and the Tiv respectively – signed a 10-point peace agreement in Wukari. Representatives from both Taraba and Benue governments, Reverend Jolly Nyame and Moses Adasu, were in attendance.
Earlier that day (13 February 1992), the group had gathered at Aguda House in Abuja with Admiral Augustus Aikhomu in order to discuss the conflict issues and the potential for signing a ceasefire.

On 24 September 2001, Vice-President Atiku Abubakar, following the order of President Olusegun Obasanjo instructed the governments of Benue and Taraba to resolve the continued conflict during a reconciliation meeting in Abuja. Representatives of both warring groups were present.  In addition, at the national level, the Federal Government and military authorities asserted that they sent soldiers to Tarabata State and the areas around the Tarabata-Benue border at the beginning of October 2001 in order to restore peace in the region. Meanwhile, on 10 October 2001, a Tiv armed group abducted 19 soldiers. Tiv elements claim that the soldiers were armed Jukuns and did not believe that these soldiers were coming to restore peace. This event triggered the start of a new wave of violence against civilians in the region conducted by the military between 22 and 24 October 2001. The Governors of Benue and Taraba State met several times before the violence erupted, but they failed to prevent the massacre. In response to the outbreak of violence, traditional rulers and opinion leaders from across the confederation went to Warri on 31 October 2001 to discuss the religious clash in Kano and the Tiv/Jukun ethnic conflict in Benue and Taraba States. This discussion was part of a more general meeting on ethno-religious crises within Nigeria. Seen as an “advisory forum”, this general meeting aimed to initiate calm dialogue and find long-term solutions. However, the conflict continued.

From 2 to 4 November 2001, the Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF) attempted to mediate directly with the conflict parties in Alhaji Muhammadu Gambo Jimeta, in Abuja. This did not produce an agreement. Another peace meeting was therefore scheduled for mid-November.

To brainstorm on a path towards peace, President Obasanjo met with the state leaders and leaders from Nasarawa, Benue, Taraba and Plateaus on 11 November 2001. The meeting lasted five hours with observers from Kano and Kaduna present. This meeting addressed conflict between Muslims and Christians more generally, rather than solely focusing on the Jukun-Tiv conflict. This meeting led to the establishment of a Judicial Commission of Inquiry.

The meeting with President Obasanjo also paved the way for a meeting involving Jukun and Tiv leaders on 16 November 2001. This meeting was brokered by the Arewa Consultative Forum in Kaduna and led to the signing of a ceasefire. At this meeting, the Nigerian government announced a plan to convene the tribes for another round of peace talks on 19 and 20 December 2001, but no public information exists that suggests that this meeting took place.

Between 24 and 26 January 2002, President Obasanjo went to several states in central Nigeria, including Benue and Taraba, to encourage peace and conflict resolution highlighting the notions of indigenes and settlers. Senate President Pius Anyim conducted visits to both states. He went to Benue State in February 2002, where he visited the settlement camps of the Tiv people displaced from Taraba during the crisis.
The ACF tried to mediate a negotiated solution to the conflict between the Jukun and Tiv during a meeting in Kaduna in March 2002.

On 30 August 2003, a peace conference was held with fifty-one Tiv and Jukun stakeholders from Taraba and Benue State and nine witnesses from state, national and international organizations. This led to the signing of the so called “Jalingo Resolution” in Taraba State, granting indigenous status to the Tiv people in the Taraba State and calling for reconciliation between the Tiv and the Junkun. This agreement was the product of more than two years of consultations and workshops with Jukun and Tiv representatives – between 21 September 2001 and 31 August 2003 – organized in in Mkar, Wukari, Abuja, Gboko, Makurdi, Suntai and Jalingo by the Peace, Justice and Reconciliation Committee of the Reformed Ecumenical Council of Nigeria (RECON) and its implementation committee. The traditional ruler of the Tiv, Dr. Alfred Akawe Torkula, however, contested this resolution, claiming that he never signed it: “he had neither prior knowledge of, nor was briefed before or during the said consultation.”

Another peace effort took place in 2014 and this time not only focused on the Tiv and Jukun, but also included the Fulani and the Hausa communities. On 5 April 2014, Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga and Takum LGA signed a peace agreement in Jalingo (Taraba State) brokered by Michael Zuokumor, Deputy Inspector General of the Police. The secretary General of Tiv Taraba Cultural Social Association, Mr. Julius Butu, the President of Jukun Youth Cultural Development Association, Mr. Zando Hoku, and the State Chairman of Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association, Alhaji Mafindi Danburam signed the resulting communiqué that appealed for peace between the four communities.

On 29 April 2014, representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes signed another peace agreement in Bali LGA. No mediator was involved in these negotiations. This agreement failed, as hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014.

After the violence of 15 April 2014 in Wukari, the Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders of the Wukari LGA signed yet another peace agreement on 30 April 2014. The peace agreement was mediated by Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu and signed by Mr. Zando Hoku, President of Jukun State Cultural Association, Mr. James Nungwa, President of Tiv State Cultural and Development Association, and Alhaji Mafindi Danburam, Chairman of Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association.

Despite repeated peacebuilding efforts between Jukun and Tiv during an absence of fighting between 2002 and 2015, a new outbreak of fightng occurred on 14 April 2016. A conflict between a small settlement of Jukun and the neighboring community of Angbaye Tiv along the Makurdi-Gboko road in Benue State resulted in between seven and ten deaths. Armed clashes continued during the rest of the year. On 22 December 2016, community representatives from six local areas in the Southern Plateau, including the Tiv and Jukun communities, signed the South Plateau Peace Declaration. This peace agreement was the product of an inter-community dialogue process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in the Southern Plateau launched in June 2016.

In June 2017, the governor of Taraba State convened a peace meeting between Tiv, Junkun, Kuteb, and Miyeti Allah leaders in Jalingo in order work towards lasting peace. No agreement was signed during this meeting.

In the aftermath of clashes in Abinsi town in the Local Government Area of Guma in Benue State, the Tiv, Jukun and Fulani leaders gathered at a peace meeting in Benue in January 2019. The peace meeting was mediated by the army commander of the joint military operation in Benue State, Major General Adeyemi Yekini. The conflict parties agreed on the need to end violence, but no written agreement was concluded at the meeting. On 5 March 2019, a commission of inquiry into the Tiv/Jukun crisis set up by the Benue State Government was inaugurated in Makurdi. The commission, headed by Judge Wilfred Kpochi, was mandated to investigate the causes of the crisis and to restore peace to the affected region.
In early April 2019, the conflict parties engaged in bilateral negotiations in Taraba State. This led to the signing of a peace agreement. However, fighting resumed already one week later.

On 15 April 2019, the deputy governors of Taraba and Benue, Haruna Manu and Benson Abounu respectively, organized a peace meeting between the leaders of the Jukun and the Tiv at the Federal University in Wukari in Taraba State. The meeting resulted in the signing of a communiqué that called uppon the youth of the two communities to lay down their arms and follow the path of peace. However, the armed violence continued.

The Tiv Youth Organization (TYO) convened a peace meeting in Makurdi on 20 April 2019, with the involvement of the Jukun Youths Congress (JYC). Both sides stressed the need and desire for peace between them, but no written agreement was concluded.

A peace meeting between the conflict parties mediated by the army in Kente in Taraba State led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 10 June 2019. In addition to stipulating a ceasefire, the agreement stipulated that the roadblocks that had been erected on the Gbeji-Kente-Wukari axis should be dismantled. However, armed violence continued.

Jukun and Tiv leaders met for a round of negotiations at the St. Charles Boromeo Pastoral Center in Jalingo on 24 July 2019. This round of negotiations was mediated by the Catholic Bishop of the Diocese of Jalingo, Reverend Charles Hammawa. The meeting did not result in a written agreement, but the leaders of the conflict parties assured their willingness to achieve peace.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

Despite numerous mediation efforts, the conflict parties continued to fighteach other. A peace meeting was therefore held at the federal level. Benue and Taraba state representatives, Samuel Ortom and Darius Ishaku, together with traditional Jukun and Tiv leaders, met in Abuja with Federal Government officals on 4 September 2019. This resulted in a communique in which the Federal Government pledged its support for the peace effort between the two communities and in which the Tiv and Jukun leaders called for an immediate cessation of hostilities. However, hostilities resumed in Taraba village already one week later.

On 25 and 26 September 2019, a peace meeting was held at the Government House in Jalingo in Taraba State. The peace meeting was attended representatives of the Tiv, Jukun, and Etulo communities of the Local Government Areas of Wukari, Donga, and Takum. State officials security chiefs acted as the mediators at the peace meeting. The meeting resulted in a ceasefire and the establishment of a 30-member committee composed of representatives of the Tiv and Jukun tribes, which was tasked with ending the conflict through supporting the implementation of the ceasefire. In spite of this agreeement, hostilities resumed within a couple of days after it was signed.

From 10 to 11 October 2019, the leaders of the Jukun and Tiv communities met in Jalingo at the initiative of the Coalition of Northern Groups (CNG) to find a lasting solution to the crisis. This meeting, mediated by the CNG, led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement by the President of the Tiv community, Goodman Dahida, and the spokesperson of the Jukun community, Daniel Emmanuel Angyu. The President of the Tiv-Jukun Conflict Reconciliation Committee signed in his capacity as mediator.

A two-day peace meeting, attended by the 30-man committee consisting of representatives of Tiv and Jukun that had been set up by Governor Darius Ishaku, was in Jalingo in late October 2019. Deputy Governor of Taraba State, Haruna Manu, acted as the chief mediator at this meeting. The meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. Danjuma Adamu, Markus Ikitsombika and John Mamman signed the communiqué on behalf of the Jukun community, while Jime Yongo, Kurason Kura and Isaac Waakaa represented the Tiv community. Armed fighting resumed only few weeks later.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); traditional leaders; religious leaders; government forces; local government

description: Newly elected President Olusegun Obasanjo met leaders of Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo communities on 9 June 1999 in Abuja. He then visited Warri on 11 June 1999, and said committed to finding a solution to the turmoil. On the same day, the National Assembly of Nigeria set up a 12-person committee to investigate the Warri crisis.

Itsekiri, Ijaw and Urhobo representatives met for two days of closed deliberations on 16 and 17 June 1999 to discuss the Warri crisis mediated by Governor James Ibori in the Delta State capital Asaba. This only resulted in the postponement of the peace meeting a week later.

Negotiations between the three communities one week later, mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 24 June 1999 in Asaba. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos.

In February 2003, in the run-up to Nigeria’s 2003 legislative and presidential elections, fighting broke out between the Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo ethnic groups in the Niger Delta. The government sent more than 1,000 troops to the Niger Delta to contain the fighting. On 24 March 2003, James Ibori held an emergency meeting with the leaders of the three ethnic groups in conflict, the Ijaws, the Urhobo and the Itsekiri in Warri. No agreement was signed on this occasion.

On 7 April 2003, President Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri and Ijaw leaders in Abuja, along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peace solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the conflict parties reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee tasked with resolving the Warri Crisis. This committee was headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, who was the former Minister of Defense.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, the Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups, Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo, to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri claimed the plan to be “illegal” and “unconstitutional” and expressed to not be satisfied with the plan.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dungs, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri’s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori’s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

Governor James Ibori called a security meeting on 10 November 2003 in Warri to prevent a resurgence of crisis in Warri. State officials as well as representatives of the Ijaw, Urhobo and Itsekiri tribes took part in the discussion.

In the end of November 2003, President Obasanjo set up a new committee to resolve the Warri crisis, headed by Delta State governor James Ibori. James Ibori subsequently mediated several negotiations between the Itsekiri, Urhobo and Ijaw leaders in late November 2003.

Traditional rulers of the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo participated in a traditional leaders’ forum in Ozoro on the weekend between 18 and 19 June 2005. This forum was aimed at minimizing the tensions between feuding ethnic groups. Ijaw Brigadier General (retired) Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide led the meeting. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities

In November 1998, Colonel Moses Fasanya conducted shuttle mediation between the tribal leaders in their respective Local Government Areas. Both sides expressed interest in finding a peaceful solution.

The general chief of staff Admiral Akhigbe mediated between the conflict parties in Azure in mid-February 1999. The Ijaws expressed their wish for a local government during these negotiations. The Ijaw and Ilaje promised to establish a joint peace committee to move the reconciliation process forward during a round of negotiations in Akure on 4 August 1999. The conflict parties also agreed to a truce in the presence of federal security forces and the governor of Ondo State, Adebayo Adefarati.
In mid-August 1999, the two communities met with the Minister of Internal Affairs Chief Afolabi, who tried to negotiate an end to the clashes.
On 30 September 1999, Deputy Governor Afolabi Iyanta mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Akure.

A round of negotiations in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 3 November 1999. Governor Bola Ahmed Tinubu mediated these negotiations.
On 16 July 2003, the two conflict parties signed a peace agreement at a round of negotiations mediated by Ondo State governor Olusegun Agagu.

The conflict between communities from Ife and Modakeke, two cities in Osun State in the southeast of Nigeria, was centered on control over land and political power. The inhabitants of these cities share the same Yoruba ethnicity, but have different historical narratives and claims on political representation and influence. The citizens of Ife see the town of Modakeke as a recent settlement on already occupied land. Long-standing tensions between the two cities escalated into deadly clashes in August 1997, when the local government headquarters was relocated from Modakeke to Ife. Following the clashes, on 25 August 1997, the Osun State Council of Obas and Chiefs from both communities met in Oshogbo and established a seven-man committee to investigate the events. Directly after renewed violence, on 25 September 1997, the military governor of the state, Lieutenant-Colonel Anthony Obi, invited the leaders of the two communities to an emergency meeting at his headquarters in Oshogbo to end the fighting. However, no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
The Ife and Modakeke leaders agreed to peace following negotiations in Ife on 10 November 1997. However, on the same day, new clashes erupted.
On 8 December 1997, tribal leaders met with military representatives to discuss how to end the fighting in Ife Town.

Negotiations between the Modakeke and Ife leaders, mediated by the state government (led by the administrator, Lt-Col Assan Ubi), led to the signing of a peace agreement in Oshogbo on 9 December 1997.

Negotiations between the ibale (traditional ruler) of Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi led to the signing of another peace agreement on 15 December 1997. Colonel Ubi, Osun State administrator, mediated this accord.
