In response to the resurgence of violence between the two communities in September 1998, the state administrator, Col Theophilus Bamigboye, met separately Modakeke and Ife communities for shuttle negotiations on 7 September 1998. At this occasion, both communities vowed to end hostilities. However, no written agreement was agreed uppon.

On 14 September 1998, Oba Okunade Sijuade and Oba Francis Adedoyin, respectively the Ooni of Ife and the Ogunsua of Modakeke met again separately with Col. Theophilus Bamgboye to negotiate an end to the fighting. Both agreed to comitt to peace, but no written agreement was signed.
Negotiations led to the signing of another peace agreement in 1999.
The Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande, met with the Modakeke traditional Monarch, Oba Francis Adedoyin, to ease tensions on 9 March 2000. However, violence conintued.
On 17 March, the Ife and Modakeke leaders signed a peace agreement, after engaging in indirect negotiations mediated by the Osun Governor Bisi Akande in Oshogbo.

From 23 to 24 March, President Olusegun Obasanjo met with representatives of the Ife and Modakeke, as well as the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande and Commodore Olabode George to discuss lasting measures for peace. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

Violence erupted again in the beginning of March 2000. In reaction to this, the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande, imposed a curfew on 7 March 2000. On that same day, on 7 March 2000, Frederic Fasheun and Beko Ransome-Kuti – two officials of the Odua People’s Congress (OPC), a pan-Yoruba organization – met with leaders of the conflict parties to negotiate a solution. The following day, the two tribes agreed to a temporary ceasefire that was set to last until 10 March.
On 14 April 2000, both sides reiterated their commitment to maintain peace at a peace meeting of the Olabode George committee – also known as the 27-man committee – in Oshogbo.
On 27 May 2000, President Obasanjo mediated peace talks between the two feuding communities in Abuja, while violence erupted again in the cities of Modakeke and Ife.

Following the recommendation of the Olabode George committee, the Ooni of Ife, Oba Okunade Sijuade and the Ogunsua of Modakeke Chief Francis Orafidiya reached a peace agreement at another round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo in Abuja on 21 June 2000. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire and a power-sharing mechanism ensuring proportional representation of the two cities on the regional council.

On 15 December 2000, after a two-day meeting with the country’s human rights panel, representatives of the two cities of Ife and Modakeke signed a “Memorandum of Understanding”, reiterating their commitment to peace.

Negotiations between Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi, mediated by Prince Olagunsoye Oyinlola, took place on 6 February 2009. The talks resulted in Adedoyin being recognized as the Oba of Ifeland on 8 February. Furthermore, the agreement provided for the establishment of a unique local council that would be based in Modakeke. The agreement was concluded between the Osun State Government, the Ooni of Ife, the Oba Okunade Sijuwade, the Olubuse II and the Ogunsua of Modakeke, Francis Adedoyin.

In September 2001, clashes erupted in direct response to a dispute over a recent political appointment. Armed fighting led to several thousand deaths. A 10-man commission – referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission – led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate the conflict. This commission subsequently mediated between the conflict parties at a peace conference. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign it.
Tribal and religious figures representing the conflict parties engaged in peace talks mediated by state officials in early September 2001. These talks ended in a stalemate.

On 16 September 2001, President Obasanjo, reacting to the violence in Jos, met political, religious and community representatives at the government building of Plateau State and encouraged them to make peace.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to a an agreement.

Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002. Furthermore, in 2002, the Nigerian government created a body to investigate the causes of the conflict, the Justice Opene Commission led by Justice C. Okpene.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau – Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba – signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

In addition, local authorities organized a month-long peace conference aimed at bringing peace to Plateau State was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was conducted under a twelve-member steering committee and brought together several represenatives of the conflict parties. Government officials and traditional leaders acted as the mediators. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State such as the Afisare, Anaguta, and Birom were allowed to send two representatives each to the conference, while “settlers” such as Fulani and Hausa were allowed only one representative each. The conference culminated in a draft agreement containing a number of resolutions. The draft agreement included a resolution stating that the Berom, Anaguta, and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos. The Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it.

On 10 July 2013, following consultations with each of the conflict parties, the conflict parties agreed to engage in peace talks in Jos. The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue subsequently facilitated a series of peace meetings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders; government; local government

description: The Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace Center (DREP) facilitated a meeting with eight religious leaders and six community leaders from the Hausa, Afisare, Birom, Igbo, Anaguta, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 19 June 2014. The meeting was aimed at working towards peaceful coexistence between Christian and Muslim communities.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau communities leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

Armed fighting between the Muslim Azara and the Christian Tiv erupted in June 2011. Both conflict parties claimed ownership of the same land. In the context of this land dispute, a traditional Azara leader, Alhaji Musa Ibrahim, was killed along with his entourage, including two policemen. The Tivs in the town of Lafia were soon accused of committing the murders and the ensuing violence was mainly concentrated in Nasarawa State and led more than 50,000 people to flee the area. On 18 June 2001, the Nigerian government mediated peace talks between the conflict parties. This meeting did not lead to a written agreement, but it did result in the establishment of a commission of inquiry into the conflict.

In the beginning of September 1993, Mr Saro-Wiwa, the founding member of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), together with Senator Birabi and representatives of the Rivers State Security Council, went to the destroyed village of Kaa, and Ogoni town, and urged Governor Ada George to take steps to stop the violence between the Adoni and Ogoni. In addition, a Peace Committee was created. This committee was led by headed by Professor Claude Ake. On 25 September 1993, the Nigerian government instructed the military to halt the fighting. Following the creation of the Peace Committee, Claude Ake went on to organize a peace conference, which was organized by the Rivers State Peace Conference Committee and National Council on Inter-Governmental Relation on 6 October 1993. After the conference, a joint resolution was issued, claiming that all parties accept the immediate resolution of the conflict. Ake dismissed this resolution as he suspected that the government played a role in the conflict. In addition, some of the Ogoni leaders, such as Saro-Wiwa, refused to sign the agreement, arguing that were still too many unanswered questions regarding the role of the government.

Negotiations in February 1995 led to the signing of a peace agreement by three Adoni and three Ogoni representatives in Port Harcourt. The agreement was signed in front of an audience of journalists, government commissioners, and elders from the concerned communities. They agreed to perform traditional rituals to complete the reconciliation and asked the government to devolve more authority, so local leaders could better keep the peace.

The Fulani people, also referred to as – Fula, Fulbe, and Pueuhl – are a large ethnic and ethno-linguistic community spread across several countries in West Africa. The Tuareg are an ethnic group residing in the northern parts of western Africa. Being a nomadic and pastoral tribe, the Tuareg are present in a number of countries. In 1997, armed fighting broke out between the Nigerien Fulani herders and the Malian nomadic Tuaregs. The conflict was triggered by a dispute over the use of a well. The government of Mali responded to the violence by inviting the Nigerian government to talks in the city of Menaka in Mali. These talks were held in mid-March in Menaka after the first outburst of violence. The talks were unsuccessful since violence flared up once again in July 1997. However, armed fighting did not continue after the summer of 1997. After the start of the civil war in Mali in 2012, the Fulani became fearful that the Tuareg would dominate the inner delta of the Niger river. As a result, tensions between the two tribes increased. In February 2014, tensions between the Fulani and Tuareg escalated into violent clashes, resulting in some 30 Tuaregs killed by armed Fulani around 80 kilometres from Gao, allegedly in revenge for the kidnapping and killing of a member of their community.
Fulani and Malian Tuareg began fighting over the use of a well in Niger in July 1997. Malian and Niger government officials met in Menaka in March 1997 to try and reconcile the two groups.

In March 2014, inter-communal violence between the Tuareg and the Fulani in Gao region further intensified. From 17 to 19 March 2014, the governments of Mali and Niger organized a peace meeting of Fulani and Tuareg community leaders of both countries in an effort to address long-standing intercommunal tensions and foster reconciliation.

Between 14 and 19 April 2015, MINUSMA, in line with its mandate concerning the protection of civilians, which includes the mitigation of intercommunal violence, supported a peace caravan to Goundam Cercle. To restore trust between the communities of Goundam, peaceful messages were disseminated to people in over 20 localities in the Cercle, including members of Arab, Fulani, Songhai and Tuareg communities, as well as representatives of the M’bera refugee camp in Mauritania. Activities included large public meetings in Bintagoungou, Douékiré, Goundam, Mbouna and Scale, as well as the facilitation of several focus group sessions aimed at promoting reconciliation. In addition, MINUSMA facilitated a number of intercommunal dialogues between the Tuareg and the Fulani communities in Bamako and the Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions between September to December 2015.

With support from MINUSMA, the Ministry of National Reconciliation organized two intercommunal dialogues between the Tuareg and the Fulani communities in Ansongo and Gao in the Gao region on 10 and 11 November 2015 respectively.

The Mouvements et fronts unifiés de l’Azawad (MFUA) (English: the Unified Movements and Fronts of Azawad) was a coalition of four Tuareg and Moorish armed factions formed in northern Mali in the early 1990s. The coalition included the L’Armée révolutionnaire de libération de l’Azawad (ARLA), Le Front islamique arabe de l’Azawad (FIAA), Le Front populaire de libération de l’Azawad (FPLA), and the Mouvement populaire de l’Azaouad (MPA) (English: Popular Movement of the Azawad). Following the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992, a conflict arose between the MPA and ARLA. The FIAA and the FPLA supported the ARLA during this conflict. The conflict had an ethnic element because the vassal Imghad clan made up for most of the ARLA, while the noble Ifoghas clan dominated the MPA. Negotiations between the ARLA and the MPA, without the involvement of a mediator, led to the conclusion of a treaty on 11 April 1994. The treaty was aimed to close the ranks between the two groups in preparation for a meeting in Tamanrasset between MFUA and the Government of Mali.

FPLA leader Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine initiated another round of negotiations between the MPA and ARLA, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 15 December 1994. The FPLA also signed the agreement. However, the FIAA was not part of this round of peace talks process. On the contrary, the agreement signed by the MPA, ARLA, and FPLA on 15 December 1994 not only stipulated peace between the signatory groups, but also included a provision that the three groups would fight ‘renegade rebels’, referring to the FIAA. In the weeks prior to this formal treaty, the MPA and FPLA, toghetter with the Mouvement Patriotique Ganda Koi (MPGK), had already reached an informal agreement to fight the FIAA together.

The conflict between the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Alhaji Kromah (ULIMO-K) and the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J) was essentially a power struggle between rival factions within the United Liberation Movement of Liberia (ULIMO).The ULIMO consisted of mainly two ethnicities: the Krahn and the Mandingo. The leadership of the ULIMO reflected these ethnicities. Alhaji Kromah, of Mandingo ethnicity, was the head of the organization, while Roosevelt Johnson, of Krahn ethnicity, was the field commander. This division of power kept internal rivalries largely in check, but this changed with the conclusion of the Cotonu Peace Agreement on 25 July 1993. This agreement aimed to end the national-level conflict and specified the transitional arrangements until the presidential elections. The agreement led to the inauguration of the Transitional Ruling Council of State in April 1994. ULIMO was represented within this council with two seats, but the candidates for both seats were assigned by Alhaji Kromah. In March 1994, already prior to the council being fully installed on 20 April 1994, tensions about who should take the seats within the council and about the leadership question of the ULIMO more broadly had led to clashes between the two rival factions within the rebel group. The ULIMO split along ethnic lines in March 1994 and intense fighting took place between March and June 1994. In April 1994, ECOMOG mediated negotiations between the two ULIMO factions, but without any results. Fighting broke out again between the two factions in May in Grand Cape Mount and Bomi Counties.

Mediation efforts conducted by UNOMIL and ECOMOG to resolve the dispute within ULIMO resulted on 6 May 1994 in a ceasefire and an agreement to hold further negotiations. However, the negotiations collapsed and serious fighting resumed on 26 May 1994. Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings, who acted as the chairman of ECOWAS, mediated negotiations in Akosombo. These negotiations involved the Government of Liberia, the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), and the of ULIMO-K, but not ULIMO-J.
On 30 November, the ULIMO-J and the ULIMO-K signed a ceasefire agreement during a round of negotiations mediated by UNOMIL and ECOMOG.

In order to bring all major non-state armed groups in Liberia on board of the peace process, another round of negotiations was held in Accra in December 1994. The parties signed the Accra Agreement on 21 December 1994, which enabled the non-signatories to the Akosombo Agreement that had been concluded in September 1994, including ULIMO-J, to accept that agreement. The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. This ceasefire also entailed an obligation of ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J to stop fighting.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. Both factions of the ULIMO were part of this agreement and both factions committed to a ceasefire and several power-sharing provisions included in the agreement.
On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations aimed at ending the civil war in Liberia was mediated by Nigeria’s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the ULIMO-K on the one side and the ULIMO-J, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL)  on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor’s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS – with support from the UN and the OAU – led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU third parties led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K. Nevertheless, tensions between ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J remained.

On 6 September 1996, the two groups concluded another ceasefire during a round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN. Hostilities subsequently ceased in Bomi county and both groups disengaged their forces.
On 24 September 1996, ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN mediated another ceasefire after some fighting had resumed.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Alhaji Kromah (ULIMO-K) on the one side and the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor’s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS – with support from the UN and the OAU – led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July 1996.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.

The OAU appointed Reverend Cnaan Banna, the former President of Zimbabwe, as its eminent person to Liberia in January 1993. Together with Gordon-Sommers, Bannana was actively involved in peacemaking activities and discussed the establishment of a ceasefire with Charles Taylor in April 1993.

A UN-sponsored peace conference was held in the UN Palais des Nations in Geneva from 10 to 17 July 1993, under the joint chairmanship of the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU. The Interim Government of National Unity (IGNU), the NPFL, and ULIMO attended this conference.

The early July effort paved the way for another round of negotiations that started on 22 July and led to the signing of a peace agreement between the conflict parties in Cotonou on 25 July 1993. At this peace conference, Somers acted as the UN’s chief mediator, while the OAU’s eminent for Liberia person Canaan Banana acted as the OAU’s chief mediator. In addition, Nicéphore Soglo, President of Benin and chairman of ECOWAS, acted as the chief mediator of ECOWAS. According to the provisions of the agreement, which was signed in Cotonou, Benin, a ceasefire was to take effect on 1 August 1993, after which a provisional government was to be established by the end of September 1993. Elections were scheduled for 1994. In order to ensure compliance with the ceasefire, the agreement also set up a Joint Ceasefire Monitoring Committee, comprising representatives of the Interim Government, the NPFL, and ULIMO, as well as representatives of ECOWAS and the UN. However, the Cotonou ceasefire broke down almost as soon as it was signed. There was renewed fighting between the NPFL and ULIMO, while a new Krahn-dominated militia, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), emerged in the south-east of the country where it was immediately at odds with the NPFL.

In 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Progress in the peace process halted as heavy fighting took place between ULIMO and NPFL in April 1994. Consequently, with support from a mediation team consisting of UN, OAU, and ECOWAS diplomats, Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in April 1994.
On 9 September, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire and the next day ULIMO also announced a ceasefire.

The parties engaged in another round of negotiations and finalized the Akosombo Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. The agreement was signed by the NPFL, ULIMO, and the Liberian Armed Forces. However, at the time of the signing of the Akosombo Peace Agreement, the fighting was still raging throughout Liberia. In fact, Charles Taylor and his forces were being expelled from their headquarters in Gbarnga simultaneously to the peace process in Akosombo.

The earlier peace process continued and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government  (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra Agreement lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995.

On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations between the NPFL and the ULIMO was mediated by Nigeria’s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU. Prior to these talks, Abacha met with Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings. It became clear during this meeting that Nigeria would accept Ghana’s position that only the inclusion of the warlords in the government would bring peace to Liberia. Consequently, Abacha had also held private consultations with NPFL leader Taylor for four days prior to the negotiations in Abuja, which had led to a rapprochement between Nigeria and the NPFL. With Nigeria no long opposing his ambitions, Taylor became more amenable to a political solution to the conflict. The Abuja Agreement gave sole authority for military enforcement to ECOMOG and removed the role that the Akosombo Agreement had assigned to the LNTG.  A ceasefire was re-declared, which would take effect on 26 August 1995. The agreement also established a time-frame for the formation of an interim government and the distribution of positions within the interim government.  All signatory rebel groups of the Abuja Agreement – including the ULIMO, the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), NPFL, the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia - Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC), and LNC – sent orders to their commanders to cease hostilities. The only exception was LPC, which continued fighting. Fighting continued in the south-east and west of Liberia.

In April 1994, the transitional government, UNOMIL and ECOMOG undertook efforts to bring about a ceasefire between NPFL and LPC as well as to bring LPC into the disarmament and demobilization process. However, in May 1994, LPC continued to attack NPFL.

In 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in order to salvage the Cotonou agreement, which led to the conclusion of the Akosombo Peace Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. Yet, the LPC was not included in this peace process either. Hence, the LPC rejected the Akosombo agreement. Consequently, the peace process continued and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions which also included the LPC, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government  (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra cease-fire lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995.   Unlike previous agreements, the Abuja Agreement included most non-state armed groups, including the ULIMO, the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), LPC, NPFL, AFL, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia - Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC), and LNC. The Abuja Agreement gave sole authority for military enforcement to ECOMOG and removed the role that the Akosombo Agreement had assigned to the LNTG.
On 21 and 22 August 1995, a new round of negotiations aimed at ending the civil war in Liberia was mediated by Nigeria’s General Sani Abacha in Abuja, with support from the UN and the OAU.

A ceasefire was re-declared, which would take effect on 26 August 1995. The agreement also established a time-frame for the formation of an interim government and the distribution of positions within the interim government. All signatory rebel groups of the Abuja Agreement sent orders to their commanders to cease hostilities. The only exception was LPC, which continued fighting. Fighting continued in the south-east and west.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Alhaji Kromah (ULIMO-K) on the one side and the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor’s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS – with support from the UN and the OAU – led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.

The armed conflict between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the Independent National Patriotic Front of Liberia (INPFL) originated from internal disagreements within the NPFL, prompting a faction within the NPFL to break away and form the INPFL. More specifically, NPFL leader Charles Taylor was challenged by Prince Yormie Johnson in January 1990. Johnson subsequently left NPFL and set up the INPFL. He was followed by around 500 fighters. In response to the split, the two conflict parties clashed in late January 1990. The groups were geographically separated for some time following this initial clash. The INPFL was based in and around Monrovia, while Charles Taylor had set up a parallel government in the northern city of Gbarnga in Bong County. The conflict parties clashed occasionally during attempts of the NPFL to capture the capital. It should, however, be noted that the level of fighting between the NPFL and the INPFl was low in comparison to the violence between these two groups on the one side and the government forces on the other side. Negotiations mediated by ECOWAS between the Government of Liberia, the NPFL, and the INPFL led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement on 28 November 1990.
Another round of talks between these conflict parties, mediated by ECOWAS, led to signing of the Banjul IV agreement on 21 December 1990.

Following two days of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in the Togolese capital Lome, the INPFL and the NPFL, as well as the government forces, signed a ceasefire on 14 February 1991. The ceasefire was signed by NPFL leader Charles Taylor, INPFL leader Prince Yormie Johnson, and commander of Liberia’s armed forces General Hezekiah.

On 15 March 1991, the All-Liberia National Conference was held to discuss political power-sharing arangements in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent a NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference ended on 20 April 1991. The conflict parties agreed to form an Interim Government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held as early as October 1991. Subsequent widespread infighting took place within the INPFL over disagreement about cooperating with the Interim Government. The infighting within the INPFL effectively ended the fighting between the INPFL and the NPFL.The INPFL was excluded from subsequent peace talks in 1991 between the Government of Liberia and the NPFL at Yamossoukro, which were mediated by ECOWAS and the INN.

Prince Johnson and Charles Taylor concluded a modus vivendi in 1992, under which their two militias agreed to cooperate in taking over Monrovia. In what the parties dubbed operation “Octopus”, the NPFL and INPFL were to launch a joint military assault against ECOMOG. However, Prince Johnson reneged on this agreement last minute. Consequently, the NPFL overran the INPFL’s Cadwell Base and killed some of its fighters. Prince Johnson surrendered to ECOMOG and was given sanctuary in Nigeria. The INPFL thus ceased to exist in October 1992.

The Wardei and the Wardei fought the Pokomo over control over grazing land and water in 2001. The Orma and Pokomo engaged in peace talks mediated by the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya on 21 July 2001. The chief mediator was Sheikh Ali Shee. An Imam, a priest, and tribal representatives from the Ngao, Sailoni, and Simi Karo were also present. This effort resulted in the Orma and Pokomo signing a ceasefire agreement. In October, the Kenyan government led a disarmament operation and suspended the land adjudication program in December 2001.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met for a peace meeting at the Almond Resort in Garissa. Leaders of the Oma, Wardei, and Pokomo attended the meeting. All representatives renewed their commitment to the Modogashe Declaration in the presence of provincial Commissioners.

The NCIC initiated a mediation effort in September 2014. The NCIC worked with religious and community leaders, civil societies, the National Steering Committee on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management (NSC), and the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS). The mediation effort focused on mitigating violence in the towns of Amu, Faza, Hindi, and Witu. On 17 September 2014, community leaders signed The Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County. President Uhuru Kenyatta attended the signing ceremony. To follow-up with the implementation, peace committees were created in Hindi, Lamu, and Mpeketoni.
agreement_name: Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County

description: The Nandi and the Pokot both reside in the Rift Valley Province of Kenya. Once a mainly pastoralist group, the Nandi increasingly turned to farming during the 1900s. Despite this lifestyle change, cattle still holds a significant position in the group’s lifestyle has been a source of conflict with the pastoral Pokot. On 26 August 1998, the Nandi and Pokot – as well as the Luhya, Sabaot and Sengwe – convened for a peace meeting in Kitale. These tribes created a 15-person committee to advocate for an end to raiding and help from the District Commissioner.

In January 2002, the National Council of the Churches of Kenya (NCCK), Oxfam, the Office of the President, and the Department for International Co-operation and Development mediated a round of peace talks between the Nandi and Pokot. The actors established an early warning system and conflict resolution mechanisms during these peace talks.

In January 2013, tribal representatives of the Nandi and Pokot – as well as the  Elgeyo Marakwet, Turkana,  and Baringo – engaged in a peace meeting. The meetine ended with the signing of a statement that committed them to a later meeting in Eldoret to negotiate a peace coalition.
The Catholic Justice and Peace Commission (CJPC), with government officials in attendance, mediated between the conflict parties in July 2002.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the CJPC led to signing of the Kolowa Declaration at Kolowa in October 2002.
On 28 March, the Marakwet and Pokot convened for a peace effort led by the Pokot Education and Development Programme (PEDP).
In 2003, district commissioners from each tribe’s district attended a peace meeting in Chesegon. This peace meeting was interrupted by an attack.

In 2016, large-scale conflict between the tribes reignited. In response, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) organized and supported several peace meetings between representatives of the Marakwet and the Pokot. A round of peace talks led to the conclusion of the Nakuru Declaration in September 2016.
The NCIC mediated another round of peace talks between the Pokot and Marakwet, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement at the Bontana Hotel on 4 November 2016.
Government officials from the West Pokot and Elgeyo Marakwet districts mediated between the conflict parties in January 2018.
On 31 July 2018, local officials from the Marakwet and Pokot districts met for a peace meeting at their shared border.
Elders from both the Marakwet and Pokot tried to mediate between the communities in April 2019, but this effort failed to resolve the conflict.

On 31 July 2019, Deputy President William Ruto mediated a round of peace talks in the Kerio Valley. This mediation effort led to the signing of an agreement between communities of the the Baringo, Elgeyo-Marakwet, and West Pokot counties in which these communities committed to disarmament.

Nakuru district commissioner Aden Noor Aden led a  reconciliation meeting between the Maasai and Kikuyu in Longonot on 17 January 1995. The meeting was attended by elders, religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: local government; religious leaders; traditional leaders

description: On 2 February 2005, after two-week long clashes over the water of the Ewaso Kedong River, a round of negotiations between the Kikuyu and Maasai was held at the Karima Catholic Church in Mai Mahiu. Internal Security Minister Chris Murungaru mediated these negotiations. Although the conflict parties agreed that a joint solution over the use of water had to be found, no peace agreement was concluded.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) that had been established through the National Cohesion and Integration Act of 2008, the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. While the peace talks focused mainly on the armed conflict between the Kikuyu and Kalenjin, other tribes such as the Maasai also joined the peace talks in order to mitigate all armed violence in the area. The negotiations in April 2011 first consisted of separate meetings for each tribe with the NCIC and NSC, after which the mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. Another round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and NSC was held in May 2011. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) joined the mediation team for the round of negotiations in May 2011.

HD mediated a round of negotiations between the Kikuyu and the Maasai in March 2012. This round of negotiations led to the signing of a peace agreement. In order to gather social support for the agreement, the NCIC and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women’s Club, religious leaders, and youth.

A round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and HD led to conclusion of the Nakuru County Peace Accord on 19 August 2012 in Nakuru, signed by the  Kalenjin and the Kikuyu, but also other communities in Kakuru such as the Maasai.
On 3 June 2001, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi mediated between the leaders of both tribes in Nairobi.
On 6 June 2001, the Kisii and Maasai participated in a reconciliation meeting mediated by district commissioners.
Another round of negotiations took place in Trans Mara in late June 2001. These talks were mediated by district leaders.

Several peace meetings between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya, and Luo elders took place in Kaptembwo in August 2008. The UN Development Programme supported the meetings and 52 conflict resolution experts were also involved. The Kenya National Dialogue and Reconciliation (KNDR) process led by Kofi Annan started in early 2008. The UN and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) supported this peace initiative. Several national commissions were established during this process that were designed to support peaceful coexistence. The National Cohesion and Integration Act 2008 established the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) in 2009 as a permanent body for achieving this goal. In February 2010, the NCIC began to investigate the conflict and initiated the Nakuru peace process.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC), the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. Eighty elders, 40 from the Kikuyu and 40 from the Kalenjin, participated in the peacetalks. While these meetings were centered around the latter two’s conflict, other tribes such as the Luo and the Kisii joined the peace talks in order to help resolve broader conflict in the area. The peace process started with separate meetings for each tribe that were mediated by the NCIC and NSC. The mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. The Provincial Administration also attended some of these meetings. HD officially joined the peace process at the third joint meeting that was held in May 2011.

A mediation effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) between 24 elders from each tribe led to the conclusion of a draft agreement  that was revised and agreed to in March 2012. To gather social support for the agreement, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women's Club, religious leaders, and youth.

The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Kisii and the Luo, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the agreement was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner’s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); government; local government

description: Following up on the Nakuru County Peace Accord concluded in 2015 that addressed many different inter-ethnic conflicts in the Nakuru County, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) conducted a specific mediation effort to facilitate an end to the conflict between the Kalenjin and Luo. In January 2016, the commission collaborated with the local administrative officials from Kisumu and Nandi Counties and began to mediated between the two tribes. NCIC Chair Hon. Francis Ole Kaparo acted as the chief mediator. Another round of peace talk was scheduled for June, but the mediation team chased out of town by a mob of citizens who were angry that the mediation effort had not made any progress.
In August 2016, another round of negotiations resulted in the Chemelil Declaration in which both communities agreed to end hostilities.

Several peace meetings between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya, and Luo elders took place in Kaptembwo in August 2008. The UN Development Programme supported the meetings and 52 conflict resolution experts were also involved. The Kenya National Dialogue and Reconciliation (KNDR) process led by Kofi Annan started in early 2008. The UN and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) supported this peace initiative. Several national commissions were established during this process that were designed to support peaceful coexistence. The National Cohesion and Integration Act 2008 established the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) in 2009 as a permanent body for achieving this goal. In February 2010, the NCIC began to investigate the conflict and initiated the Nakuru peace process.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC), the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) and the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. Eighty elders, 40 from the Kikuyu and 40 from the Kalenjin, participated in the peacetalks. While these meetings were centered around the latter two’s conflict, other tribes such as the Luhya joined the peace talks in order to help resolve broader conflict in the area. The peace process started with separate meetings for each tribe that were mediated by the NCIC and NSC. The mediation team later facilitated joint meetings. The Provincial Administration also attended some of these meetings. HD officially joined the peace process at the third joint meeting that was held in May 2011.

A mediation effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) between 24 elders from each tribe led to the conclusion of a draft agreement that was revised and agreed to in March 2012. To gather social support for the agreement, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women's Club, religious leaders, and youth.

The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Luhya, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the Accord was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner’s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); government; local government

description: In addition, several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa, where they renewed the Modogashe Declaration.

Internal Security Permanent Secretary Francis Kimemia mediated peace talks between the Borana, Turkana, Meru, Samburu, and Somali at Harambee house on 16 and 17 November 2011. The peace talks did not end in the conclusion of a peace agreement.
A peace meeting between the Samburu, Turkana, Borana, and Turkana was held in Marsabit on 24 March 2013. The Marsabit Catholic Peace Justice Commission mediated the peace talks.
In February 2015, Francis ole Kaparo and Yusuf Haji, the former National Assembly speaker and county senator respectively, mediated negotiations between 35 community elders in Marsabit.
On 15 February, leaders of the conflict parties engaged in bilateral negotiations in Marsabit.

Another round of negotiations between the conflict parties, between 21 and 22 February, led to the conclusion of the Boma Peace Agreement. This round of negtoiations was mediated by government officials and other community leaders. The Boma Peace Agreement included a provision for a team to oversee the implementation of the agreement.
In late September and early October, multiple reconciliation talks were led between tribal elders of the Turkana, Borana, Meru and Samburu tribes in Isiolo County.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa. On the final day, representatives renewed the “Modogashe Declaration” in the presence of respective provincial Commissioners.

The peace process led by the PPNT broke down when the Konkomba found out that the PPNT team had already accepted elements of the Nanumba’s position paper without consulting with the Konkomba representatives. Fighting subsequently erupted again from February to March 1995. The Ghanian government attempted to end the fighting through a military intervention. Meanwhile, civil society groups took over peace talks between the conflict parties. Several NGOs – including ActionAid, Catholic Relief Services, Oxfam, Red Cross, World Vision International, and the Nairobi Peace Initiative (NPI) – formed a consortium. These NGOs mediated peace talks involving 16 members from the Konkomba, Nanumba, Dagomba and Gonja (4 from each group) in Kumasi in May 1995. By the end of this peace meeting, the sides agreed to seek form a Peace and Reconciliation Follow-Up Committee, comprising of eight members from the groups.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative

description: In June 1995, the Gonja and Konkomba participated in a reconciliation talk in Accra organized by President Rawlings. The Konkomba delegation pledged that Konkomba would no longer attack Gonja farms.
Another round of peace talks mediated by the consortium of NGOs was held in Kumasi in September 1995. These talks are generally referred to as the Kumasi II peace talks.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative

description: The Kumasi III peace talks were held in November 1995. Religious NGOs – including the Catholic Relief Service (CRS), Action Aid, and the Ghana Council of Churches – facilitated peace activities such prayer meetings during this round of talks.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative

description: The Kumasi IV peace talks in December were aimed at preparing for a round of negotiations in which the conflict parties would sign a final peace agreement.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative

description: The Kumasi V peace talks held in March 1996 led to the signing of the Kumasi Accord on Peace and Reconciliation Between Ethnic Groups in the Northern Region of Ghana.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative
agreement_name: Kumasi Accord on Peace and Reconciliation Between Ethnic Groups in the Northern Region of Ghana

description: In May 1996, the Gonja and Konkomba participated in a reconciliation ceremony that led to another peace agreement.

A final round of negotiations, known as the Kumasi VI peace talks, took place in December 1996. This round of peace talks led to the creation of the Northern Ghana Youth and Development Association (NORYDA), which was mandated to build peace in the region.
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid; Catholic Relief Services; Oxfam; Red Cross; World Vision International; Nairobi Peace Initiative

description: Disputes over land ownership between the Gonja on the one side and the Konkomba and Nawuri on the other side escalated into armed conflict in Kpanda town in Ghana’s Northern Region in 1991. On 7 May 1991 in Tamale, the Northern Regional Security Committee (REGSEC) convened a round of pre-negotiations with members of the Gonja and Nawuri. The conflict parties agreed to mediation by the Bimbilla Na.

Following the pre-negotiations in Tamale, the conflict parties met for peace talks at the palace of the Bimbilla Na on 7 June 1991. This round of talks did not lead to an agreement. In 1991, the Gonja asked to reconcile with the Konkomba through mediation by the Nanumba chief of Bimbila.

side_a: Rer Liban subclan of Habr Awal (Issaq)
side_b: Rer Samatar subclan of Habr Awal (Issaq)
description: Land disputes between the Rer Liban and Rer Samatar subclans of the Habr Awal escalated into armed conflict in 1992. Both sides received external support from actors in Somaliland during the conflict. The Rer Liban were affiliated with Ibrahim Egal’s government, while the Rer Samatar aligned with opposition movements. In July 1992, the Ethiopian government mediated between leaders of the Red Liban and Rer Samatar. This mediation effort successfully ended the armed conflict.
A peace conference, attended by leaders of the Gedeo and Guji, was held in Borana in July 1998, but this conference ended violently.
In response to the July violence, Gedeo and Guji elders and neighboring clan leaders mediated a ceasefire.
When clashes reignited in August 1998, a mediation team set up by the government and led by Dr. Kassu Illala and Ato Hassen Ali mediated between the conflict parties.

On 4 November 1998, the President of Oromia Region Ato Kuma Demekssa mediated a peace meeting attended by 164 Gedeo and Guji tribal representatives. This mediation effort did not result in a formal peace agreement or ceasefire.
In early 1998, peace talks were held in the Gedeo and Borana zones in response to renewed fighting.

The Borana, Degodia, Ajuran, Garre, Rendille participated in a peace meeting in Modogashe on 31 August 2001. This meeting was mediated by local communal leaders and provincial commissioners. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and included a disarmament provision.

In May 2009, the central government initiated the Negelle Peace Process. The Ethiopian central government worked closely together with the Kenyan government, regional states authorities of the Oromia and Somali, and local tribal leaders. USAID funded the project and Mercy Corps assisted the local actors. On 8 and 9 May 2009, the Kenyan and Ethiopian governments convened peace talks between multiple elders from various communities, including the Borana and Garre, in order to garner their support for the Negelle Peace Process.
third_party: government; Kenya; USAID; Mercy Corps; local government; traditional leaders

description: In the first week of June 2009, a peace meeting between the Borana and Garre, as well as some other communities, was held in Dukana. Ethiopian and Kenyan government officials acted as mediators during this round of negotiations.

The local peace committees from the Oromia and Somali districts in Moyale met for a peace meeting in Balale kebelle on 23 October 2010. The conflict parties did not reach a peace agreement at this meeting, but another peace peace meeting was planned.
The second meeting led by the local peace committee took place on 10 November. The peace meeting did not result in the conclusion of an agreement.
In June 2011, the Negelle Peace Accords were ratified.
third_party: government; Kenya; USAID; Mercy Corps; local government; traditional leaders

description: Fighting between the Borana and the Gabra and Garre alliance erupted again in November 2011. The district governments deployed security forces to end fighting between the conflict parties. Local government officials also brought all three tribes together for a peace meeting in Moyale on 28 and 29 November 2011.

Government forces intervened in response to fighting between the Borana and Garre in December 2012. This military intervention was followed by a mediation effort by government officials in December 2012 that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.
In 1998, the Degodia accused the Borana of robbery. The two tribes met for peace talks mediated by Ethiopian government officials in Negelle in Ethiopia, but no agreement was concluded.

Another round of peace talks was mediated by government officials from the Oromiyya and Somali Regions. Since this peace effort did not succeed, the federal government sent security forces to stop the fighting.

The Degodia and Borana were brought back together for peace talks mediated by a Joint Peace Committee created by the federal government. These talks were held in Filtu. Each tribe tribe returned stolen cattle following this peace meeting.

The Borana, Degodia, Ajuran, Garre, Rendille participated in a peace meeting in Modogashe on 31 August 2001. This meeting was mediated by local communal leaders and provincial commissioners. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and included a disarmament provision.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa. On the final day, representatives renewed the “Modogashe Declaration” in the presence of respective provincial Commissioners.
In January 1993, the Arbore and Borana engaged in bilateral peace talks. This peace meeting focused on reaching an agreement on free grazing access for all livestock.

Elders from both tribes participated in another peace meeting in Turmi from 6 to 9 March 1993. This led to the signing of a peace agreement that addressed the land rights of Borana, as well as access to this land for non-Borana, including the Arbore, Bodi, Dassanetch, Hamar, Konso, Mursi, Nyangatom, and Tsemai.
A peace meeting between the Amhara and Oromo, without the involvement of a mediator, led to a ceasefire in 2000.

In mid-December 2019, the Oromo and Amhara held a two-day peace forum. By the end of this peace forum, the attendees recognized the significance of future negotiations, but none were formally planned.

However, at the national level, both conflict parties participated in several round of negotiations involving the Government of the DRC, the rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi. These negotiations took place in the context of the Inter-Congolese dialogue facilitated by the OAU/AU and the UN.  On the initiative of South Africa, and with support from the OAU and the UN, the Congolese government and the rebel groups, but also the Mayi Mayi militias, met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.

The April negotiations paved the way for another round of negotiations, in which the representatives of the government, the rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka on 4 May 2001.
agreement_name: Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue

description: On 19 April 2002, the government, rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed a partial peace agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC, also referred to as the Sun City Accord.

Another round of  negotiations as part of the Inter-Congolese dialogue led to signing of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on Transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo – also known as the Pretoria Agreement – on 16 December 2002.
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: In early 1999, a split emerged within the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie (RCD) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy) between the Goma faction supported by Rwanda and the Kisangani faction supported by Uganda. Tensions rose due to Uganda falling out with Rwanda, as well as more general leadership struggles within the RCD, not least due to the upcoming negotiations in which many individuals wanted to have an important role. After a congress aimed at uniting the movement in Goma in January 1999, Emile Ilunga was appointed as the new leader of RCD-Goma. Wamba dia Wamba subsequently moved to Kisangani, where he was protected by Ugandan troops, declaring that he was not stepping down. The split was finalized in May 1999, resulting in the formation of the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-Mouvement de Libération (RCD-ML) (English: Congolese Democratic Rally-Liberation Movement). After clashes between the Ugandan backed RCD-ML and Rwandan backed RCD-Goma in Kisangani in August 1999, Wamba again had to flee, this time to Ituri, where he set up the RCD-ML headquarters in Bunia. In 2000, the RCD-ML experienced a split, when the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-Kisangani-Mouvement de Libération (RCD-K-ML) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-Kisangani-Liberation Movement) broke away. Ugandan generals started to support Wamba’s principal lieutenants. This further fueled an underlying conflict between Wamba dia Wamba, Nande Mbusa Nyamwisi, and the Hema John Tibasima. Both lieutenants started to train separate militias. The two factions fought each other in the context of this split, with violent battles taking place in Bunia in October and November 2000. Museveni subsequently chose the side of Wamba and evacuated Wamba to Uganda in November 2000. Factional fighting continued and spread to the Ugandan border-post Kasindi. After several unsuccessful attempts at mediation by Uganda during November and December, Wamba dia Wamba was exiled to Kampala in December. In order to restore calm to Ituri and avoid new splinter groups developing within the RCD-ML, Uganda forced all militias under their control: RCD-ML, the new RCD-K-ML, RCD-N and MLC to join forces within a new movement: the Front de libération du Congo (FLC). MLC leader Jean-Pierre Bemba was appointed as the leader of the FLC.

The conflict between Banyarwanda on the one side and the Hunde and Nyanga on the other side was mainly fought in the Nord Kivu province of the DRC. Banyarwandas are seen as outsiders that have moved to Nord Kivu, while the Hunde and Nyanga are seen as the natives. In 1993, an armed conflict broke out when the Hunde, together with the Nyanga, aimed to chase the Banyarwanda out from Walikale and Masisi areas. Violence subsequently spread across the entire region. In July 1993, a group of churches and local NGOs brought members of the warring groups together in an effort to ease tensions in the region. At this meeting, the conflict parties agreed that the conflict had been manipulated by Zairian state-level politicians, but disagreed about how to resolve the underlying issues of the conflict. In addition to this local peacemaking effort, President Mobutu visited Goma in July 1993 to discuss the ethnic conflict and subsequently deployed elite troops in the region to curb the fighting. These troops managed to remain impartial and prevent further fighting. This military intervention ended what came to be known as the Masisi war by November 1993.

However, the key issues of nationality, land distribution, and political representation had not been resolved, and government officials at both the provincial and national levels showed no interest in seeking a lasting solution to the conflict. In early 1994, local peace conferences led by local leaders took place in Mweso town and Masisi town in which members of the different ethnic groups discussed the causes of the violence and sought to make recommendations for preventing its recurrence in the future. The conferences were a joint initiative between a number of local NGOs and OXFAM. The main recommendation of these conferences was that resolution of the nationality question by the Zairean Government was a necessary condition for peace in Masisi.

The conflict between Hunde and Hutu in the Nord Kivu province of Zaire started in 1993, when the Hunde, together with the Nyanga, aimed to chase the Hutu out from the Walikale and Masisi regions. Armed fighting subsequently spread across the region. The regional governor fueled the conflict when he suggested that security forces would assist efforts by Nyanga and Hunde to “exterminate” the Hutu. The Hunde formed a coalition with Nyanga, Twa, and Nande Mayi-Mayi, while the Hutu allied with fellow Tutsi Banyrwandans. In July 1993, a group of churches and local NGOs brought members of the warring groups together in an effort to ease tensions in the region. At this meeting, the conflict parties agreed that the conflict had been manipulated by Zairian state-level politicians, but disagreed about the how to resolve the underlying issues of the conflict. In addition to this local peacemaking effort, President Mobutu visited Goma in July 1993 to discuss the ethnic conflict and subsequently deployed elite troops in the region to curb the fighting. These troops managed to remain impartial and prevent further fighting. This military intervention ended what came to be known as the Masisi war by November 1993.

However, the key issues of nationality, land distribution, and political representation had not been resolved, and government officials at both the provincial and national levels showed no interest in seeking a lasting solution to the conflict. In early 1994, local peace conferences took place in Mweso town and Masisi town in which members of the different ethnic groups discussed the causes of the violence and sought to make recommendations for preventing its recurrence in the future. The conferences were a joint initiative between a number of local NGOs and OXFAM. The main recommendation of these conferences was that resolution of the nationality question by the Zairean Government was a necessary condition for peace in Masisi.

On 3 August 1997, the Mouvement Populaire Anjouanais (MPA) (English: Anjouan People’s Movement) declared independence from Comoros as the Republic of Anjouan. Internal turmoil soon arose about the rest of the world not recognizing the Republic of Anjouan. Most of the MPA led by Abdallah Ibrahim believed that solution lied in collaboration with another island of Comoros, Moroni. However, the Anjouan prime minister Said Omar Chamassi argued for formal alignment with France, the former colonial power.  Said Omar Chamassi and those supporting him formed the MPA Said Omar Chamassi faction (MPA-SOC). Negotiations between the MPA/Republic of Anjouan and the MPA-SOC led to the signing of a ceasefire on 5 December 1998, the day that fighting started.
On 13 December 1998, a day after the clash in Mutsamudu, the two parties reached an informal truce. Attempts by local elders to mediate continued after the agreement.

Members of a French humanitarian mission, Jean-Luc Machuron and Jacques Amblard, with local leaders from Ouani mediated between Ibrahim and Chamassi. Negotiations between the two sides at the Anjouan airport on 16 December led to a 48-hour ceasefire. This ceasefire was a formal iteration of the 13 December agreement that had lasted until then.

The Choa Arab and Kotoko clashed on 29 January 1992. On 30 and 31 January, in response to the violence, the Far North governor Benoit Namvou held multiple meetings with local leaders from the government and tribes in order to reach a ceasefire.

President Paul Biya directed the central council of the Cameroon People’s Democratic Movement (CPDM) to mediate between the Choa Arab and Kotoko. Negotiations led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement in Kousseri on 18 September 1993. The United Nations collaborated with the government to oversee the ceasefire by launching a peace mission in October 1993.

On 14 January 1994, fighting between the two tribes resumed. On 17 January, the government represented by Gilbert Andre Tsoungui, the local territorial administrator, tried to mediate a ceasefire, but did not succeed.

The Social Democratic Front (SDF) struggled to be granted basic political rights prior to the first multi-party elections that were held in Cameroon in October 1992. The SDF subsequently organized strikes in order to legalize opposition parties in Cameroon. These strikes included the closing of marketplaces. During the fourth week of the strike, on 15 July 1991, Banya women opened  a local market in Meiganga in northern Cameroon. This triggered an attack by the Foulbe and Hausa in the area. The government deployed troops in the town after two days of fighting. On 19 July 1991, a government mediation effort succeeded in ending the fighting. The tribal leaders shared a symbolic drink of water as a sign of peace.

President Dingha Ignatius Bayin of the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (CPDM) mediated peace talks between Bafanji and the Blikumbat aimed at resolving their land dispute. On 29 June 2009, the two conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and the creation of peace committees.

The Zaghawa have historically mainly inhabited the northern part of Darfur, but some Zaghawa have moved southwards. This created tensions with other ethnic groups, including with the Ma’aliyah. Armed clashes between the two groups in Muhajiriya in October 2008 resulted in over 40 people. Members of the Sudan Liberation Army/Movement-Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) mediated between the conflict parties in October 2008.
UNAMID also mediated between the conflict parties in October 2008.

President of Chad, Idriss Déby Itno, acted as the chief mediator at tribal mediation forum in Um Jaras from 26 to 29 March 2014. The forum was attended by tribal leaders from Darfur, including the Zaghawa, Rizeigat, Massalit, Ma’alia, Salamat and Ta’isha tribes. Sudanese Vice-President Hassabo Mohamed Abdul Rahman acted as the Joint Chief Mediator. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir joined the forum on 29 March. The forum ended with the participants’ announcement of their full support for peace and peaceful coexistence in Darfur.

Between April and May 2000, the Somalia National Peace Conference was held in Arta, Djibouti, which resulted in the creation of the Transitional National Government (TNG) led by Abdulkassim Salat Hassan. In response, Hussein Aideed formed the Somalia Reconciliation and Restoration Council (SRRC) as a political and paramilitary opposition organization in southern Somalia. The creation of the TNG and the SRRC led to tensions among the leadership of the United Somali Congress/Somali Salvation Alliance (USC/SSA). Itself a breakaway faction, the USC/SSA experienced a split in the context the creation of the TNG. While USC/SSA leader Musa Sudi sided with the SRRC, one of his deputies, Omar “Finish”, broke away and instead aligned with the TNG. This led to armed fighting between the USC/SSA and the USC/SSA faction led by Omar “Finish” (USC/SSA-OMF) on 26 December 2001. The next day, on 27 December 2001, the two sides reached a ceasefire agreement in Mogadishu after a first round of negotiations mediated by local elders led by Hussein Jila'ow. This ceasefire did not last.

Musa Sudi and Omar “Finish” engaged in direct negotiations following another round of fighting near Mogadishu in February 2003. Clan elders mediated between the two leaders, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 26 February 2003.

From 13 to 16 November 1996, the Pokot and Turkana attended a peace meeting in Moroto. This peace meeting was mediated by government officials from Uganda and Kenya. The meeting did not result in the conclusion of an agreement.

In 1997, elders from the Karimojong, Pokot, Sabiny, and Turkana collaborated to form the Pokot-Karamojong-Turkana-Sabiny (POKATUSA), a peace organization aimed at bringing an end to the conflicts in Karamoja. POKATUSA collaborated with World Vision and received funding from the United Kingdom. POKATUSA held several peace meetings in 1997.

In July 2002, the representatives from POKATUSA organized a peace meeting in order to find a solution for cattle raids and to stop the violence at the shared border between Uganda and Kenya. Those meetings were attended by Kenyan central government officials as well as regional government representatives, who mediated between the different communities.

A round of negotiations, mediated by the Rift Valley Province Provincial Commissioner (PC), was held near Chesegon in September 2002. This round of negotiations ended with one participant being killed.
In 2003, the POKATUSA organized peace meeting between the Pokot, Karimajong, Turkana, and Sabiny tribes. However, this peace effort was interrupted by a Pokot attack, which resulted in 27 casualties.

In November 2005, the Tegla Loroupe Foundation organized a peace forum for representatives of the Pokot, Turkana, and Karamonjong at Mtelo Hall, West Pokot District. The main aim was to end violence and stop cattle rustling.

In January 2006, some members of the Pokot and Turkana communities established a peace committee. World Vision North Rift peace and the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) participated in the committee’s meetings.
On 16 July 2006, the conflict parties met in Turkana Central for a peace meeting. The Karamojong, Tepeth, and Turkana also participated in this meeting.
In August 2006, the Pokot and Turkana, as well as the Marakwet, met in Turkana South for another peace meeting.

On 29 August, 50 representatives of the Pokot, Samburu, and Turkana convened for an ecumenical prayer meeting and some peace talks. This meeting led to an 8-point peace plan that included provisions for future talks.
In September 2006, the Turkana, Pokot, and Saburu attended a peace meeting mediated by church and community leaders in Laikipia.

The District Commissioner mediated a peace meeting between the Turkana and Pokot in  Chepchoina on 16 April 2007. This meeting led to the creation of a committee of 13 members tasked with finding a solution to the land dispute between the conflict parties. The Catholic Justice and Peace Commission, National Council of Churches of Kenya, Action Aid, World Vision, and Sikom mediated negotiations between the Pokot and Turkana between July and August 2007.
From 26 to 27 April 2007, the Rift Valley Provincial Commissioner mediated peace talks between he conflict parties.
The Rift Valley Provincial Commissioner mediated another round of peace talks on 30 April 2007.

The Internal Security Assistant Minister mediated peace talks between the Turkana, Samburu, and Pokot tribes in the North Rift in August 2008. These negotiations ended without the conclusion of an agreement.
Following negotiations mediated by Rift Valley Provincial Commissioner Hassan Noor Hassan, the Turkana and Pokot agreed to a truce on 3 July 2009.

On 11 September 2010, the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong pastoralists met at a cross-border peace meeting in Moroto to discuss peace at the Uganda and Kenya border. Peace committee members from Amudat, Nakapiripirit, Moroto, and Kaabong districts attended the talks.

Several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

Following negotiations between the Turkana and Pokot in December 2010, the two tribes agreed to the Kainuk-Sarmach-Turkwel-Masol Corridor Peace Agreement. This agreement includes several provisions to prevent cattle rustling and also includes standards for sharing resources.

On 7 and 8 April 2011, the leaders from the counties of Marsabit, Isiolo, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Tana River, Samburu, Meru, and Nairobi met at the Almond Resort in Garissa, where they renewed the Modogashe Declaration.
On 11 April 2011, leaders from West Pokot and Turkana met for a peace meeting at Kainuk Centre.
A reconciliation meeting between the Pokot and Turkana, mediated by local government officials, was held at Sigor in June 2011.
On 6 July 2011, a round of peace talks between the Pokot, Turkana, and Samburu was held at the boundary of Laikipia and Samburu counties.
The Pokot and Turkana representatives met in Turkwel in early 2012. This led to the conclusion of an agreement that broke down in March 2012.
On 5 March 2014, Kenyan government officials and the Kenya Red Cross Society facilitated a peace talk in Eldoret between the Pokot and Turkana, which culminated in the signing of a peace agreement.

Following a new bout of fighting in November 2014, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) organized various peace negotiations to resolve the conflict between the Pokot and the Turkana. The mediation efforts by the NCIC resulted in the signing of the Sirikwa Declaration.

The National Steering Committee on Peace Building and Conflict Management mediated peace talks between the administrators and peace officers from the Turkana and Pokot communities at Starbucks Hotel in Eldoret in November and December 2014.

Turkana and Pokot leaders attended a peace conference that was facilitated by the Catholic Church and Finn Church Aid on 31 January 2015. Senators, governors, Members of Parliament, and local officials also attened this peace conference.
third_party: religious leaders; Finn Church Aid; government; local government

description: On 9 May 2015, Finn Church Aid mediated peace talks in Eldoret between the two sides after another violent clash. Bishop Cornelius Korir of Eldoret Diocese took on the role as lead mediator during these peace talks. The tribal leaders agreed an immediate cessation of hostilities, as well as to participate in a more comprehensive peace process in the following months.
