In May 2015, elders from the Pokot and Turkana tribes reached another ceasefire. This ceasefire was mediated by Finn Church Aid.
From 30 November to 3 December 2015, the National Steering Committee on Peace Building and Conflict Management facilitated peace talks in Eldoret.
Bishop Cornelius Korir convened government officials, as well as leaders from Turkana, West-Pokot, Samburu, and Baringo counties at multiple peace caravans during 2015.

On 22 January 2016, the Karamoja Cluster Project held a cross-border peace meeting in Moroto with the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong. The Karimojong youth requested from the Kenyan government to disarm the Turkana and Pokot. No peace deal was brokered between the two tribes.

A peace meeting between the the Karimojoing, Turkana and Pokot in Moroto on 12 September 2019, mediated by UN officals, led to the conclusion of the Cross-border Sustainable Peace and Development Agreement. The signing ceremony was witnessed by Ugandan and Kenyan presidents, Yoweri Museveni and Uhuru Kenyatta, and representatives of the United Nations Development Programme.
agreement_name: Cross-border Sustainable Peace and Development Agreement

description: The Inter-African Bureau for Animal Resources (IBAR) of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the Government of Kenya, and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army (SPLM/A) facilitated a peace conference between the Toposa and the Turkana in Lodwar in March 1999.

In June 2008, a four-day intercommunity peace conference was organized in Kapoeta, Southern Sudan. It gathered youth from the Turkana (Kenya), the Toposa, Jie, Murile, Kachipo, Buya, Lotuko, Dodoth, and Lokir (Sudan) the Dodoth, Jie, Theuso, Acholi, and Matheniko (Uganda), and the Dongiro (Ethiopia) communities. The conference was facilitated by Netherlands-based IKV Pax Christi and Wilde Ganzen, East African Safari Air Express, and Intervida World Alliance – and supervised by Seeds of Peace in Africa. Attendees acknowledged that peaceful coexistence was a priority and that they aimed to reach this through joint activities, and agreed to create an independent peace committee to observe and report all incidents. Local organizations, particularly Lokado (Turkana), Kopein, Dado Kaabong (Uganda), Kuron Peace Village, and Catholic Diocese of Torit (Southern Sudan), were tasked to implement the adopted activities. As a part of the International Cross border Peace Conference, Seeds of Peace Africa and IKV Pax Christi facilitated several peace meetings between the Turkana and the Toposa in 2008.
third_party: IKV Pax Christi; Wild Ganzen; East African Safari Air Express; Intervida World Alliance; Seeds of Peace Africa

description: Several peace meetings between the Toposa and Turkna wered held in 2009. These meetings were mediated by local organizations involved in peacebuilding, supported by IKV Pax Christi and Seeds of Peace Africa.
third_party: local NGO; IKV Pax Christi; Seeds of Peace Africa

description: On 1 December 2015, Turkana and Toposa representatives, including Turkana Governor Josphat Nanok and South Sudan’s Eastern Equatorial region Governor Luis Lobong, held a peace meeting in Lodwar. The main aim of the meeting was to encourage peaceful relations and stop clashes between two communities.

On 28 July 2018, leaders from the Toposa community from South Sudan and Turkana community from neighboring Kenya met in Narus county of Torit state. The leaders discussed the issue of cattle rustling, which they saw as the main source of conflict between the two communities.

Another cattle raid by Turkana took place in Losolia county in South Sudan in early September 2018. In response, Losolia county commissioner Koetein Thomas discussed the armed attack with Turkana leaders in Turkana County.

At a peace meeting in July 2019, Kenya and South Sudan decided to establish a joint border commission to stop conflict and promote peace between the Toposa, the Turkana, and the Nyangatom in the Elemi Triangle. The Commission was mainly focused on resolving border issues between those communities.

When Idriss Debý, who is Zaghawa, took power in Chad in 1990, members of the Zaghawa began to occupy land in the heartland of the Tama. This land, Dar Tama, is located on the Chadian side of the Chad-Sudan border. This led to tensions and occasional clashes between the two groups. Tensions increased even further due to many prominent rebel leaders in Chad belonging to the Tama. With Zaghawa targeting Tama people, the conflict escalated in 2006. The Chadian government supported the Zaghawa wit weapons. Following a meeting with President Debý and the local governor in Biltine, the main town of the eastern Wadi Fira border region, the local governor traveled to Guereda to mediate between the conflict parties in October 2007. The mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

side_b: Hawarsame Rer Hasan and Habar Ya'qub subclan of Marehan clan (Darod)
description: Around 60 Imams from the conflict parties attended a peace meeting in Berhano in July 2007. This peace meeting was mediated by the Center for Research and Dialogue (CRD). The peace meeting resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on the 14 July 2007 and a peace agreement on 23 July 2007.

Instead of attending a reconciliation meeting with Abdul Wahid in N’Djamena in early November 2005, Minnawi organized a conference with solely members of his faction in Haskanita, where his followers “elected” him as the new president of the SLM/A. Minnawi subsequently sent some of his men to attack northern SLM/A commanders who had attended a round of negotiations with the government in Abuja against his wishes. The United States Deputy Secretary of State, Robert Zoellick, mediated between delegations of the SLM/A and the SLM/A-MM on 9 November 2005. However, Minnawi himself did not attend this meeting and the meeting failed to lead to an agreement.

Tensions between Sudan Liberiation Movement/Army (SLM/A) leader Abdul Wahid and Minni Minnawi had been steadily increasing throughout 2004, especially after Minnawi had refused to send reinforcements to Wahid when the Wahid and some of his fighters had been cornered by government forces in southwest Jebel Marra in early 2004. Negotiations between the Sudanese government and the Darfuri rebel groups were scheduled to resume in early 2005, but tensions within the SLM/A delayed this round of negotiations. The SLM/A leadership repeatedly requested more time to organise a congress that would appoint the leader of the SLM/A and designate a new negotiating team. However, the efforts during the first half of 2005 to reorganise the SLM/A leadership failed and tensions between Abdul Wahid and Minni Minnawi grew even more.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Fighting between the Sa’ad and Suleinam communities resumed in 2004. Heavy clashes took place with both sides using technicals, rocket launchers, and old Soviet-style tanks. The Transitional National Government (TNG) swiftly tried to initiate a peace process. This peace effort was funded and mediated by the TNG, the Puntland administration, and Norway and Sweden through the NGO Interpeace. In June 2004, clan representatives from both sides attended a peace meeting in Mogadishu at Sahafi Hotel. This effort produced a ceasefire agreement and plans to continue reconciliation between the two communities. Iman Jirow would spread the news of the ceasefire first with a delegation from each side and then with a joint delegation. However, the ceasefire broke down before the planned next round of reconciliation talks could take place, as the Suleiman delegation of the joint committee was ambushed by Sa’ad fighters in November 2004.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Several bloody clashed took place in January 2005. In February 2005, President Abdulahi Yusuf Ahmed mediated a ceasefire, but this ceasefire was violated within a month.In addition, throughout 2005, TNG representatives consulted with the Sa’ad and Suleinam sub-clans in Nairobi and Mogadishu, paving the way for a reconciliation conference.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: On 13 February 2006 a six-day meeting started in Galkayo. This conference brought together 60 business and political leaders that represented the conflict parties. The TFG mediated between the conflict parties, with both the President and the Prime Minister of the TFG attending the conference. Representatives of the Center for Research and Dialogue (CRD) and the Puntland Development Research Center (PDRC) were also present. The conference focused on resolving issues concerning access to water points and grazing areas, as well as focused on developing mechanisms to deal with various grievances and avoid revenge killings. The conference ended with the conclusion of an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and the initiation of follow-up effort to promote reconciliation. The representatives of both conflict parties traveled throughout the region to spread the news of the ceasefire from 7 to 11 April 2006.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: From 17 to 22 April 2006, local militia leaders received conflict management training in south Galkayo. Furthermore, smaller meetings were held in Bandiradley and El Hurl by elders from both sides across the region to establish peace agreements on the return of the displaced people and the creation of committees to monitor the ceasefire agreement. From 2 to 6 May, 60 clan representatives from both sides in the conflict and 100 observers attended the meeting in Bandiradley.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: From 23 to 26 June, 68 clan members from both sides in the conflict attended the El Hur conference. The smaller peace meetings in Bandiradley and El hur served to build trust for the main reconciliation conference planned to take place Adado in February 2007.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: From 7 to 18 February 2007, a major peace conference was held aimed at concluding a peace agreement that would settle the conflict. Women from both sides of the conflict established pressure groups to keep the signatories at the table. The conflict parties signed a final peace agreement on 18 February 2007. The agreement led to the forming of security committees which would responds to several to small armed confrontations between the rival clans. The agreement successfully terminated the conflict.

The conflict further escalated when Colonel Hasan Muhammad Nur Shatigadud decided to continue his role as chairman for the RRA when he became president of the Southwest State of Somalia in April 2002. Heavy fighting between forces loyal to Shatigadud and forces loyal to his deputies Shaykh Adan Madobe and Muhammad Ibrahim Habsade subsequently took place in and around Baidoa. A 22-person committee, consisting of Clan elders and local businessmen, headed by Sharif Salah mediated between the conflict parties in July 2002. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 6 July 2002, which was officially signed on 10 July 2002. The document outlined not only a ceasefire, but also specified fines should the conflict parties violate the ceasefire. However, fighting reignited on 27 July 2002, when Adobe declared himself to be the legitimate chairman of the RRA.
Sheikh Qasim Ibrahim Nur, a clan elder, mediated between the conflict parties in August 2002, but without success.

On 2 September 2002, Hasan Shire Muhammad mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties. This ceasefire also stipulated future talks to the resolve the conflict issues.  These reconciliation talks broke down on 30 October 2002.

Mediation efforts by Asharaf clan elders led by Sherrif Ahmed Mohamud Abukar were resumed in November.  This mediation effort between the RRA and RRA-MH led to a ceasefire in early November. The conflict parties promised to vacate the conflict zone completely by 14 November, but this ceasefire was broken in December 2002.

Both the Terjam and the Reizegat Abbala were at times part of the Sudanese government’s counter-insurgency operations in Darfur. In fact, A large number of the Terjam fighters belong to the Popular Defense Forces (PDF), while many of the Rizeigat Abbala fighters belonged to the Border Intelligence Guards. The background to the conflict between the two tribes is that with many of the Fur fleeing their home land, the Terjam and the Reizegat Abbala competed over control over parts of this land. Moreover, the Reizegat Abbala encroached on small areas controlled by the Terjam, increasingly leading to tensions between the two groups. These tensions eventually escalated into armed confrontations, starting in the Bulbul area of South Darfur in January 2007. Since the Reizegat Abbala had been heavily armed by the Sudanese government forces in order to fight the Darfurian rebel groups, it was able to inflict many losses on the Terjam fighters. On 7 January 2007, the Deputy Governor, traveled to the Bulbul area to attempt to mediate between the conflict parties, but his convoy was ambushed and he was forced to return. The government managed to organize a reconciliation conference in Um Zaifa in late February 2007. The representatives of the Terjam and the Reizegat attending this conference agreed on turning over the perpetrators of theft and murder and pay compensation in the form of blood money for losses. However, on 25 February 2007, before the reconciliation conference concluded, Reizegat fighters attacked Amar Jadeed. This attack undermined the prospects for a successful reconciliation conference.
The Terjam and the Reizegat concluded a ceasefire on 11 August 2007.

The Terjam and the Reizegat Abbala clashed again in Bulbul, 40 kilometers north-west of Nyala, in February 2008. This episode of armed fighting started following the abduction of two Reizegat Abbala boys by Terjam tribesmen on 22 February 2008. The fighting lasted for four days. The Deputy Wali mediated to try to calm the situation down on 25 February 2008.

The Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-Kisangani-Mouvement de Libération (RCD-K-ML) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-Kisangani-Liberation Movement), the Mouvement pour la Libération du Congo (MLC) (English: Movement for the Liberation of Congo), and the Rassemblement Congolais pour la Démocratie-National (RCD-N) (English: Congolese Rally for Democracy-National) formed an alliance in January 2001 following negotiations by Uganda. Uganda supported the formation of the FLC because it wanted to reunite the actors it supported and that had previously split. Uganda in particular wished to reunite Wamba dia Wamba on the one side with Mbusa Nyamwisi and John Tibasima on the other side. The alliance Uganda-Rwanda split and also because there were leadership struggles within the RCD (not least due to the upcoming negotiations in which many individuals wanted to have an important role).  Hat was formed as a result of Uganda’s mediation effort was called the Front de Libération du Congo (FLC) (English: Front for the Liberation of Congo). MLC leader Jean-Pierre Bemba was chosen as the front figure and Mbusa Nyamwisi as number two (after Wamba dia Wamba renounced). They formed a government in Gbadolite with 32 members. However, the alliance was short-lived due to leadership struggles between Jean-Pierre Bemba and Mbusa Nyamwisi. After Nyamwisi entered an alliance with Kabila in June 2001, the RCD-ML (Nyamwisi’s forces) and the MLC (Bemba’s forces) clashed in Beni – and the alliance subsequnety broke down. Mbusa Nyamwisi moved back to Beni in August and Bemba moved to Gbadolite. The original RCD leader Wamba-dia-Wamba continued to claim legitimacy as leader of the original RCD-ML. In response to the fighting between the conflict parties, the Ugandan government requested Bemba and Nyamwisi to come to Kampala to find a compromise. The two leaders arrived on 12 and 13 August respectively. Negotiations mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni  started in in Kampala on 16 August and led to a compromise on 17 August 2001. While the MLC would control the Equateur region to Bumba in the East, the RCD-K-ML would control the area from Butembo to Isiro. During the latter half of December 2001, RCD-K-ML sought MONUC assistance in order to avoid a military advance by the MLC.

On 6 January 2002, Brigadier General Mwaniki led a MONUC team to Gbadolite in an effort to persuade MLC leaders to resolve the dispute by peaceful means. Another team went to Isiro to talk to the RCD-K-ML. The MLC leadership promised the MONUC team that they would not take Isiro, would halt their advancement at their traditional area of control, and would stick to a ceasefire unless for reasons of self-defense. However, the MLC took control of Isiro on 7 January 2002. Some of the other areas the MLC took control of seemed to reflect previous agreements about zones of control between the MLC and the RCD-K-ML.

In addition to bilateral negotiations between the rebel groups, the RCD factions and the MLC were engaged in a peace process with the Government of the DRC. Both the RCD factions and the MLC had signed the Lusaka Accord in 1999, which set up the Inter-Congolese Dialogue in which the OAU/AU and the UN would mediate between the conflict parties. The RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side continued to meet as part of this peace process after they fought each other from June 2001 onwards. The rebel parties and the Government of the DRC were planning to meet as part of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February 2002, but the MLC boycotted the meeting last minute. The MLC did participate in a round of negotiations which started on 9 April 2002 and led to conclusion of a partial agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC on 19 April 2002. This agreement specified a political power-sharing formula among the rebel groups and the Government of the DRC. Yet, fighting between the RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side continued.
agreement_name: Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC

description: To move the peace process forward based on political power-sharing agreement the parties had concluded, the UN Secretary-General mandated Moustapha Niasse as his Special Representative to the DRC to mediate a comprehensive peace agreement. Niasse conducted three missions in the region between June and October 2002 during which he consulted with the main rebel leaders and the government officials. Niasse visited the DRC on 16 June 2002. In Pretoria, talks were held in Kinshasa from October 25 to 27 between the rebels and the government.

In November 2002, another round of negotiations as part of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue began, resulting in the conclusion of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo in Pretoria on 17 December 2002. However, on 20 December 2002, fighting erupted again between the RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side.
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: On 30 December 2002, the leaders Jean-Pierre Bemba of the MLC, Roger Lumbala of RCD-N, and Mbusa Nyamwisi of the RCD-K-ML met in the northern town of Gbadolite, Equateur Province, in the presence of the ambassadors of the permanent members of the UN Security Council, Belgium, and South Africa, as well as the United Nations’ Secretary General’s Deputy Special Representative in the DRC Amos Namanga Ngongi. They reached a ceasefire agreement that same day. The ceasefire agreement stipulated the formation of a ceasefire monitoring body, comprising representatives of the three movements, MONUC, and of South Africa. In addition, MONUC was mandated to supervise buffer zones between the rival forces. The three movements also agreed to demilitarize Mambasa and Komanda. However, the MLC and the RCD-N resumed fighting against the RCD-K-ML already a day after signing of the UN-sponsored ceasefire.

The leaders of the MLC, RCD-N, and the RCD-K-ML met in Kisangani in early January 2003 in order to build confidence among the rebel groups at a time when they were fighting in the east and northeast of the DRC.

In addition, the national-level peace process in which the rebel groups participated continued. In 2003, South Africa was hosting continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. On 6 March 2003, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition Period

description: In later March 2003, talks were held on integrating the rebel fighters into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period. On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act.
agreement_name: Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act

description: On 6 August 2003, the Follow-up Committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue held a meeting to come up with division of military zones of control for signatories to the final peace agreement. The parties concluded an agreement that allocated control of three military regions to the former government, two regions each to RCD-Goma and the MLC, and one region each to RCD-K-ML and the RCD-N.

The leaders of the MLC, RCD-N, and the RCD-K-ML met in Kisangani in early January 2003 in order to build confidence among the rebel groups at a time when they were fighting in the east and northeast of the DRC.

In addition, the national-level peace process in which the rebel groups participated continued. In 2003, South Africa was hosting continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. On 6 March 2003, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition Period

description: In later March 2003, talks were held on integrating the rebel fighters into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period. On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act.
agreement_name: Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act

description: On 6 August 2003, the Follow-up Committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue held a meeting to come up with division of military zones of control for signatories to the final peace agreement. The parties concluded an agreement that allocated control of three military regions to the former government, two regions each to RCD-Goma and the MLC, and one region each to RCD-K-ML and the RCD-N.

The Mayi Mayi were not an official party to the negotiations between the Government of the DRC and the rebel groups that led to the Lusaka Agreement concluded in July 1999, but, in 2001, they did become part of the Inter-Congolese dialogue that was started following the Lusaka Agreement. The Inter-Congolese dialogue was jointly mediated by the UN and the OAU. Former President of Botswana Ketumile Masire had assumed the role of chief mediator of the Inter-Congolese dialogue on 15 December 1999, following his nomination by the OAU Secretary-General. In January 2001, following the killing of his father, President Laurent Kabilla, Joseph Kabila assumed the presidency. This gave some impetus to the Inter-Congolese dialogue. In early March 2001, President Joseph Kabila invited Masire, to Kinshasa and promised to resume discussions with the mediator in the Inter-Congolese dialogue. On the initiative of South Africa, and with support from the OAU and the UN, the Congolese government and the rebel groups, but also the Mayi Mayi militias, met in a closed-door meeting at Shumba Village (between Pretoria and Johannesburg) in April 2001.

The April round of negotiations paved the way for another round of negotiations, in which the representatives of the government, the rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka on 4 May 2001.
agreement_name: Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue

description: Another round of negotiations between the Mayi Mayi and RCD-Goma took place from 22 to 26 September 2001 in Bukavu, dubbed the Inter-Kivu Dialogue. At this meeting, the conflict parties, among others, discussed options for including Mayi Mayi representatives in the RCD-Goma delegation to participate in the upcoming inter-Congolese dialogue that was about to begin on 15 October 2001 in Addis Ababa.

Following the willingness of both the RCD and the Mayi Mayi to participate in the Inter-Congolese dialogue, a high-level United Nations Development Program (UNDP) mission reported that the time was ripe for direct, local ceasefire negotiations between the Mayi Mayi and the RCD-Goma. Some NGOs subsequently started to mediate, but without support from MONUC.

On 19 April 2002, the government, rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed a partial peace agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC, also referred to as the Sun City Accord. As part of the wider national-level peace process, the Rwandan army began their withdrawal from the DRC on 17 September 2002, handing over power to the Rwandan-backed RCD-Goma in Kindu. However, Mayi Mayi militias took advantage of the Rwandan withdrawal and attacked RCD forces.
On 19 September 2002, negotiations took place between RCD and Mayi Mayi in the town of Walungulu near Kindu, but these did not lead to any tangible results.

At the national level, however, both parties participated in another round of the Inter-Congolese dialogue, which was mediated by the OAU and the UN. This led to signing of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on Transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo – also known as the Pretoria Agreement – on 16 December 2002.
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on Transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: In 2003, South Africa, with support from the UN and the AU, hosted continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. Negotiations in Pretoria that had started in late February resulted in the conclusion of a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period on 6 March.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition

description: In late March, talks were held on integrating the rebel groups and the Mayi Mayi into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period, which led to the conclusion of a preliminary ceasefire. On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act.

In parallel to this national-level peace process which involved both the RCD and the Mayi Mayi, direct talks between the RCD and the Mayi Mayi took place. Two months earlier, in early February 2003, RCD-Goma spokesperson Jean-Pierre Lola Kisanga had announced a general amnesty for Mayi Mayi militias. The offer applied to the members of all the factions of Mayi Mayi militias operating in territory claimed to be under the control of RCD-Goma: “We are asking the Mayi Mayi to leave the forests and disassociate themselves from other armed groups [….] They will not be charged with any crime whatsoever. Rather, it is out of our hope for reconciliation and an end to hostilities that we are offering this amnesty.” The Mayi Mayi militias and RCD-Goma subsequently began direct negotiations in Burale on 9 September 2003. According to the leader of the Mayi Mayi Marcel Munga, a joint mission of six military officials from the two movements had been sent to the field to begin the negotiations. MONUC’s Radio Okapi reported, “By order of the military leadership, Maj-Gen Sylvain Buki, formerly of RCD-Goma, and his colleague, Padiri Bulenda, formerly of the Mayi-Mayi militia and commander of one of the military regions, the Third Brigade of the Mayi-Mayi and the Tenth Brigade of RCD-Goma, both of whom occupy part of the Walungu territory, came together at the same table on Tuesday in Burale to discuss reconciliation.” The team would be responsible for creating a joint police force with soldiers from the two factions.
On 18 and 19 September 2003, negotiations between Mayi Mayi factions and RCD-Goma were held in the town of Walungulu, near Kindu.

Little more than a month after the start of talks on 9 September 2003, negotiations between Mayi Mayi leader General Padiri and the RCD-Goma, mediated by MONUC, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Shabunda, South Kivu Province, on 1 October 2003 in the presence of MONUC’s sector five commander, Col Lawrence Smith. The agreement calls for an immediate ceasefire, the free circulation of people and goods, and the creation of a follow-up commission comprising three members from each of the two sides to monitor implementation of the agreement.
Follow-up negotiations, also mediated by MONUC, led to the conclusion of a follow-up mechanism to the agreement on 21 October 2003.

Finally, in cooperation with the newly appointed commander of the military region, another meeting was organized in the Uvira-Baraka area. This meeting was attended by the entire Mayi Mayi leadership and many national army commanders. This peacemaking effort contributed to a reduction in armed fighting in the province.
Armed fighting spiked in 2004. However, clan elders were able to mediate between the two sides in November 2004.
Following armed clashes in Las Anod, local clan leaders organized a peace meeting among themselves on 17 November 2007.
Ethiopia mediated between the political heads of Somaliland and Puntland in Addis Ababa in June 2010. This led to the signing of a peace agreement on 9 June 2010.

The Pokot and Sabiny have repeatedly clashed in the context of cattle raiding. The Pokot and Sabiny frequently clash in the context of cattle raids in the Karamoja region in Uganda. The Pokot and Sabiny engaged in a peace meeting in Trans Nzoia at the Chepchoina Primary School in April 2004. With a thousand people in attendance, Mutea Iringo and Joseph Aruwating, the West Pokot District Commissioner and District Commissioner of Kapchorwa County respectively, acted as the mediators. The Pokot and Sabiny agreed to turn to local authorities to deal with issues of animal theft.

On 10 July 2006, in an attempt to resolve the conflict, the Kenyan government offered over two hundred cattle to the Sabiny after a raid from the Pokot. This offer was rejected by the Sabiny out of fear that this would exacerbate the conflict. Community leaders from Sebei and West Pokot mediated a peace agreement between the Sabiny and Pokot at the Suam border in November 2006. Government officials also participated in this peace meeting. The Kenya Catholic Justice and Peace Commission and the Kapchorwa Civil Society Association funded this peace meeting.
third_party: community leaders; government; religious leaders; local NGO

description: Around 1500 tribesmen of the Sabiny and Pokot attended a peace meeting mediated by Kenyan and Ugandan government officials in Bukwa County on 9 February 2007. The conflict parties agreed to continue negotiations and the government officials planned to include disarmament on the agenda.
The communities verbally agreed to end the conflict during a round of negotiations at Suam in Mt Elgon Fores in 9 June 2008. These negotiations were mediated by religious and government officials.

The Kween Women in Peace Initiative (Kwipi) facilitated a week of peace talks, mediated by Action Aid Uganda, between the Karimojong, Matheniko, Pokot, and Sabiny in the Suam in the Bukwo District on 20 May 2011. The peace meeting did not lead to a peace agreement, but the tribes recognized the need to end cattle rustling.
A round of bilateral negotiations between tribal leaders from the Pokot and the Sabiny led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 26 February 2013.

Another round of talks between 130 Pokot elders and 80 Sabiny elders was held in Kanyerus in early March 2013. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. This round of peace talks received support from Oxfam and a local NGO called Saferworld. At this meeting, they reached a peace accord.
The Pian Karimojong and Pokot attended a peace meeting in May 2005, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

Armed fighting again arose in 2004, following referendum that allocated 80 percent of more than 420 kebeles (i.e. the smallest administrative unit in Ethiopia) of land to the Oromo. Although this decision was not implemented, the decision had a major negative impact on the relationship between the groups and led to some clashes. In December 2004, the Oromo and Somali participated in a reconciliation effort organized by local elders. Although no official peace agreement was reached, the talks led to the return of stolen cattle by both groups.

The Ethiopian government set up a committee to monitor the conflict between the groups in 2013.A land dispute between the Oromo and Somali escalated into heavy fighting in 2017, which ultimately led to at least 276 battle-related deaths that year. The Ethiopian government, specifically the Minister for Federal and Pastoral Affairs, mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in April 2017. This led to the signing of a peace agreement on 20 April 2017. The agreement addressed the implementation of a 2004 border and the ethnic affiliation of Moyale. On 16 September 2017, local elders as well as communal and religious leaders from both tribes convened for a round of peace talks mediated by Ethiopian Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn. The talks did not lead to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but did lead to the deployment of federal security officers and the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission was tasked with investigating the violence between the tribes.
The Ethiopian government mediated another round of negotiations in October 2017.
In December 2017, the Oromo and Somali clashed again in the Oromia regional state. In response, the Ethiopian government mediated between communal and religious leaders from both sides.
The Ethiopian government mediated between the the Oromo and Somali at a peace meeting in Moyale in April 2019.
Another peace conference was held in Adam on 1 May 2019. In addition to the two tribes, the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) participated as well.
On 4 August 2019, Oromo and Somali leaders convened for a peace meeting in Jigjiga.
On 10 August, the two sides convened in Jigjiga for a peace conference.

The Ogaden and Sheikhal clans clashed over control over territory, which both clans deemed key to gaining more representation in the Somali government. The Sheikhal felt marginalized as they did not have land of their own, instead living on territory officially controlled by the Ogaden. This provides the background to the conflict. In 1998, the Sheikhal elders convened a meeting between different clan leaders in Maramaydh locality to discuss a formula to share land, but the meeting did not produce an agreement. The conflict escalated into armed fighting in August 1999.

It took from March 2001 to early 2002 for the clan to completely migrate to their new home. The Ogaden clan opposed this move and clashed resumed in March 2002. In response to the fighting, government officials and clan leaders mediated between the conflict parties, which led to a peace agreement.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.
In 2017, multiple women’s dialogue sessions took place. Women from both tribes attended the Women Intra-healing Dialogue in Omorate from 1 to 2 March 2017.
Women from both tribes also attended the Women-Led Intra-Community Healing Dialogue in Kangaten from 3 to 4 March 2017.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter’s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)’s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017.  The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.
On 12 June 2017, the Joint Women Forum was held in Lowaregnak, Turkana County. This initiative was facilitated by PDC and SAPCONE.

A Chief’s Led Inter-Community Dialogue took place in Omorate on 12 June 2017. During this dialogue, attendees discussed past peace efforts, including the Arba Minch Resolution from 2016. The session’s main conclusion was that relations between the Dassanech, Turkana, and Nyangatom had to be further improved and that to this purpose further peace initiatives would take place in the second half of the year.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 30 August 2017, the Joint Cross-Border Lower Level Government Official’s Meeting was held at Turmi, Ethiopia in order to prioritize mitigating the conflict between the Nyangatom, the Turkana, and the Dassanech.  On 24 and 25 September 2017, the Joint Cross-border Chiefs’ Led Inter-Community Dialogue was held in Omorate, Ethiopia. The peace meeting was facilitated by PCD and SAPCONE. A total of 26 participants attended the peace meeting, including Ethiopian delegates, representatives of local governments in both countries, as well as the Dassanech, Nyangatom and Turkana representatives. During this meeting, participants agreed to conflict resolution mechanisms.
third_party: local NGO; local government; government; Kenya

description: In September 2004, the Rivers governor’s chief of staff organized a behind-the scenes peace effort between NDPVF and NDV groups with the purpose to reach a peace agreement, but the parties refused to sign an agreement.

President Obasanjo mediated a round of peace talks between Moujahid Asari Dokubo and Ateke Tom, respectively leaders of the NDPVF and NDV, in Abuja on 1 October 2004. This mediation effort resulted in the signing of a peace agreement. Both sides pledged to lay down their arms in exchange for money.

A follow-up meeting was held on 8 October 2004 in Abuja and focused on the rehabilitation of young militiamen in society. After this last meeting, President Obasanjo set up a committee responsible for the reconciliation process between the two groups. This committee, chaired by retired Major General Abdullahi Mohammed, not only mediated between the conflict parties, but also aimed to facilitate the disarming of the NDPVF.

A round of peace negotiations was held in Nakuru on 31 March 2015. Communal leaders from Bungoma County participated in this meeting that was mediated by government officals. Religious and civil leaders also attended the talks. The peace meeting ended with the signing of the Abbey Resort Resolutions.

side_a: Mohamed Muse subclan of Abgal clan (Hawiye)
description: The Mohamed Muse and Warsangeli subclass clashed over territorial control of the Middle Shabelle region in March 2003. The Warsangeli clan headed the region’s capital Jowahar, but the Mohamed Muse community opposed this rule. Clan elders from each side tried to negotiate a solution to the conflict in December 2002, prior to the violence had broken out, but this peacemaking effort failed. Fighting broke out in March 2003. Another round of fighting took place in June 2003. The Kenyan delegation responsible for monitoring the Eldoret Declaration condemned this round of fighting, but no negotiations or mediation took place between the conflict parties.

Elders from the Misseriya and the Rizeigat engaged in peace talks in August 2008 in an attempt to prevent further armed clashes. The talks were aimed at preparing for a peace conference. This reconciliation conference, which was mediated by the Deputy Nazir of Ed Daein locality, took place in El Obeid from 25 to 28 September 2008. The two tribes reached an agreement on the basis of the border demarcation between Misseriya and the Rizeigat along their tribal border as it existed in 1948.

The theft of a vehicle by some Rizeigat on 18 February 2010 led to the killing of a Missiriya.  In response, the conflict parties met to negotiate on blood money on 26 February 2010. A committee of tribes considered neutral in the conflict, including Beni Halba and Salamat, mediated between the conflict parties at this meeting. However, this mediation effort failed and the Rizeigat attacked the Missiriya right when the latter left the meeting. This led to subsequent heavy fighting in Khor Ramla in late February and early March 2010.
UNAMID mediated a ceasefire between the Misseriya and the Rizeigat Abbala on 28 March 2010.

However, fighting started again between the two tribes in the Mukjar region on 4 May. To this purpose, UNAMID Civil Affairs helped set up a Reconciliation Committee on 29 April 2010, which comprised 17 members of native administrations and local leaders. Closely working with the committee, UNAMID Civil Affairs conducted another mediation effort in May, which resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire.

Following yet another mediation effort by UNAMID, the Misseriya and the Rizeigat signed a peace agreement on 28 June 2010. This agreement set the blood money for both sides, as well as included provisions on how to control and monitor the militias and demanded that all fighters surrender their weapons and Thuraya satellite telephones.
However, fighting resumed in August 2010. A mediation effort by UNAMID led to another peace agreement in November 2010, which did terminate the armed fighting.
Following armed clashes resulting in at least 60 deaths in July 2012, Kordofan governor Ahmed Haroun talked to local leaders to prevent more armed clashes.

Armed clashes between the Misseriya and the Rizeigat resumed in January 2015 near Konga in Abu Jabra locality. In response, members of the native administration in Abu Jabra tried to mediate between the conflict parties in mid-January 2015.

The leaders of the two tribes held a reconciliation conference in September 2015, but the negotiations did not result in an agreement. The two tribes clashed again in December 2015. Publicly stating that traditional mediation had failed, government officials announced that state forces would be deployed to impose the state authority and to bring the perpetrators to justice.

An armed clash between the Misseriya and the Rizeigat in Um Dukhun locality on 25 January resulted in three Misseriya tribesmen killed. This conflict was resolved on 29 January, when the Rizeiga paid compensation money to the Misseriya. Nevertheless, fighting between the Misseriya and the Rizeigat continued in other areas in Central Darfur beween February and May 2017.

On 10 September 2002, the conflict parties engaged in a peace meeting in Lodonyang. The peace talks were mediated by the East Africa Conflict Resolution Component and Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG). The meeting led to signing of a peace agreement in the pressence of government officials from Kenya and Ethiopia.
third_party: East Africa Conflict Resolution Component; Intermediate Technology Development Group; government; Ethiopia

description: On 26 September 2002, the two sides re-convened for another peace meeting in Lodwar in which both government and communal leaders participated.
The African Union - Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU/IBAR) mediated peace talks in Lokichogio in August 2005 to resolve the conflict between the Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana.
Another peace meeting between the Dassanetch and Turkana was held in the Turkana District in Kenya  in August 2005. This peace meeting led to a peace agreement and a peace committee was established.

The Turkana-South Omo Conflict Mitigation Project was initiated in 2006. With financial support from USAID and Oxfam, the project itself was carried out with involvement from the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPaRDA) and Riam Riam Turkana (RRT). There are few details about these efforts.
third_party: Oxfam; USAID; community leaders; local NGO

description: The Catholic Church of North Kenya began to mediate between the conflict parties in Kenya 2007.
The Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA) mediated between the conflict parties in Ethiopia in 2007.
The Turkana-South Omo Conflict Mitigation Project organized a peace meeting between the Dassanetch and Turakana in Ethiopia in 2008.
District officials from the Dassanetch and North Turkana districts in Ethiopia met multiple times to try resolve conflict issues throughout 2008.
In response to an incident in July 2009, multiple peace talks were held between Dassanech and Turkana leaders. These meetings did not result in a peace agreement.

The conflict parties participated in peace talks mediated by Ethiopian and Kenyan government representatives in Hawassa on 2 November 2009. These talks ended with a peace agreement stipulating the set-up of cross-border peace structures and administrations.
In the second half of the year, a Karamoja cross border peace planning meeting was facilitated by CEWARN.
In September 2010, a committee comprising Turkana and Dassanesch elders reached a peace agreement designed to end cattle rustling.

Peace talks between the conflict parties were held in Todonyang in Kenya in April 2011. These talks were mediated by a local NGO and security forces. The peace talks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement signed by 17 tribal representatives.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.
In 2017, multiple women’s dialogue sessions took place. Women from both tribes attended the Women Intra-healing Dialogue in Omorate from 1 to 2 March 2017.
Women from both tribes also attended the Women-Led Intra-Community Healing Dialogue in Kangaten from 3 to 4 March 2017.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter’s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)’s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017.  The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.
On 12 June 2017, the Joint Women Forum was held in Lowaregnak, Turkana County. This initiative was facilitated by PDC and SAPCONE.

A Chief’s Led Inter-Community Dialogue took place in Omorate on 12 June 2017. During this dialogue, attendees discussed past peace efforts, including the Arba Minch Resolution from 2016. The session’s main conclusion was that relations between the Dassanech, Turkana, and Nyangatom had to be further improved and that to this purpose further peace initiatives would take place in the second half of the year.

At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 30 August 2017, the Joint Cross-Border Lower Level Government Official’s Meeting was held at Turmi, Ethiopia in order to prioritize mitigating the conflict between the Nyangatom, the Turkana, and the Dassanech.  On 24 and 25 September 2017, the Joint Cross-border Chiefs’ Led Inter-Community Dialogue was held in Omorate, Ethiopia. The peace meeting was facilitated by PCD and SAPCONE. A total of 26 participants attended the peace meeting, including Ethiopian delegates, representatives of local governments in both countries, as well as the Dassanech, Nyangatom and Turkana representatives. During this meeting, participants agreed to conflict resolution mechanisms.
third_party: local NGO; local government; government; Kenya

description: Reconciliation talks between the two clans were during September and October 1997. This led to a temporary stop in fighting, armed conflict reignited in May 1998.

The armed conflict between the Fiji Muhumud and Marehan subclans started in the Herale region in May 2003. Leaders from neutral clans mediated between the two sides in December 2003 but were unsuccessful.

A Peace Committee organized a reconciliation meeting between the tribal leaders in Nyala in October 2004 in response to the outbreak of armed fighting. The conflict parties agreed to resolve the conflict through the paying of double “dia” blood money for all those killed on both sides, the return of looted money and assets to each other, and the pardoning the perpetrators of violence. In addition, although not part of the official negotiations to end the tribal violence, the Ma’aliyah were granted a separate native administration headed by Nazir A.H. El Basha in 2004.

Renewed fighting broke out in August 2013. The Ma’aliyah accused East Darfur governor Abdel-Hamid Musa Kasha, who is a Rizeigat, of supporting his kin with government-issued vehicles and weapons. A mediation effort by governor of North Darfur Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir, with support from UNAMID, led to agreement on signing a ceasefire on 14 August 2013. The abduction of 24 Ma’aliyah by Rizeigat led to a delay in signing the ceasefire, but after their release the conflict parties signed a ceasefire in al-Tawisha on 22 August 2013. The ceasefire was supposed to pave the way for a reconciliation conference.

President of Chad, Idriss Déby Itno, acted as the chief mediator at tribal mediation forum in Um Jaras from 26 to 29 March 2014. The forum was attended by tribal leaders from Darfur, including the Zaghawa, Rizeigat, Massalit, Ma’alia, Salamat and Ta’isha tribes. Sudanese Vice-President Hassabo Mohamed Abdul Rahman acted as the Joint Chief Mediator. Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir joined the forum on 29 March. The forum ended with the participants’ announcement of their full support for peace and peaceful coexistence in Darfur.

Another peace conference was organized by a mediation committee with solely members of the Ma’aliya and Rizeigat in June 2014, but failing to reach an agreement the conference was suspended indefinitely on 20 June 2014.

On 22 August 2014, another mediation effort between the Rizeigat and Ma’aliya tribes was held in East Darfur, this time with the support from UNAMID Civil Affairs. This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire by the leaders of the Rizeigat and Ma’aliya tribes on 29 August 2014. Prior to this conference, UNAMID had “engaged leaders of both communities at the state and Khartoum levels, including their respective Shura Councils.”

The theft of 320 sheep belonging to the Southern Rizeigat by the Ma’aliyah in Birghit on 13 January 2015 nearly trigged armed clashes between the tribes, but with support from government officials, leaders from both tribes intervened to stem tensions.

In mid-February 2015, a peace conference, facilitated by government officals, was held between Ma’aliyah and the Rizeigat Baggara in reaction to last year’s deadly clashes, but this conference ended without an agreement.

Another peace conference, mediated by Sudan’s first Vice-President Bakri Hassan Salih, was held in the locality of Merowe in March 2015, but the negotiations stalled over the right of land ownership known as Hakura (traditional land grant). Although the conflict parties did not reach an agreement, both sides released one captive on 4 May 2015. The armed fighting continued. Fighting stopped by 13 May, following an intervention by reinforcements from the central government as well as an intervention by the Sudanese Air Force.

On 14 May 2015, a high-ranking government delegation led by the Minister of Interior, Ismat Abdelrahman, arrived to mediate between the conflict parties. After shuttling between the conflict parties, the government decided on a package of measures to be taken by the government to stop the tribal clashes and defuse the tension. Yet, the conflict parties did not sign an agreement.

UNAMID helped to facilitate another peace conference on 2 September 2015. UNAMID facilitated the travel of a government delegation comprised of senior officials including the Governor of East Darfur and the Minster of Humanitarian Affairs. Staff from the UNAMID Civil Affairs Section were also involved in the mediation effort.

Fighting between the conflict parties resumed on 20 September, when some Rizeigat stole camels from Ma’aliyah in the Adola Mountain area. The Wali of East Darfur subsequently deployed troops to the area. Following a mediation effort by the Wali, with support from UNAMID, the conflict parties reached a settlement on 27 September.

Clashes between the Ma’aliyah and the Rizeigat as a result of cattle theft erupted again in Yassin locality on 17 April 2016, resulting in at least 20 deaths. In negotiations, facilitated by UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 6 June 2016, agreeing on financial compensation for the fatalities of the clashes on 17 April 2016.

However, fighting continued between the two tribes in West Kordofan on 24 August 2016. With UNAMID support, government officials mediated another agreement between the conflcit parties in Muglad, West Kordofan, on 27 August 2016. However, however, Ma’aliyah representatives protested against this agreement in Adilla on 3 September 2016, claiming that it was not inclusive of the entire Ma’aliyah community and that it had not been signed by the actual representatives of the Agarba.

A peace conference organized by Sudanese government officials in Khartoum on 11 October 2016 ended without reaching agreement between the conflict parties and negotiations were postponed until 30 October 2016.

However, fighting between the Ma’aliyah and the Rizeigat spread to East Darfur on 14 and 15 October 2016. In response to these clashes, UNAMID managed to mediate a peace agreement, stipulating a ceasefire, between the Ma’aliya and Rizeigat tribes in East Darfur on 17 October 2016. The peace agreement also included provisions for the release of two members from the Rizeigat tribe held by the Ma’aliya and the return of 134 cows by the Ma’aliya. The agreement also stipulated that the government of East Darfur had to pay compensation of 650,000 SDG (US$102,000) to the Ma’aliya in order to cover the costs of a local rescue team, over 200 looted cattle, weapons and the blood money for the murder of a member of the Ma’aliyah tribe. The deputy governor of East Darfur subsequently visited Abu Karinka locality to pay representatives of the Ma’aliyah tribe the first half of the compensation.

Armed clashes between the conflict parties resumed in April 2017, but were not immediately followed by any mediation efforts. UNAMID participated in a peace meeting in Abu Karinka on 26 June between the Ma’aliyah native administration and a Rizeigat delegation from Ed Daein. The Sudanese government deployed security forces in late July in response to another round of fighting. Sudanese Armed Forces arrived in Ed Daein in late July to confiscate weapons from the Rizeigat and the Ma’aliyah, as well as to arrest traditional leaders and civilians from both communities.
Representatives of the Ma’aliyah and the Rizeigat set up a mechanism at regulating farming activities during a peace meeting on 7 January 2018.

Another peace meeting was held at Adilla and Abu Karinka on 27 and 28 January 2018 repsectively. The Sudanese Vice-President attended this reconciliatory meeting and made a commitment to implement several development projects related to health, education, and infrastructure in the area.
Another round of negotiations between the Ma’aliyah and the Rizeigat led to the signing of a peace agreement in Khartoum on 27 November 2018.
In August 2008, the Burnt Forest peace committee mediated between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya and Luo elders. The UN Development Programme supported these peace talks.

However, on 28 March 2018, the United Nations Peacekeeping Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) organized a two-day pre-migration conference in Duk Padiet in Jonglei. The conference was attended by 30 youth representatives of the Hol Dinka and Lou Nuer. These representatives agreed refrain from using violence during the migration season in the greater Jonglei area.

The Lou Nuer and the Murle have long been rivals, especially in Jonglei State in southern Sudan (and South Sudan after independence in 2011). Cattle raids are very common between both cattle herding ethnic groups. In addition, the Murle regularly engage in abductions of young Nuer children. The rivalry between the Lou Nuer and Murle in Jonglei State has been exploited by both local and national-level politicians. During the civil war, the Murle Pibor Defence Forces, led by Ismail Konyi, fought against the SPLM/A during the civil war, with financial and military support by Khartoum. Simon Gatwich, the former South Sudan Defence Forces (SSDF) leader, armed the Lou, also with support from Khartoum. President Salva Kiir initiated negotiations with SSDF leader Paulino Matip. This led to the Juba Declaration on Unity and Integration on 8 January 2006. The Declaration primarily laid the basis for unifying rival military forces in South Sudan, but also initiated a disarmament process. In the context of a disarmament process which also targeted the Murle and the Nuer, the SPLM/A mediated between the two tribes in June 2006. This mediation effort reportedly led to a decrease in tensions between the Murle and the Nuer.

The conflict between the Lou Nuer and the Murle escalated in 2009, with violence not only involving cattle raids, but also attacks on civilians and communities as a whole in the Greater Akobo, the greater Pibor, the Greater Bor areas. The Sudanese government, with support from the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS), facilitated a reconciliation meeting between the Nuer and the Murle in early May 2009, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire. A Joint Lou Nuer/Murle ceasefire committee was subsequently mandated to help implement this ceasefire.  This reportedly reduced tensions in Akobo and Pibor counties of Jonglei State. On 13 May, the UN Mission in Sudan (UNMIS) announced it would temporarily deploy around 120 civilian, military and police personnel to Akobo and Pibor to assist local communities to engage in dialogue to prevent further violence. In June 2009, the Southern Sudan Peace Commission worked with state authorities, traditional authorities, UNMIS, UN Development Programme, and PACT to organize a peace conference to resolve the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but this conference was postponed several times, until the governor delayed it indefinitely in December 2009.

In February 2011, a Murle milita killed three Nuer chiefs in Thiam Payam. The Southern government authorities and UNMIS mediated a peace agreement between the conflict parties, which was signed on 10 April 2011. However, the Lou Nuer conducted a coordinated, retaliatory attack on Murle cattle camps in the eastern part of Pibor county in late April 2011 and launched a large-scale attack killing hundreds of Murle in June 2011. Armed violence between the Nuer and the Murle continued following South Sudan gaining independence on 9 July 2011. On 18 August 2011, Murle youths conducted a massive attack on Nuer civilians in Pieri in Uror county, which resulted in around 740 people killed and the theft of 38,00 heads of cattle. David Yau Yau and his fighters, who had signed an amnesty agreement with the South Sudanese government in June 2011, allegedly had provided some Murle with weapons prior to this attack.

Jonglei state governor Kuol Manyang Juuk and Jonglei state Minister of Parliamentary Affairs Gabriel Gai Riem repeatedly attempted to organize an all-Jonglei peace conference aimed at resolving the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but such a conference failed to materialize in August 2011. However, the Sudan Council of Churches (SCC) managed to initiate peace talks between the Murle and the Lou Nuer at a peace conference on 7 and 8 October 2011. Archbishop of the Episcopal Church of Sudan Daniel Deng Bul acted as the chief mediator. The conference brought together representatives of the Nuer and the Murle, as well as around 100 politicians from both the South Sudan national assembly and Jonglei state legislature. However, the peace conference did not produce a tangible outcome. Instead, the mediation team and the conflict parties agreed upon a four-step process, including (1) the delegations of the conflict parties consulting with their communities how to end the violence and address their grievances; (2) joint delegations with chiefs, women, and youth from both sides visiting communities to show that the peace process is a collective responsibility; (3) consultations with the communities on how to peace process could be taken forward; and (4) a peace conference aimed at an agreement on ending the violence and the return of abducted women and children prior to the start of the dry season in mid-December 2011. UNMISS provided logistical support to the peace process between August and December 2011, supporting key leaders with authority in the communities to advocate for peace.
third_party: religious leaders; local government; government; UNMISS

description: Up until December 2011, the SCC continued consultations with all communities, trying to design a framework for peace. However, the SCC failed to initiate official negotiations because the Lou Nuer and Murle could not agree on where to hold a peace conference. The SCC proposed a neutral area, such as Juba or Rumbek, but the Lou Nuer insisted the conference be held in Waat, which is centrally located in Nuer territory. The Lou Nuer leaders set a deadline of 1 December for action by the Murle community to prevent further cattle raids and for the return of their stolen cattle and women and children. Between October and December 2011, UNMISS representatives, government officials, and church leaders all repeatedly tried to convince the Nuer prophet Dak Kueth Deng to not call for an attack.
third_party: religious leaders; local government; government; UNMISS

description: Nevertheless, following a Murle attack on Bor Dinka in the Jalle area, Dak Kueth Deng decided to a mobilize a large group of Nuer fighters, known as the White Army, to launch a revenge attack on the Murle in Pibor county in December 2011. The SCC called off a peace conference that was set for 12 December when it became apparent that the Lou Nuer would conduct an attack in revenge of the Murle attack in August 2011. In addition to deploying a battalion to the main centers of Pibor county, UNMISS flew Vice-President Riek Machar to Lekwangole town on 28 and 29 December for him to persuade the Nuer militia leaders to withdraw, but with no success. The Nuer militia proceeded towards Pibor county.

When the Lou Nuer attack Pibor town on 2 January 2012, the South Sudanese government forces stationed there opened fire and managed to fend off the attack. This was the first time South Sudanese government forces opened fire to end communal violence. Two armored UN vehicles deterred the Lou Nuer on the eastern side of Pibor town. The Lou Nuer fighters withdrew from Pibor town on 4 January 2011, but moved deeper into Murle territory. The peace conference between Murle and Lou Nuer which had been scheduled for mid-December was held in January 2012, amidst the Nuer attack on the Murle in Pibor. The South Sudanese government deployed more than 12,000 soldiers in Jonglei to stop the fighting between Nuer and Murle in March 2012. Government forces in Jonglei were also tasked with a general disarmament campaign in what was called Operation Restore Peace.
third_party: religious leaders; local government; government; UNMISS

description: In addition, a Presidential Committee for Peace, Reconciliation, and Tolerance in Jonglei led by Anglican Archbishop Daniel Deng Bul Yak was set up in April 2012. However, because the mediation effort by Daniel Deng Bul Yak as part of the mediation by the Sudan Council of Churches in October 2011 had failed to prevent the Nuer attack on Pibor, the Murle felt that Yak was biased against them. Vice-President Riek Machar launched the Presidential Committee for Peace, Reconciliation, and Tolerance with a three-day meeting on 2 April 2012 after a two-week tour of Jonglei, where he met community leaders in 11 counties.
third_party: local peace committee; religious leaders; government

description: In addition, the committee began with the facilitation of four smaller peace conferences on 25 April, talking to the conflict parties in Bor, Ayod, Pibor, and Waat.

Then, between 1 and 5 May 2012, the leaders of the conflict parties met in Bor for the All Jonglei Peace Conference. While a series of resolutions and recommendations were adopted on strategies for reducing inter-communal tensions, abduction, livestock theft, and disputes over common grazing areas, the resolutions did not detail how these measures might be put into practice and the conflict parties did not agree on a ceasefire.
third_party: local peace committee; religious leaders; government

description: In addition, the Lou Nuer leaders and politicians of Greater Akobo held a reconciliation conference from 23 to 25 May 2012, which was supported by UNMISS.

The Jonglei Women's Association (JWA) and USAID organized a women's peace conference in the state from 12 to 17 March 2013. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants discussed pathways to peace among all the different tribes in Jonglei, including the Murle and Lou Nuer.

In 2017, UNMISS facilitated several workshops between the Lou Nuer and Murle in Jonglei state in response to tensions between the two communities. These workshops were aimed at preventing a future resumption of previous hostilities.

In June 2001, the West African Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP) mediated peace talks between the conflict parties. The talks, referred to as the Damango Peace Talks, resulted in the two sides signing the Bawku Peace Initiative. WANEP collaborated with several NGOs, including the Advocacy Peace Group, Action Aid Ghana, the Centre for Conflict Transformations and Peace Studies (CECOTAPS), the Christian Council of Ghana, the Bawku East Women’s Development Association (BEWDA), and the Catholic Relief Services (CRS).
third_party: local NGO; Action Aid Ghana; religious leaders; community leaders

description: The government attempted to mediate between the two groups and established a curfew in early December 2001. On 13 December, the government set up a 13-person committee to mediate between the conflict parties and compensate victims of violence.
A round of peace talks mediated by the Upper East Regional Coordinating Council (RCC) led to the signing of a ceasefire on 20 February 2008.
Ghanian President John Kufuor mediated between the conflict parties in Accra on 13 March 2008. President Kufuor mediated a second round of talks in May 2008. However, this did not end the clashes.
The Ghanian Vice President John Mahama mediated between the conflict parties in March 2009.

President Atta Mills mediated between the conflict parties in Bolgatanga on 28 May 2009. This led to the establishment of the Bawku Inter-Ethnic Peace Committee (BIEPC) formed as a dialogue platform. The Mamprusi left the BIEPIC in September 2009.

The Ghana Kusasi and Mamprusi engaged in a round of negotiations mediated by World Vision-Ghana, WANEP, and the Northern Development Forum (NDF). This round of talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 12 May 2010.
third_party: World Vision Ghana; WANEP; Northern Development Forum

description: Following the May agreement, the Mamprusi joined the BIEPC again in June 2010. The Regional Security Council (REGSEC) mediated a BIEPIC peace meeting on 16 October 2010.

The Kalenjin and Kisii have frequently clashed over control of land, especially in the Rift Valley region of Western Kenya. In August 2008, peace talks were held between the Kalenjin, Kisii as well as Luo and Luhya communities in Kaptembwo. These talks were facilitated by the UN Development Programme.

In February 2008, five representatives of the Kalenjin and the Kikyyu each engaged in peace talks mediated by the Bishop of Korir and the Catholic Diocese of Eldoret. The meetings were held in a Catholic church in Yamumbi. Local peace committees from the Burnt Forest, Ilula, Kabiemit, Kiambaa, Kimuri, Kimumu, and Munyaka also intermittently participated in the talks.
In August 2008, the Burnt Forest peace committee mediated between Kalenjin, Kikuyu, Kisii, Luhya and Luo elders. The UN Development Programme supported these peace talks.

In April 2011, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) that had been established through the National Cohesion and Integration Act of 2008, the National Steering Committee on Conflict Management and Peace Building (NSC) invited all communities of Nakuru County to participate in the peace talks. The Kikuyu and Kalenjin participated in these peace talks with 40 elders each. The negotiations in April 2011 first consisted of separate meetings for each tribe with the NCIC and NSC, after which the mediation team later facilitated joint meetings.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and NSC was held in May 2011. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) joined the mediation team for the round of negotiations in May 2011.

In March 2012, 24 elders from each tribe negotiated a draft agreement mediated by HD. In order to gather social support for the agreement, the NCIC and HD met with representatives of Nakuru Business and Professional Women’s Club, religious leaders, and youth.
A round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and HD led to conclusion of the Nakuru County Peace Accord on 19 August 2012 in Nakuru, signed by the  Kalenjin, Kikuyu, and other communities in Kakuru.

The Somali Reconciliation Conference in Eldoret, which was mediated by the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), started on 15 October 2002 and led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire signed by 22 armed groups on 27 October. The conference was attended by most supporters of the TNG, including the JVA. While General Morgan refused to participate in this peace conference, General Morgan and the JVA signed the Eldoret Agreement in December 2002.

The resumption of armed conflict between the Forces of General Morgan and the JVA in 2004 should be seen in the context of the broader national-level power struggle between the TNG and the opposition. In early 2004, General Morgan resumed attacks against JVA. IGAD condemned this military campaign and called for sanctions on 27 July. Morgan was  subsequently also denied entry into IGAD member states. Morgan was defeated, and he fled to Nairobi following heavy fighting in Juba in September 2004. General Morgan subsequently declared a unilateral ceasefire and began to participate in negotiations at the conference on 25 September 2004.In November 2004, the Transnational Federal Government (TFG) was established, with support from JVA. With the TFG in place, IGAD stopped its mediation effort to try and reach a formal ceasefire agreement.

The Kapoeta, Jie, Dodoth, Turkana, Toposa and Didinga convened for a peace meeting on 13 May 2008. This meeting was organized by Riam Riam Turkana and the Karamoja Agro-pastoral Development Program (KADP).

In June 2008, the East African Safari Air Express, IKV Pax Christi, Intervida World Alliance, and Wilde Ganzen organized a four-day peace conference in Kapoeta in Southern Sudan. Seeds of Peace in Africa (SOPA) acted as the mediator at this conference. Representatives of the Acholi, Buya, Dodoth, Dongiro (Ethiopia), Jie, Kachipo, Lokir (Sudan), Lotuko, Matheniko (Uganda), Murile, Theuso, Toposa, and Turkana (Kenya) attended the peace conference. The conference did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
third_party: East African Safari Air Express; IKV Pax Chrsti; Intervida World Alliance; Wilde Ganzen; Seeds of Peace Africa

description: On 7 July 2008, the Jie and Turkana reached a peace agreement in the Kotido district during a round of peace talks mediated by Kenyan and Ugandan government officials.

The leaders of the Jie and Turkana engaged in peace talks in Turkana West district in December 2013. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in which both sides promised to end cattle raiding. This peace effort took place in Turkana West district.

Conflict over cattle raiding continued in 2016. The two tribes met for peace talks in Kotido. This round of talks was initiated by the Jie peace committee and mediated by KOPEIN. The meeting led to the formation of a taskforce to find the stolen cattle. Several community-level meetings were organized by the taskforce afterward to keep the peace.

Armed fighting between the Ukele and the Izzi erupted in 2005 in the contecxt of a series of land disputes. The Ukele claimed that the Izzi had taken some of their traditional lands. Moreover, the Ukele feared that the much larger Izzi (Igbo) community would assert political dominance over them. The fighting took mainly place at the border between the states of Cross River and Ebonyi and lasted two weeks in April 2005. On 23 April 2005, the authorities of Ebonyi and Cross River States met in Calabar to discuss the armed conflict. The governors of Ebonyi and Cross River States subsequently mediated between the Izzi and Ukele leaders in Abakaliki on 15 May 2005. However, fighting continued.

After renewed clashes between the Izzi and Ukele communities, the deputy governors of Ebonyi and Cross Rive States mediated between the conflict parties on 3 July 2018. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. The agreement stipulated that both sides would lay down their weapons, as well as establish a peace committee that would investigate the causes of the crisis.

In early December 2019, after repeated attacks between the Izzi and the Ukele, youth from both communities reached a peace agreement after failed efforts from the local state authorities. However, violence resumed in December 2019, which led to the death of a 17-year-old student in the Local Government Area of Izzi.

On 23 April 1997, military authorities announced that they have sent military troop to Warri to restore order. At the beginning of May 1997, youths and leaders from the Ijaw and Itsekiri communities gathered in Effon, near Warri, for a peace meeting chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. At this occasion, the warring parties agreed to end hostilities. However, there is no public information available on the signing of a written agreement.

As violence between the two communities erupted again in Orgubo on 23 October 1998, the Nigerian government asked the two tribes to meet and negotiate an end to the conflict and instituted a public curfew on 24 October 1998. The leaders of Ijaw and Itsekiri subsequently met at a peace meeting in Asaba, capital of Delta State, on 26 October 1998. This peace meeting was mediated by Commander Walter Feghabor, military administrator, and resulted in a ten-point communiqué calling for an immediate cessation of the ongoing hostilities. Feghabor, Ijaw, and Isteriki representatives were set to meet with General Abdulsalami Abubaka for follow-up.

At the end of May and June 1999, as Nigeria transitioned from a military to a civilian government, violence erupted again in Warri. As during previous episode of armed fighting, the government quickly sent soldiers to restore order. The governor of Delta State, James Ibori, announced a new curfew on 7 June 1999.
