Newly elected President Olusegun Obasanjo met leaders of Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Uroboh communities on 9 June 1999 in Abuja to show its commitment to peace in the Warri Delta region and encourage the stakeholders to respect each other and find a peaceful solution to the crisis.

On the same day (9 June 1999), Chief James Onanefe Ibori, Governor of Delta State, held a peace meeting with leaders of the Urhobo, Ijaw, and Itsekiri communities in Warri to prepare the visit of President Obasanjo to Warri.

President Obasanjo then visited Warri on 11 June 1999, held a peace meeting with the leaders and representatives of the conflict parties. On the same day, the National Assembly of Nigeria set up a 12-person committee to investigate the Warri crisis.

Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo representatives met for two days of negotiations in Asaba on 16 and 17 June 1999. The negotiations were mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State. With no progress made, another round of negotiations was scheduled for the next week.

The negotiations mediated by Governor James Ibori one week later, in Asaba on 24 June 1999, were successful and led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws, and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos.

Following negotiations, the Ijaw and Itsekiri signed a peace agreement on 1 February 2000. The Delta State Government mediated this round of negotiations. On 17 March, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko leaders visited President Obasanjo in Abuja to announce the return of peace to Warri.

The Governor of Delta State eventually agreed to renegotiate the electoral boundaries during peace talks in Warri in the end of March 2003. These peace talks between the Ijaw and Itsekiri leaders and the Delta State government led to the signing of a ceasefire between the two communities on 26 March 2003.
Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 March 2003 between the Ijaw youth (FNDIC) and the Itsekiri in the presence of state officials.
On 24 March 2003, James Ibori held an emergency meeting with the leaders of the Ijaws, the Urhobo, and the Itsekiri in Warri. No agreement was signed on this occasion.

On 7 April 2003, Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri, and Ijaw leaders in Abuja along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peace solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the warring tribes reached a ceasefire agreement.
On 15 May 2003, the national leader of Nigeria’s Ijaw ethnic communities reported that the youth of the Ijaw militia agreed to a ceasefire.
On 20 July 2003, the Delta State Governor announced that leaders of the two tribes declared a ceasefire in Warri.

Concerned about a possible offensive by the Ijaw and Itsekiri youths, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone 5, Mr. Gazali Lawal, and the Delta State Police Commissioner, Mr. Jonathan Akaya, held peace meetings with the leaders of the two communities in the Police Zone Command Office in Warri on the night of 9 to 10 August 2003. The meeting culminated in a communiqué signed by Mr. Justice Rewane for the Itsekiri, Chief Bare Etobor and Chief Tunde Smooth for the Ijaws, and by Akaya on behalf of the police. He urged the warring youth to support the government’s peace efforts.  However, armed violence still erupted in spite of this effort and Nigerian authorities imposed a curfew on the town of Warri on 15 August 2003.

Nigerian troops were deployed in Warri after some 100 people were killed between 15 and 20 August.  In addition, the federal government deployed a joint security force in Delta State: “Operation Restore Hope”, which would be maintained in the following years.  On 20 August 2003, the leaders of the two ethnic groups met in Warri and signed a ceasefire mediated by Delta State governor, James Ibori.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly in Asaba and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups – the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo – to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri referred to the plan of as “illegal” and “unconstitutional” and expressed their dissatisfaction with it.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri’s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori’s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

Governor James Ibori called a security meeting on 10 November 2003 in Warri to prevent a resurgence of figting in Warri. State officials as well as representatives of the Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri tribes took part in the discussion.

In late November 2003, President Obasanjo set up a new committee to resolve the Warri crisis, headed by Delta State governor James Ibori. The latter mediated several rounds of negotiations with Itsekiri, Urhobo, and Ijaw leaders.

New clashes began in January 2004 between the two rival ethnic groups in the swamps surrounding the port of Warri. A 28-member peace committee, consisting of 14 Itsekiri and 14 Ijaws, met on 18 February 2004 in Warri. James Ibori and the Commissioner for Special Missions, Inter-Ethnic Relations, and Conflict Resolution, Ovuozourie Macaulay, acted as the mediators. The peace committee meeting led to approval of a six-point agreement aimed at peaceful coexistence between the rival groups. Among the main points are the establishment of a joint peace vanguard composed of members of both groups and an agreement that would allow people displaced by the conflict to return to their homes of origin without fear of attack.

On 1 June 2004, leaders of ethnic Ijaw and Itsekiri youth activist groups signed a ceasefire through the platform of the Warri Ijaw/Itsekiri Grassroots Peace Front (WIIGPF) moderated by Pastor Power Ziakede Aginighan.

Three weeks after the ceasefire concluded by the militias and after more than six months of peace negotiations, the Ijaw and the Istekiri leaders signed a peace agreement on 23 June 2004 at the senior officers mess, NNS Delta Navy base, in Warri. Delta State Commissioner for Inter-Ethnic Relation and Conflict Resolution, Comrade Ovuzuorie Macauley was chief mediator of the negotiations.

The ceasefires concluded in June 2004 led to a fragile peace. However, tensions in the Delta North remained. Between 18 and 19 June 2005, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko (Urhobo) traditional rulers launched a traditional leaders’ forum in Ozoro. This forum was initially headed by Ijaw retired Brigadier General Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide and had the goal to minimize the tensions between the ethnic groups. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities.

The Huber and Yantar subclans have historically made use of traditional management structures that regulate the construction, use and maintenance of water catchments for both pastoral and agricultural communities. However, when a nomad from the Huber sub-clan bathed in the precious water source in early 2004, a man from the Yantar sub-clan killed him. This triggered armed fighting between the two sub-clans in March 2004, though the UCDP records August 2005 as the start of the conflict. At least four peacemaking initiatives to resolve the conflict between the Huber and the Yantar took place prior to August 2005: the Digil and Mirifle Malaqyo peace initiative in Xagar village in December 2004, a parliamentarians-led peace initiative in Xawaale Barbaar village on 1 January 2005, the Elay-led peace initiative in Qansaxdhere on 2 April 2005, and the IRDA-led peace initiative on 1 January 2005, and 1 August 2005. In response to several armed clashes on 12 and 13 August 2005, local clan elders mediated between the conflict parties on 20 August 2005.

Local elders mediated between the two subclans at a peace meeting in Idale in February 2006, which led to the confirmation of a peace agreement from 2005. The Transitional Federal Government (TFG) established the National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) in late 2005 with the task of facilitating reconciliation throughout the country.

On 23 November 2006, the NRC arrived in Idale to help find a solution to the conflict between the Huber and Yantar. The National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) brokered a 15-day ceasefire, which was extended for another ten days following another armed clash by the end of the 15-day period.

This ceasefire held and the National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) facilitated a peace conference in Baidoa on 15 January 2007, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 15 January 2007. This agreement stipulated that the conflict parties would forgive past actions; that the land, including Idale village, belongs to Allah but that the state would manage it through the municipality; and that the water catchments that triggered the conflict would be managed by the municipality of the village.

Tensions between the Hotiya Baggara tribe on the one side and the Newiba, Mahariba, and Mahamid on the other side increased in years prior to the armed conflict because the Hotiya started to farm alongside the keeping of cattle. This made them less willing to share pasture fields. During 2005, the Hotiya Baggara clashed repeatedly with the Newiba, Mahariba and Mahamid groups over natural access to land and water. The trigger for a full-scale armed conflict was the rape of a Newiba girl by a member of the Hotiya in Serif Omra locality. The Hotiya Baggara financially compensated the Newiba during a customary conflict resolution process in October 2005, but this reconciliation process collapsed following an insult by someone from the Newiba delegation. The Hotiya subsequently killed the entire seven-man delegation, which, in turn, prompted a massive counter-attack by the Newiba with support from the Mahariba and Mahamid. The fighting took mainly place in the Nyangadoula area in the Abaata locality.
A reconciliation conference facilitated by the local authorities led to an agreement in March 2006.  This agreement successfully terminated the armed conflict.

On 19 June 1999, Christian Nganga Lolo, the administrator of the territoire in which the conflict broke out, organized a conference inviting representatives of the Hema and Lendu elites to settle their dispute. However, the mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.
On 29 July 1999, a reconciliation meeting began in CCI-Nyakasanza and 451 people attended. It continued on 30 July, but did not result in a peace agreement.

Throughout the year, the Ugandan army and rebels aided in mediating the conflict. Wamba dia Wamba who had fled to Bunia in Ituri from Kisangani in August 1999 after the RCD’s split between RCD-Goma and RCD-ML (the latter being thereafter led by Wamba) also tried to mediate between the ethnic groups in 1999 and initially had a pacifying influence as he initiated peace talks and promoted ceremonies of mutual forgiveness. Two initiatives were established by the end of the year to pacify the conflict. The first initiative was the establishment of the Committee of Pacification and Follow-Up in August 1999 by Adèle Lotsove to investigate the outbreak of violence. The second initiative was the creation of the Commission for Security and Peace in the Djugu Zone by RCD-ML leader Wamba dia Wamba. This commission was led by Jacques Depelchin. Negotiations mediated by Depelchin between November and December 1999 resulted in a brief pause in the fighting, but the conflict reignited in mid-December 1999.

In December 1999, Ugandan president Museveni invited representatives of the Hema, Lendu, and other Iturian communities to Kampala. As a result of this meeting, he replaced some of the Ugandan soldiers which had taken sides and deployed more UPDF troops. In addition, during the negotiations in in Kampala, Wamba dia Wamba had asked Uganda to revoke Lotsove’s appointment as governor. She was subsequently replaced with a less controversial figure, Ernest Uringi Pa Ndolo, an ethnic Alur. The violence decreased temporarily.

A second round of heavy fighting erupted at the beginning of 2001, at the beginning of 2001 Lendu militias attacked Bunia for the first time, especially targeting UPDF headquarters and the airport. From 14 to 17 February, the Front de Libération du Congo (FLC) (English: Front for the Liberation of Congo), specifically via Jean-Pierre Bemba, mediated negotiations between the two groups. A peace agreement was signed by more than 150 local chiefs and notables on 17 February 2002. This agreement stipulated an end to hostilities, as well as included a provision for the new governor to be from neither ethnic group and two vice-governors one from each ethnic group. The agreement also tasked the FLC “with closing ethnic militia training camps, disarming civilians, deploying security forces, setting up peace tribunals throughout the region, rehabilitating prisons, and creating a special provincial follow-up committee.” The eminent persons present thereafter buried their machetes as a sign of reconciliation. Yet, the agreement was not fully implemented as Bemba lost control over Ituri in November 2001 after the disintegration of the FLC in June 2001 and several violent confrontations took place between RCD-ML and MLC. Ituri was subsequently almost fully controlled by RCD-ML.

The RCD-ML appointed a new governor and chief of staff in Ituri in early 2002, Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo. Many Hema perceived Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo as biased in favor of the Lendu, although he was from the Nande ethnic group. This further exacerbated local tensions and violence escalated again throughout Ituri, including in Bunia. In August 2002, the Union des Patriotes Congolais (UPC) (English: Union of Congolese Patriotes), a militia predominately made of Hema fighters, formed a government in Bunia and temporarily managed to rule over most of Ituri. In July and August 2002, informal talks were held between Hema and Lendu representatives in Kinshasa. These talks were facilitated by the Congolese Government with human rights minister, Ntumba Luaba, in the lead. The negotiations did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.

Direct negotiations between the Government of the DRC and the Government of Uganda, mediated by Angolan President José Eduardo Dos Santos, led to the conclusion of the Luanda Peace Agreement on 6 September 2002. This agreement not only put forward a timetable of three months for the Uganda forces to leave Ituri, it also established the Ituri Pacification Commission (IPC). The IPC was tasked, with support from MONUC, to bring together the leaders of all armed groups and representatives of civil society in Ituri in an effort to create an administrative authority for the region acceptable to all parties. However, it would not be until April 2003 before the first meeting of the IPC finally took place. In the final days of December 2002, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh and Ugandan gender, labour and social affairs minister, Zoe Bakoko Bakoru started to mediate a round of negotiations between the ethnic groups in Arua. The negotiations were aimed at concluding a peace agreement that would commit the Hema and the Lendu to halt hostilities.

The representatives of the UPC and the Front des Nationalistes et Intégrationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front), representing the Hema and Lendu, respectively, were supposed to finalize the agreement in Arua on 1 January 2003, but the UPC refused to sign the agreement last minute. However, five days later, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh succeeded in persuading UPC to sign the accord on behalf of the Hema.

The MONUC leadership sent an exploratory committee to Ituri to secure a local ceasefire and start building confidence among the members of the IPC from 22 to 29 January 2003. The MONUC team met all the actors in the Ituri crisis, including the Hema and the Lendu leaders. All agreed in principle to sign a peace agreement in Bunia. However, the UPC remained reluctant to support the IPC, stating that it was dominated by the government that had sided with Lendu ethnic groups through Mbusa Nyamwisi and wanted to pursue its own peace process so it could recuperate Ituri from the Ugandans.

On 11 February 2003, there was a summit in Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania between Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, Hema leader Thomas Lubanga, Congolese President Joseph Kabila, and representatives from Rwanda. This meeting served to relaunch the peace process. It was decided that the IPC would meet for the first time on 25 February 2003 and that the Ugandan troop withdrawal from Ituri would start on 20 March 2003. A ceasefire was scheduled to take effect in February 2003, before the first meeting of the IPC, but this ceasefire was postponed because the UPC questioned the good faith of the governments of Uganda and the DRC and MONUC. This stalled the process once again.

On 3 March 2003, the UN Special Representative Namanga Ngongi, with help from Pétronile Vaweka of the Alur tribe and founder and president of the association Fondation pour la Paix Durable, negotiated a ceasefire in Ituri. On 18 March 2003, Ngongi finally succeeded in creating a ceasefire at a round of negotiations in Bunia: the Ituri Cessation of Hostilities Agreement. However, the UPC, claiming to represent the Hema, refused to sign the ceasefire. The ceasefire also included a provision that stipulated the Ugandan troops to leave the DRC by 24 April 2003

From 4 to 14 April 2003, the IPC held a meeting with 32 delegations representing all socio-professional categories and armed movements, the governments of DRC, and Uganda. The meeting took place under the aegis of MONUC, represented by deputy special representative Behrooz Sadry. The IPC worked in three sub-commissions on security and cessation of hostilities, reestablishment of public services and rule of law, and humanitarian assistance and rehabilitation. Questions of reconciliation were addressed in bilateral meetings initiated by MONUC. The meeting led to the conclusion of another ceasefire, but also to the creation of an interim administration, the Administration Spéciale et Intérimaire de l’Ituri (ASII) (English: Ituri Special and Interim Administration). The ASII was presided over by an Alur women, Pétronile Vaweka and consisted of a General Assembly with 32 members, an interim executive organ with 5 members, a prevention and verification commission with 18 members, a committee for armed groups concertation with 9 members, and an interim human rights observatory with 17 members. The ASII was eventually relinked to Kinshasa and integrated into the national structure to consolidate the government’s control over its entire territory. When the final act to the Global and Inclusive Agreement at the national level was signed on 2 April 2003 in South Africa, Ituri was not pacified yet. Accordingly, Thabo Mbeki, in his capacity as chairperson of the African Union, invited the presidents of the DRC, Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania to a meeting in Cape Town on 11 April 2003. In this meeting, Uganda reiterated its willingness to withdraw its forces from Ituri by 24 April 2003. Yet, this withdrawal led to intensified fighting.

On 26 April 2003 the Ugandan army handed over command of Ituri to MONUC. MONUC deployed 700 peacekeepers, while the DRC government deployed 700 Special Forces. Yet, one week later, violence completely escalated with the government forces overwhelmed and MONUC losing control over Bunia in May 2003. In only two days, 562 civilians were killed by militias. In response, the Government of Tanzania and MONUC facilitated a round of negotiations between the Government of the DRC and leaders of the main Iturian militias on 17 May 2003. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement on 17 May 2003, which stipulated a ceasefire and the rights of the militias to be eligible for either integration into the national army or civilian reinsertion. On 30 May 2003, the Security Council adopted Resolution 1484, which authorized an interim emergency multinational force to restore peace and aid in humanitarian relief. This force, called Operation Artemis, consisted of 1,800 French troops and a small 80-man Swedish special forces unit. On 12 June 2003, the EU-led mission was launched in Bunia, the main town of Ituri region. The mission was mandated to last until 1 September 2003. In June 2003, the peacekeepers managed to restore security in the town, although massacres continued in the countryside.

On 1 August 2003, three Ministers of the new transitional government, set up in April and May 2003 and coming into being on 18 July 2003, visited Bunia to support the Ituri Interim Administration. With the exception of UPC, the armed groups expressed their willingness to be incorporated into the new armed forces. The new government mediated a round of negotiations between the Ituri militias in Kinshasa on 22 August 2003, which led to a memorandum of understanding in which the militias agree to work with the government to restore state authority across the region.

On 16 September 2003, an agreement to make Bunia a weapons free zone was reached between the conflict parties. Members of the Interim Administration regularly participated in information-gathering missions outside Bunia, where meetings were held with local authorities and populations to inform them of the existing peace process. The Interim Administration also organized successful peace marches in the town and was solving problems related to illegally occupied houses in Bunia. Yet, between 2003 and 2005, Bunia remained divided into two parts: one controlled by FNI and dominated by Lendu ethnic groups and one controlled by UPC and dominated by Hema ethnic groups. All aspects of public life were separated.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). This agreement, among others, stipulated a ceasefire. The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).

In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started. In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach another ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi’s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking.

Fighting resumed in 2016. In March 2016, MONUSCO and provincial authorities helped to facilitate negotiations between the Hema and Lendu in the Irumu territory. This led to a pledge to cease hostilities and a subsequent reduction in violence. However, violence increased not long after.

On 14 July 2017, a commission with Hema and Lendu leaders was formed. Negotiations as part of this commission were mediated by MONUSCO and the regional authorities. Yet, another upsurge in violence took place in December 2017.

Following a series of armed clashes between the Hema and Lendu communities in Djugu territory , MONUSCO staff from Bunia co-mediated a round of peace talks on 29 December 2017, along with the Territorial Administrator of Djugu territory and the president of Committee of Customary Chiefs of Ituri (COCCI). The traditional chiefs from both communities concluded a local agreement. It was also decided to set up local peace committees between neighbouring Hema and Lendu communities in order to enhance mutual trust.
In response to renewed fighting in late 2017, Ramazani Shadary, the Minister of the Interior, came to the region to mediate between Hema and Lendu representatives on 12 February 2018.
From 1 to 22 June 2018, Hema and Lendu community members came to together in Bunia for dialogue facilitated by MONUSCO.
The territory administrator and the traditional chiefs mediated between between Hema and Lendu in Djugu in Ituri in July 2018.
Representatives of the Hema and Lendu engaged in peace talks in the week of 10 March 2019. The peace talks were mediated by a government delegation led by the country’s deputy prime minister.
The provincial government of Ituri facilitated a three-day intercommunity dialogue between the Hema and the Lendu in Tchomia between 19 and 21 November 2019.

From 19 to 21 November 2019, tribal and administrative leadership from different communities from Ituri, including the Hema and the Lendu convened for a peace conference. This conference was facilitated by MONUSCO.

In late July 1999, Bola Tinubu, the Governor of Lagos, held a meeting with Hausa and Yoruba leaders in Lagos to encourage peaceful cooperation. Negotiations between both sides in the palace of the Akarigbo led to the signing of a peace agreement on 24 July 1999. The peace pact led to a few months of peace in the region.
The newly elected President of Nigeria, Olusegun Obasanjo, also met with the warring leaders in Kano on 10 August 1999.

Representatives of the conflict parties met again in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State on 3 November 1999 and agreed to an immediate cessation of hostilities in Lagos. The signatories were representatives of the Ijaw, the Ilaje, the Hausa and the Oodua People’s Congress (OPC – a Yoruba militia). Dele Alake, the Information Commissioner, along with other members of the State Executive Council acted as mediators.

On 28 November 1999, in reaction to renewed fighting between Hausa and Yoruba over the control over the Ketu / Mile 12 market in Lagos, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated negotiations between the leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. This led to a peace agreement in early December.

However, the armed conflict continued in 2000. In October 2000, the government banned the OPC and imposed a curfew on the city of Lagos. Several members of the OPC went to court. On 17 October 2000, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated between Igbo, Hausa, and Yoruba leaders during an emergency meeting at the state government secretariat auditorium. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. However, armed fighting resumed the next day.

Violent clashes erupting in Idi-Araba on 2 to 4 February 2002 led to the deployment of the Nigerian army in the area and several meetings between government officials and leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. On 5 February 2002, a meeting between the Governor of Lagos State, Bola Tinubu, and the Hausa and Yoruba leaders took place in Lagos. The Governor encouraged the two ethnic groups to achieve peace and reconciliation.

Furthermore, the Chairman of the Lagos Mainland Local Government, Alhaji Bashir Omolaja Bolarinwa, also mediated between Hausa and Yoruba community leaders in February 2002, but this did not lead to a written agreement.

A further meeting was organized by the new Director of the State Security Service (SSS) in the second half of February in Abeokuta, Ogun State, with Yoruba and Hausa leaders to prevent a crisis like the one in Lagos State from recurring. This meeting was aimed at ensuring peaceful coexistence between the communities, but did not result in a peace agreement.
In March 2002, representatives of the Hausa, Yoruba, and Igbo communities gathered at a peace meeting hosted by Igwe H.N. Ohazulike, who himself led the Igbo delegation, in his palace in Ifako.

Violent clashes resumed in the Idi-Araba region of the Mushin local government in October 2002. In response, the Inter-Ethnic Forum brought together Hausa, Yoruba, and Igbo representatives on 11 December 2002 for a peace meeting. This did not result in a written agreement.

A peace meeting hosted by the Inter-Ethnic Forum in Lagos in January 2003 gathered ethnic leaders from the Yoruba and Hausa communities from Idi-Araba. The leaders pledged to cease hostilities. The meeting led to the establishment of several committees – for example elders and youth committees composed of both Yoruba and Hausa – that were to ensure a lasting peace.

On 20 November 2003, in reponse to a dispute between Yoruba and Hausa traders at the Bodija market (Ibadan North, Oyo State), state police commissioner Felix Ogbandu mediated between representatives of the Bodija market in order to maintain peace in the area.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau – the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba – signed a peace agreement in Jos. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace. The peace meeing was not mediated by an external third party.

On 20 March 2012, following renewed violence in the Mile 12 market in Lagos between youth from the two communities; the local police organized a peace meeting between community leaders at the State Command Headquarters, Ikeja. The Lagos State Police Commissioner, Mr. Umaru Manko, mediated between the conflict parties. The conflict parties agreed to set up a 12-person peace committee. Alhaji Haruna Mohammed represented the Hausa, while Mr. Ashowade Adesina headed the Yoruba delegates. The two groups pledge to stop armed fighting, but did not conclude a written agreement.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated a series of peace meeings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders; government; local government

description: The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. Umaru Sani and Bankole Falade signed on behalf of the Hausa and Yoruba communities respectively. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

However, this joint declaration did not prevent new clashes that started in Mile 12 market and the Kosofe Local Government Area of Lagos on 3 March 2016. While Governor Akinwunmi Ambode immediately shut the market, Police Commissioner initiated peace talks with market leaders to ease tensions.

On 6 March 2016, following the armed violence in Mile 12, the secretary to the state government, Mr. Tunji Bello, representing Governor Akinwunmi Ambode, met with market stakeholders including Yoruba and Hausa traditional leaders at the Alausa Secretariat, Ikeja. This meeting led to a peace agreement signed by the stakeholders and the 12 Mile market reopened. Oba Akiolu of Lagos also held a stakeholders’ and residents’ meeting in at the Iga-Idugaran, Lagos Island at the beginning of March 2016. He supported the relocation of the market as a path to peace. Finally, on 16 March 2016, community leaders and market traders followed the plan of the state government and accepted the relocation of the market.

Five Local Government Areas – including Sanga, Kachia, Kaura, Zangon Kataf, and Jema’a – were brought together by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue in Kafachan on 23 March 2016 for a peace meeting. Both the Yoruba and Hausa were residing in these areas. The peace meeting led to the signing of the Kafanchan Peace Declaration, which guarantees the fostering of peace in Kaduna State and was signed by a wide range of actors, including representatives of development and cultural associations, traditional councils, elders, youth, women, and religious leaders.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: Senior police officers and leaders from the Hausa and the Yoruba gathered at a peace meeting in Ibadan on 18 May 2016. This meeting, which was mediated by Oyo State Governor Senator Abiola Ajimobi, was aimed at reinforcing and ensuring peace in the state, especially between herders and farmers.

On 23 March 2017, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Lagos and Ogun, Mr Kayode Aderanti organized a security meeting with representatives of several ethnic groups in Ogun State. The aim of the meeting was to prevent the Yoruba-Hausa crisis from happening again.

On 29 March 2017, the Yoruba socio-cultural organization, Afenifere, together with representatives of the Hausa and the Yoruba communities met for peace talks mediated by the Ooni of Ife, Oba Adeyeye Ogunwusi.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau communities leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Chief Bankole Falade spoke on behalf of the Yoruba people. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

Tensions rose again in Akure in May 2018. In response, the state government brought the leaders of the two communities together in the Cocoa Conference Hall for a peace meeting. The meeting resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement.

On 15 August 2019, after a year of shuttle diplomacy and pre-mediation meetings, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) launched the Benue Mediation Process to find a lasting solution to the farmer-herder conflicts in the region. The meeting took place at the Benue Hotel in Makurdi and brought together representatives of the Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Egede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba communities of Benue State. On this occasion, HD pledged to help the communities achieve lasting peace, while the attending communities pledged to support and actively participate in the mediation process. During this first meeting, it was announced that the mediation process would take place in a joint meeting between tribes from the same senatorial zones.

Clashes erupted between traders of the two ethnic groups at the Oke-Odo market in Lagos on 17 and 18 August 2019, injuring several people and destroying entire food stalls. Immediately after the turmoil, the army, the divisional police officers of the Oke Odo station, and officials of the Lagos State Waste Management Authority mediated between Hausa and Yoruba traders and market stakeholders in an attempt to calm the situation and bring peace to the market. No written agreement was signed but market activities quickly returned to normal.

HD convened a peace meeting with representatives of the Tiv, Idoma, Igede, Agatu, Etulo, Jukun, Fulani, Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa communities in Makurdi in Benue State in early November 2019. Traditional leaders, religious leaders, civil society groups, and security agencies, and state officials were also involved in the peace meeting. This meeting was part of the ongoing mediation dialogue between the conflict parties in the region. Stakeholders stressed the need for peace, but no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); traditional leaders; religious leaders; government forces; local government

description: The Muslim Hausa and Christian Tarok are two ethnic groups that have lived peacefully for a long period of time, being linked together through trade and cooperation in cattle. However, violence broke out between the two communities in 2002. This conflict is to be considered as part of the ethnic and religious conflict that has ravaged Plateau State since 1999. Both conflict parties participated in the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit.
Four smaller follow-up meetings were held in September 2002.

Several communities in the Wase Local Government Area, including Hausa and Tarok, took part in a peace meeting in the conference room of Rayfield Government House in Jos on 24 June 2004. The participants concluded the conference with issueing a communiqué that was signed by the communities at the end of the peace meeting.

In June 2016, Hausa and Tarok representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

The conflict between the Hausa and Igbo is reflective of a broader conflict going on between the Muslim and Christian communities in Nigeria. The Hausa are Muslim and reside mostly in northern Nigeria together with the Fulani, while the Igbo are mostly Christian and the majority live in southeastern Nigeria. Moreover, Igbo feel discriminated at the political level, claiming more political rights. This greater political assertation increased following the end of military rule in 1999. In 2000, the violence broke out in the town of Kaduna, leading to more than 200 casualties. Following this violent confrontation, the conflict leaders entered into a round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo, which led to an informal agreement on 29 February 2000 in Abuja. Hausa leaders agreed to stop pursuing strict Islamic law.
On 1 March, the Hausa and Igbo met with local and military leaders. This meeting produced a camp for people displaced by the fighting.

On 17 October 2000, during an emergency meeting mediated by the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, at the state government secretariat auditorium, the Igbo, Hausa and Yoruba leaders reached a peace agreement. However, new clashes broke out the next day.
On 17 October 2001, the Igbo and Hausa engaged in peace talk mediated by the police in Kano. The peace meeting let to the reopening of the Sabon Gari market, where Hausa and Igbo had fought.

Fighting between the conflict parties resumed in February 2002. Representatives of the Igbo and Hausa met in early March 2002 in Lagos at a peace forum inaugurated by the Igbo Eze-Ndi of Lagos, Eze Nwabueze Ohazulike. Alhaji. Hammed Yusuf represented the Hausa community. Both parties expressed their desire to end the ethnic conflict and urged the state government to participate in the peace process and to strengthen equity between the two groups.

In mid-March 2002, the peace forum was held again, this time with representatives of the Yoruba communities in addition to the Igbo and Hausa leaders in the Eze-Ndi Igbo – Eze Nwabueze Ohazulike – palace in Lagos, in Ifako. Alhaji Ahmed Arewa led once again the Hausa delegation. The peace talks did not lead to a written agreement.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau – Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba – signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated a series of peace meeings between the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba between August 2013 and June 2014. Umaru Sani and Barr Zacch O. Nwankpa represented the Hausa and Igbo communities respectively during these negotiations. These meetings were part of the Jos Forum in which in addition to the community leaders, the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Government of Plateau State also participated.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); government; local government; community leaders

description: The Dialogue, Reconciliation and Peace Center (DREP) facilitated a meeting with eight religious leaders and six community leaders from the Hausa, Afisare, Berom, Igbo, Anaguta, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 19 June 2014. The meeting was aimed at working towards peaceful coexistence between Christian and Muslim communities.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

Representatives of five Local Government Areas – including Sanga, Kachia, Kaura, Zangon Kataf, and Jema’a – were brought together by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue in Kafachan on 23 March 2016 for a peace meeting. Inter-community fighting, including between the Hausa and the Igbo, was on the agenda of this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of the Kafanchan Peace Declaration, which guarantees the fostering of peace in Kaduna State and was signed by a wide range of actors, including representatives of development and cultural associations, traditional councils, elders, youth, women, and religious leaders.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders; traditional leaders; religious leaders

description: Peace talks involving community representatives from six Local Government Areas in the Southern Plateau, including representatives of the Hausa and Igbo communities, led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated the talks leading up this agreement.

In August and September 2016, Alhaji Kabir Kasim, Deputy Chief Imam of the Jema’a Local Government Area facilitated a meeting between Hausa and Igbo representatives at the Igbo community town hall in Kafanchan. The meeting resulted in the partnership of the security agencies of the two communities to prevent violence from erupting in Kafanchan.

In mid-June 2017, President Yemi Osinbajo met separately with Hausa and Igbo leaders. The purpose of these shuttle talks was to avoid secessionist claims by Igbo leaders, but conflict between the Hausa and Igbo was also discussed. However, the conflict did not subside after these meetings.

On 4 August 2017, a 10-man peace committee equally composed of Hausa and Igbo was set up to find solution to the conflict. A meeting of the committee was held in Kano on 8 August 2017. Isa Tijani acted as the mediator of this meeting, which was aimed at reaching a peace agreement between the two tribes. However, both sides wanted further consultations before committing to an agreement.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau communities leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Barr. Zacch O. Nwankpa spoke on behalf of the Igbo people. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

The armed conflict between the Habaniya and the Rizeigat Baggara revolves mainly around access to land and water. Fighting between the tribes resulted in at least 150 deaths in July 2006. In 2006, the local administration organized a reconciliation conference. There, both parties signed a reconciliation document.

Fighting resumed in Sunta locality in March and again in July 2015. No mediation or military intervention took place immediately following the outbreak of clashes in March and early July, but the Sudanese Armed Forces reinforced buffer zones between the two communities in late July. In addition, a “taskforce” including local authorities and representatives of both tribes met in late July to find a sustainable solution to the conflict.

The Habaniya and Fulani (commonly referred to as Fallata in Sudan) repeatedly clashed in 2007 as a result of Fulani claiming land in Darfur. In an attempt to end the fighting, a government reconciliation mission met with conflict parties on 13 January 2007.

Following a series of retaliatory attacks throughout the first half of December 2008, both tribes agreed to attend reconciliatory talks in Nyala on 20 December 2008, but this was postponed to 25 December. This peace conference was mediated by the Sudanese government with support from UNAMID. The conference would take until 20 February, but failed because the decision on the boundary demarcation between the tribes was unacceptable to the Fulani. Fighting resumed on 9 March 2009.

UNAMID Civil Affairs subsequently mediated between the leaders of the conflicts parties on 19 March 2009. Local authorities also attempted to mediate between the leaders of the conflict parties at a peace meeting between the conflict parties on 30 and 31 March 2009.

Cattle rustling resulted in renewed clashes between the Habaniya and Fulani in early September 2014. In response, UNAMID held meetings with tribal leaders and state authorities to encourage dialogue between the two communities. This resulted in the creation of a mediation committee to further dialogue and peace. UNAMID also met with South Darfur state officials to urge that the underlying and unresolved issue of border demarcation be addressed, which contributed to the defusing of a potentially volatile situation between the two tribes.
The Ethiopian government mediated between the conflict parties in June 2008.

The murder of a Garre man by Murule clansmen in late December 2004 escalated into armed clashes between the Garre sub-clan and the Murule sub-clan in Mandera in 2005. Already in December 2004 before the violence had esclated into armed conflcit, a team of women mediators led by Dekha Ibrahim Abdi started to held consultations regarding the violence in Mandera in response to the growing tensions. In December 2004, the Malaqyo of the two clans convened for a peace meeting, along around 100 community and religious representatives. The tribes reached a 15-day ceasefire by the end of the talk, but the ceasefire soon broke down.
third_party: traditional leaders; community leaders; religious leaders

description: Another round of negotiations in December led to a verbal 15-day ceasefire, but this ceasefire also broke down.

Dekha Ibrahim Abdi mediated between members of the Garre and Murule communities in a round of peace talks on 11 January 2005. Kenyan government officials were also involved in these talks. These talks led to the establishment of an internal policing system.
On 17 January, Garre and Murule elders attended a round of peace talks mediated by the provincial government. This meeting led to the signing of a ceasefire.
A round of negotiations in April 2005 led to the Umal Accord. The Kenyan government served as a guarantor of this agreement and the District Peace Committee was tasked to oversee its implementation.

The Kenyan government dispatched a 40-elder peace team to the Mandera district to foster continued reconciliation in February 2006. This led to the conclusion of another peace agreement between the Garre and Murule.
In 2007, the Ministry for Northern Kenya convened a peace meeting between 50 representatives from the Garre, Murule, and surrounding tribes. This meeting was held in Nairobi.
Peace talks between the two tribes led to the signing of a peace agreement in Mandera on 14 February 2008.

From 28 to 29 April 2008, 15 leaders from the two tribes met for another round of negotiations in Mandera. The negotiations began with separate meetings with each tribe before the two presented their positions in front of the Mandera Mediation Council led by chief mediator Sheikh Ahmed Sudan. The mediation effort led to a peace agreement that included a provision for a task force to monitor the implementation of the February agreement.

Competing claims by the Garre and Marehan communities over the town El Wak in Mandera, along the Somali-Kenyan border, escalated into an armed conflict in April 2005. A subsequent mediation effort was led by Shaikh Ali Gure, a Somali-Kenyan religious leader from the Ogaden clan that had participated in a peace process for a Kenyan conflict involving the Garre. Shaikh Ali Gure mediated between the clan elders of both conflict parties between July and August 2005. This mediation effort led to the conclusion of a power-sharing agreement, but the conflict issue of ownership over the town was left for further peace efforts.
In August 2005, several NGOs from Beled Hawa and the Mandera District Peace Committee mediated between the conflict parties in El Wak, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.

In June 2006, representatives of the Garre and Marehan attended the El Wak peace conference. This conference was convened by the Somali and Kenyan government representatives, as well as the Mandera District Commissioner. The Juba Valley Alliance (JVA) funded the event. The El Wak peace conference did not end in a written agreement, but the conflict parties agreed to postpone the establishment of an El Wak district administration and instead set up a committee of 15 members to manage the affairs of the district.
third_party: government; Kenya; local government; local NGO

description: Following armed clashes between Gamai and Pan tribes over land ownership in Namu in Plateau State, Governor Joshua Dariye established a committee for inquiry into the conflict as well as implemented a curfew. Governor Joshua Dariye mediated between the conflict parties in the last week of April 2006, which led to a white paper on resolving the conflict.

From 17 to 19 July 2006, Gamai and Pan leaders attended a peace meeting mediated by the International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH) and the Inter-Faith Mediation Center (IMC). This peace meeting culminated in the signing of a peace agreement.
third_party: International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH); local NGO

description: In June 2016, Gamai and Pan representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD); community leaders

description: The Galje’el clan and Jejele subclan clashed on 6 June 2005 in the contect of a conflict over natural resources in the city of Beledweyne. A mediation team consisting of clan elders and local scholars was quickly formed to mediate between the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire on 7 June, but the conflict reignited the next day.
third_party: traditional leaders; community leaders; local peace committee

description: The Hiran Council of Elders held talks among each other between 10 and 11 June 2005 in order to determine how to best find a solution to the ongoing conflict. It was decided that a set of elders from the Xawaadle clan would mediate between the conflict parties.  Following an intervention executed by a disengagement force on 12 June, the fighters on both sides respected a ceasefire.  The Xawaalde team mediated negotiations in  Beledweyne between 13 and 14 June. The conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 17 June and a standing committee was set to monitor the implementation of this agreement.

A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.

side_b: Ma'alin Weyne subclan of Mirifle clan (Digil-Mirifle)
description: The armed conflict between the Gaadsan and Ma’alian Weyne subclans started in Luq in March 2008 following a dispute over access to water sources and grazing land rights. Local administration and neutral clan leaders mediated between the two sides, but this did not lead to an agreement.
The UN engaged in shuttle talks between the conflict parties in April 2016.

In June 2017, Deputy Haruna Manu, on the orders of Governor Darius Ishaku, held a security meeting with the various tribes of the Mambila Plateau, including the Mambila and Fulani. Yet, violence broke out again soon after this meeting.
After the crisis re-erupted in June 2017, the police commissioner, Mr. Yakubu Babas, summoned the tribal chiefs to a meeting in order to avoid an escalation of the crisis.

Another meeting between the Mambila and Fulani communities took place at the Nigeria Union of Teacher’s hall in Gembu in early July 2017. The chairman, Rev. Ben Ube of the Taraba State chapter of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) spoke on behalf of the Mambila tribe, while Alhaji Ahmadu Bello, chairman of the Sardauna chapter of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association of Nigeria, was representing the Fulani. This meeting was aimed at ending violence and finding a solution to the crisis.

On 5 March 2018, President Buhari mediated between Mambila and Fulani leaders at the government house in Jalingo. He appealed for justice and peace in the area. However, armed fighting resumed Shortly after.

Heavy fighting took place in January 2002. Local clan elders subsequently mediated between the conflict parties in Garowe on 11 January 2002. This effort did not bring peace and on 26 January, they requested Jama and Yusuf demilitarize the city. Abdullahi Yusuf managed to defeat the forces of Jama Ali Jama. As such, Abdullahi Yusuf remained in power throughout his second term as president of Puntland until October 2004. He subsequently became the became President of the Transitional Federal Government (TFG).
Both Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama attended the national reconciliation conference in Eldoret, Kenya, in October and November 2002.

Building on the Eldoret conference, Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama signed a peace agreement, which stipulated a formal power-sharing formula, on 17 May 2003. This peacemaking effort was independent of the national process.

In addition, the FNI and the FAPC both signed the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) on 14 May 2004, along other armed groups such as the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).
In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful.

The Forces armées du peuple Congolais (FAPC) (English: People’s Armed Forces of Congo) was formed in early 2003, when Kérôme Kakwavu who was formerly with RCD-ML and then UPC defected. He was in control of Mahagi and Aru. The Front des Nationalistes et Intégrationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front) was formed in late 2002, with support from the RCD-ML under Mbusa Nyamwisi and the Government of the DCR. One faction was led by Floribert Njabu at the northern border of Djugu, while another faction was led my Mathieu Ngudjolo located east of Bunia. The FAPC and FNI concluded a non-aggression pact in 2003, as well as an agreement to split taxes earned on trade in the region. Yet, this agreement broke down when the FAPC signed a mining deal with a Ugandan-based company to mine gold in the Zani river in Djalasiga. The conflict parties clashed on 15 June 2004, with both parties trying to control the goldmine and the wider region. MONUC mediated between the conflcit parties in July 2004, since the fighting was seen as violating the terms of the Acte d’Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) which had been concluded on 14 May 2004. Both the FAPC and the FNI were signatories of this agreement, which committed seven militias active in Ituri to end hostilities. MONUC’s mediation effort led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 July 2004. However, this ceasefire was already violated on 9 July 2004.

side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: However, when conflict between the clans over land and water rights reignited on 1 December 2012, Al-Shabaab and local clan elders immediately started to mediate between the leaders of the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 December, which was officially signed on 14 December.
In 1998, Nyangatom elders visited Turkana elders to perform reconciliation rituals.
The two sides performed traditional rituals at a peace meeting in Kibish in 2004, as well as promised to respect a cessation of hostilities.
In May 2005, bilateral peace talks between the Turkana and Nyangatom led to pledge to normalize relations.

Later in May 2005, peace conference, with support from the Kuraz wereda administration, led to the signing of a peace agreement outlining plans for shared grazing resources. However, renewed violence during the second half of May terminated the peace process.

A peace conference was held with 20 participants in Lokichogio in August 2005. Aimed at reconciling the Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana, this conference was faciliated by the African Union – Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU-IBAR). This peace conference did not result in a peace agreement.
From 5 to 8 April 2006, Development Alternative, the Turkana Peace Initiative, and Oxfam collaborated and facilitated a peace meeting in Turkana North. This meeting did not lead to a peace agreement.
third_party: community leaders; local peace committee; Oxfam

description: In the first half of 2006, Ethiopian and Kenyan government officials organized a peace meeting that brought together 120 Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana delegates. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants indicated interest in a second peace conference in Kenya.

After a flare-up of violence on 14 March 2007, district representatives from the Nyangatom administration in Ethiopia convened in Lokitang in Kenya with their Kenyan counterparts to discuss plans for organizing  a peace meeting.

The March peace meeting was followed up with a peace meeting between Nyangatom and Turkana representative, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 6 April 2007. Despite this agreement, there were some violent incidences in June 2007.

In August 2007, the Ethiopian Pastoralist Research and Development Association (EPARDA), Riam Riam, and USAID mediated between the conflict parties. These talks did not lead to an agreement, but both conflict parties agreed to continue peace talks.

The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) mediated a four-day peace meeting between the conflict parties and some other tribes in early December 2007, which led to a peace agreement.
The Conflict Early Warning and Response Mechanism (CEWRAN) collaborated with Ethiopian and Kenyan Conflict Early Warning Response Units (CEWERU) to hold peace talks that started in March 2008.

On 11 and 12  July 2008, at another round of talks mediated by CEWARN, attendees agreed on long term strategies to sustain and enhance peace, as well as to establish local peace committees in Nyangatom Wereda of Ethiopia and Kibish division, Turkana North District in Kenya.

On 12 August, the Turkana stole around 13,000 cattle from the Nyangatom. Government delegates from Ethiopia and Kenya mediated between community representatives from the Nyangatom and the Turkana in Nakuru on 10 October 2009.

A second peace meeting mediated by Ethiopian and Kenyan government officals was held in Hawassa on 2 November 2009. During this second meeting the conflict parties agreed on the establishment of a joint cross border administrators committee, to strengthen joint cross border peace structures, and to issue monthly reports on the implementation of the peace process. The Ethiopian delegation was led by the president of the Southern Nations Nationalities and People Region (SNNPNR) and the Provincial Commissioner of the Rift Valley Province led the Kenyan delegation.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.
In 2017, multiple women’s dialogue sessions took place. Women from both tribes attended the Women Intra-healing Dialogue in Omorate from 1 to 2 March 2017.
Women from both tribes also attended the Women-Led Intra-Community Healing Dialogue in Kangaten from 3 to 4 March 2017.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter’s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)’s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017.  The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.
On 12 June 2017, the Joint Women Forum was held in Lowaregnak, Turkana County. This initiative was facilitated by PDC and SAPCONE.

A Chief’s Led Inter-Community Dialogue took place in Omorate on 12 June 2017. During this dialogue, attendees discussed past peace efforts, including the Arba Minch Resolution from 2016. The session’s main conclusion was that relations between the Dassanech, Turkana, and Nyangatom had to be further improved and that to this purpose further peace initiatives would take place in the second half of the year.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 30 August 2017, the Joint Cross-Border Lower Level Government Official’s Meeting was held at Turmi, Ethiopia in order to prioritize mitigating the conflict between the Nyangatom, the Turkana, and the Dassanech.  On 24 and 25 September 2017, the Joint Cross-border Chiefs’ Led Inter-Community Dialogue was held in Omorate, Ethiopia. The peace meeting was facilitated by PCD and SAPCONE. A total of 26 participants attended the peace meeting, including Ethiopian delegates, representatives of local governments in both countries, as well as the Dassanech, Nyangatom and Turkana representatives. During this meeting, participants agreed to conflict resolution mechanisms.
third_party: local NGO; local government; government; Kenya

description: In January 2019, the communities met at a peace conference organized by SAPCONE in the Illemi Triangle. Representatives from South Sudan and Uganda also participated. The conflict parties reached  a peace agreement. On 6 April 2019, the Ateker Economic Summit convened tribal youth (from the Jie, Karamojong, Nyangatom, Teso, Toposa, and Turkana communities) in Teso North Sub County. Although this summit did not engage in direct negotiations, it was aimed at promoting peaceful relations.
On 28 April, the governor of Turkana county met in Kibish with representatives from the Nyangatom Woreda District to promote peace between the communities.
In May 2019, Nyangatom and Turkana governors and tribal leaders met for peace talks to further mitigate cattle raiding and tensions.

In July 2019, Kenya and South Sudan decided to establish a joint border commission to stop conflict and promote peace between the Toposa, the Turkana, and the Nyangatom in Elemi Triangle. The Commission was mainly focused on resolving border issues between those communities.

The Dizi and Suri have repeatedly engaged in armed fighting from the late 1980s onwards, particularly in the Maji region. Conflict between the two ethnic groups centered on resource competition, settling, and issues of traditional authority. The Ethiopian People’s Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) mediated between the two groups, as well as representatives of the Me’en, in Maji on 6 December 1991. This peace meeting did not result in a peace agreement.

Another round of negotiations – in which 80 Me’en, 350 Dizi and 20 Suri participated – was held on 11 December 1991. This meeting ended with the conclusion of an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and a pledge to disarm. The disarmament was scheduled for 15 February 1992. Local elders from the three tribes were selected to oversee implementation.

On 15 February 1992, the EPRDF oversaw the disarmament of the Me’en, Dizi and Suri. When the Suri did not turn in all their weapons, the EPRDF sought to keep the peace and responded by sending troops to Maji and Turn.
By 2003, the conflict between the Dizi and Suri reignited. The Ethiopian government mediated between the communities various times during 2003.
However, the Didinga and Toposa reached a peace agreement in 2013 in which the leaders of the tribes vowed to end hostility.

In March 2014 a second peace conference, facilitated by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) and the East Equatorian State Government, led to another agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, as well as condemned cattle raids and requested the state government to deploy police personnel into the area.

The Da’ud and Warsangeli subclans clashed in the Manopolyo neighborhood of Mogadishu in January 2004. The conflict was mainly about which of the subclans controlled this neighborhood. On 30 May 2004, local elders mediated negotiations between the Da’ud and Warsangeli, which led to a ceasefire agreement.
A round of negotiations between the conflict parties on 11 May 2005 failed.
On 12 May 2005, a chief named Muhamoud Ali mediated between the conflcit parties. His efforts resulted in a ceasefire between them.

The Kibete and the Darsalim are two ethnic groups living in eastern Chad. The Kibete and the Darsalim clashed throughout 2006, particularly in November 2006. A government commission traveled to the conflict area to mediate between the chiefs of the two communities in November 2006.

The armed conflict between the Dabare and Luway subclans of the Digil-Mirifile took place in the context of disputes over land rights and local political power. Armed fighting started in May 2004 in the Bay region.The two sides reached a temporary ceasefire agreement in late June, but this agreement did not address the underlying conflict issues. Fighting began again on 13 August 2004.

Once the fighting stopped on 16 August, neutral clan leaders from Baidao attempted to reconcile the two sides. While this mediation did not lead to an agreement, it reduced tensions between the conflict parties.

In 2005, leaders from the Dabare and Luway convened at the Togaar Hoos peace conference that was funded by the community. Without any third party involvement, this effort led to the signing of a peace agreement.

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held between 6 and 23 January 2008. During this conference, a meeting was held between the CNDP, PARECO, the Government of the DRC, and the Government of Rwanda at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma on 16 January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abbé Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The role of the UN representatives was twofold. First, the served as observers in order to ensure the neutrality of the talks. Second, in addition to participating in the plenary meetings, the UN representatives held secret bilateral meetings with Government of the DRC and the CNDP leadership. This led to PARECO ending its conflict with the CNDP on 17 January and the conclusion of a peace agreement between CNDP and the Government of the DRC on 23 January.  In addition, the Congolese government and 22 armed groups signed a peace agreement – the Acte d’engagement – in Goma on 23 January 2008, committing all parties to an immediate ceasefire and the disengagement of forces from frontline positions. However, soon after the conclusion of this agreement, the CNDP launched a military offensive to dislodge PARECO and Mayi Mayi Mongol fighters from the Bukombo area. Fighting between these parties continued between February and April 2008.

In 2002, Jacob Zuma, the Deputy President of South Africa, mediated negotiations between the Burundian Government, a smaller faction of the Conseil national pour la défense de la démocratie-Forces pour la défense de la démocratie (CNDD-FDD) (English: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy), and a smaller faction within the Parti pour la libération du peuple Hutu - Forces nationales de liberation (Palipehutu-FNL) (English: Party for the Liberation of the Hutu People- Forces for the National Liberation). This led to the signing of a ceasefire between the Government of Burundi and these two rebel groups on 7 October 2002. The Nkurunziza faction of the CNDD-FDD subsequently signed a ceasefire with the Government of Burundi on 2 December 2002, preparing the fighters of this faction for inclusion in the transitional government and in the army. The Palipehutu-FNL, on the other hand, continued to fight the Government of Burundi. Refusing to join the government, the Palipehutu-FNL remained as the only powerful rebel group that had not joined the peace process. By signing the agreement, the CNDD-FDD became part of the government. This placed the CNDD-FDD and the Palipehutu-FNL at loggerheads, which led to several clashes between the two rebel groups. On 25 January 2003, Burundian President Pierre Buyoya held talks with CNDD-FDD leader Jean-Bosco Ndayikengurukiye and the leader of a splinter of the Palipehutu-FNL led by Alain Mugabarabona. At this meeting, the leaders signed a memorandum of understanding with regards to the 7 October 2002 agreement. This memorandum established a joint ceasefire commission comprising six members each from the two rebel groups and the government, under the direction of a UN official. However, fighting continued, which ended more or less with a victory for the CNDD-FDD and its government ally. The Palipehutu-FNL nevertheless survived as a rebel group, although having been severely weakened by the fighting.
The Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus mediated between the Burji and the Guji at a peace conference in Doqonnu on 28 March 2010.
In 1997, the Ethiopian People’s Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) mediated a round of peace talks between the Borana, Gabra and Garre.

On 5 and 6 January 2010, the tribes took part in a cross-border peace meeting. This meeting was organized by the Dire CEWERU LPC with ACCORD. There were 111 attendees from both countries. The conflict parties reached an agreement regarding resource sharing. To implement this, 14 joint committees were established (9 in Ethiopia and 5 in Kenya) for oversight.

In September 2010, the Borana and Gabra communities participated in locally-organized peace caravans. The tribal delegates of the Borana and the Gabra – as well as the Meru, Pokot, Rendile, Samburu, Somali and Turkana – engaged in reconciliation talks as part of these peace.

A land dispute between the Borana and the Konso escalated into an armed conflict in 2007. The Borana Aba Gadaa (tradional leader) mediated between the conflict parties in 2008, but there is no information on the outcome of this mediation effort.
On 15 May 2018, the Borana and Konso attended a peace meeting mediated by the Borena district administrator Abdel Kedir Abdinur. This round of peace talks did not lead to an agreement.

Fighting in 2006 was sparked over the government’s 2003 land policy, which re-assigned portions of the Borana district to the Guji. A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.

Baba Medan and Philip Aguer Panyang, the governors of Boma and Jonglei States respectively, organized a peace meeting at Gumuruk, in Boma State, on 19 August 2016. The conference ended without the conclusion of an agreement.

On 30 August 2016, Jonglei state governor Philip Aguer and deputy minister for Defense David Yau Yau mediated between Murle and Bor Dinka representatives. This peace conference was co-facilitated by UNMISS.

Another peace conference was held between the Bor Dinka and the Murle in Bor on 20 September 2016. This conference was mediated by local state officials. The conference ended without the conclusion of an agreement.

On 4 December 2016, Jonglei State Peace Advisor Deng Aguer mediated between the Bor Dinka and Murle at a peace conference in Pibor State. The conference was co-organized by the governments of Jonglei and Boma states, with assistance from UNMISS and ZOA International. The mediation effort led to the conclusion of a peace agreement which stipulated a ceasefire, as well as an end to child abductions, cattle raiding, revenge killings, and hate speech. The agreement also called for the promotion of peace and reconciliation between the communities involved, establishing a secure and safe environment to facilitate free movement of people, goods, and services, and respect for rule of law, human rights and traditional cultures. The peace agreement also stipulates the creation of a joint police force consisting of 1,000 officers. The joint force is to patrol the borders, arrest criminals and ensure the safety of movement and trading activities between Boma and Jonglei.

In February 2017, the UN declared famine in Unity State. This famine triggered cattle raids between Dinka groups and Murle and a series of revenge attacks from both sides. On 11 May 2017, the head of UNMISS, David Shearer, expressed concerns over rising tensions in the Bor-Pibor area, especially tensions between youths from the Dinka Bor and Murle communities. He confirmed UNMISS’ commitment to providing support to peace efforts on the ground between these communities. On 13 May 2017, Murle tribesmen carried out a major cattle raid in Jonglei state. UNMISS tried to facilitate peace talks in response. At a peace conference in Juba on 23 May, facilitated by UNMISS, Dinka Bor and Murle representatives signed a ceasefire agreement. Chuol Rambang, Chairperson of the South Sudan Peace and Reconciliation Commission, acted as the chief mediator. The stated objective of the agreement concluded was to “commit and obligate the two communities to immediately cease hostilities and create conducive atmosphere to a comprehensive and inclusive dialogue.” This ceasefire succeeded in preventing any further large scale violence between these communities in the subsequent months.
A peace meeting between the Bokora Karimojong and Pian Karimojong took place in late October 2005.

The Bokora Karimojong and Jie frequently clash in the context of cattle raids in the Karamoja region in Uganda. The Catholic Diocese mediated a truce between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie in March 2001.

Another round of peace talks between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie was held in Nakithikilet in August 2002. This led to a truce on 20 August 2002, which was adopted through traditional rather than the signing of a document.
Terrence Achia, the chairman of the Local Council responsible for the entire district (LC5) of Moroto, mediated a peace agreement between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie clans on 21 October 2005.
