The Bokora Karimojong, Jie, and Matheniko engaged in negotiations that led to the signing of a peace agreement in July 2009.

The Bena Nshimba are the inhabitants of the Bena Nshimba village in the Kasaï Oriental province of the DRC. The Bena Kapuya are the inhabitants of the Bena Kapuya village in the Baluba Lubilanji sector of the Katanda territoire of the Kasaï Oriental province of the DRC. In September 2007, a conflict erupted between these communities over fertile farm-land situated in the Katanda Territorie of Tshilenge in the Baluba Shankadi sector. A police force was sent to the villages to restore order. In addition, a government delegation donated 20,000 US dollars in favor of the victims of the fighting a week following the armed clash between the two communities. The police left the villages in early 2008. In April 2008, the Bena Nshimba launched some new attacks on the crops of Bena Kapuya. As a response, a committee of elders from both the communities came together to discuss peaceful co-existence between the two communities.

On 28 September 2007, government officials, including the inspector general of the police and various ministers, visited the conflict zone of Mbuji Mayi to meditate between the communities, but this did not lead an agreement.

The conflict between the Alliance for the Restoration of Peace and Counter-Terrorism (ARPCT) and Alliance for Re-liberation of Somalia/Union of Islamic Courts (ARS/UIC) mainly revolved around political control over Mogadishu. In 2006, the ARS/UIC was renamed into the Supreme Islamic Council of Somalia (SICS). The ARPCT was formed on 18 February 2006 by a group of warlords that aimed to counter the growing influence of the SICS. The ARPCT subsequently attacked the ARS/UIC on 18 February 2006. A team of local elders and civil societies immediately intervened to mediate an informal ceasefire on 22 February.

On 22 March, fighting resumed following a dispute between two businessmen associated with each side. On 26 March, another round of negotiations mediated by local clan leaders and religious leaders succeeded in creating a formal ceasefire. This ceasefire was concluded in order to pave the way for negotiations in Mogadishu aimed at concluding a formal peace agreement. However, the ceasefire did not hold, and a third round of fighting took place from 7 to 14 May.

On 13 May, a mediation team made up of the Mudulood clan mediated a temporary ceasefire. This ceasefire collapsed the same month. The ARS/UIC defeated the ARPCT forces in June 2006, which terminated the conflict.

On 15 November 2003, the Anuak and Nuer attended a peace meeting in Gambella in Ethiopia. This round of negotiations was mediated by a delegation from the Ethiopian government. The peace meeting did not lead to a peace agreement.
In 2004, the Anuak and Nuer participated in a round of mediated negotiations in Ethiopia, but this did not end the conflict.

Beginning in mid-March 2012, a disarmament program was implemented for Jonglei State in South Sudan. With thousands of guns collected, the next step was a peace conference between multiple tribal groups – including the Anuak, Dinka Bor, Jie, Kachipo and Nuer – that was held at South Sudan Hotel in Bor on 1 May 2012. The talks were mediated by Archbishop Daniel Deng along with members of a peace committee and culminated with the signing of a peace agreement by all those present on 6 May 2012. The implementation of the agreement was overseen by tribal leaders, civil society, and the members of the peace committee.

On 23 and 24 May 2012, another round of peace negotiations took place South Sudan Hotel in Bor. More than 250 representatives of different tribes and the government discussed ending conflict in Jonglei in South Sudan.

The Jonglei Women's Association (JWA) and USAID organized a women's peace conference in the state from 12 to 17 March 2013. Although no peace agreement was reached, the participants discussed pathways to peace among all the different tribes in Jonglei, including the Annuak and Nuer.
In December 2003, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Ethiopian government organized a peace meeting directly between the Anuak and Dinka.

In late March and April 2012, a disarmament campaign for Jonglei state gathered more than 10,000 arms. Following this effort, on 1 May, a peace conference was held in Bor with the aim to bring peace to the area. Leaders from the Anuak and Nuer participated alongside the Dinka-Bor, Jie, Kachipo, and Murle. Archbishop Daniel Deng acted as the mediator. This peace effort proved successful. On 6 May, with the president of the respective peace committee as witness, the tribal representatives signed a peace agreement. The agreement’s implementation process was moderated by a mixed team of tribal leaders, peace committee members and a civil society group involved in a previous implementation process in Pibor County.

On 23 and 24 May, an inclusive peace meeting was held once again in Bor Town. More than 250 people attended the confernece, with participants ranging from government officials to youths. Anuak and Dikna representatives also attended the conference. This conference did not end in a peace agreement.
In early December 2013, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Ethiopian government mediated a peace meeting between the Anuak and Dinka.
The Prime Minster’s office also mediated between the conflict parties in December 2013.

In January 2002, the Alur clashed with the Lendu in the context of the conflict between Hema and Lendu in the Ituri region of the DRC. The Lendu subsequently accused the Alur of backing the Hema. Ugandan Colonel Peter Kerim mediated a round of peace talks between the Alur and the Lendu in Mahagi on 15 January 2002. Local leaders from the Warr-Palara, Panduru, and Jukot tribes as well as the district commissioner, were also in attendance at this round of peace talks.

Armed fighting between the Ali-Galif and Mahadade subclans started in August 2002. Clan elders, including Hassan Fidow Asir, mediated between these two subclans of the Hawiye between August and September 2002. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire by September 2002, which terminated the conflict.

The conflict between the Agon-Yar subclan and Warsangeli subclan of Abgal clan was about control over a roadblock. The conflict parties clashed in Fagah, Kallunkah, and El-Tubboweyneh on 26 and 27 October 1999. Negotiations began at night on 27 October 1999. These talks would end on 28 October with the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

Armed fighting reignited in June 2002. The conflict was this time about control over Middle Shabelle, an area controlled by Somali Restoration and Reconciliation Council (SRRC). The Agon-Yar were aligned with the SRRC, while the Warsangeli allied with the Transitional National Government (TNG), which was fighting the SRRC at that time. In response to the new outbreak of armed fighting in June 2002, some elders from Mogadishu and Jowhar mediated negotiations between the conflict parties, but without any results.

A delegation of five ministers of the TNG was subsequently sent to mediate between the clan elders, Sharif Hussein Jilaow and Omar Fiasco, in July 2002. These negotiations did not result in an agreement. Heavy fighting took place between the clans on 3 and 4 September 2002.
Negotiations following these clashes mediated by Hussein Haji Bod, an Abgal politician, led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 September 2002.

The armed conflict reignited in January 2004, following a land dispute on the west bank of Belet Weyne. Elders mediated between the conflict parties during January 2004, but this effort did not lead to an agreement.
A  mediation effort by Elders in June 2004 led to conclusion of an agreement in which both sides promised to avoid civilian causalities. However, both sides violated this agreement.

A peace conference was held in Buqda-Aqable village in January 2005 to reconcile the two subclans, which led to the signing of a peace agreement. This peace conference was mediated by Haji Hussein Ugaases.

Armed violence reignited in March 2002. Minister of Federal Affairs Seyoum Mesfin mediated a reconciliation meeting in Awash in March 2002. This meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
Mesfin mediated another reconciliation meeting in Dire Dawa in March 2002. This meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated a peace meeting in Addis Ababa in March 2002. These meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
Ethiopian government officials and a local peace committee called Araaraa mediated between the Afar and Kereyou on 8 January 2003. It is unclear whether this effort was successful.

The Alliance for Democracy (AD) and the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) have been political rivals since their formation in 1998. Armed clashes between the supporters of these parties in 2003 was linked to the control of a bus station, which was an important source of income for the PDP supporters whom had hitherto controlled it. On 11 March 2003, President Obasanjo convened the leaders of the AD and PDP to a peace meeting at Ibadan Airport lounge in view of the April elections. The leaders signed a pact guaranteeing efforts towards peaceful elections.

On 17 June 2003, after violence erupted between supporters of the AD and PDP in Effurun, Divisional Police Officer Umar Mohammed summoned the leaders of the supporters of the PDP and AD to a peace meeting at Ekpan Police Station in the Uvwie Local Government Area in Delta State. This mediation effort did not result in a written peace agreement.

The Action Congress of Nigeria (ACN) and the People’s Democratic Party (PDP) have been vying for political power since the emergence of the ACN in 2006. Tensions escalated into violent clashes between the supporters of both parties in January 2008 in Okene in Kogi State. The leaders of the political parties took part in the inter-party Peace and Security Committee’s meeting held at Transcorp Hilton Hotel on 17 January 2008 in response to this outbreak of violence. Negotiations mediated by the Honourable Ado Moses Okino led to the signing of a ceasefire on behalf of their supporters.

In early September 2011, after renewed clashes between the supporters of the PDP and ACN, the Oyo State Police Commissioner invited the executive committee of the PDP and ACN to a peace meeting aimed at ending the violence.

A new round of peace talks between supporters of the PDP and the ACN was held in Afon Allaye in Ekiti State in July 2013 in response to renewed fighting. The traditional chief of Afon Allaye, Oba Emmanuel Aladejare, the Allaye-in-Council, and the Efon Development League acted as the mediators.

Quickly after the clashes between the Ghana Abudu and Andani began, the Ghanian government stepped in and created a specialized committee to support peace efforts. Led by Professor Adzei Bekoe, this group was composed of six members and collaborated with religious groups and the Northern Regional Security Council. The mediation committee mediated between the leaders of the conflict parties in Tamale and Yendi in early April 2002. Additionally, on 25 April 2002, the government created a three-person commission of inquiry called the Wuaku Commission in order to help reconcile the communities.
third_party: government; religious leaders; Northern Regional Security Council; local peace committee

description: In April 2002, the Coalition of Muslim Organizations (CMO) facilitated a peace meeting between the Ghana Abudu and Andani.

In 2003, the Ghanian government formed the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs, tasked with resolving the conflict. This team was headed by Asantehene Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, chief Nayiri-Na Bohugu Shirigu of the Mamprugu, and chief Yagbonwura Bawa Dosie of the Gonja. This mediation team collaborated with the Ministries of Interior and Chieftaincy and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). Negotiations mediated by these third parties led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Dagbon on 14 April 2003.
The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs continued mediating between the conflict parties throughout 2004.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs continued mediating between the conflict parties throughout 2005. This led to the signing of a roadmap to peace that called to establish an interim regent from the Andani.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs mediated peace talks between the conflict parties in 2006. Consequnetly, the conflict parties signed the Roadmap to Peace in Dagbon in Kumasi on the 30 March 2006.
Fighting began again on 25 August 2006. On 29 August 2006, Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, mediated between the tribal leaders from both sides
A mediation effort by the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs from 16 to 18 November 2007 led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement on 18 November 2007.

Tensions between the Abgal and Xawaadle clans, who both reside in the Middle Shabelle region of Somalia, were exacerbated by a severe drought in late 2007 and early 2008. In early January 2008, the conflict parties clashed in Beled Weyne following a dispute over access to water. These clashes violated a peace agreement that had been mediated by Imam Mahmud Imam Uma of the Xawaadle clan in December 2007, among growing tensions between the two clans. On 20 February 2008, elders from the Xawaadle and Abgal clans mediated between the conflict parties in Beled Weyne.
When violence broke out again on 11 September 2008, clan elders from the area once again immediately mediated between the conflict parties.

A round of negotiations mediated by representatives of the Islamic Administration and clan elders led to the conclusion of a preliminary peace agreement on 24 February 2009, which among other stipulated a ceasefire. Islamic Administration forces were subsequently deployed in the area in order to sustain the ceasefire while reconciliation talks continued.

On 26 October 2009, mediation by local leaders and Harakat Al-shabab Mujahideen (also known as Al-Shabaab) led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement. In addition to stipulating a ceasefire, this agreement stipulated that future disputes would be resolved according to Sharia law.
